superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter w *
The twenty-seventh letter of the alphabet; called waAwN: it is one of the class termed $afahiy~ap [or labials], and is a letter of augmentation. ― -b2- For the uses of w as a particle see Supplement; for w in the sense of bl see a verse in art. qaSada; w giving fulness of sound to
1a2u3a
, see naZara; w used lilt~a*ak~uri, see Alf Alt~aEaAyiY in art. A, and see Alf AlA_isotinokaAri; w in the sense of b, see a verse in art. Easiyla. ― -b3- As a numeral it denotes Six.

R. Q. 1 waA^owaA^a *
R. Q. 1. waA^owaA^a, inf. n. waA^owaA^ahN, He (a dog) barked. (A.) ― -b2- Also inf. n. waA^owaA='N ([respecting the form of which see ZaA^oZaA^a] in the CK and a MS. copy, waA^owaA^N) He (a jackal, Aibonu A=waY,) cried, or barked. (K.) ― -b3- [See also waEowaEa.]

1 waA^aba *
1. waA^aba, aor. yay^ibu, inf. n. waA^obapN [app. a mistake for waA^obN and A_ibapN], It (a hoof) was contracted in its edges, or in its fore edges. (Az.) See waA^obN. ― -b2- waA^aba, aor. yay^ibu, (S, K,) inf. n. waA^obN (S) and A_ibapN (S, K) He contracted himself, or drew himself together, or shrank; and was ashamed. (S, K.) ― -b3- waA^aba (TA) and A`t~aA^aba↓ (S, K) He was ashamed, (S, K,) mino $aYo'K of a thing. (TA.) ― -b4- waA^aba, aor. yay^ibu, i. q. Anf [app. meaning He was disdainful]. (TA.) ― -b5- way^iba, [aor. yawo'abu: see waTiy^a:] He was angry. (K.)

4 A^awo'abahu *
4. A^awo'abahu He did to him an action of which one should be ashamed: (S, K:) or he made him angry: [mentioned twice in the K: once as though there were no difference of opinion respecting it:] or he turned him, or drove him, back with ignominy, from his affair, or from the object of his want: (so in the copies of the K; but in an old copy, relied upon as correct, of the Tahdheeb el-Af'ál, from his companion, En SAHbh: TA:) as also Ait~aA^abahu↓; (K;) meaning he turned him, or drove him, back with ignominy: (TA:) or Aw'bh also signifies he turned him, or drove him, back from his affair, or from the object of his want. (S.)

8 Ait~aA^aba *
8. Ait~aA^aba: see 1 and 4.

waA^obN *
waA^obN, as an epithet applied to a solid hoof, Strong, contracted in the edges, or in the fore edges, and light: (K:) or simply strong: (L, art. rDH:) or round like a cup (such as is called qaEobN); cup-shaped; (S, K;) and that takes [app. meaning occupies] much of the ground: [(see also tanaAhaba:) accord. to Freytag, hollowed within, so that it takes up (tollat) much earth:] (K:) or i. q. HfyZ: (Az, as cited in the TA:) [but this I incline to think a mistake for xafiyfN light:] or of excellent size: (K:) or of moderate size; not wide, nor contracted. (T.) ― -b2- waA^obu AlHawaAfiri Having hoofs contracted in the edges, or in the fore edges. (Az.) See also waA^obN above. ― -b3- waA^obN A large, or big, and wide, arrow: (K:) [but I think that, for mina AlqidaAHi, in the K, we should read mn AlA^qodaAHi; and that wA^b is therefore an epithet applied to a cup, such as is called qadaHN; as Golius and Freytag have understood it; and not to a qidoH: see what follows]. A_inaA'N waA^obN A large, or big, and wide, vessel: a wide vessel: pl. A^awoA=bN. qdHN wA^bN A large, or big, deep, and wide, [cup]. (TA.) ― -b4- qidorN waA^obapN A wide, or ample, cooking-pot. (TA.) ― -b5- See also waviybN. ― -b6- waA^obN A great camel: (S, K:) accord. to some. (S.) ― -b7- waA^obapN A short and broad she-camel, or woman. (TA.) ― -b8- A female of middling make, between good and bad, or handsome and ugly. (TA.) ― -b9- A small hollow, or cavity, in a rock, that retains water. (S, K.) ― -b10- biy^orN waA^obapN A wide and deep well: (K:) or a deep well. (L, K.)

way^iybN *
way^iybN Wide, or ample: syn. ragiybN. (TA.) ― -b2- qidorN way^iybahN A deep cooking-pot. (T, K.)

A_ibapN *
A_ibapN, (S, K,) in which the p is a substitute for the [incipient radical] w, (S,) and tuw^abapN↓, (S, K,) in which the t is originally w, (S,) and mawovibapN↓, (K,) A disgrace; a shame; a thing of which one should be ashamed: disgrace, or ignominy: (S, K:) shame; (K;) and a contracting of one's self, or shrugging: (TA:) a vice; fault; or the like. (Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee.) ― -b2- Ex. nakaHa fulaAnN fiY A_ibapK [Such a one married in a manner that was disgraceful; or, of which one should be ashamed: i. e., married a woman of low origin, or the like]. (S.) ― -b3- Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
A_i*aA Almaray^iY~u $ab~a lahu banaAt
EaSabona biraA^osihi A_ibapF waEaAraA
[When the Maraee has daughters that have attained to puberty, they bind upon his head disgrace and ignominy]. (S.) ― -b4- TaEaAmu tuw^abapK↓ (or TaEaAmN *uw tuw^abapK, as in the TA,) Food of which one should be ashamed to eat. Mentioned by AA on the authority of an eloquent Arab of the desert. (S.)

tuw^abapN *
tuw^abapN and mawoy^ibapN: see A_ibapN.

muwy^ibaAtN *
muwy^ibaAtN Foul, or disgraceful, qualities, or dispositions. (S, K.)

1 waA^ada *
1. waA^ada, aor. yay^idu, (inf. n. waA^odN, S, L, &c.) He buried his daughter alive (S, L, Msb, K) in the grave, (S, L,) and put a load of earth upon her. (A.) It was customary for a man in the time of paganism, when a daughter was born to him, to bury her alive when her mother brought her forth, from fear of reproach and want: but this is forbidden in the Kur. xvii. 33: and some of them used to bury their children alive in times of famine: (L:) the tribe of Kindeh used to bury their daughters alive. (S, L.) ― -b2- AlwaA^odu AlxafiY~u a term used in a trad. as meaning Extractio penis tempore concubitus, ne conciperet femina: as also AlS~ugoraY Almawow^uwdapu↓ because this act resembles that of burying a child alive, and is done with the same motive. (L.)

5 twA^~dt Ealayohi AlA^aroDu *
5. twA^~dt Ealayohi AlA^aroDu The earth, or the land, hid, or concealed him, and [as it were] removed him: (T,:) formed by transposition from twd~A^t, [q. v. in art. wdA^]. (T.) See 8.

8 Ait~aA^ada *
8. Ait~aA^ada (originally AiwotaA^ada, S,) and tawaA^~ada↓ He acted, or behaved, with moderation, gentleness, or deliberation, moderately, gently, deliberately, or contr. of hastily: with gravity, staidness, sedateness, or calmness: (T, S, M, A, L, Msb, K:) from tuw^adapN [q. v.]: (S:) or from waA^odN: or, as some say, formed by transposition, and from taA^aw~adat fiY qiyaAmihaA, meaning “ she (a woman) bent in her rising, by reason of her heaviness. ” (T, L.) Ex. At~A^d fiY A^amorihi, and fiyhi twA^~d↓, He acted with moderation, gentleness, &c., in his affair: (S, * A, L, * Msb:) and fiY ma$oyihi in his walk, or pace, or gait. (S, L.)

wA^odN *
wA^odN and way^iydN↓ A sound, or noise; (K;) absolutely: (TA:) or a loud sound or noise; (S, L, K;) as that of a wall falling, and the like. (L.) ― -b2- The sound occasioned by vehement or heavy treading of the ground: the heavy sound of the feet of camels. (L.) ― -b3- Also the former, (L,) or both, (K,) The braying (hadiyr) of a camel. (L, K.)

way^iydN *
way^iydN and way^iydapN (L, K) and mawow^uwdapN↓, (S, L, K,) and, by abbreviation, mawodapN, (Abu-l-'Abbás, T,) A daughter buried alive. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- Almawow^uwdapN↓ AlS~ugoraY: see AlwaA^odu AlxafiY~u, voce waA^ada. (L.) ― -b3- See waA^odN. ― -b4- See also tuw^adapN.

waAy^idN *
waAy^idN A man burying, or who buries, his daughter, or daughters alive. (L.)

tawo'adN *
tawo'adN: see tuw^adapN.

tuw^adapN *
tuw^adapN (T, S, M, L, Msb, K) and tuw^odapN (M, L, K) and twdp, without ', [i. e., tuwadapN or tuwdapN,] (TA,) and tawo'adN↓ (M, L, K) and way^iydN↓; (K;) the first originally wuw^adapN; like as tukaA^apN is originally wukaA^apN; (T, L;) Moderation; gentleness; deliberateness; a leisurely manner of proceeding, or of deportment, &c.; contr. of hastiness: and gravity; staidness; sedateness; calmness: syn. naA^an~K, (T, M, L, K,) and tamah~ulN, (T, L,) and razaAnapN, (M, L, K,) and sakiynapN. (Msb.) Ex. faEalahu fiY tuw^adap He did it in a moderate manner; with gentleness; &c.] (A.) And ma$aY EalaY tuw^adap (S, Msb) [He walked moderately; gently; &c.;] calmly; or quietly. (Msb.) ma$aY ma$oyFA way^iydaA↓ i. q. EalaY tuw^adapK [He walked moderately; gently; &c.]; (S;) calmly, or quietly. (Msb.)

mawow^uwdapN *
mawow^uwdapN and mawodapN: see way^iydN and waA^ada.

mawaAy^idu *
mawaAy^idu Calamities,: (IAar, T, K:) formed by transposition from maA=widu. (IAar, T.) See art. Awd.

1 wab~a *
1. wab~a (originally A^ab~a, the A^ being changed into w, Az,) inf. n. wab~N; and wabawba↓, inf. n. wabowabapN; He prepared to charge, or make an assault, in battle. (K.) See art. A^b.

R. Q. 1 wabowaba *
R. Q. 1. wabowaba: see 1.

1 wabiy^ati AlA^aroDu *
1. wabiy^ati AlA^aroDu, (S, K,) aor. tiybaA^u, (K, TA,) or tayobaA^u, (CK,) and tawobaA^u, (accord. to the K: in the (S and) L and other lexicons, only this last aor. is mentioned; but it is asserted on the authority of AZ, who says that this form of the pret. is of the dial. of the Kusheyrees, that the aor. is tiybaA, with kesr to the t, [contr. to analogy,] TA,) inf. n. wabaA^N; (K;) or wabaA='apN; (S;) and wabiyat, aor. tayobaA and tawobaA; (Moo'ab and Jámi') and wabuw^at, inf. n. wabaA='N and wabaA='apN and A^abaA= and A^abaA=pN (K, the w being changed into A^ in the latter two); and with w without
wabuAa
, [i. e., wabuwat]; (Moo'ab and Jámi'] and wubiy^at, (S, K,) like EuniYa, [i. e., pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] (K,) aor. tiybaA^u, (L and other lexicons,) in which, the w being changed into Y, the vowel of the first letter necessarily becomes kesr, (TA,) or tuwbaA^u, (S,) inf. n. wabo'N, (K, TA: in the CK wabaA^N,) or wabaA='N; (S, L, &c.;) and A^awobaA^at↓, (S, K,) inf. n. A_iybaA='N; (TA;) The land was, or became, afflicted with wabaA^: (K:) or, much afflicted with disease. (S.) ＝ -A2- wabaA^a, aor. yawobaA^u; (K; contr. to rule, which requires that the aor. should be yabaA; MF;) and wb~A^↓; He put the utensils, or goods, one upon another; or packed them up: or he prepared, set in order, or arranged, them; syn. EabaA^a. (K.) ＝ -A3- wabaA^a A_ilayohi; (S, K: Ibn-El-Mukarram says, I think that Th has mentioned wabaA^otu, without tesh-deed; but I am not confident of it; TA;) and AwbA^↓, inf. n. A_iyobaA='N; (S, K;) dial. vars. of wamaA^a and A^awomaA^a; (S;) He made a sign to him: (S, K:) or AwbA^ Alyh signifies he made a sign to him with his fingers, forwards, that he should approach; and AwmA^ Alyh “ he made a sign to him with his fingers, backwards, that he should retire, or remain behind. ” So accord. to the K; but this is at variance with what the leading lexicographers have transmitted. In the L it is said, wbA^ Alyh and AwbA^ are dial. syns. of wmA^ and AwmA^ he made a sign to him: or, accord. to some, AwmA^ Alyh signifies “ he made a sign with his hand to him, (i. e., to a person before him,) turning his fingers towards the palm of his hand, in order that he should approach him; ” [in doing which, the palm of the hand is held towards the person beckoned;] and AwbA A^lyh↓ he made a sign to him; (i. e., to a person behind him,) opening his fingers [from the palm] towards the back of the hand, in order that he should retire, or remain behind; [in doing which, the palm of his hand is towards himself]. El-Ferezdak says,
taraY Aln~aAsa A_ino sironaA yasiyruwna xalofanaA
Aln~aAsi waq~afuwA waA_ino naHonu wab~aA^onaA A_ilaY↓
[If we journey on, thou seest the people journey on behind us; and if we make a sign to the people to remain behind, they stop, one after another]. A^awobaA^onaA↓ is also read in this verse for wab~aA^onaA. Ibn-Buzruj says, that AwmA^ signifies “ he made a sign with the eyebrows, and the eyes; ” and wb~A^↓, he made a sign with the hands, and a garment, and the head. (TA.) ― -b2- wabaA^ato A_ilayohi, aor. tabaA^u, She (a camel) yearned towards it [i. e., towards her young one]; or uttered to it the cry produced by yearning: syn. Han~ato. (K.)

2 wab~aAa
2: see 1.

4 AwbA^ *
4. AwbA^ It became unwholesome: syn. SaAra wabiyoA^F. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See 1. ＝ -A3- A^uwbiy^a He (a young weaned camel) suffered in the stomach from indigestion, in consequence of repletion. (K, TA.) ＝ -A4- maA'N laA yuwbiy^u, like yuwbiY, Water that does not fail, or stop. The like is said of pasture. (TA.)

5 tawab~aAa
5: see 10.

10 AstwbA *
10. AstwbA (S, K,) and twb~A^↓ (TA) He found, or deemed, a country, (S, K,) or water, (TA,) unhealthy, or unwholesome: (K, TA:) [see wabaA^N:] or, much afflicted with disease. (S.)

wabaA^N *
wabaA^N and wabaA='N↓, (S, K,) and also without
wabuAa
, [wabFA,] (TA,) Plague, or pestilence; syn. TaAEuwnN: (K:) or a common, or general, [or an epidemic,] disease: (S:) or any such disease: (K:) or a quickness, and commonness, of death among men. (TA.) Accord. to Ibn-En-Nefees, it is a corruption happening to the substance of the air, by reason of causes in the heavens or the earth; as stinking water, and carcases, such as are the result of bloody battles. Accord. to the hakeem Dá-ood, it is a change effected in the air by events in the higher regions, as the conjunction of beaming stars; and by events in the lower regions, as bloody battles, and the opening of graves, and the ascending of putrid exhalations; with which causes conspire the changes of the seasons and elements, and the revolutions of the universe. They mention also its signs; among which are fever, small-pox, defluxions, itch or scab, tumours, &c. What is said in the Nuzheh necessarily implies that the TAEwn is one of the different kinds of wbA; as the physicians hold to be the case: but the opinion which the
critics among the professors of practical law and the relaters of traditions hold is, that these two diseases are distinct, the one from the other; the wbA being an unwholesomeness in the air, in consequence of which diseases become common among men; and the TAEwn being that kind [of disease] with which men are smitten by the jinn, or genii: an opinion which they corroborate by the words in a trad. A_in~ahu waHozu A^aEodaAy^ikumo mina Aljin~i [Verily it is the unpenetrating thrusting of your enemies among the jinn]. (TA.) The pl. of wabaA^N is A^awobaA='u; and of A^awobiyapN, wabaA='N↓ (S, K, TA) or A^awobiy^apN. (CK.)

biy^apN *
biy^apN The state of a land being afflicted with wabaA^. (K.)

A^aroDN wabiy^apN *
A^aroDN wabiy^apN, and wabiyoy^apN↓, (S, K,) and mawobuwo'apN↓, (S, L,) and muwbiy^apN, (S, K,) a land much, or often, afflicted with wabaA^: (K:) or, much afflicted with disease. (S.)

wabaA@'N *
wabaA@'N: see wabaA^N.

wabiYo'N *
wabiYo'N Sick; unwell; (IAar:) See A^roDN wabiy^apN. ― -b2- wabiYo'N Unwholesome water. (TA.)

muwbiy^N *
muwbiy^N Engendering wabaA^. (TA.) ― -b2- juroEapa $aruwbK A^anofaEu mino Ea*obK muwbK A draught of brackish water is more profitable than sweet water that engenders wabaA^. (A trad.) Here the
wabuAa
is omitted in the last word to assimilate it to $rwb. It is a proverb, applied to two men; one, superior in station, and more slim; the other, inferior in station, but more useful. (TA.) ― -b3- See A^aroDN wabiy^apN. ― -b4- muwbiy^N Water that is little in quantity; and failing, or stopping. (K.)

mawobuwo'apN *
mawobuwo'apN: see A^aruDN wabiy^ahN.

1 wabata biAlmakaAni *
1. wabata biAlmakaAni, aor. yabitu, (inf. n. wabotN, L,) He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in the place. (K.)

2 wb~xhu *
2. wb~xhu, inf. n. tawobiyxN, He reproved him, or lamed him, (L, Msb, K,) bisuwo'i fiEolihi for his evil action or conduct: (L:) reproved or blamed him, or did so severely, or with the utmost severity; and threatened him: (S, L, K:) reproached or upbraided him. (El-Fárábee, Msb.) Ab~xhu is a dial. form of the same: (IAar:) or its hemzeh is a substitute for the w. (ISd.)

waboxapN *
waboxapN A burning reproof: (L:) as also wmoxapN; (IAar;) in which the b is changed into m because of the nearness of their places of utterance. (AM.)

1 wabida *
1. wabida, (K,) aor. yawobadu, (TA,) inf. n. wabadN, (S, M, L, K,) It (life, or manner of living,) was, or became, hard, strait, or difficult: (S, M, L, K:) it (a man's state, or condition,) was, or became, evil, (S, M, L, K,) by reason of the largeness of his family, and the littleness of his property: (M, L:) you say wabidato HaAluhu. (M, L.) See also wabadN below. ― -b2- wabida Ealayohi, (S, M, L,) aor.
wabada
, (K,) inf. n. wabadN, (M, L, K,) He was angry with him: (S, M, L, K:) like wamida. (S, L.) ― -b3- wabida, aor.
wabada
, inf. n. wabidN, It [a day, &c.] was, or became, hot, (M, L, K,) and without wind: (M, L:) like wamida. (M, L.) ― -b4- wabida, aor.
wabada
, inf. n. wabadN, It (a garment) became old and worn-out. (M, L, K.)

wabodN *
wabodN: see wabadN.

wabadN *
wabadN Hardness, straitness, or difficulty, of life, or manner of living: evilness of one's state, or condition, (S, M, L, K,) by reason of the largeness of his family, and the littleness of his property: (M, L:) indigence; (M;) poverty, adversity; (T, L;) largeness of family, and littleness of property: (K:) pl. A^awobaAdN. See 1. ― -b2- wabadN, an inf. n. used as an epithet, and [therefore] sing. and pl., A man, and men, in an evil state, or condition: and sometimes A^awobaAdN is used as its pl.; (S, L, K;) as though it were imagined to be a proper epithet: (S, L:) or this is for *awuwA A^awobaAdK: (M, L:) also musotawobidN↓ signifies the same [applied to a single person]: (S, L, K:) and wabadN, (TA,) or wabodN↓, (L,) a poor man: pl. A^awobaAdN. (L, TA.) ― -b3- wabadN A vice, fault, or defect. (M, L, K.)

musotawobidN *
musotawobidN: see wabadN.

1 wabira *
1. wabira, (S, Msb,) aor.
wabara
, inf. n. wabrN, (Msb,) He (a camel) had much wabar [i. e. fur, or soft hair]. (S, Msb.)

waborN *
waborN, a pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is with p; (S, Mgh;) or a masc. n., of which the fem. is with p, (Lth, T, M, Msb, K,) and also a pl. [or coll. gen. n.], (M,) [The hyrax Syriacus; believed to be the animal called in Hebr. שָׁפָן ;] a certain small beast, (Lth, T, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) like the cat, (Msb, K,) or of the size of the cat, (Lth, T, M, Mgh,) or smaller than the cat, (S,) of the beasts of the desert, (M,) of a dust-colour, (Lth, T, Mgh, Msb,) or of a hue between dust-colour and white, (TaHolaA='u, this epithet being applied to waborapN, S,) or white, (TA,) having beautiful eyes, (Lth, T, Mgh,) or having eyes bordered with black, or very black eyes, (kaHolaA='u, Msb,) having no tail, (S, Msb,) or having a small tail, (Mgh,) [Golius says, on the authority of Dmr., “ longiore caudâ, ” which is a mistake, for it has no tail,] said to be of the weasel-kind, (Msb,) very shy, (Lth, T, Mgh,) living in low grounds, (Lth, T,) and dwelling in houses [of its own or of men], (S,) or it is confined in houses, and is taught; and it is eaten, because it feeds upon leguminous plants: (Mgh:) it is [said to be] a ruminant; [but this is not the case;] and therefore it is said in a trad., that when a man in a state of A_iHoraAm kills it, he must sacrifice a sheep or goat: (TA:) [a full and correct description of this animal is given in art. “ Shaphan ” of Dr. Kitto's “ Cyclopædia of Biblical Literature: ”] pl. wibaArN (S, M, Msb, K) and wubuwrN and wibaArapN (M, K) and A_ibaArapN, (M, TA,) with hemzeh in the place of the w. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN A^asomaHu mino mux~a Alwabori The text has missing characters between مُخ and مِن [Such a one is more liberal than the marrow of the webr]: because the marrow of the webr comes forth easily. (IAar, T.) And fulaAnN A^a*am~u mina AlwibaArapi [Such a one is more dispraised than the webrs]. (Fr, T.) ＝ -A2- Alwaboru One of the days called A^ay~aAmu AlEajuwzi, (S, M, K,) which are seven, falling at the end of winter: or it is called waborN, without the article: for the Arabs say, Sin~N waSin~aburo waA^axay~uhumaA waboro [Sinn and Sinnabr and their little brother Webr]: but this may be for the sake of the rhyme. (M.)

wabarN *
wabarN The Suwf, [here meaning the fur, or soft hair,] of the camel, (Lth, T, S, * M, A, K,) and of the hare or rabbit, and the like; (Lth, T, M, A, K;) and in like manner, that of the sam~uwr [or sable], and of the fox, and of the fanak [or marten]: (T:) or it is to the camel like wool (Swf) to the sheep; and so to the hare or rabbit, and the like: (Msb:) originally an inf. n.: (Msb:) n. un. with p: (S:) pl. A^awobaArN. (M, Msb, K.) ― -b2- A^aholu Alwabari (tropical:) The people of the deserts; [or rather the people of the tents;] because they make their tents of the wabar of camels [as well as of goat's hair, which is not included in the term wabarN, but is called $aEarN]: opposed to A^aholu Almadari the people of the cities and of the towns and villages. (TA.) See also madarN. ― -b3- A^axa*a Al$~aYo'a biwabarihi (tropical:) He took the thing altogether; he took the whole of the thing: as also A^axa*ahu bizawobarihi. (A.)

wabirN *
wabirN A camel having much wabar [i. e. fur, or soft hair]; (S, M, * A, * Msb, K;) and in like manner, a hare or rabbit, and the like; (K;) as also A^awobaru↓: (S, M, A, K:) fem. of the former, wabirapN; (M, A, Msb, K;) and of the latter, waboraA='u. (M, A, K.)

A^awobaru *
A^awobaru: see wabirN. ― -b2- banaAtu A^awobara, (As, A 'Obeyd, AHn, T, S, M, K,) and banaAtu AlA^awobari, (AZ, T, S, M,) the art. being added by poetic license, (M,) A species of kamoA^ap [or truffles], downy, (AZ, As, A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, [the epithet thus rendered is written in copies of the K muzogibapN, and in the T, S, M, muzag~ibapN, but in art. zgb in the TA it seems to be indicated that it is probably muzogib~apN,]) small, and of the colour of earth: (AZ, S, K:) or,
accord. to AHn, truffles (kmA^p) like pebbles, small, found in places where they have broken through the crust of the soil, in number from one to ten; they are bad in flavour; and are the first of kmA^p: or, as he says in another place, they are like kmA^p, but are not kmA^p; and they are small: (M: see also jabo'N:]) n. un. A_ibonu A^awobara. (As, A 'Obeyd, T.) You say, A_in~a baniY fulaAnK mivolu banaAti A^awobara [Verily the sons of such a one are like benát-owbar]: one imagines that there is good in them [when there is none]. (M.) And laqiytu manohu banaAta A^awobara I experienced from him [a disappointment, or] a calamity, or misfortune. (Sgh, K.) ― -b3- daAhiyapN waboraA='u, (S, A, art. $Er), (tropical:) An evil, a foul, or an abominable, calamity, or misfortune. (TA, voce A^a$oEaru, q. v.)

2 wb~$ *
2. wb~$ (TA,) or wb~$ A^awobaA$FA, (S, L,) inf. n. tawobiy$N, (TA, He collected companies, bodies, or forces, of various tribes, for war. (S, * L, TA.)

wabo$N *
wabo$N (ISd, TA,) and waba$N↓ (ISd, K,) sings. of A^awobaA$N (ISd, K, TA) which signifies A medley, or mixed multitude; (S, A, K;) and the lowest or basest or meanest sort, or refuse, or riffraff; (A, K;) of men, or people; (S, TA;) or of troops, or soldiers; (A;) like A^awo$aAbN; [and similar to A^a$owaAbN, but more particular;] and said to be a pl., formed by transposition, of bawo$N [q. v.]: (S) or sundry, or separate, sorts, of men, or people: (As, ISd, TA:) and of trees and plants: (ISd, TA:) or a small number, and those separate, of trees and plants. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] wabo$u AlkalaAmi (assumed tropical:) What is bad of speech, or language. (TA.)

waba$N *
waba$N: see wabo$N.

1 wabaSa *
1. wabaSa, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor. yabiSu, (S, K,) inf. n. wabiySN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and waboSN (M, K) and biSapN, (M, TA,) said of lightning, (S, A, K,) and of other things, (S, M,) It shone, gleamed, or glistened. (S, M, A, Msb, K.) You say, [also,] wabaSati Aln~aAru, inf. n. wabiySN, The light shone, or shone brightly; accord. to AHn; and naAriY A^awobaSato↓, signifies my light shone, or shone brightly: (M:) or the latter signifies my light showed its flame: (K:) or my light began to show its flame: (ISk, S:) or Aln~aAru AwbSt↓ signifies the fire appeared on being struck. (TA.) And wabiySu AlT~iybi signifies The shining of perfume. (Mgh, TA.)

4 A^awobaSa
4: see 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] AwbSt AlA^aroDu (assumed tropical:) The land began to show its plants, or herbage. (ISk, S.) ＝ -A2- A^awobaSotu naAriY I made my fire to burn, or blaze, intensely. (A.)

wabaSapN *
wabaSapN: see waAbiSN.

waboSaAnu *
waboSaAnu (Fr, M, K) and wuboSaAn, (IDrd, K,) [or wabuSaAnN and wabiSaAnN, (see art. bSn,)] in some copies of the Jm., buS~aAnN, [which see in art. bS,] (TA,) The month of rabiyEN AlA=xiru: (M, K:) i. e. the name of that month in the Time of Ignorance: pl. waboSaAnaAtN. (TA.)

wabiySapN *
wabiySapN: see waAbiSN.

.wab~aASN *
.wab~aASN: see what follows, in four places.

waAbiSN *
waAbiSN Shining, gleaming, or glistening: (Msb:) and wab~aASN↓, (as in some copies of the K,) or both, (M,) shining, gleaming, or glistening, much: (M, and some copies of the K:) or the latter, shining, gleaming, or glistening much in colour; (so in other copies of the K;) in which last sense, both are added to the epithet A^aboyaDu: (TA:) and wab~aASN↓, applied to a cloud, signifies also intensely shining, or gleaming, with lightning. (M.) You say qamari wab~aASN↓ [A moon shining brightly]. (A.) And Alwab~aASu↓ signifies The moon. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- waAbiSapN signifies i. q. baroqapN [app. A flash of lightning]: (M:) and fire; as also wabiySap↓: (IAar, K:) and a live coal; as also wabaSapN↓. (M.) ― -b3- raHulN waAbiSapu Als~amoEi, (M,) or waAbiSapu samoEK, (S, A, K,) means A man who relies upon what is said to him: such a man is called A^u*unN: and the epithet is made fem. because A^u*unN is meant: or the p may be added to render it intensive: (M:) or the meaning is, who trusts in all that he hears: (S, K:) or who hears speech and trusts in it: (A:) or who hears what is said and relies upon it, and thinks it true, but is not yet sure. (TA.) You say also, waAbaSapu samoEK bifulaAnK [One who relies upon what he hears of, or from, such a one]: and waAbiSapu samoEK bih`*aA AlA^amorai [One who relies upon what he hears of this affair]. (TA.)

wat~N *
wat~N (L, K) and wut~N and wut~apN (K) or wat~apN (L) The cry of the bird called wara$aAn. (AA, L, K.) A^awotaY signifies He cried as cries the wr$An. (IAar, L.)

wataAwitu *
wataAwitu i. q. wasaAwisu Evil suggestions, &c. (K.) The s is thus changed, in poetry, into t, as in naAtN and A^akoyaAtN. (MF.)

1 wataA^a *
1. wataA^a, aor. yataA^u, (K,) inf. n. wato'N, (TA,) He was heavy and slow in his gait, by reason of age, or by nature. (K.) Not mentioned by J. because esteemed by him not chaste. (TA.)

tayotaA^ *
tayotaA^: see art. tA^.

1 wataba *
1. wataba, aor. yatibu, inf. n. watobN, He remained fixed in the place, and did not move. (K.) Omitted by most of the lexicographers; and said by some to be a word mispronounced [app. for wavaba]. (TA.)

1 watuHa *
1. watuHa, aor. yawotuHu, inf. n. wataAHapN (S, K) and wutuwHapN (K) and watoHapN, (L,) It (a thing, S, or a gift, K) was little, or small, and paltry, mean, or contemptible. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- wataHa EaTaA='ahu, aor. yatiHu; (K;) and AwtHhu↓; (S, K;) and wat~Hhu↓, inf. n. tawotiyHN; (S;) He made his gift little, or small, (S, K,) and paltry, mean, or contemptible. (K.) ― -b3- lahu Al$~aYo'a AwtH↓ He made the thing little to him. (L.) ― -b4- AwtH↓ He became a person of little property. (K)

2 wat~aHa
2: see 1 and 4.

4 A^awotaHa
4: see 1. ― -b2- AwtH fulaAnFA He harassed and distressed him; syn. jahadahu wabalaga minohu; (L, K;) and in like manner, AwtH jahodahu, and AwtH minohu, and wt~H↓. (L.) ― -b3- AwatH, in this sense, occurs in a verse as related by Th: as related by IAar it is Awtx. (TA.)

5 twt~H mina Al$raAbi *
5. twt~H mina Al$raAbi He drank a little of the beverage: (S, L:) or, as also twt~H Al$~araAba, he drank the beverage by little and little. (TA.)

$aYo'N watoHN *
$aYo'N watoHN, and watiHN↓, (S, K,) and wataHN↓, and watiyHN↓, (K,) A little, or small, and paltry, mean, or contemptible, thing. (S, K.) One says also $aYo'N wataHN waEorN A small, or little, or scanty, thing: the latter of the two epithets being an imitative sequent; (S;) or, correctly, a corroborative. (Marg. note in a copy of the S.) ― -b2- maA A^agonaY wEan~iY wataHapF↓, a phrase like mA AgnY En~Y EabakapF, (L,) or He, or it, was of no profit, or advantage, to me. (L, K.) ― -b3- TaEaAmN watoHN Food in which is no good; like waHotN. (L.) ― -b4- rajulN watHN↓ A vile, mean, or contemptible, man. (S.)

wataHN *
wataHN see watoHN.

wtiHN *
wtiHN see watoHN.

wataHapN *
wataHapN see watoHN.

watiyHN *
watiyHN see watoHN.

2 wat~ada
2: and 4: see 1.

watadN *
watadN and watodN and wad~N: see watidN.

watidN *
watidN, (S, M, K, &c.,) of the dial. of El-Hijáz, and the most chaste form, (Msb,) and watadN↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) and watodN↓, (L, K,) and wad~N↓, (S, M, Msb,) of the dial. of Nejd, (Msb,) the t being made quiescent, and then changed into d, and incorporated into the final d, (S, * Msb,) and watiydN↓, (L, art. wd,) A wooden pin, peg, or stake, which is fixed in the ground or in a wall: (M, L, K:) pl. A^awotaAdN. (S, M, L, K.) [You say,] A^a*al~u mano watidK biqaAEK [More vile than a wooden peg in a plain]: because it is always knocked. A proverb. (TA.) ― -b2- watidN waAtidN, an expression like $ugolN $aAglN, (As, S,) the latter word a corroborative; (K;) or A wooden pin, peg, or stake, firm, or fast, (A, L,) and erect. (L.) ― -b3- A^awotaAdu AlA^aroDi (tropical:) [lit. The pegs, or stakes, of the earth; i. e.] the mountains: (A, L, K:) so called because they make the earth firm, or fast. (L.) ― -b4- A^awotaAdu AlbilaAdi (assumed tropical:) The chiefs of the towns, provinces, or countries. (L, K.) ― -b5- A^awotaAdu Alfam (tropical:) The teeth. (L, K, TA.) ― -b6- watidN, of a sandal, (assumed tropical:) The part that projects from the ear [or loop]. (L.) ― -b7- watidN (assumed tropical:) [A peg of a bayot, q. v.;] a portion, or division, of a foot of a verse, consisting of three letters: (L, K *:) it is of two kinds: one consisting of two movent letters followed by a quiescent letter; as faEuw and Eiluno; which kind is called watidN maqoruwnN, a conjoined peg; because each two letters are conjoined by a vowel: the other consisting of three letters; one movent, then one quiescent, then one movent; as laAtu in mafoEuwlaAtu; which kind is called watidN maforuwqN, a disjoined peg; because the quiescent letter disjoins the two movent letters: pl. A^awotaAdN. ziHaAf does not take place in the AwtAd, because the foot depends upon them; but it does in the A^asobaAb. (L.) ― -b8- watidN (A, L, K) and watidapN (L) of the ear., (tropical:) [The tragus;] the small prominent thing in the anterior part, (A, L, K,) like a teat, (A, L,) next the uppermost part of the side of the beard: (L:) or the prominent part next the temple: (L:) or the watidaAni of the two ears are the two parts in the interior thereof resembling a watid, also called the EayoraAni. (S.)

watiydN *
watiydN: see watidN.

waAtidN *
waAtidN (tropical:) A man standing fixed, or firm, or motionless. (A, L.) ― -b2- (tropical:) An erect horn. (A.) ― -b3- Fixing, or making firm or fast, a wooden pin, peg, or stake. (L.)

mawotuwdN *
mawotuwdN A wooden pin, peg, or stake, fixed, or made firm or fast. (L.)

miytadapN *
miytadapN (S, L, K,) and miytadN (L, K) A mallet (mirozab~ah, L, K,) with which wooden pins, pegs, or stakes are knocked [into the ground or a wall]. (S, L, K.)

1 watarahu *
1. watarahu, aor. yatiruhu, inf. n. watorN; (Msb;) and Awtrhu↓; (S, Msb, K;) He made it, (a number, Msb,) sole; or one, and no more: syn. A^afa*~ahu, (S, K,) or A^aforadahu. (Msb.) It is said that the latter verb only is used in relation to a number; but both are said to be thus used in the M [as well as in the Msb.] (TA.) ― -b2- [And He made it to be an odd number.] You say, watara Alqawoma, (M, K,) aor.
watira
, inf. n. watorN; (M;) and A^awotarahumo↓; (M, K;) He made the people, they being an even number, to be an odd number. (M, K, TA.) 'Atà says, kaAna Alqawomu witorFA fa$afaEotuhumo wakaAnuwA $afoEFA fawatarotuhumo [The people were an odd number and I made them an even number, and they were an even number and I made them an odd number]. (TA.) You say also, watara AlS~alaApa, (Msb, K,) and A^awotarahaA↓, (T, S, Msb, K,) and wat~arahaA↓, (K,) and fiYAlS~alaApi A^awotara↓, (Lh, M,) He made the prayer to be such as is termed witor [i. e., to consist of an odd number of rek'as; as is done in the case of a prayer which is performed in the night, consisting of three rek'ahs, and particularly called SalaApu Alwitori]; (S, * Msb, K; *) he performed prayers of double rek'ahs, two and two together, and then performed the prayer of one rek'ah at the end, making what he performed an odd number: (T:) and A^awotara↓, alone, signifies he performed the prayer called Alwitor [explained above]; (T, M, A, Mgh, K;) or he performed prayers of [an odd number of rek'ahs,] two and two together, and then a single rek'ah at the end. (TA.) It is said in a trad. A_in~a A@ll~`ha witorN yuHib~u Alwitora faA^awotiruwA yaA A^ahola A@loquroA=ni [Verily God is one only: He loveth the odd number: therefore perform ye the prayer of an odd number of rek'ahs, O people of the Kur-án]. (T.) And in another trad., A_i*aA A@sotajomarota faA^awotiro When thou employest stones in the purification termed A_isotinojaA=', use an odd number; (TA;) i. e. use three stones for that purpose, or five, or seven, and not an even number. (T.) ＝ -A2- watarahu, (T, S, A, Mgh,) aor. yatiruhu, inf. n. watorN (S,) and witorN and tirapN, (T, S,) He slew his relation, and so separated him from him, and rendered him solitary: (A, Mgh:) or he slew a person belonging to him, or related to him, without the latter's obtaining revenge, or retaliation, for the blood of the slain: (S:) or he slew a person belonging to him, or related to him; or took property belonging to him. (T.) It is also doubly trans.: you say, watara fulaAnN fulaAnFA A^aholahu Such a one committed a crime against such a one by slaying his family; or by taking them away: (T:) and watarapu maAlahu (T, M, K) (assumed tropical:) he committed a crime against him by taking away his property: (T:) or (assumed tropical:) he made him to suffer loss or detriment in respect of his property; or he deprived him of it in part, or altogether; syn. naqaSahu A_iy~aAhu: (T, * M, K:) and watarahu Haq~ahu, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) aor. as above, (Msb,) (tropical:) he made him to suffer loss or detriment in respect of his right or due; or he abridged him, or deprived him, or defrauded him, of it partially, or wholly; syn. nqShu. (S, Mgh, Msb.) It is said in a trad., mano faAtatohu SalaApu AlEaSori fakaA^an~amaA wutira A^aholahu wamaAlahu (T, M, * Msb, * TA) By whomsoever the prayer of the afternoon passeth unobserved, he is as though he had his family slain and his property taken away: or as though he had his family and his property taken away: (T:) or as though he were deprived (nuqiSa) of his family and his property, (T, M, Msb, TA,) and remained alone: (T, TA:) the loss of the family and property is thus likened to the loss of the recompense: Ahlh and mAlh being in the accus. case as objective complements: (Msb:) Ahlh is a second objective complement: for the first is understood, as implied in the verb: but if we read A^aholuhu wamaAluhu, accord. to another relation, Ahlh supplies the place of the agent, nothing being understood, and the family and property are the objects to which the loss is made to relate. (TA.) And it is said in another trad., mano jalasa majolisFA lamo ya*okuri A@ll~`ha fiyhi kaAna Ealayohi tirapF (assumed tropical:) He who sitteth in an assembly in which God is not mentioned is obnoxious to detriment, or loss: or, as some say, to a claim of reparation for wrongful conduct. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur, [xlvii. 37,] walana yatirakumo A^aEomaAlakumo (assumed tropical:) And He will not deprive you of aught of the recompence of your deeds: (Zj, T:) or will not make you to suffer loss in respect of your deeds; like
as you say daxalotu Albayota, meaning daxalotu fiY Albayoti. (S.) ― -b2- [Also,] watarahu, (M, K,) aor. yatiruhu, (K,) inf. n. watorN (M, K) and witorN (TA) and tirapN, (M, K,) He executed blood-revenge upon him: or did so wrongfully: (M, * K, * TK:) expl. by A^aSaAbahu bi*aHolK. (TK.) ― -b3- He overtook him (A^adorakahu) with some displeasing, or abominable, or evil, action. (M, K.) ― -b4- He frightened him; terrified him. (Fr, K.) ＝ -A3- watara Alqawosa: see 2, in two places.

2 wt~r AlS~alaApa *
2. wt~r AlS~alaApa: see 1, near the beginning. ＝ -A2- wt~r Alqawosa He fastened, bound, firmly, or braced, the string of the bow; expl. by $ad~a watarahaA; (Lh, M, K;) as also A^awotarahaA↓; (Lh, M, Msb;) both these signify the same; (S, in which the meaning is not explained;) and watarahaA↓, (M, TA,) inf. n. watorN: (TA:) or AwtrhA↓ signifies he put to it a string: (M, K:) and watarahaA↓, (M, K,) aor. yatiruhaA, (K,) inf. n. tirapN, (TA,) he attacked to it its string: (M, K:) this, accord. to some, is the proper signification of the last. (M.) It is said in a proverb, A_inobaADN bigayori tawotiyrK [Twanging the bow without bracing the string]: (S:) or laA tuEojili AlA_inobaADa qabola Alt~awotiyri [Hasten not the twanging of the bow before the bracing of the string]: alluding to the hastening a thing before its proper time. (M.) [See also art. nbD. And see 2 in arts. jnb and Hnb.]

3 wAtr bayona A^axobaArihi *
3. wAtr bayona A^axobaArihi, (A, and so in some copies of the K,) or A^awotara↓, (M, and so in some copies of the K,) and byn kutubihi, (M,) and wAtr A^axobaArahu, (M, K; in the latter of which waAtarahu is put by mistake for waAtarahaA, as is observed in the TA,) and kutubahu, (M, A, K,) inf. n. muwaAtarapN (S, M, K,) and witaArN, (M, K,) He made his tidings, or narrations, and his writings, or letters, to follow one another: (M, A, K:) or with some intervals between them; for mwAtrp between things is only when there is some interval between them; otherwise it is mudaArakapN and muwaASalapN: (S, K:) or wAtr Alkutuba signifies he made the writings, or letters, to follow one another nearly, one by one, without ceasing: (S:) or he made them to follow one another with a small interval between every two: (T:) and waAtr Alxabara he made the tidings, or narration, to follow one part after another: or, accord. to As, with a small space between every two portions thereof: from witorN in the sense of farodN. (T.) You say also waAtr bayona miyarihimo He made their supplies of wheat to come to them without stopping; time after time. (TA, from a trad.) And it is said in a trad., laA baA^osa A^ano yuwaAtira qaDaA='a ramaDaAna There will be no harm in his performing the fast of Ramadán at intervals, fasting one day and breaking fast one day: (TA:) muwaAtarapu AlS~awomi is the fasting one day and breaking fast one day, or two; performing it separately: it does not mean AlmuwaASalapu, because it is from Alwitoru, (S, K, TA,) i. e., Alfarodu. (TA.)

4 A^awotara
4: see 1, in seven places, first part. ― -b2- Awtr bayona A^axobaArihi: see 3. ＝ -A2- Awtrhu He made him to attain, or obtain, his blood-revenge. (Az, TA; and L in art. vA^r.) See an ex., voce vaA^orN. ＝ -A3- Awtr Alqawosa: see 2, in two places.

5 twt~r *
5. twt~r (tropical:) It (a sinew, or nerve, T, M, A, K, and a vein, M, TA, not the neck, for AlEunuqu in the K is a mistake for AlEiroqu, TA) became tense, (M, K, TA,) like a bow-string. (M, TA.)

6 twAtr *
6. twAtr It was consecutive: or was so with intervals: (M, A, K:) or was so with separation, or interruption. (Msb.) You say, twAtrt AlA_ibilu, and AlqaTaA, and so of any other things, The camels, and the birds of the kind called AlqTA, &c., came one near after another, not in a rank. (Lh, M.) And twAtrt Alxayolu The horses came following one another. (Msb.) And twAtrt Alkutubu The writings, or letters, came one near after another, separately. (S.)

watorN *
watorN: see witorN, throughout.

witorN *
witorN and watorN↓, (T, S, M, A, Msb, K, &c.,) the former, [which is the more common,] in the dial. of Nejd, (Lh, M,) and of the tribe of Temeem, (T, S, M, Msb,) and of the people of El-'Áliyeh, (ISk, as on the authority of Yoo, and S) or the latter in the dial. of the people of El-'Áliyeh, (T, as on the authority of Yoo,) or of the people of El-Hijáz, (Lh, S, M,) Single; sole; only; one, and no more: syn. farodN: (T, S, M, A, Msb, K:) or maA lamo yu$ofaEo mina AlEadadi: (M, A, K; except that in the K, instead of yu$ofaEo, we find yata$af~aEo:) or contr. of $afoEN: (Mgh:) [and an odd number:] all [even and odd] numbers are termed [respectively] $afoEN and waitorN, whether many or few. (T.) ― -b2- witorFA witorFA [Singly; separately; one by one]. (S, K.) [See $afoEN.] ― -b3- Alwitoru, one of the names of God, The Single; the Sole; the One; He who has no equal, or like; the Unequalled; syn. Alfa*~u and Alfarodu. (TA.) ― -b4- SalaApu Alwaitori, and Alwitoru alone: see 1, first part: it was sometimes said by Mohammad to be a single rakoEap. (T.) ― -b5- In the words of the Kur, [lxxxix. 2,] waA@l$~afoEK waA@lowatori by the former is meant all creatures which are created in pairs; and by the latter, God: (T:) or [by the former, Adam and his wife; and] by the latter, Adam, who was made a pair with his wife: (I' Ab, T:) or by the former, the day of the sacrifice; (T;) and by the latter, the day of 'Arafeh. (T, K.) (See more voce $afaEN.] ＝ -A2- Also witorN and watorN↓, (T, S, M, A, Msb, K,) the former, [which is the more common,] in the dial. of Nejd, (Lh, M,) and of the tribe of Temeem, (Lh, T, S, M, Msb,) and of the people of El- 'Áliyeh, (T, as on the authority of Yoo,) and El- Hijáz, (S,) or the latter in the dial. of the people of El-'Aliyeh, (ISk, as on the authority of Yoo, and S) and El-Hijáz, (Lh, M,) Blood-revenge; or retaliation of murder or homicide: or a seeking to revenge, or retaliate, blood: or a desire, or seeking, for retaliation of a crime or of enmity: syn. *aHolN: (T, S, M, Msb, K:) or wrongful conduct therein: as also tirapN↓ and watiyrapN↓, in either sense: (M, K:) or a crime which a man commits against another by slaughter or by plundering or by capture: (TA:) pl. [of waitorN] A^awotaArN and [of tirapN] tiraAtN. (A.)

watarN *
watarN The string, and the suspensory, syn. $iroEap and muEal~aq [the latter signifying properly the appendage, (see xaTama Alqawosa biAlwatari, and see nayATN,)] (M, K,) of a bow: (S, M, Msb, K:) [and in like manner, a chord of a lute and the like:] pl. A^awotaArN (S, M, Msb, K) and witaArN. (Fr, Sgh, TA.) ― -b2- Also pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of watarapN [q. v.] in all the senses of the latter. (K.)

watarapN *
watarapN, of the nose, The partition between the two nostrils [consisting of the septum and subseptum narium, or the subseptum alone]; (S, A, Msb;) as also watiyrapN↓: (S, A, Msb, K:) or the former signifies what is between the two nostrils: (M:) or the junction that is between the two nostrils: (T:) or the edge of the nostril: (M, K:) accord. to Lh, (M,) what is between the tip of the nose and the sabalap [or middle of the mustache; app. meaning, the subseptum narium]: (M, K:) and the latter, the partition between the two nostrils, of the fore part of the nose, exclusive of the cartilage; [i. e., app. the subseptum narium: (AZ, T:) and the former, in a horse, what is between the tip of the nose and the upper part of the lip: (M:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of the former, in all its senses, watarN. (K.) In a trad. in which it is said that the fine for destroying the watarap is a third of the fine for homicide, by this word is meant the watarap of the nose. (TA.) ― -b2- The sinew, or nerve, (Eaqabap,) of the back (mtn). (M.)

watiyrN *
watiyrN: see watiyrapN, near the end.

watiyrapN *
watiyrapN: see witorN. ＝ -A2- A way, course, mode, or manner of acting, or conduct, or the like: (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) and nature, or disposition: (A, Mgh:) from tawaAtara: (Th, M, A, Mgh:) or a road keeping close to a mountain, (K, TA,) and pursuing a regular, uniform course: (TA:) or constancy, or perseverence, in a thing, (AO, T, Msb, TA,) or in a work. (TA.) You say, maAzaAla EalaY watiyrapK waAHidapK He ceased not to follow, or continue in, one way, (&c.,) of acting or the like: (T, S, M, A:) or one disposition. (A.) And humo EalaY watiyrapK waAHidapK They follow, or con-
tinue in, one way, &c. (A, Mgh, Msb.) ＝ -A3- Remissness, or languor, syn. fatorapN, (S, M, Msb, K,) in an affair: (M, K:) and syn tawaAnK [which signifies the same]: and faultiness; syn. gamiyzapN, (M, K,) [in some copies of the latter, gamiyrapN, with the unpointed r.]) You say, maA fiY Eamalihi watiyrapN There is no remissness, or languor, in his work. (S, A, Msb.) And sayorN layosa fiyhi watiyrapN A journeying, or pace, in which is no remissness, or languor. (S.) ― -b2- Delay. (M, K.) ― -b3- Confinement; restriction; restraint. (M, K.) ＝ -A4- I. q. watarapN, as explained above. ＝ -A5- A ring (S, M, K) of Eaqab [or sinew], (S,) by aiming at which one learns the art of piercing with the spear; (S, M, K;) also called dariyoy^apN: (S:) or a ring that is made at the end of a spear or spear-shaft, by aiming at which one learns the art of shooting, or casting [the lance]; made of bow-string or of other string or thread. (M.) ＝ -A6- A white rose: (S, M, A, K:) or red rose: (Kr, M, K:) or a rose-flower; a rose-blossom: (AHn, M, K: *) n. un. of watiyrN↓. (AHn. M.) ＝ -A7- A star, or blaze, or white mark, on the forehead or face of a horse, when round, (T, M, A, K,) and small: (A:) when long, it is called $aAdixapN: (AO, T:) likened to the ring above mentioned, thus called; (T;) or to a white rose, which is also thus called. (A.) See gur~apN.

tirapN *
tirapN: see witorN. The t is substituted for the elided w. (TA.)

jaAw^uwA tatoraY *
jaAw^uwA tatoraY, and tatorFY, with and without tenween, and with t substituted for the original incipient w, (T, * S, * M, A, * Msb, * K,) in the former whereof, (S, M,) which is the better, (S,) and the more common, (Fr,) pronounced by Hamzeh and Ibn-'Ámir and Ks with imáleh, [i. e. tetrè,] (Bd, xxiii. 46,) the A [which is written Y] is a sign of the fem. gender, and in the latter whereof it is an A of quasi-coördination, (S, M,) from witorN in the sense of farodN, (S,) They came following one another; one after another; (A, Msb;) syn. mutawaAtiriyna: (M, K:) or interruptedly. (Yoo, T.) It is said in the Kur, [xxiii. 46,] vam~a A^arosalonaA rusulanaA tatoraY, or tatarFY, Then we sent our apostles one after another: (S:) or interruptedly; at intervals: (Yoo, T, M:) or making a long time to intervene between every two. (T.)

farasN muwat~aru AlA^anosaA='i *
farasN muwat~aru AlA^anosaA='i (tropical:) A horse contracted in the [veins called] A^anosaA=', [pl. of nasFA,] as though they were braced, or made tense. (A, * TA.) See $anijN.

mawotuwrN *
mawotuwrN One who has his relation slain, and so is separated from him, and rendered solitary: (TA:) and one who has a person belonging to him, or related to him, slain, and has not obtained revenge, or retaliation, for his blood: (S, K, TA:) a seeker of blood-revenge, or retaliation; one to whom belongs the revenging of blood, or retaliation. (TA.) [See an ex. voce vaA^orN.]

mutawAatirN *
mutawAatirN Consecutive, but with small intervals: thus differing from mutadaArikN and matataAbiEN. (Lh, M. [But see tataAbaEa.]) You say, jaAw^uwA mutawaAtiriyna: explained above, voce tatoraY. (M, K.) xabarN mutawaAtirN Tidings, or a narration, told, or related, by one from another: (T:) or by one after another. (TA.)

wavowavapN *
wavowavapN Weakness; impotence. (L.)

wavowaAvN *
wavowaAvN A weak, impotent, man. (L.)

1 wavaA^ato yaduhu *
1. wavaA^ato yaduhu, aor. tavaA^u, inf. n. wavo'N; (AZ;) and waviy^ato, (a form disapproved by some, TA,) aor. the same, inf. n. the same and wavaA^o, (K, TA,) or wavaA='N; (CK and a MS. copy) and wavuw^ato; and wuviy^ato, (S, K,) like EuniYa, [i. e., pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] (K,) which is the chaste form of the verb; and to the inf. ns. are added, on the anthority of the Wá'ee, wavuwo'N and wavoA^apN; (TA;) [but it is not said to which form or forms of the verb these belong;] His hand became affected by what is termed wavo'N. (K.) ― -b2- wavaA^a yadahu (S, K) and AwvA^↓, (K,) He caused his hand to be affected by what is termed wavo'N. (S, K.) ― -b3- All~`hum~a vaA^ayadahu [O God, bruise his hand! &c.] is a form of curse used by the Arabs. (IAar.) ― -b4- wavaA^a All~`Homa He, or it, (i. e. a blow,) deadened the flesh. (K.) Alwatada ― -b5- wavaA^a (tropical:) i. q. $aE~ava, q. v. (A.)

4 A^awovaAa
4: see 1.

wavo'N *
wavo'N and wavoA^apN A breaking of the flesh without separation of the parts, (waSomN,) not reaching to the bone, (K,) producing a swelling: (TA:) or a pain in the bone, without fracture: (IKoot, K:) or a dislocation (K, TA) and concussion of the joints, which affects the hand, without fracture: (TA:) or [an injury] resembling dislocation; in the flesh as a fracture in a bone: (AM:) or a bruising or breaking of the flesh without breaking the bone: (IAar.:) or a bruising of the skin and flesh, reaching to the bone, without its breaking: (TA:) or a bruising of the bone, without breaking: (Lth, S:) in which last sense, Lth uses also the word wavaA^N. (TA.) The
wavuAa
in wavo'N is sometimes omitted, and the word is written wavN, like yadN and wavoYN.damN is condemned as vulgar. wavN is authorized by As; but wavoYN (which is said by the vulgar, S, [and is disallowed in the K,]) and wavowN are disallowed by him. (TA.)

waviy^N *
waviy^N Having a broken hand: (TA: [but see wavo'N:]). ― -b2- yadN waviy^apN, and waviyoy^apN↓, (K,) and mawovuwo'apN↓, (S, K,) A hand affected by what is termed wavo'N. (K.)

waviyy^apN *
waviyy^apN and mawovuwo'apN: see waviy^N.

miyvaA^apN *
miyvaA^apN A mallet with which pegs, or stakes, or tent-pins, are driven. (TA.)

1 wavaba *
1. wavaba, aor. yavibu, inf. n. wavobN and wuvuwbN (the latter agreeable with analogy, TA,) and wavabaAnN and waviybN (S, K) and wivAabN (K; but this is generally affirmed to be an inf. n. of waAvaba, TA;) and vibapN, (Ibn-Málik and others) He leaped; jumped; sprang; bounded: (S, K:) or he leaped down, or downwards. (Mgh, Msb, art. Tfr.) ― -b2- wavaba AlmawoDiEa [He leaped, or jumped, upon, or over the place]. (TA.) ― -b3- wavaba A_ilaY Al$~arafi wavobapF (tropical:) [He made a single leap to eminence, or nobility]. (TA.) ― -b4- wavaba A_ilayohi [app., He leaped, or sprang up, or he hastened, to him]. (TA.) ― -b5- Alwuvuwbu, except in the dial. of Himyer, signifies The act of rising, or standing up. (TA.) ― -b6- It is also much used by the vulgar as signifying The act of hastening to a thing; as observed by MF, who is wrong in saying that there is nothing in the lexicons that favours its being so used. (TA.) ＝ -A2- wavaba, [aor. yavibu,] inf. n. wavobN, in the dial. of Himyer signifies He sat; sat down. (K, TA, from a trad.) vibo in that dial. signifies Sit; sit down. (S.) It is related that Zeyd Ibn-Abd-Allah Ibn-Dárim came as an envoy to one of the kings of Himyer, and found him at a hunting-place belonging to him, on a high mountain, and he saluted him, and mentioned to him his lineage, or relationship; whereupon the king said to him vibo, meaning A_ijoliso, Sit; but the man thought that he commanded him to leap from the mountain; and he said, “ Thou shalt find me, O king, very obedient: ” then he leaped from the mountain, and perished. So the king said, “ What ailed him? ” And they explained to him his case, and his mistake respecting the word: upon which he said layosato EinodanaA Earabiy~ato mano daxala ZafaAri Ham~ara i. e., [“ Arabic is not current with us: ” (for, probably, in the time of this king, the term Earabiy~ap was only applied to the general language of Arabia:) “ whoso entereth Dhafári,] let him learn [or, rather, speak, as MF says,] the Himyeree language. ” (Mz., 16th nwE.) [The principal facts of this anecdote are also mentioned in the S, on the authority of As.] By the king's saying Earabiy~ato was meant AlEarabiy~apu: the p is pronounced t in the case of a pause (which is the case here) in their dialect. (S.) Or, accord. to another relation of the above anecdote, the king said layosa EinodanaA Earabiy~ato kaEarabiy~atokumo [“ Arabic like
your Arabic is not current with us: ”] and this, says ISd, is the right reading in my opinion: for the king did not mean to exclude himself from the Arabs. (MF.)

2 wt~bh *
2. wt~bh, inf. n. tawoviybN, He seated him upon a cushion: (S, K:) asserted to be of the dial. of Himyer. (MF.) ― -b2- wv~bh wisaAdapF, (S, K,) in some copies of the K wavabahu, (TA,) He threw to him a cushion (S, L, K) that he might sit upon it: (S:) [app. in the dial. of Himyer]. ― -b3- wav~abotuhu wivaAbFA I spread for him a bed, or the like. (TA.)

3 wAvbh *
3. wAvbh He leaped, or sprang, upon him, or at him; he assaulted or assailed him; syn. saAwarahu (S, K) and vaAwarahu. (K, art. vwr) and SaAwalahu. (K, art. Swl.) ― -b2- [Also, perhaps, He contended with him in leaping, jumping, springing, or bounding.] ― -b3- [wAvbh is also mentioned in the TA as having a signification not explained in the K: app., He contended with him in hastening to a thing.]

4 Awvbh *
4. Awvbh He made him to leap, jump, spring, or bound. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- Awvbh AlmawoDiEa [He made him to leap, or jump, upon, or over, the place]. (TA.)

5 twv~b fulaAnN fiY DayoEapK liY *
5. twv~b fulaAnN fiY DayoEapK liY (tropical:) Such a one took possession unjustly of an estate belonging to me; he seized upon it unjustly. (S, K.) ― -b2- twv~b fiY A^aroDihi EalaY A^axiyhi (tropical:) He took possession of his land with injustice towards his brother. (A.) ― -b3- twv~b EalaY manozilatihi (tropical:) He took possession unjustly of the place occupied by him. (A.)

6 humo yatawaAvabuwna EalaY ka*aA *
6. humo yatawaAvabuwna EalaY ka*aA They leap, or rush, together upon such a thing [in an evil, or injurious, or a contentious manner]. (S, art. klb.) Alt~awaAvubu is syn. with Alt~akaAlubu. (S, K, art. klb.)

wavobapN *
wavobapN A single leap, jump, spring, a bound: (TA:) or a leap down, or downwards. (Mgh, Msb, art. Tfr.)

vubapN vbh vbp
vubapN An assembly; a company; a troop; a congregated body. (K.) [But it seems rather to belong to the root vbY, as remarked by Freytag; or, accord. to some, to art. vwb. See arts. vbY and vwb.]

wavabaY *
wavabaY: see wav~aAtN.

wivaAbN *
wivaAbN A throne, or couch; syn. sariyrN; (K;) accord. to some, that is always occupied by the king; or that the king does not cease to occupy: (TA:) [app. of the dial. of Himyer]. ― -b2- A bed; or what is spread to lie or recline upon: (K:) ex. wat~abotuhu wivaAbFA I spread for him a bed, or the like: (TA:) or places where persons sit; syn. maqaAEidu: (S, K:) in which case it is a pl., as some have expressly affirmed it to be: (TA:) accord. to IF and others, of the dial. of Himyer. (MF.) Applied to heaven (Als~amaA'u) as being the sittingplaces of the angels. (S.)

ZaboYN wav~aAbN *
ZaboYN wav~aAbN The original text has t, not v.
An antelope that leaps, jumps, springs, or bounds, quickly. farasN wav~aAbapN A mare that leaps, &c., quickly. (TA.) ― -b2- wavabaY↓ i. q. wav~aAbapN; (K;) i. e., That leaps, &c., quickly. (TA.)

mawovabaAnN *
mawovabaAnN A king who sits still, and does not undertake military expeditions: (S, K:) asserted to be of the dial. of Himyer. (MF.)

miyvabN *
miyvabN A plain, or level, land, or tract of land. (K.) ― -b2- A leaper, or jumper. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- Also, [contr.,] A sitter: (IAar., K:) [app. in the dial. of Himyer]. ― -b4- What is elevated, of land. (K.) ― -b5- A rivulet, stream, or streamlet: syn. jadowalN. (K.)

1 wavuja *
1. wavuja, aor. yawovuju, inf. n. wavaAjapN; (S, K;) and Awvj↓, and Astwvj↓; (TA;) It (anything, S,) became dense; thick; compact. (S, K.) ― -b2- wavuja, aor. yawovuju, inf. n. wavaAjapN, He became abundant in flesh; or very fleshy: wavura, inf. n. wavaArapN signifying he became abundant in fat; or very fat: and both signify he became bulky, or big; or large in body, corpulent and fleshy. (AZ, S.) ― -b3- wavuja Aln~abotu The herbage, or plants, became dense, thick, or compact, and tall.

4 A^awovijo lanaAmino h`*aA AlT~aEaAmi *
4. A^awovijo lanaAmino h`*aA AlT~aEaAmi Give us much of this food. (TA.) See 1.

10 Astwvj *
10. Astwvj It became in a complete, or perfect, state: (TA:) or it became so in a certain way: (S:) one says Astwvj Aln~abotu (tropical:) the plants, herbs, or herbage, clung together, one part to another, and became in a complete, or perfect, state. (S, K.) ― -b2- See 1. ― -b3- Astwvj AlmaAlu The property [app. meaning camels or the like] became much, or abundant. (S, K.) ― -b4- Astwvj mina AlmaAli He desired, wished for, or longed for, much of property [app. meaning camels or the like]; syn. Asotakovara: (As, Th, S, K *:) as also Astwvq. (TA.) ― -b5- Astwvjt She (a woman) became large in body, or corpulent and fleshy, and perfect in make. (T.)

waviyjN *
waviyjN Anything (S) dense; thick; compact. (S, K.) ― -b2- A horse, (S,) and a camel, (TA,) compact in flesh: (S:) or strong. (TA.) ― -b3- Dense, thick, or compact, herbage. (TA.) [See also ArD mwtvjp.] ― -b4- vawobN waviyjN (tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, of firm texture. (A.) [See also vyAb mwvwjp.]

waAvijN *
waAvijN, applied to herbage, Dense, thick, or compact, and tall. (TA.)

A^aroDN muwtavijapN *
A^aroDN muwtavijapN (in the CK muw^otavijapN [which is evidently a mistake]) Land abounding with herbage, or pasture, (S, K,) and with tangled trees; as also waviyjapN: (ISh:) land of which the herbage is dense, thick, or compact. (TA.) [See also waviyxN.]

viyaAbN mawovuwjapN *
viyaAbN mawovuwjapN Garments, or pieces of cloth, of which the threads and texture are slack, or loose. (K, from Sh, on the authority of a man of Bá- hileh: but see waviyjN. TA.)

1 wavura *
1. wavura, aor.
wavura
, inf. n. wavaArapN; [and app., watorN; (see the second signification;)] It (a thing, S, M, Msb, or a bed, A) was, or became, plain, level, smooth, soft, or easy to lie or ride or walk upon. (S, M, A, Msb, K.) ― -b2- wavirati AlEajuzu; and wavurat, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) The buttocks became fat. (A.) See also wavaArapN, below. ＝ -A2- wavarahu, (M, A, K,) aor. yaviruhu, (K,) inf. n. wavorN (M, TA) and virapN; (TA;) and wv~rhu↓, inf. n. tawoviyrN; (M, A, K;) He made it plain, level, smooth, soft, or easy to lie or ride or walk upon. (M, A, K.) And wv~r marokabahu He made the thing on which he rode smooth, soft, or easy to ride upon. (A, Msb.)

2 wav~ara
2: see 1, in two places.

4 maA A^awovara firaA$aka *
4. maA A^awovara firaA$aka How smooth, soft, or easy to lie upon, is thy bed! (A, TA.)

10 Astwvr AlfiraA$a *
10. Astwvr AlfiraA$a He found, or deemed, the bed smooth, soft, or easy to lie upon. (A, * TA.) ― -b2- A_i*aA tazaw~ajota A@moraA^apN faA@sotawovirohaA (tropical:) [When thou takest a woman as thy wife, choose her fat, suitable for a bedfellow: see waviyrN]. (A, TA.)

wavorN *
wavorN: see waviyrN.

wivorN *
wivorN: see waviyrN, in three places. ― -b2- See also miyvarapN, throughout.

wavirN *
wavirN: see waviyrN.

wavaArN *
wavaArN: see wivaArN.

wivaArN *
wivaArN, a subst., Plainness, levelness, smoothness, softness, or state of being easy to lie or ride or walk upon; as also wavaArN↓. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- See also waviyrN, in two places.

waviyrN *
waviyrN Plain, level, smooth, soft, or easy to lie or ride or walk upon; (T, S, M, A, K;) as also wivorN↓ (T, S, K) and wavorN↓ and wavirN↓; (M, K;) applied to a bed, (T, S, A, K,) and anything upon which one sleeps, (T, TA,) or sits, (TA,) and finds it to be thus, (T, TA,) and to other things: (M, K;) and thick and soft; applied to a bed: (Msb:) [and wivaArN↓ seems to signify the
same; or this and wavorN↓ are epithets in which the quality of a subst. predominates:] fem. waviyrapN. (M K.) You say, maA taHotahu wivorN, and wivaArN, (S, TA,) There is not beneath him a smooth, or soft, bed. (TA.) ― -b2- waviyrapN (tropical:) A woman having much flesh: (IDrd, S, Msb, K:) or fat; (T, A, K;) suitable for a bedfellow: (T, K:) and waviyrapu AlEajuzi (tropical:) large, (T,) or fat, (A,) or soft, (M,) in the buttocks: (T, M, A:) pl. wavaAy^iru and wivaArN. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- See also miyvarapa, throughout.

wavaArapN *
wavaArapN: see 1. ― -b2- (tropical:) Abundance of fat: (AZ, S:) or of flesh: (K:) or the latter is termed wavaAjapN. (AZ, S.)

A^awovaru *
A^awovaru More [and most] smooth, or soft; applied to a bed. (TA, from a trad.)

miyvarapN *
miyvarapN, (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) of the measure mifoEalapN, from AlwavaArapu, (TA,) without hemz, (S, TA,) originally miwovarapN, (Msb, * TA,) the w being changed into Y because of the kesreh before it, (TA,) and waviyrN↓ and wivorN↓, (K,) or [only] miyvarapN, (TA, &c.,) of a horse's saddle, (T, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and of a camel's saddle, (T,) A thing in the form of a pillow, made for the saddle, like the Suf~ap [q. v.], (M, Mgh, K,) to render it soft, or easy to ride upon: (T:) or the saddlecloth or housing (libodap) of a horse: (S:) pl. mawaAviru and mayaAviru, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) the latter agreeing with the sing., (Msb,) retaining the permuted letter, as is the case in A^aEoyaAdN, pl. of EiydN. (IJ, M.) ― -b2- Also, accord. to the K, [referring to the three words above,] or [correctly] the red mayaAvir, (AlmayaAviru AlHumoru,) which are forbidden to be used, (S, IAth, TA,) Certain things to ride upon, (maraAkibu, S, IAth, K, TA,) used by the A^aEaAjim, (S,) or Eajam, (IAth, TA,) [meaning Persians or other foreigners,] made of diybaAj or Hariyr [silk brocade or other silk]: (S, IAth, K, TA:) or the red miyvarap, (miyvarapu AilA^urojuwaAni,) forbidden, in a trad., to be used, is a stuffed thing to ride upon, which is put upon a camel's saddle: (TA:) and the red myvrp which is put upon a horse's saddle is included in the prohibition. (IAth, TA.) ― -b3- Also, the first of the above three words, (M,) or all of them (K) A garment or piece of cloth which is put as a covering over other garments or pieces of cloth. (M, K.) ― -b4- Also, (accord. to the K [referring to the three words above,] or [correctly] mayaAviru, (TA,) The skins of beasts of prey. (K, TA.)

wj~N *
wj~N A kind of medicine; (S, K;) certain twigs, or rods, with which one fumigates; (TA;) or which are used medicinally or remedially; (T;) [acorum, (Golius,) or acorus; sweet-cane, or, as some say, galangal: see Diosc., I. i., c. 2., referred to by Golius:] thought by ElJawáleekee to be not pure Arabic; i. e., an arabicized word, from the Persian [wajo]: (TA:) so says J. (S.)

1 wajaA^a *
1. wajaA^a, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yawojaA^u, and sometimes yajaA^u, (Msb,) inf. n. wajo'N; (TA;) and twj~A^↓; (K;) He beat, or struck, or smote, a person with his hand, (S *, K,) or with a knife, (S, Msb, K,) or the like, on any part. (Msb.) ― -b2- wajaA^a Eunuqahu, inf. n. wajo'N, He beheaded him: syn. Daraba Eunuqahu. (S.) ― -b3- wajaA^a (tropical:) Inivit feminam. (K.) ― -b4- wajaA^a Alt~ayosa, inf. n. wajo'N and wijaA='N, (or the latter is a simple subst., TA,) He beat the veins of the testicles of the goat between two stones, without extracting the testicles themselves: or he bruised or beat the goat's testicles until they broke, (K,) and he became like one gelded. (TA.) You say also wajaA^a Alkabo$a. (S.) [See wjaA='N.] wujiy^a He (a goat) had the operation termed wajo'N performed upon him. (K.) ― -b5- He was struck with a knife. (S.) ― -b6- wajaA^a (tropical:) He bruised, or pounded, dates until they cohered. Hence wajiyoy^apN, q. v. (TA.)

2 waj~aAa
2: see 1. ― -b2- wj~A^ Alr~akiy~apa, inf. n. tawojiYo'N, He found the well to be what is termed wajoA^apN, [fem. of wajo'N, q. v.: app. signifying without water]. (K.)

4 AwjA^ Eanohu *
4. AwjA^ Eanohu He repelled from him; removed, or put away, from him. (K *, TA.) ― -b2- AwjA^ He came in search of a thing that he wanted, or in pursuit of game, and did not attain it. (K.) ― -b3- It (a well) failed; i. e., its water ceased: or it contained no water. (TA.) [See also A^awojaY.]

8 A_it~ajaA^a Alt~amoru *
8. A_it~ajaA^a Alt~amoru (tropical:) The dates became closely packed, or pressed together: (K:) they were bruised, or pounded, until they cohered. (TA.)

maA='N wj'N *
maA='N wj'N, and wajaA^N↓, and wajaA='N↓, A water where there is no good: (K:) [app., a source of water where there is no herbage, or pasture; or, more probably, a source without water; or a water that has failed: see 2 and 4.]

wajaA^N *
wajaA^N and wajaA='N: see maA='N wajo'N.

wijaA='N *
wijaA='N, a subst., A striking with a knife or the like, on any part. (Msb.) [See also 1.] ― -b2- wijaA='N The bruising of the veins of the testicles until they break, so that it is like gelding. (S.) [See also 1.]

wajiYo'N *
wajiYo'N and mawojuwo'N↓ A goat on which has been performed the operation called wajo'N. (K.) [See 1.] ― -b2- The latter is said to be used in a trad. as signifying Gelded. ― -b3- Also the latter, Struck with a knife. (S.)

wajiyoy^apN *
wajiyoy^apN (assumed tropical:) Dates, (K,) or locusts, (ISk, S, K,) bruised, or pounded, and then stirred up with clarified butter (samon), or with oil, and so eaten: (S, K:) or dates moistened with milk or with clarified butter, and then bruised, or pounded, until they are consolidated: (TA:) or dates bruised, or pounded, until the stones come forth, and then moistened with milk or with clarified butter so that they become macerated and cohering, in which state they are eaten. (ISk, S.) ― -b2- Also, A cow. (IAar., K.)

mawojuwo'N *
mawojuwo'N: see wajiYo'N.

1 wajaba *
1. wajaba, aor. yajibu, inf. n. wajobapN (Lh, K) and wajobN (Lh) It (a wall, or the like, Msb, or a house, or anything, Lh,) fell down. (Lh, K, Msb.) See wajobapN. ― -b2- wajaba, inf. n. wajobapN, It fell to the ground. (TA.) ― -b3- wajobapN does not signify a single act; but is an inf. n. in an absolute sense, unrestricted to the signification of a single act: ex. wajobapu Al$~amosi The falling of the sun, in setting. (TA.) ― -b4- faA_i*aA wajabato junuwbuhaA [Kur. xxii. 37,] is said to signify And when their sides fall down upon the ground: or and when their souls depart, and they fall down. (TA.) ― -b5- wajabati Al$~amosu, (S, K,) inf. n. wajobN and wujuwbN (K) and wajobapN (see above), The sun set. (S, K.) ― -b6- wajabati AlEayonu (tropical:) The eye was, or became, sunk in the head. (K.) ― -b7- wajaba, (S, K,) aor. yajibu, inf. n. wujuwbN and mawojibN, (TA,) He fell down and died: (S:) he died. (K.) ― -b8- Hudbeh Ibn-Khashram says,
faqulotu lahu laA taboki Eayonuka A_in~ahu
bikaf~aY~a maA laA qayotu A_i*o HaAna mawojibiY
[And I said to him, Let not thine eye weep; for by my own hands is occasioned what I experience, now that my death has come to pass]. By mwjb he means mawotN. (TA.) ― -b9- [See also wajobapN, which seems to be a third inf. n. of the verb in this sense.] ― -b10- wajaba, (aor. yajibu, TA,) inf. n. wajiybN (Th, S,) and wajobN and wajabaAnN (K) and wujuwbN and wajobapN, (TA,) It (the heart) palpitated, beat, throbbed; (K;) was agitated, or in a state of commotion. (S.) ― -b11- wajabati AlA_ibilu, and wj~bt↓, The camels could scarcely arise from the places where they lay down. (TA.) ― -b12- waHuba, [aor. yawojubu,] inf. n. wujuwbapN, He was cowardly, or pusillanimous. (S, K.) ― -b13- wajabahu Eanohu He drove him back, or turned him back, from it, (K,) when he had long kept to it. (Nawádir el-Aaráb.)
＝ -A2- wajaba and Awjb↓ and wjb↓ (tropical:) He (a man, TA,) ate once a day. (Th, K) See wajobapN. ＝ -A3- wajaba, aor. yajibu, inf. n. wujuwbN (S, K,) and jibapN, (K,) It (a thing) was, or became, necessitated, necessary, requisite, or unavoidable: it was binding, obligatory, incumbent, or due: syn. lazima; (S, K, Msb;) [lit. accord. to some, it fell on a person: see 4;] and vabata, (Telweeh,) which means nearly the same as lazima. (TA.) ― -b2- For a fuller explanation, see its syn. Haq~a. [In the science of the fundamentals of religion, It necessarily was or existed; was a thing of which the nonexistence could not be mentally conceived: as is the essence of God. (Ibr. D.)] ― -b3- [wajaba Ealayohi ka*aA, or A^ano yafaEala ka*aA, Such a thing, or the doing of such a thing, was binding, incumbent, or obligatory upon him; was unavoidable to him; lay on him; was his necessary, or indispensable duty: or was binding, incumbent, or obligatory upon him, by God's express appointment, so that he would be punished for neglecting it: and it was that which should be preferred and approved. See waAjibN.] ― -b4- See also another explanation, afterwards. ― -b5- wajaba AlbayoEu, aor. yajibu, inf. n. jibapN (Lh, S, Msb) and wujuwbN (Lh, Msb) The sale was, or became, binding, or obligatory; (Msb, TA;) ratified, fixed, settled, decided, or determined; (Msb;) completed, accomplished, or concluded; it had, or took, effect; it was extended, or performed; or it was, or became, effectual: (TA:) and wajabato yamiynuhu, i. q. bat~ato, q. v. (M, in art. bt.) ― -b6- It is said in a trad., A_i*aA kaAna AlbayoEu Eano xiyaArK faqado wajaba [When the sale is optional, it is binding, or obligatory]: i. e., when one says, after the contract, “ Take thy choice to reject the sale, or to make it effectual, ” and the person so addressed chooses to do the latter, the sale is binding, even if the two parties have not yet separated. (TA.) ― -b7- In like manner, wajaba AlHaq~u, inf. ns. as above, The right, due, or claim, was, or became, binding, or obligatory; or fixed, settled, decided, or determined. (Msb.) ― -b8- wjb Alwjb, inf. n. wjb: (TA: [unexplained; but following wajobN as signifying “ a bet, &c.: ” app. meaning The bet, wager, or stake, became due, or incumbent]. ― -b9- [wajaba Ealayoh It was, or became, necessitated, necessary, requisite, or unavoidable, for him to do, or suffer, such a thing; and hence, sometimes, it was, or became, binding, obligatory, or incumbent, on him.] ― -b10- wajaba Ealayohi Alqawolu [The saying or sentence became necessitated to take effect upon him; or it became requisite that the saying or sentence should take effect upon him.] Jel, in xxxvi. 6, &c. ― -b11- [wajaba lahu ka*aA Such a thing was, or became, due to him; as, for instance, a reward, or a punishment.] ― -b12- wajaba Ealayohi Alqatolu [Slaughter was, or became, his due.] (TA, in art. bqY, &c.)

2 wj~b bihi AlA^aroDa *
2. wj~b bihi AlA^aroDa, inf. n. tawojiybN, He threw him down upon the ground. (S.) ― -b2- wj~b, inf. n. tawojiybN, The camel lay upon his breast with folded legs, falling down upon the ground. (TA.) ― -b3- wj~bt, inf. n. tawojiybN She (a camel) became milkless: (TA:) or [her biestings coagulated in her udder: see wajobN]. ― -b4- wj~b, (inf. n. tawojiybN, K,) He was fatigued, tired, or weary: (S, K:) said of a camel. (S.) ― -b5- wj~b All~ibaA^u, inf. n. tawojiybN, The biestings coagulated in the udder. (K.) ＝ -A2- wj~b, (inf. n. tawojiybN, TA,) He milked (a camel, K,) but once in the course of each day and night. (S, K.) ― -b2- wj~b, inf. n. tawojiybN, He accustomed himself, (Lh, S,) in which case you also say wj~b linafosihi, (Lh,) and his family, or household, and his horse, (Lh, K,) to eat but one meal (K) in the course of each day and night. (Lh, S.) ― -b3- See 1. ＝ -A3- wj~b He took, got, or won, a bet, wager, or stake, at a shooting-match or race. (L, in TA, voce nadabN.) ― -b2- See 4.

3 waAojaba
3: see 4.

4 Awjbhu *
4. Awjbhu (S, K,) and wj~bhu↓ (K) but this latter is by some rejected, (TA,) He (God, S) made it, or rendered it necessary, requisite, or unavoidable; necessitated it; made it, or declared it to be, binding, incumbent, or obligatory: (S, K:) [lit. accord. to some, he made it to fall on a person: see faraDa.] ― -b2- Awjb AlbayoEa, (Lh, S,) inf. n. A_iyjaAbN, (Lh,) He made, or rendered, or declared, the sale binding, or obligatory; (Msb, TA;) ratified it; made, or rendered, it fixed, settled, decided, or determined; (Msb;) completed, accomplished, or concluded; effectual. (TA.) ― -b3- Awjb laka AlbayoEa He made the sale to thee to be binding, or obligatory; &c. (Lh, K.) ― -b4- In like manner, AlbayoEa waAjabahu↓, inf. n. muwaAjabapN and wijaAbN; (Lh; in quoting whose words, the author of the K has made an omission, so as to cause it to appear that these two words are inf. ns. of Awjb; TA;) He, with his (another's) concurrence, made the sale to him to be binding, or obligatory; &c. (TA.) ― -b5- Awjb Ealayohi $ayoy^FA [He made a thing, or declared it to be, binding, obligatory, or incumbent, upon him; or unavoidable to him]. (TA.) ― -b6- Awjb Ealayoh AlqaDaA='a He necessitated the sentence to take effect upon him; syn. Haq~ahu and A^aHaq~ahu. (TA, in art. Hq.) ― -b7- Awjb He did a great sin, or an act of great goodness, making [the punishment of] hell, or [the reward of] paradise, the consequence thereof [unless followed by different conduct &c.]: (S, K:) he committed sins for which he who should punish him would be excusable, because he deserved punishment. (IAar, in TA, art. lwT.) ― -b8- It is said, in a trad., that some persons came to Mo- hammad, saying, A_in~a SaAHibFA lanaA A^awojaba, i. e., Verily a companion of our's hath committed a sin for which he has become deserving of hell: to which he replied, Command him to emancipate a slave [as an expiation]. (TA.) ― -b9- In another trad. it is said, A^awojaba *uw Alt~alaAvapi waAlA_ivonayoni, meaning, He of whom three children, or two, have gone before him [to paradise] hath become entitled to paradise. (TA.) ― -b10- A^awojaba lahu Aljan~apa A^awi Aln~aAra It (an action) procured for him as a necessary consequence thereof [the reward of] paradise, or [the punishment of] hell; or made such to be to him a necessary consequence thereof; [unless followed by repentance &c.:] (S, K *:) [it required for him paradise or hell.] ― -b11- [yuwjibu ka*aA It necessitates, or renders necessary, such a thing. ― -b12- It requires such a thing, as a necessary consequence. ― -b13- It necessarily implies the coexistence of such a thing therewith. Used in physics &c., and perhaps in classical writings.] ― -b14- A^awojabotu lifulaAnK Haq~ahu means I regarded such a one's right or due: and you say faEalotu *`lika A_iyjaAbFA liHaq~ihi [I did that from regard to his right or due] (Har. p. 490); [and Awjbhu lahu He made it, or declared it to be due to him]. ― -b15- [Awjbhu also signifies He affirmed it, he averred it; i. q. A^avobatahu as contr. of nafaAhu. ― -b16- And It necessarily occasioned it.] ＝ -A2- Awjb Ealayohi He beat him, overcame him, in a case of laying a bet, wager, or stake, at a shooting-match or race. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Awjb All~`hu qalobahu God made his heart to palpitate, beat, or throb; [to be agitated, or in a state of commotion]. (Lh, K.) ＝ -A4- See 1.

6 tawaAjabuwA *
6. tawaAjabuwA They laid a bet, wager, or stake, one with another, at a shooting-match or race: as though one party of them made a thing binding, or obligatory, on another party of them. (TA.)

10 Astwjbhu *
10. Astwjbhu He had a right or just title or claim, to it; deserved it; merited it: syn. A_isotaHaq~ahu [q. v.] (S, K.) See the act. part. n. below. ― -b2- Astwjb A_vomFA i. q. AisotaHaq~ihu; (TA, in art. Hq;) which means He did what necessitated sin; (Ksh, Bd, Jel, in v. 106;) [was guilty of a sin;] and deserved its being said of him that he was a sinner. (Ksh.) ― -b3- rakaba xaTiy^apF A@sotawojaba bihaA Aln~aAra [He committed a sin for which he became deserving of hell]. (TA.)

wajobN *
wajobN and muwaj~ibN↓ A she-camel whose biestings coagulate in her udder. (K.) ― -b2- wijaAbN Places in which water stagnates: (K:) pl. of wajobN. (TA.) ― -b3- wajobN A large skin of the kind called siqaA'N, made of the (complete, TA,) hide of a he-goat: pl. wijaAbN. (AHn, K.) ― -b4- wajobN Stupid; foolish; of little sense. (K.) ― -b5- wajobN (S, K) and waj~aAbN↓ (K) and waj~aAbapN↓ (IAar, K) and muwaj~ibN↓ (IAar) A coward; cowardly; pusillanimous. (S, K, &c.) [The second and third, and more especially the latter, are probably
intensive epithets.] ＝ -A2- wajobN A bet, wager, or stake, at a shooting-match (Lh, K) or a race. (IAar; and L in TA, voce nadabN.)

wajobapN *
wajobapN inf. n. of wajaba “ it fell down, &c., ” q. v. ― -b2- bijanobihi falotakuni Alwajobapu, a proverb, (S,) [(May a disease be) in his side, or (may God afflict him, or smite him, with a disease) in his side, and may falling down upon the ground, and dying, happen (or be the result thereof)! i. e. bjnbh dA'N fltkn Alwjbh bh; or ramaAhu All~`hu bidaA'K bjnbh Alx. (Freytag, Arab. Prov. i. 156)]. ― -b3- wajobapN A falling with a sound, or noise, such as that produced by the fall of a wall or the like: (S, K:) [see 1, where it is given as an inf. n. unrestricted to the signification of a single act:] or the sound of a thing falling (K) and producing a sound such as above mentioned. (TA.) ＝ -A2- wajabahN An eating but once in the course of a day and night: (S, K:) or an eating but once in a day until the like eating in the following day: (K:) an inf. n. (Lh) [restricted to the signification of a single act]: you say, fulaAnN yaA^okulu wajobapF Such a one eats but once (T) in the course of the day and night. (AZ, S.) [See also SayoramN.] ― -b2- In a trad. respecting the expiation of an oath, it is said, yuToEimu Ea$arapa masaAkiyna wajobapF waAHidapF [He shall feed ten poor men with a meal sufficient for a day and a night]. (TA.)

wujaAbN *
wujaAbN: see wuHaAbN.

wajiybapN *
wajiybapN A daily allowance of food; or daily maintenance: syn. waZiyfapN: (K:) i. e., what a man is accustomed to allow himself [each day] as that which is necessary, and fixed: but the word in the A is wajobapN, q. v. (TA.) ― -b2- wajiybapN [A term employed in the case of] one's concluding a sale, and then taking it [meaning what is sold to him] by regular successive portions, one after another, (AA, S, K,) or, as some say, on the condition of his taking a portion of it every day, (TA,) until he has taken the whole of his wajiybap: (K:) [which hence appears to signify both the act above described and also what is due to one of a thing purchased and taken in this manner; but more probably the latter is the only meaning intended]. When a person has finished doing this, one says to him qadi A@sotawofayota wajiybataka [Thou hast taken the whole of what was due to thee of the thing purchased and taken by thee in the manner above described]. (S.)

wujuwbiY~N *
[wujuwbiY~N Obligatory, or incumbent: opposed to AimotinaAniY~N.]

waj~aAbN *
waj~aAbN and wj~aAbapN: see wajobN.

waAjibN *
waAjibN Slain: (S:) dying; or dead. (TA.) So in the following verse of Keys Ibn-ElKhateem:
A^aTaAEato banuw EawofK A^amiyrFA nahaAhumu
Eani Als~ilomi Hat~aY kaAna A^aw~ala waAjibi
[The sons of 'Owf obeyed a commander who forbade them to make peace until he was the first who was slain, or who died]. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- waAjibN [act. part. n. of wajaba; Necessary; requisite; unavoidable: binding, incumbent, or obligatory. In the science of the fundamentals of religion, Necessarily being or existing; of which the nonexistence cannot be mentally conceived: as the essence of God. (IbrD.)] ― -b2- Accord. to [the Imám] Aboo-Haneefeh, waAjibN [in matters of religion] is not so strong a term as faroDN: [and so may be rendered incumbent, or obligatory; or that which is a necessary, or indispensable, duty; yet not so decisively or manifestly shown to be such as that which is termed frD:] or, accord. to Esh-Sháfi'ee, these two terms are syn., signifying [binding, incumbent, or obligatory, by God's express appointment, as] a thing for neglecting which one will be punished: and wAjb signifies that which should be preferred and approved; thus explained by ElKhattábee as occurring in the following trad.: gusolu AljumoEapi waAjibN EalaY kul~i muHotalimK The ablution prescribed to be performed on Friday is an act which every one who has experienced a nocturnal pollution should prefer and approve.
