(K, TA.) ― -b2- warobN The space between two ribs; maA bayona AlD~ilaEayoni: (K:) but this (says SM) I find not in any other book than the K; and probably it should be mA byn A_iSobaEayoni the space between two fingers; for we read in the L that wrb is said to signify mAbyn AlA^aSaAbiEi: (TA:) pl. A^aworaAbN. (K, TA.) [See also A^arobN.] ― -b3- warobN The space measured by the extension of the thumb and forefinger; syn. fitorN: pl. A^aworaAbN. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- warobN
A member; a limb: pl. A^aworaAbN. (K, TA.) wirobN↓ [also] is a dial. from of A_irobN, (K,) as signifying “ a member, or limb. ” (TA.) The form of word commonly known, says AM, is A_irobN; but I do not deny that wrb may be a dial. form, like as wirovN and A_irovN are two words whereof one is a dial. form of the other. (TA.) ― -b2- warobN and warobapN↓ The podex: syn. A_isotN: pl. of the former A^aworaAbN. (K, TA.) ― -b3- warobapN↓ The pit, or hollow, that is in the lower part of the side, i. e., the hypochondre, or flank. (TA.) ― -b4- warobN The mouth of the hole of a rat, or mouse, (faA^orap,) and of a scorpion: pl. A^aworaAbN. (K.)

wirobN *
wirobN: see warobN.

warobapN *
warobapN: see warobN.

waribN *
waribN Corrupt. (K.) ― -b2- EiroqN warib A corrupt root, origin, or stock. (S, K.) Aboo-Dharrah El-Hudhalee says,
A_ino tanotasito tunosabo A_ilaY EiroqK waribo
[If thou mention thy lineage, thy lineage is traced up to a corrupt origin, or stock]. (S.) ― -b3- rajulN waribN A corrupt man. (TA.) ― -b4- waribN A cloud that is loose (K) and much broken. (TA.)

muwar~abN *
muwar~abN [i. q. muw^ar~abN] A member, or limb, cut off entire. (TA.)

1 wariva *
1. wariva, aor. yarivu, (S, K,) an instance of deviation from a constant rule, there being only the following verbs of the measure faEila which have the aorists of the measure yafoEilu only, namely, waviqa, wariva, wariEa, warima, wariYa, wafiqa, waliYa, and wamiqa, (Ibn-Málik and others,) and waSiba: (TA, art. waSb:) the w falls out in yarivu [&c.] because it occurs between Y and kesreh; and in those persons of the aor. which begin with A and t and n because these letters are changed from Y, which is the original: (S:) inf. n. wirovN and A_irovN, (S, K,) in which the w is changed into A^, (S,) and rivapN, (S, K,) in which the p is a substitute for the [elided] w, (S,) and wiraAvapN (S, K,) [the most common form] and A_iraAvapN, (TA,) and accord. to some miyraAvN, but this is an error, for mifoEaAlN is not one of the measure of inf. ns., (ISd,) [but it is used by some of the professors of practical law as an inf. n.,] and turAvN: (Msb [but see wirovN below]:) He inherited. (S, K, &c.) You say wariva A^abaAhu He inherited [the property of] his father: (S, K:) but the original phrase is wariva maAla A^abiyhi He inherited the property of his father. (Msb.) Also wariva mino A^abiyhi (and Eanohu, A,) He inherited of his father: (K:) or he inherited part of the property of his father. (Msb.) And wariva Al$~aYo'a mino A^abiyhi He inherited the thing of, or from, his father. (S.) When you say wariva zayodN A^abaAhu maAlFA [Zeyd inherited of his father property], the word mAlA is a second objective complement, if the verb be doubly trans.; or it is a substitute of implication (badalu A@$otimaAlK) for zyd. (MF.) You say warivotuhu maAlahu, and majodahu, I inherited his property, and, (tropical:) his glory: and warivotuhu Eanohu I inherited it from him. (TA.)

2 wrv~hu *
2. wrv~hu, inf. n. taworiyvN, He included him among the heirs of his property: (S:) or made him to be one of his heirs: (TA:) [see also 4:] or wrv~hu maAlFA he included him among his heirs, he not being one of them, and assigned him a portion: (AZ, Msb:) [in like manner,] wr~v fiY maAlihi he included among his heirs of his property one or more not of them. (TA.) ― -b2- war~avotu fulaAnFA mino fulaAnK I made such a one to be the heir of such a one. (TA.) See 4. ＝ -A2- wr~v He stirred a fire, in order that it might burn up, or blaze: (K:) a dial. form of A^ar~ava, q. v. (TA.)

4 Awrvhu Al$~aYo'a *
4. Awrvhu Al$~aYo'a He (his father) made him to inherit the thing. (S.) ― -b2- Awrvhu A_iyraAvFA HasanFA He made him to have a goodly inheritance. (TA.) Awrvhu AlA_irova, and AlmiyraAva, and A_iy~aAho wr~vhu↓, He made him to inherit the heritage. (A.) ― -b3- Awrvhu and wrv~hu↓ He (his father) made him to be one of his heirs. (K.) [See also 2.] ― -b4- Awrv waladahu He made his son sole heir. (AZ.) ― -b5- Awrvhu $ayoy^FA (tropical:) It occasioned him, as its result, a thing. Ex. Awrvh AlmaraDu DaEofFA (tropical:) The disease occasioned him, as its result, weakness. (TA.)

6 tawaAravwuhu kaAbirFA Eano kaAbirK *
6. tawaAravwuhu kaAbirFA Eano kaAbirK (tropical:) [They inherited it by degrees, one great in dignity and nobility from another great in dignity and nobility]. (S.) [See art. kbr.] ― -b2- tawaAravaniY AlHawaAdivu (Bedr Ibn-'Ámir El-Hudhalee) (tropical:) Misfortune took me by turns, as though they inherited me, one from another. (TA.)

warovN *
warovN (tropical:) What is fresh, juicy, or moist, of things. (K.)

wirovN *
wirovN and A_irovN↓ [see 1] and turaAvN↓ (in which the t is originally w, S,) and miyraAvN (originally miworaAvN, the w being changed to Y because of the kesreh immediately preceding it, S.) What is inherited; an inheritance, or a heritage: or, accord. to some, wrv and myrAv are used with reference to property, or wealth; and Arv with reference to rank or quality, nobility or eminence, reputation, or the like, in Arabic, Hasab: (M:) [the pl. of myrAv is mawaAriyvu.] [See also art. A^riv.] ― -b2- A^uvobutuwAEalaY ma$aAEirikumo h`*ihi faA_in~akumo EalaY A_irovK mino A_irovi A_ibor`hiyma (tropical:) Remain ye steadfast in the observance of these your rites, or ceremonies; for ye act [therein] according to usage inherited from Abraham. (TA, [app. from A'Obeyd].) [See also A_irovN in art A^rv.] ― -b3- lahumo A_irovu majodK (tropical:) They have an inheritance of glory. (TA.)

warovapN *
warovapN Fire. (L.)

waArivN *
waArivN An heir: pl. wur~aAv and waravapN. (Msb.) ― -b2- It is said in a prayer (of Mohammad, TA) A^all~`hum~a A^amotiEoniY bisamoEiY wabaSariY waA@joEalohu AlwaAriva mn~iY [O God, cause me to enjoy my hearing and my sight, and make it (i. e. the enjoyment that I pray for, TA) survive me: or,] make it to continue with me until I die. (K.) Or, accord. to another relation, which substitutes waA@joEalohumaA for wAjElh, make them both to continue with me, sound, until I die. Or, as some say, what is meant is the continuance and strength of those two faculties in old age, so that they may survive all the other powers: so says ISh. Some say, that by samoE is meant the remembering of what is heard, and the acting according thereto; and by baSar, the being admonished by what is seen, and the light of the heart, whereby one escapes from perplexity and darkness to the right course. (TA.) ― -b3- AlwaArivu (as an epithet applied to God, TA.) He who remains after the creatures have perished. (K.) He remains after everything beside Him has perished; and thus, what was the property of mankind, his servants, returns to Him. (TA.)

A_irovN A^rv A_rv Arv rAv rv rvA rvY wrv
A_irovN: see wirovN, and 1.

miyraAvN *
miyraAvN: see wirovN, and 1.

turaAvN trAv
turaAvN: see wirovN, and 1.

maworuwvN *
maworuwvN Property inherited. (Msb.)

Almajodu mutawaAravN bayonahumo *
Almajodu mutawaAravN bayonahumo (tropical:) Glory is inherited among them. (A.)

1 warixN *
1. warixN, aor. yaworaxu, (S, L, K,) inf. n. waraxN; (S, L;) and twr~x↓; (L;) It (dough) was, or became, thin, or flaccid, (S, L, K,) by reason of the abundance of water in it. (S, L.)

2 wr~x AlkitaAba biyawomi ka*aA *
2. wr~x AlkitaAba biyawomi ka*aA He inscribed the writing, or letter, with the date of such a day; i. q. A^ar~axahu; (S, K *;) of which it is a dial. form. (Yaakoob.)

4 Awrx *
4. Awrx He made dough thin, or flaccid, (S, L, K,) by putting much water to it. (L.)

5 tawar~axa
5: see 1: ― -b2- and 10.

10 Astwrxt AlA^aroDu *
10. Astwrxt AlA^aroDu, and twr~xt↓, The land, or ground, became wet, or moist. (K.)

waroxN *
waroxN A kind of tree resembling the marox in its
growth, (L, K,) except that it is dust-coloured, having slender leaves, like the leaves of the Taroxuwn, or larger. (L.)

A^aroDN warixapN *
A^aroDN warixapN Land having tangled and luxuriant herbage. (K.)

wariyxapN *
wariyxapN Dough that is thin, or flaccid, (S, K,) by reason of the abundance of water in it. (S.) ― -b2- Wet, or moist, land, or ground. (K.)

tawaAriyxu *
tawaAriyxu, pl. of taworiyxN: see taA^oriyxN.

1 waradahu *
1. waradahu, (S, M, L, Msb,) aor. yaridu, (S, L, Msb,) inf. n. wuruwdN (M, L, Msb) and maworidN (L) and wirodN, (M, L, K,) or the last is a simple subst., (L, Msb,) He (a man, and a camel, &c., Msb) came to it, or arrived at it, (M, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) [and repaired to it,] namely a water (S, M, L, Msb, K) &c., (M, L, K,) whether he entered it or did not enter it; (M, Mgh, L, Msb, K;) as also warada Ealayohi, (M, L,) and twr~dhu↓, (M, L, K,) and Astwrdhu↓: (M, A, Mgh, L, K:) he came to it (namely a water) to drink: (L:) (tropical:) he arrived at it (namely a town or country or the like), whether he entered it or did not enter it: (Mgh, L:) it is allowed by common consent not necessarily to imply entering. (L.) [Hence, waradati AlA_ibilu, the objective complement maA='F or AlmaA='a being understood, The camels came to water.] ― -b2- warada, inf. n. wuruwdN, He came; he was, or became, present. (S, L.) ― -b3- warada EalayonaA, inf. n. wuruwdN (assumed tropical:) He (a man) came to us. (Msb.) ― -b4- wirada AlkitaAbu (A, Msb,) inf. n. [wuruwdN and] maworidN (A,) (tropical:) The letter came, (A, Msb,) EalaY~a to me: you say, warada EalaY~a AlkaitaAbu. (A.) ― -b5- AlmahaAlika huwa yatawar~adu↓ (tropical:) He ventures upon, or goes into, places of destruction]. (A.) ― -b6- AlD~alaAlapa Astwrd↓, and waradahaA, (tropical:) [He ran into error]. (A.) ― -b7- warad Ealayohi A^amorN lamo yuTiqohu (tropical:) [A thing befell him which he was unable to master]. (A.) ― -b8- warada Ealayohi It contravened it; presented itself as an objection to it; opposed it.] ― -b9- [warada, said of a word or phrase or the like, It occurred.] ― -b10- waradatohu AlHum~aY, (aor. taridu, Msb, inf. n. wuruwdN, A) (tropical:) The fever attacked him periodically. (S, A, L, Msb.) ― -b11- wurida (tropical:) He suffered a periodical attack of fever. (A, L, Msb.) ＝ -A2- waruda, aor.
waruda
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. wuruwdapN; (S, L, Msb;) and A_iyraAd~a↓, originally A_iworaAd~a, the w becoming Y because of the kesreh before it; (S, L, K;) (tropical:) He (a horse) was, or became, [of a bright, or yel-lowish bay colour;] of a colour between that called kumayot and A^a$oqar: (S, L, K:) or, of a red colour inclining to yellow. (M, L, Msb.) ― -b2- wuruwdu AlA^aronabapi see $amama and A^aronabapN.

2 wr~d vawobahu *
2. wr~d vawobahu (tropical:) [He dyed his garment, or piece of cloth, red, or of a rose-colour]. (A.) ― -b2- wr~dti Al$~ajarapu, (AHn, L, K,) inf. n. taworiydN; (K;) and waradato, aor. tardu; (Msb;) The tree flowered, or blossomed. (AHn, L, Msb, K.) ― -b3- wr~dt (tropical:) She (a woman) reddened her cheek with the dye of dyed cotton. (L.)

3 wArdhu *
3. wArdhu, (inf. n. muwaAradapN, A,) He came to water with him. (L, K.) ― -b2- bayona Al$~aAEirayoni muwaAradapN, and tawaArudN, (tropical:) [Between the two poets is an agreement, or a coincidence, in ideas and expressions; as though they both drew from the same source]. (A.) Similar to this is the phrase tawaArudu AlxaATiri (tropical:) [Agreement, or coincidence, of thought, or idea]. (TA.)

4 Awrdhu *
4. Awrdhu, and Astwrdhu↓, (K,) and twr~dhu↓, (ISd,) He brought him to the watering-place. (K.) ― -b2- Also, the first and second of these verbs, He brought him; made him to come, or to be present. (S, L.) ― -b3- [And the first, He adduced it, or cited it; namely, an evidence, a speech or saying, a word, &c. ― -b4- He set it forth, or expressed it; namely, a meaning.] ― -b5- Awrdhu AlmaA='a, (inf. n. A_iyraAdN, A.) He made him to come to the water. (L, Msb.) [See an ex. voce HamoDN.] ― -b6- Awrdhu AlD~alaAlapa (tropical:) [He made him to run into error. (A.) ― -b7- A^aworada Ealayohi xayorFA [He brought to him wealth, property, or what was good.] (Mugh, in art. HTb.) ― -b8- Awrd Ealayohi Alxabara (tropical:) He related to him the news. (L.) ― -b9- Awrd Al$~aYo'a (tropical:) He mentioned the thing. (TA.) ― -b10- A^worada wA^aSodara (tropical:) He began and compelled. (TA, art. Sdr) ― -b11- Awrdh wASdrh He brought it and he took it away. (Har. p. 361.)

5 tawar~ada
5: see 1, and 4, and 10. ― -b2- tawr~dti Alxayolu Albalodapa (tropical:) The horses entered the town by little and little. (S, L, K. *) ＝ -A2- twr~d (tropical:) [It became red, roseate, or rose-coloured]: said of a woman's cheek. (A.)

6 twArdnA *
6. twArdnA We came to water together. (A.)

10 Astwrd *
10. Astwrd (ISd) and twr~d↓ (K) He desired to come to water. (ISd, K.) [See an ex. of the part. n. voce HamoDN.] ― -b2- See 1 and 4.

11 A_iworaAod~a
11: see 1.

warodN *
warodN [coll. gen. n.] The flower, or blossom, of any tree (AHn, L, K) or plant: (AHn, L:) but its predominant application is to the rose Hawojam, (L, K,) the well-known red flower (TA) which one smells: (S, L, TA:) its colour varies in winter and summer: (L:) and it is of different kinds in the cultivated soil and in the desert and in the mountains: (AHn, L:) n. un. with p. (S, L.) Said to be an arabicized word. (Msb.) ― -b2- warodN (tropical:) A horse [of a bright, or yellowish, bay colour;] of a colour between that called kumayot and A^a$oqar: (S, L, K:) a horse, (M, L, Msb,) or other thing. (M, L,) of a red colour inclining to yellow, (M, L, Msb,) beautiful in everything: (M, L:) fem. with p: (S, L, Msb:) applied in the above sense to the sky, in the Kur, lv. 37: (L:) or it there means roseates, or of a rosecolour: (Zj, L:) pl. wurodN, (S, L, K,) like as juwnN is pl. of jawonN, (S,) and wiraAdN (S, L, Msb, K) and A^aworaAdN: (K:) but this last is unknown, and app. a mistake. (M, F, TA.) ― -b3- warodN (tropical:) A lion of the colour termed warod: (S, A, L:) or a lion; as also mutawar~idN↓. (K.) ― -b4- Ea$iy~apN warodapN (tropical:) An evening when the horizon is red (L, K) at sunset; which is a sign of drought: and in like manner the morning at sunrise. (L.) ― -b5- layolapN warodapN (tropical:) A night of which the beginning and end are red; which is the case in a time of drought. (A.) ― -b6- warodN Bold, or daring; (K;) an epithet applied to a man; (TA;) as also waAridN↓. (K.) ― -b7- warodN Saffron. (K.) ― -b8- Alwarodu AljabaliY~u: see EabaAlN. ― -b9- A^abuw Alwarodi (tropical:) The penis: (K:) so called because of its redness. (TA.)

wirodN *
wirodN A coming to, or arriving at, water &c., whether one enters it or does not enter it; (S, * L, Msb, K;) contr. of SadarN. (S, L, Msb.) See also 1. ― -b2- wirodN Water to which one comes to drink. (L.) ― -b3- wirodN The time of the day of coming to water, between the two periods of abstaining from water: (L:) a time, or turn, of coming to water. (TA in art. Hzb.) ― -b4- wirodN The arrival of the day of coming to water. (L.) ― -b5- waradati AlA_ibilu AlmaA='a wirodFA, and A^aworaAdF, and in like manner, AlT~ayoru, The camels, and the birds, came to the water in a herd, or in a flock, and in herds, or in flocks. (L.) ― -b6- wir~dN A company of men, (S, L, Msb, K,) and a number of camels, and of birds, &c., (L,) coming to, or arriving at, water; (S, L, Msb, K;) as also waAridapN↓: (L, Msb, K:) the former originally an inf. n.: (Msb:) its pl. is A^aworaAdN. (L.) See also waAridN. ― -b7- wirodN A herd of camels. (L.) ― -b8- A flock of birds. (L, K.) ― -b9- (tropical:) An army, (L, K,) so called as being likened to a herd of camels, or to a flock of birds. (L.) ― -b10- A portion, or share, of water. (L, K.) ― -b11- Thirst. (L.) ― -b12- nasuwqu Almujorimiyna A_ilaY jahay~ama wirodFA [Kur, xix, 89,] (assumed tropical:) We will drive the sinners to hell like beasts that come to water: or, thirsty: (Beyd:) or, walking and thirsty. (Zj, L.) ― -b13- wirodN (tropical:) The day of a fever, when it attacks the patient periodically: (As, S, L, Msb, * K *:) or one of the names of fever: (L, K:) but the former explanation is the more correct. (TA.) ― -b14- wirodN (assumed tropical:) A portion of the night when a man has to pray. (L.) ― -b15- wirodN (tropical:) A section, or division, (S, L, K,) of the Kur-án: (L, K:) a set portion of recitation or the like: (Msb:) a certain portion of the Kur-án, as a seventh, or half a seventh, or the like, (Mgh, L,) which a person recites at a particular time: (L:) a set portion of the Kur-án, or of prayer; &c., of which a man imposes upon himself the recital on a particular occasion, or at a particular time; i. q. HizobN q. v.: (Mgh, L:) pl. A^aworaAdN. (L, Msb.) Ex. qaraA^otu wirodiY [I recited my set portion of the Kur-án, &c.]: (S, L:) and lifulaAnK kul~a layolapK wirodN
mina AlquroA=ni yaqoraA^uhu Such a one has every night a set portion of the Kur-án which he recites. (L.)

warodapN *
warodapN [A bright, or yellowish, bay colour;] a colour between that of a horse that is termed kumayotN and that of one termed A^a$oqaru: (S, L:) or a red colour inclining to yellow. (L.)

binotu warodaAna *
binotu warodaAna, (Msb,) pl. banaAtu warodaAna, (K,) A certain insect, (Msb, K,) well known, (K,) like the beetle, of a red colour, mostly found in baths and in privies. (Msb.)

Alwariydu *
Alwariydu, and Habolu Alwariydi, [Each of the two carotid arteries: and sometimes applied to each of the two external jugular veins:] each of two veins asserted by the Arabs to be from the watiyn [or aorta], on the right and left of the two sides of the neck, next the fore part, and thick: (S, L:) or the wryd is a certain vein, said to be the wadaj [or external jugular vein]: or, by the side of the wdj: or, accord. to Fr, a certain vein between the windpipe and [the two sinews called] the EilobaAwaAni, always pulsing; being one of the veins in which is the life; the blood not flowing in it, but only the soul, Alnfs [i. e., Aln~afosu, not Aln~afasu; for, accord. to the Arabs, the animal soul (Alr~uwHu AlHayowaAniY~u, as is said in the KT,) diffuses itself throughout the body, from the heart, by means of the pulsing veins, or arteries: see also wadajN]: (Msb:) or the wariydaAni are two veins in the neck, (AZ, L, K,) between the A^awodaAj [or external jugular veins] and [the two parts of the neck called] the liytaAni: in the camel, the wadajaAni [or two external jugular veins]: (AZ, T:) or, accord. to AHeyth, and his is the correct explanation, two veins beneath the wadajaAni, [see above,] which latter are two thick veins on the right and left of the pit between the clavicles; they (the former) are always pulsing, in man: the wryd is a vein in which the soul (Alnfs [see above]) flows, and in which the blood does not flow: and every pulsing vein, in which the life flows, is of those thus called: (T:) or the wryd is the vein in each side of the neck which swells out on an occasion of anger: (L:) or four veins in the head; of which two descend before the ears, and of which are the wrydAn in the neck: or a certain vein beneath the tongue: and, in the upper half of the arm, the faliyq [or cephalic]: and, in the fore arm, the A^akoHal [or median]: and, among those which separate in the outer side of the hand, the A^a$aAjiE: and, in the belly of the fore arm, the rawaAhi$: (T:) pl. A^aworidapN [a pl. of pauc.] (M, Msb, K) and warudN, (M, Msb,) like as burudN is pl. of bariydN, (Msb,) [and wutunN of watiynN, &c.,] or waruwdN, (K,) [but this I think a mistake]. ― -b2- rajulN munotafixu Alwariydi [A man whose external jugular vein swells out;] a man of bad disposition or temper, prone to anger. (TA.)

war~aAdN *
war~aAdN: see waAridN.

waAridN *
waAridN A man, and a camel, or other animal, (L,) coming to, or arriving at water, &c., whether he enter it or do not enter it; (L, Msb, K;) as also war~aAdN↓: (L, CK:) pl. of the former, wur~aAdN (S, L, Msb, K) and waAriduwna: (L:) and of the latter, war~aAduwna. (L.) See also wirodN. ― -b2- A_ino manokumo A_il~aA waAriduhaA [Kur, xix. 72, There is not any of you that shall not come to it,] means, accord. to Th, that the Muslims shall come to hell with the unbelievers, but not enter it with them. (L.) ― -b3- TariyqN waAridu (tropical:) A road, or way, by which people come to water: opposed to SaAdirN. (M, A, art. Sdr.) See also maworidN ― -b4- maA lhu SaAdirN walaA waAridN: see art. Sdr. ― -b5- waAridN A preceder. (L, K.) So (accord. to some, TA) in the Kur, xii. 19. (L.) ― -b6- waAridN Courageous; (K;) bold; forward in affairs. (TA.) See also warodN. ＝ -A2- $aEorN waAridN (tropical:) Long and lank hair: (L, K:) or hair so long as to reach the buttocks, (A,) of a woman. (L.) ― -b2- waAridN (tropical:) Anything long. (L.) ― -b3- A^aronabapN waAridapN (tropical:) The end, or tip, of a nose advancing over the middle of the mustaches: (A, L:) because the nose, when it is long, reaches to the water when the person drinks: and in like manner, a lip, and a gum. (L.) ― -b4- fulaAnN waAridu AlA^aronabapi (tropical:) Such a one has a long end, or tip, to his nose. (S, L, K.) $ajarapN waAridapu AlA^agoSaAni (tropical:) A tree having pendulous branches. (L.) ― -b5- See wirodN.

waAridapN *
waAridapN: see waAridN, wirodN and maworidN.

A_iyraAdN *
[A_iyraAdN (assumed tropical:) Income; revenue: pl. A_iyaraAdaAtN.]

maworidN *
maworidN A place of coming to water: (Msb:) a watering-place: (L:) and maworidapN↓ a road, or way, by which one comes to water; (L, K;) as also waAridapN↓: (A, K:) pl. of the first (L) and second, (TA,) mawaAridu; (L, TA;) and of the third, waAridaAtN. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (A, TA,) maworidN and waAridN↓ (tropical:) A road, or way; (S, L;) as also waAridapN↓: (TA:) or the last, the middle and main part of a road; or a main road; or simply, a road; syn. jaAd~apN; (K;) as also maworidapN↓: (L, K:) pls. as above. (A, TA.) ― -b3- mawaAridu A^amorK (tropical:) [The ways leading to a thing: or the ways of commencing a thing]: (TA, art. rHb.) [See an ex., voce taraAHaba; and see its opposite, maSaAdiru A^amorK, voce maSodarN.] ― -b4- [maworidN also signifies, agreeably with analogy, The time of coming to water: pl. mawaAridu: see the last signification of val~apN in this lexicon: see also wirudN.] ＝ -A2- maworidu mavalK (tropical:) [The primary idea, or thing, signified by a parable or proverb: correlative of maDoribu mavalK: pl. mawaAridu]. (TA, &c., passim.)

maworidapN *
maworidapN: see maworidN.

maworuwdN *
maworuwdN (tropical:) Attacked by a fever periodically: (S, L:) or suffering a periodical attack of fever. (Msb.) ― -b2- An Arab of the desert said to another, maA A^amaAru A_iforaAqi Almaworuwdi [What is the sign of the convalescence of him who is attacked by a periodical fever?] and he answered, Alr~uHaDaA='u [The sweat which follows it; or copious sweat]. (S.)

muwar~adN *
muwar~adN (tropical:) A shirt dyed of a rose-colour; of a less deep dye than that which is termed muDar~ajN: (S, L;) or dyed with saffron. (TA.) ― -b2- xad~N muwar~adN (tropical:) A reddened cheek. (TA.) ― -b3- rajaEa muwar~ada Alqa*aAli (tropical:) He returned [with the back of his head] slapped, or thumped with the fist, [and rendered red]. (A.)

mutawar~idN *
mutawar~idN: see warodN.

1 warasa *
1. warasa, inf. n. wuruwsN, It (a plant) became green. (AA, A, Hn, M.) ― -b2- See also 4. ― -b3- warisa, (M, K,) aor. yaworasu, (K,) It (a rock, M, K, in water, K) became overspread with [the green substance called] TuHolub, so that it became green and smooth. (IDrd, M, K.) ― -b4- See also 4.

2 wr~shu *
2. wr~shu, inf. n. taworiysN, He dyed it (a garment, or piece of cloth,) with waros, q. v. (S, K.)

4 Awrs AlmakaAnu *
4. Awrs AlmakaAnu The place produced the plant called waros. (S.) ― -b2- Awrs Alr~imovu The [trees called] rmv produced waros, a thing yellow like the [garments termed] mulaA='; as also warasa↓: so it is asserted, on trustworthy authority: (M:) or became yellow in their leaves, (S, K,) after attaining to maturity, (S,) and had upon them what was like yellow mulaA='; (S, K;) and in like manner one says of a place, Awrs AlmakaAnu: (TA:) or became yellow in its fruit: (A:) ― -b3- Awrs Al$~ajaru The trees put forth leaves; (K;) as also warisa↓. (IKtt.)

warosN *
warosN A certain plant, (S, A, Msb, K,) of a yellow colour, (S, Msb,) resembling sesame, (A, K,) with which one dyes, (A, Msb,) and of which is made the [liniment called] gumorap for the face, (S,) existing in El-Yemen, (S, K,) and nowhere else, (K,) being there sown; (Msb;) it is not wild, but is sown one year, and remains ten years, (AHn, M,) or twenty years, (K,) without ceasing to be profitable, resembling sesame in its manner of growth; and when it dries, on its attaining to maturity, its pericarps (xaraAy^iT) burst, and it is shaken, and the waros shakes out from it: (AHn, M,) it is useful for the [discolouration of the face termed] kalaf, used as a liniment; and for the [leprous-like discolouration of the skin termed bahaq, [prepared] as a drink; and the wearing of a garment dyed with it strengthens the venereal faculty: (K:) or a certain yellow dye: or, as some say, a certain plant, of sweet odour: or, as is said in the qaAnuwn [of Ibn-Seenà, or Avicenna,]
a certain thing of an intensely red colour, resembling powdered saffron, brought from El-Yemen, and said to be scraped or rubbed off, or to fall off, from its trees: (Mgh:) or, as some say, a species of kurokum, q. v.: or, as some say, resembling kurokum: (Msb:) or a certain thing, yellow, like the [garments of the kind called mulaA=', that comes forth upon the [trees called] rimov, between the last part of summer and the first part of winter, (M, TA,) which, when it touches a garment, soils it: (TA:) or it also, sometimes, [accord. to certain persons who seems to misapply the word, is a substance which] pertains to the [trees called] EaroEar and rimov, and to other trees, above all in Abyssinia; but this is inferior to that first mentioned (K, TA) in virtue and properties: as to that of the ErEr, it is found between its rind and the main substance, when it dries up; and when it is rubbed, it rubs off; and there is no good in it; but wrs [properly so called] is adulterated with it: and as to that of the rmv, when it is the end of summer, and it has attained its utmost state, it becomes intensely yellow, so that what envelops it becomes yellow, and with this also one adulterates: so says AHn: (TA:) wrs is called in Persian AsPrk [A_isoPariko]; and in Turkish, A=lAjhrh. (TK.) [Freytag adds to what he has given on this word from the K, S, TK. as follows: “ Memecylon tinctorium. Sprengel. hist. med., t. ii., p. 444, ed. tert. (ubi wrz scriptum est). Spreng. hist. rei herb., t. i., p. 258. Avicenn. p. ??? ”]

warisN *
warisN: see wariysN.

warosiY~N *
warosiY~N A yellow bowl: (A:) or a bowl made of nuDaAr, (M,) which is a yellow wood: (TA:) or of the best kind of those made of nuDaAr. (Lth, K.) ― -b2- A pigeon that is red inclining to yellowness: (M:) or a pigeon inclining to redness and yellowness. (K.) ― -b3- See also wariysN.

wariysN *
wariysN A garment dyed with waros; as also warisN↓ and waArisN↓ (M) and muwar~asN↓. (M, A.) You say, maloHafapN wiriysapN, (so in some copies of the S and K) or warosiy~apN↓, (as in other copies of the S and K, and thus in a copy of the Msb,) [An outer wrapping garment] dyed with ws; (S, Msb, K;) i. q. muwar~asapN↓; (K;) which latter epithet is sometimes used. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also waArisN.

waArisN *
waArisN applied to a place [Producing the plant called waros]. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a tree of the kind called rimov, Producing waros, a thing yellow like the [garments termed] mulaA=': (M:) or becoming yellow in the leaves, (S, K,) after attaining to maturity, (S,) and having upon it what is like yellow mulaA='u: (S, K:) or becoming yellow in its fruit: (A:) or, app., having waros, like as taAmirN signifies “ possessing dates; ” (AHn;) and wariysN↓ likewise has the last of these significations: (TA:) muwrisN↓ also signifies the same as waArisN, applied to a tree of the kind abovementioned; (A, K;) but is very rare, though agreeable with analogy: (K:) it is said (M) one should not say muworisN; (S, M;) but it occurs in a poem of Ibn-Harmeh. (M.) ― -b3- Applied to a tree [of any other kind], Putting forth leaves. (TA.) ― -b4- Applied to a plant, Becoming green. (M.) You say also, SaxorapN waArisapN biAlT~uHolubi, A rock overspread with the green substance called THlb, so that it is green and smooth: see 1]. (A.) ― -b5- It also denotes intenseness of colour, in the phrase A^aSofaru waArisN Yellow intensely bright. (M.) And [in like manner] you say, jamalN waArisu AlHumorapi A camel intensely red. (Sgh.) And zaEofaraAnN waArisN [app., Bright-coloured saffron]. (A.) See also wariysN.

muwrisN *
muwrisN: see waArisN.

muwar~asN *
muwar~asN: see wariysN, in two places.

1 wara$a *
1. wara$a, (S, A, K,) aor. yari$u, inf. n. wuruw$N (K) and waro$N, (TA,) He took, or reached, or took or reached with the hand, or with the extended hand, (S, A, K,) food, (A, K,) or somewhat thereof, (S,) or a little thereof. (AZ.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) inf. n. waro$N and wuruw$N, (TA,) He ate vehemently and greedily: (Ibn-'Abbád, A, K:) but accord. to IAar, rawo$N, with the rá first, signifies the “ eating much; ” and waro$N, with the wáw first, the eating little. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) inf. n. waro$N, (TA,) He coveted; longed; yearned; eagerly desired; strove to acquire; obtain, or attain. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) You say, wara$a A_ilyhi He coveted it; &c. (TK.) ― -b4- wara$a Ealayohimo, (A, K,) inf. n. waro$N, (TA,) He came in to them uninvited when they were eating, (A, K, TA,) to get some of their food: and when one has gone in to others while they were drinking, you say, wagala Ealyohimo: but see waAri$N. (TA.) ＝ -A2- wara$a fulaAnFA bifulAanK He incited such a one against such a one: (Ibn-'Abbád, TA:) in the K, erroneously, wara$a fulaAnN bifulaAnK. (TA.) See also 2.

2 war~a$a bayona Alqawomi *
2. war~a$a bayona Alqawomi, (S,) inf. n. taworyi$N, (S, K,) He excited discord, dissension, disorder, strife, quarrelling, or animosity, between, or among, the people; syn. Har~a$a; (S, K;) as also A^ar~a$a (S) [and har~a$a]. See also 1, last signification.

wara$aAnN *
wara$aAnN A certain bird, (S, Mgh, K,) of the pigeon-kind, (AHát, Mgh, Msb,) or resembling the pigeon, (TA,) also called saAqu Hur~K, (S, Msb, K,) which is the male of the qamaAriY~ [or kind of collared turtle-doves of which a single female is called qumoriy~apN (see qumoriY~N)], (Msb,) of the birds of the desert, (TA,) the flesh of which is lighter than that of the [common] pigeon: (K:) fem. with p: (K:) pl. waraA$iynu (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and wiro$aAnN, (S, Msb, K,) like as kiruwaAnN is a pl. of karawaAnN, contr. to rule. (S.) It is said in a proverb, biEil~api Alwara$aAni taA^okulu ruTaba Almu$aAni [With the pretext of the warashán, thou eatest the fresh ripe dates of the excellent kind called m$An]: (S, A, K:) said to him who pretends one thing and means another: (A, K:) originating from the fact that some people employed a slave belonging to them to guard the fresh ripe dates of their palm-trees, and he used to eat them, and, when reproved for his evil conduct, laid the blame upon the warashán; wherefore this was said to him. (Sgh.)

waAri$N *
waAri$N One who comes in to a people uninvited, when they are eating; like waAgilN in the case of beverage: (S:) and, accord. to some, i. q. waAgilN but others say, that wAr$ has the first signification only, relating to food: and that of a sponger desiring food. (TA.) See raA$inN and TufayoliY~N.

1 waraTahaA *
1. waraTahaA He veiled, concealed, hid, or covered, her, or it, or them; [to what the pronoun relates is not said; but I incline to think that the right reading is war~aTahaA, and that the pronoun relates to camels; (see 2;) as also AwrThA↓: (L, TA:) from IAar. (TA.)

2 wr~Thu *
2. wr~Thu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. taworiyTN, (S, Msb,) He made him to fall into what is termed waroTap [properly and also tropically, or in its primary sense and also in any of its subordinate senses]; as also AwrThu↓, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iyraATN: (Msb:) both signify (assumed tropical:) he made him to fall into that from which he could not extricate himself: (TA:) or into that from which he could not easily extricate himself. (Msb.) ― -b2- wr~T A_ibilahu fY A_ibilK A^axoraY (assumed tropical:) He hid, or concealed, his camels among other camels [in order that they might escape the notice of the collector of the poor-rates]; as also AwrT↓. (K.) [See also 1, and 3.]

3 wiraATN *
3. wiraATN (S, Msb, TA) and muwaAraTapN (TA) [The act of mutually making to fall into what is termed waroTap. ＝ -A2- And hence,] (assumed tropical:) The act of mutually deceiving, beguiling, or circumventing; or endeavouring to deceive, beguile, or circumvent; (TA;) or the act of deceiving, beguiling, or circumventing; (S, Msb;) and the acting, or advising, or counselling, dishonestly, or insincerely; (S, Msb, TA;) and waroTN↓ and wiraATapN↓, the latter on the authority of J, [accord. to some
copies of the S, but in other copies wiraATN,] signify the same [as substs.] (TA.) You say, laA tuwaAriTo jaAraka faA_in~a AlwiraATa yuwridu AlA^aworAaTa (assumed tropical:) [Do not thou practise mutual deceit with thy neighbour, or endeavour to deceiving him, &c., for the doing so brings upon its author things, or affairs, from which it is difficult to escape]. (Z, TA.) And it is said in trad, laA xilaATa walaA wiraATa, which is like his [Mohammad's] saying, (assumed tropical:) There shall be no putting together what is separate, nor separating what is put together, from fear of the poor-rate: (S:) xlAT has been explained in its place: (TA:) wrAT [has also been variously explained in that place, and, it is said,] signifies the putting together what is separate: and the reverse: (K:) or the dispersing camels (K, TA) among other camels: (TA:) or the hiding camels among other camels; (Th, K;) or in a low, or depressed, piece of ground; in order that the collector of the poor-rate may not see them: (K:) or the making one another to fall into a waroTap, (TA,) one saying to the collector of the poor-rate, “ Such a one has that for which a poor-rate is due, ” when he has not; (K, TA;) so accord. to IAar: accord. to Ibn-Háni, it is from A^aworaTa Aljariyra fiY Eunuqi AlbaEiyiri. (TA.) See 4.

4 A^aworaTa
4: see 2, in two places; and 1. ― -b2- AwrT Aljariyra fiY Eunuqi AlbaEiyr (assumed tropical:) He put the end of the jryr [q. v.] of the camel into its ring, and then pulled it so as to throttle him. (Ibn-Háni. K.)

5 twr~T fiY waroTapK *
5. twr~T fiY waroTapK He fell into what is termed waroTap [properly and also tropically, or in its primary sense, and also in any of its subordinate senses]. (S.) You say, twr~Tti Alganamu wagayoruhaA The sheep, or goats, &c., fell into mud from which they could not extricate themselves; or into a depressed piece of ground in which was no way directing to escape: and hence the verb is used in relation to any straitness or difficulty. (Msb.) Thus you say, twr~T fulaAnN fiY AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) Such a one undertook, or embarked in, the affair, and could not easily extricate himself; and so fyh AstwrT↓: (Msb:) or the former signifies (assumed tropical:) he fell into the affair, or case: (K:) or (assumed tropical:) he became entangled in the affair, and could not easily extricate himself from it; (TA;) and so ↓the latter: (Sh, K, TA:) and twr~T and AstwrT↓ both signify he stuck fast: or (assumed tropical:) he perished; or died. (TA.)

10 A_isotaworaTa
10: see 5, in three places. ― -b2- AstwrT maEa fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) He behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently, in speech, with such a one. (TA.)

waroTN *
waroTN: see 3.

waroTahN *
waroTahN Slime, or thin mud, [in the CK, Alr~aHolu is erroneously put for AlwaHolu,] into which sheep or goats fall, and from which they cannot extricate themselves: (Msb, K:) this, or, as some say, what here next follows, is the primary signification: (Msb:) a low, or depressed, piece of ground or land, in which is no way, or road, (S, Msb, K,) directing to escape: (Msb:) this is said by A'Obeyd to be the primary signification: (S:) a deep hollow, cavity, or pit, in the ground: (TA:) a deep hollow, cavity, or pit, formed for the purpose of a stratagem, such as may be in a mountain, occasioning difficulty to him who falls into it: (As:) and hence, (TA,) a well: (K, TA:) and anything that is gaAmiD [app. here meaning low, or depressed]: (K:) also, by derivation from the first of these significations, (Msb,) or from the second, (S, Msb,) [or some other,] (assumed tropical:) perdition; or destruction; or death: (S, Msb, K:) and (assumed tropical:) [any embarrassing, or difficult, case, or affair;] any case, or affair, from which escape is difficult: (K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aworaATN, (S, IS,) the p in the sing. being app. regarded as elided; (IS;) and [of mult.] wiraATN, (K,) and waraTaAtN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) The podex: or the anus: syn. A_isotN. (K, TA.)

wiraATapN *
wiraATapN: see 3.

waz~N *
waz~N a dial. var. of A_iwaz~N, (S, K,) A kind of water-fowl; (S;) [the goose, or geese; and the duck, or ducks; but generally the former of these birds;] as also waz~iynN↓: (K:) n. un. of the former, waz~apN; (Msb, art. wz;) and of the latter, waz~iynapN. (Sgh, TA.) See kurokY~.

waz~iynN *
waz~iynN and waz~iynapN: see waz~N.

A^aroDN mawaz~apN *
A^aroDN mawaz~apN A land abounding with the birds called waz~; (K;) like maA^owazapN from A_iwaz~N. (TA.)

1 wazaA^a *
1. wazaA^a, (S, K,) aor. yazaA^u, (K,) inf. n. wazo'N, (S,) He dried flesh-meat: (S, K:) or he roasted and so dried it. (TA.) ― -b2- wazaA^a Alqawoma He repelled one part of the people from another. (K.) ― -b3- wazaA^a Alqawomu One part of the people repelled another part. (TA.)

2 wz~A^ AlwiEaA='a *
2. wz~A^ AlwiEaA='a, inf. n. tawoziy^apN and tawoziYo'N, He made tight the contents of the bag; or other repository: syn. $ad~a kanozahu. (AZ, S, K.) ― -b2- wz~A^, (S, K,) inf. n. tawoziYo'N, (S,) He filled a water-skin (S, K) or other vessel. (TA.) ＝ -A2- wz~A^t bihi, (S, K,) inf. n. tawoziy^apN, (S,) She (a mare, TA) or a camel, S, K,) threw him (i. e. her rider, TA,) down prostrate. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- wz~A^h He made him bind himself by every oath: (K:) or by a hard, or severe, oath. (L.)

5 twz~A^ *
5. twz~A^ It (a water-skin, K, or other vessel, TA) was filled, or became full. (K.) ― -b2- He was, or became, filled with drink to satiety. (As, S.)

wazaA^a *
wazaA^a Strong-made: (S, K:) or a short, fat, strong-made, man. (TA.)

1 wazaba *
1. wazaba, aor. yazibu, inf. n. wuzuwbN, It (water, K, or a thing, T,) flowed. (T, K.)

4 Awzb fiY AlA^aroDi *
4. Awzb fiY AlA^aroDi (tropical:) He went, or went away, or pursued his course, through the land, (K,) like as does water. (TA.)

waz~aAbN *
waz~aAbN (tropical:) A clever thief: (K:) so called because quick in his motions, like running water. (TA.)

miyzaAbN *
miyzaAbN A water-spout; a pipe or other channel that spouts forth water; (TA, art. A^zb;) that by which water pours down from a high place; (Towsheeh;) a water-spout of wood, or the like, to convey away the water from the roof of a house: (MF, art. zwb:) from wazaba AlmaA='u “ the water flowed: ” (K:) or a Persian term, arabicized; (S, K;) i. e., composed of the Persian words, (TA,) signifying “ make water: ” (K:) also written miy^ozaAbN; and in this case its pl. is maA=ziybu: (S, K:) but if without ', its pl. is mayaAziybu, (S,) or mawaAziybu; the latter agreeable with analogy, like mawaAEiydu and mawaAziynu. (TA.) [See also arts. A^zb and zwb. It has also two other forms, mizoraAbN and mirozaAbN.]

1 wazara *
1. wazara, (A, Mgh, K,) aor. yaziru, inf. n. wizorN, with kesr, (K,) He bore, or carried, a heavy load, or burden. (A, Mgh, K.) It is said in the Kur, [vi. 164, &c.,] walaA taziru waAzirapN wizora A^uxoraY Nor shall any [soul] bearing [a heavy burden] bear the [heavy] burden of another soul; (S;) i. e., its burden of sin: (Mgh, Msb:) meaning, that no one shall be punished for the sin of another; nor shall any sinning soul bear the heavy burden of another soul; every one shall be requited for his [own] deeds: (TA:) or nor shall any sinning [soul] sin by the sin of another. (Akh, S, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (Akh, S,) wazara, (Akh, S, A, Msb, K,) aor. yaziru; and wazira, aor. yawozaru; (Akh, S, A, Msb, K;) and wuzira (the same and A,) aor. yuwzaru; (Akh, S, K;) inf. n. wizorN and wazorN and zirapN, (K,) or wizorapN, accord. to Zj, as I have seen it [says IM] pointed and well written; (L;) (tropical:) He sinned: (Akh, S, A, K:) or he bore [a burden of] sin- (Msb.) See also 8. ― -b3- wuzira also signifies (tropical:) He was charged with, or accused of, a sin. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- wazara liloA^amiyri, (A,) and lilos~uloTaAni, (Msb, [this I believe to be the right reading; but in the only copy of the Msb, that I have, I find it written AlslTAn;]) aor. yaziru; (A, Msb;) inf. n. wazaArapN; (A;) and liloA^amiyri twz~r↓, (S.) or lalomaliki; (K;) and waAzrhu↓; (S, K;) (tropical:) He was, or became, waziyr [or vicegerent] (S, A, Msb, K) to the governor, (S, A,) or sultán, (Msb,) or king. (K.)

3 waAozara
3: [waAzrhu He bore a burden with him. ― -b2- [Hence,] wAzr Almalika A^aEobaA='a Almuloki (tropical:) He bore with the king (HaAmalahu) the burden of the regal office. (A.) See also 1, last signification. ― -b3- wAzrhu EalaY AlA^amori, (TA,) inf. n. muwaAzarapN, (A, TA,) He aided, assisted, or helped, him, and strengthened him, to do the thing: originally A=zarahu: (A, * TA:) the former of these, wAzrh, is the more chaste. (TA.)

4 Awzrhu *
4. Awzrhu He appointed him a wazar, (K, TA,) i. e., a place of refuge to which to betake himself. (TA.)

5 tawaz~ara
5: see 1, last signification.

8 A_it~azara *
8. A_it~azara, of the measure A_ifotaEala, (S, Msb,) [originally A_iwotazara,] (tropical:) He committed a wizor, (S, K,) i. e., a sin. (Msb, TA.)

10 A_istwzrhu *
10. A_istwzrhu (tropical:) He took him, or chose him, as a waziyr [or vicegerent]. (K.) You say, A^usotuwzira fulaAnN (tropical:) Such a one was taken, or chosen, as a wzyr. (S, A. *)

wizorN *
wizorN A heavy load or burden, (A, Mgh, K,) a bundle, (S,) or great bundle, (K,) that is carried on the back: (S, K:) a weight; syn. vql: (S, [in which the syn. is written viqol: so in two copies; and so app. accord. to A 'Obeyd, who makes its pl. A^avoqaAl:] and Msb [in which, in my copy, the syn. is written without syll. signs:] and K [in which it is written viqal:]) pl. A^awozaArN. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A weapon; an instrument of war: or weapons; arms: syn. silaAHN: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) because heavy upon the wearer: (Mgh, Msb:) or A^awozaArN signifies the burdens and instruments of war, &c.; and the sing. is wizorN; (A 'Obeyd, TA;) or it has no sing., accord. to some. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely El-Aashà, (Mgh, TA.)
waA^aEodadotu liloHarobi A^awozaArahaA
rimaAHFA TiwaAlFA waxayolFA *ukuwraA
[And I prepared for the war its weapons and other apparatus; long lances and male horses]. (S, Mgh, TA.) And it is said in the Kur, [xlvii. 5,] Hay~aY taDaEa A@loHarobu A^awozaArahaA, meaning, (tropical:) Until the war terminates: (Mgh, Msb:) because then the people thereof lay down their arms: (Mgh:) properly, until the people of the war lay down their burdens: (Msb:) their weapons and burdens: or, as some say, their sins. (Bd.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A sin: (S, Bd, ubi supra, and Msb, K:) and [especially] polytheism: (Fr, Bd, TA:) pl. as above. (Bd, Msb, &c.) This is the sense in which it is most frequently used in the traditions. (IAth.)

wazarN *
wazarN A mountain: this is the primary signification: (S:) or a mountain difficult of access, or strong: (K, TK:) or a mountain to which one betakes himself for refuge: this is the primary signification. (Aboo-Is-hák.) ― -b2- A place of refuge: (S, Msb, K:) any such place. (Aboo-Is-hák, K.) So in the Kur, lxxv. 11. (TA.) ― -b3- See also waziyrN.

waziyrN *
waziyrN i. q. muwaAzirN [One who bears a burden or burdens with another: or one who aids, assists or helps, and strengthens, another: see 3:] (S, A, K:) like as A^akiylN signifies i. q. muw^aAkilN, (S,) and jaliysN i. q. mujaAlisN. (A.) ― -b2- (tropical:) [A vicegerent of a king or the like: or a confidential minister of state: in English commonly written vizier, in imitation of the Turkish pronunciation; but properly, wezeer:] the familiar of the king, who bears his master's burden, and aids him by his counsel: (K:) or the wzyr of the king is the person who bears with him (yuwaAziruhu, i. e. yuHaAmiluhu,) the burdens of the regal office: not from muwaAzarapN, signifying the “ act of aiding or the like, ” because the w in this latter word is substituted for ', and the derivative from it of the measure faEiylN is A^aziyrN: (A:) ISd says, some hold that the w in wzyr is substituted for '; but Abu-l-'Abbás says, that this is not agreeable with analogy; for the substitution of ' for w in a word of this measure is rare, and that of w for ' is more strange: (TA:) the wzyr is so called because he bears for the king the burden of administration: (S, * Msb:) or it is from wazarN↓, signifying “ a mountain to which one has recourse to save himself from destruction: ” so the wzyr of the khaleefeh is one upon whose counsel the khaleefeh relies in his affairs, and to whom he betakes himself for refuge or safety: (Aboo-Is-hák, TA:) pl. wuzaraA='u (A, Msb, K) and A^awozaArN; (A, K;) the latter like A^a$oraAfN and A^ayotaAmN, (A, TA,) pls. of $ariyfN and yatiymN. (TA.)

wizaArapN *
wizaArapN and wazaArapN The condition, or office, of a waziyr: (S, Msb, K:) the former word is the more approved. (ISk, Msb.)

waAzirN *
waAzirN Bearing, or carrying, a heavy load, or burden. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] also, (A,) and mawozuwrN↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) (tropical:) Sinning: (S, A, K:) or bearing [a burden of] sin. (Msb.) maA^ozuwraAtK occurs in a trad., for mawozuwraAtK, the regular form, because it is there coupled with maA^ojuwraAtK, to which it is opposed. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.)

mawozuwrN *
mawozuwrN: see waAzirN.

R. Q. 1 wasowasa *
R. Q. 1. wasowasa, [inf. n. wasowasapN and wisowaAsN, and simple subst. wsowaAsN, but see ZA^oZaA^a,] He spoke, or talked, indistinctly: (TA:) [or in a low, faint, gentle, or soft manner, with confusedness: for] Aboo-Turáb is related to have said, that he heard Khaleefeh say, wasowasapN signifies the speaking in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, manner, with confusedness: or, accord. to one relation, it is [wa$owa$apN,] with $. (TA.) [It is generally intrans., agreeable with the above explanations: but sometimes trans.; for you say,] wasowasa Alr~ajula He spoke to the man with low, faint, gentle, or soft, speech. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] wasowasatN A_ilayohi nafosuhu, (S, M, * A, * Msb, K, *) and wasowasa A_ilayohi Al$~ayoTaAnu, (S, A, * Msb, K,) and lahu, (S, Msb, K,) and fiyhi, (TA,) or fiY Sadorihi, (M,) inf. n. wasowsapN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and wisowaAsN, with kesr, (S, A, Msb, K,) and wasowaAsN, with fet-h, is also allowable in the case of this and similar reduplicative verbs, (MF, voce ZaA^oZaA^a,) or this last is a simple subst., (S, Msb, K,) His mind, or soul, (S, M, A, &c.,) and the devil, (S, A, Msb, K,) prompted, or suggested to him [something], or talked to him, (S, M, Msb,) and [in him, or] in his bosom: (M:) or suggested to him, or talked to him of, (A, * K,) and suggested in him, or talked in him of, (TA,) what was vain, or unprofitable, and destitute of good: (A, K, TA:) and in like manner one says of the thoughts. (TA.) By the prep. l by which it is made trans. in the Kur, in vii. 19, is meant A_ilaY. (S, Msb.) You say also, wusowisa bihi [as though signifying properly He had vain things suggested in him by the devil, so that his mind was disturbed thereby, and] his speech became confused, and he became stupified, or deprived of his reason. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] wasowasa AlHaloYu, (M, A, Bd, in vii. 19,) inf. n. wasowasapN and wisowaAsN, (M,) (tropical:) The woman's ornament sounded, or made a sound or sounds: (M:) or made a low, or gentle, sound; or a chinking. (Bd, [who holds this to be a primary signification: but it is said in the A to be tropical.]) And wasowasa AlqaSabu (tropical:) [The reeds made a low sound; or rustling]. (A.) And samiEotu wisowaAsahu (tropical:) I heard its low sounding, or its chinking; or its rustling]. (A.) See also wasowaAsN.

wasowasapN *
wasowasapN: see 1; and wasowaAsN, in two places.

wasowaAsN *
wasowaAsN a subst. from wasowasa; (S, Msb, K;) signifying, [Speech, or talk, that is indistinct: or low, faint, gentle, or soft: or low, &c., and confused: see 1. ― -b2- And hence,] The soul's, or mind's, (S, M, Msb, K,) and the devil's, (K,) prompting, or suggestion, or talk, (S, M, Msb, K,) of what is vain, or unprofitable, and destitute of good; (K;) as also wasowasapN↓ [used as subst., in which case its pl. is wasaAwisu, occurring below]. (S, K.) ― -b3- [And hence,] (assumed tropical:) An evil, or unprofitable, idea, imagination, or thought, which bestirs itself in, or occurs to, the mind. (Msb.) ― -b4- And
[by a metonymy,] (assumed tropical:) A certain disease, [i. e. melancholia, in which is a doting in the imagination and judgment, a sort of delirium, vulgarly attributed to diabolical prompting or suggestion, but, it is said,] arising from a predominance of the black bile, attended with confusion of the intellect. (Msb.) ― -b5- [And from the primary signification seem to be derived those which here follow.] (assumed tropical:) The low, or faintly heard, sound of the hunter and the dogs. (S, K.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A low or faint sound [or rustling] of wind; as also wasowasapN↓. (M.) ― -b7- (tropical:) The sounds, (S,) or sound, (M, K,) of women's ornaments: (S, M, K:) [the chinking thereof: see 1.] ＝ -A2- Also, AlwasowaAsu The devil; (M, K;) a name of the devil: (S:) it occurs in verse 4 of the last chap. of the Kur; and is said to mean there *uw AlwasowaAsi [the prompter, or suggester, of what is vain, or unprofitable, and destitute of good. (M.)

maraDN wasowaAsiY~N *
maraDN wasowaAsiY~N [A disease of the nature of melancholia]. (K in art. E$q.)

muwasowasN *
muwasowasN: see muwasowisN.

muwasowisN *
muwasowisN, with kesr, A man subject to wasaAwis [or diabolical promptings, or suggestions, of vain, or unprofitable, things, and thereby confused in his intellect, or disordered in his mind]: (M:) an act. part. n., applied as an epithet to a man, because he to whom it is applied talks to himself: and one also says muwasowasN, [or muwasowasN A_ilayohi,] like AlmagoDuwbu Ealayohimo: (Msb.) or, accord. to IAar, one should not say muwasowasN. (TA.)

1 wasabati AlA^aroDu *
1. wasabati AlA^aroDu, aor. tasibu, (inf. n. wasobN, TA;) and Awsbt↓; The land became abundant in fresh herbage, such as is called Eu$ob, (S, K,) and in dry herbage. (TA.) ― -b2- wasiba, aor. yawosabu, inf. n. wasabN, He, or it, was dirty: (IAar, K:) syn. with wakiba and Ha$ina. (TA.)

4 A^awosaba
4: see 1.

wasubN *
wasubN Wood that is put in the lower part of a well, when its earth is such as would pour in, (K,) and that prevents the earth from doing so: called by the people of Egypt xinoziyrap, and only of the wood of the sycamore fig-tree: (TA:) [the xnzyrp is a lining of planks, resembling a barrel; and the wood above mentioned is used in its construction because water does not rot it so quickly as it rots other kinds of wood:] pl. wusuwbN. (K.) [Accord. to IDrd, of the dial. of El-Yemen. (Freytag.)]

wisobN *
wisobN Plants; herbs; herbage: (S, K:) or abundance of herbage. (M, in art. Asb.)

muwsibN *
muwsibN (tropical:) A ram abounding with wool: (K:) likened to a land abounding with herbage. (TA.)

miysaAbN *
miysaAbN Dates such as are termed mujaz~aEN, [i. e., half, or two-thirds, ripe]: (K:) i. e., as applied to ruTab, vile, or bad. (TA.)

1 wasaja *
1. wasaja, (aor. yasiju, K,) inf. n. wasiyjN (S, K) and wasojN and wasajaAnN; (L;) He (a camel) went a certain pace; (S, L, K;) [more quick than that called EasojN: the contr. is said in the TA, app. by a mistranscription: but see naSaba, and *amala:] the first pace, accord. to En-Nadr and As, is called Ald~abiybu; the next, AlEanaqu; the next, Alt~azay~udu; the next, Al*~amiylu; the next, AlEasoju; and the next, Alwasoju: or he went quickly, or swiftly. (TA, L.)

4 Awsj *
4. Awsj He incited, urged, or made, a camel, to go at the pace called Alwasiyj. (S, K.)

jamalN was~aAjN Eas~aAjN *
jamalN was~aAjN Eas~aAjN A quick, or swift, camels. (K.) A_iblN wasuwjN EasuwjN Quick, or swift, camels. (K.)

1 wasixa *
1. wasixa, aor. yawosaxu (S, K) and yaAsaxu and yayosaxu, (K,) [the last two of which are irregular forms,] inf. n. wasaxN; (L;) and A_it~asaxa↓ and tws~x↓ (S, K) and Astwsx↓; (K;) It (a garment, S, L, K, and the skin, L, or some other thing, Msb) was, or became, dirty, filthy, (S, L, K,) in consequence of its being seldom washed, (L,) or from want of care. (Msb.)

2 was~axa
2: see 4.

4 Awsx *
4. Awsx (S, L, K) and ws~x↓ (L, K) He, or it, made a garment, (S, L, K,) and the skin, (L,) or some other thing, (Msb,) dirty, or filthy. (S, L, K.)

5 tawas~axa
5: see 1.

8 A_iwotasaxa
8: see 1.

10 A_isotawosaxa
10: see 1.

wasoxN *
wasoxN Dirt, filth, or soil; (S, L;) what collects upon a garment, or the skin, (L,) or some other thing, (Msb,) in consequence of its being seldom washed, (L,) or from want of care: (Msb:) pl. A^awosaAxN. (Msb.) ― -b2- laA taA^okulo A^wosaAxa Aln~aAsi (tropical:) [Live not thou upon the alms of men]. (A.)

wasixN *
wasixN Dirty, or filthy, [in consequence of being seldom washed, or] from want of care: an epithet applied to a garment &c. (Msb.)

2 ws~dhu wisaAdFA *
2. ws~dhu wisaAdFA, or wisaAdapF, (L, K,) and $ayoy^FA, (S,) He put a pillow, (L, K,) and a thing, (S,) beneath his (another's) head. (S, L, K *.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce *anuwbN: and another voce sawaAdN.]

4 Awsd fiY Als~ayori *
4. Awsd fiY Als~ayori He hastened, or was quick, in his pace. (L, K.) ― -b2- Awsdhu, (S, L, K,) or Awsdhu biAlS~ayodi, (Msb,) He incited him (a dog) to the chase: as also A=sadahu. (S, L, Msb, K.)

5 tws~d *
5. tws~d, (L, K,) and tws~d wisaAdFA, or wisaAdapF (L,) and $ayoy^FA, (S,) He put for himself a pillow, (L, K,) and a thing, (S,) beneath his head; (S, L,) he rested his head upon a pillow. (L.) ― -b2- tws~d *iraAEahu He made his fore arm his pillow; i. e., lay upon his fore arm, putting it as a pillow. (L.)

wisaAdN *
wisaAdN (S, L, Msb, K) and wisaAdapN↓ (S, A, L, Msb, K) and wasaAdapN and wusaAdapN, (K,) but some disallow the last two forms, (TA,) and A_isaAdapN, (L,) and A^usaAdapN, (K, art. A^sd,) A pillow, or cushion, upon which one rests his cheek (S, A, L, Msb, K) or head: (L:) and the first, a thing upon which one reclines, or rests: (M, L, K:) or the first, only, signifies, anything that is used as a pillow, (A, Msb,) or put beneath the head, (L,) whether of household-furniture, (Msb,) or stones, (L,) or earth (A, L, Msb) &c.: (Msb:) pl. of the first, wusudN (S, Msb, K) and wusodN; (L, TA;) and of the second, wasaAy^idu (S, L, Msb, K) and wasaAdaAtN. (Msb.) ― -b2- A_in~a wisaAdaka laEariyDN (tropical:) [lit., Verily thy pillow is wide:] said by Mohammad (L, K) to 'Adee Ibn-Hátim: (L:) alluding to his sleeping much; (L, K;) because he whose pillow is wide sleeps pleasantly: (K:) or to his sleeping night and day: (L:) or to his having a wide back to his neck, and a great head, indicating want of understanding. (L, K.) You say, huwa EariyDu AlwisaAdi, meaning, He is stupid, dull, or wanting in intelligence: (Msb:) or sleepy. (TA, art. ErD.)

waiusaAdapN *
waiusaAdapN: see wisaAdN.

1 wasaTa Alqawoma *
1. wasaTa Alqawoma, aor. yasiTu, inf. n. wasoTN (S, Msb, K) [and wusuwTN (as shown below)] and siTapN, (S, K,) He sat, [or was, or became,] in the middle, or midst, of the people, or company of men; (K;) or among them: (TA;) i. q. tws~Thumo↓; (S, K;) or bayonahumo tws~T↓: (Msb:) and in like manner, wasaTa AlmakaAna [he was, or became, or sat, in the middle, or midst, of the place]: (Msb:) and wasaTa Al$~aYo'a, and ws~Thu↓, and tws~Thu↓, he was, or became, in the middle, or midst, of the thing: and [in like manner] wusuwTu Al$~amosi signifies Als~amaA='a tawas~uTuhaA↓ [The sun's being, or becoming, in the middle, or midst, of the sky]. (M.) ― -b2- wasaTa Al$~aYo'a also signifies He, or it, was, or
became, in the best part of the thing, most remote from the two extremes. (TA.) And wasaTahu He alighted, or took up his abode, in, or among, the best, or most generous, thereof. (M.) And wasaTa Alr~ajulu qawomahu, and fiY qawomihi, inf. n. wasaATapN, The man occupied, or held, a middle place, [meaning the best place, or one of the best places,] among his people, in respect of truth and equity. (Msb.) And wasaTa qawomahu fiY AlHasabi, aor. yasiTu, inf. n. siTapN, [He held a middle, or good, or the best, rank among his people in regard of grounds of pretension to respect.] (M.) And wasuTa fiY Hasabihi, [aor. yawosuTu,] inf. n. wasaATapN and siTapN, [He held a middle, or good, or the best, rank in regard of his grounds of pretension to respect;] (M, TA;) and wasaTa signifies the same; (M;) and so does ws~T↓, (M, TA,) inf. n. tawosiyTN. (TA.) [See wasaTN, below.]

2 ws~Thu *
2. ws~Thu, (K,) inf. n. tawosiyTN, (S, K,) He put it in the middle, or midst. (S, K.) ― -b2- And [so in the S, but in the K “ or, ”] He cut it [in the middle, or midst, i. e.] in two halves. (S, K.) [See the pass. part. n., below.] ― -b3- [In the Kur, c. 5,] some read, fawas~aTona bihi jamoEFA [which may mean And have put in the midst, thereby, a company of the enemy: or have divided in two halves, thereby, &c.: or have thereby become in the midst of a company of the enemy]: (S, TA:) others read fawasaTona. (TA.) See 1, first sentence. ― -b4- ws~T fY Hasabihi: see 1, last sentence.

5 tawas~aTa
5: see 1, first sentence, in four places. ― -b2- tws~T bayona Aln~aAsi He mediated, or interceded, between the men, or people, for the purpose of accommodation; from wasaTa Alr~ajulu qawomahu and fiY qawomihi, explained above; (Msb;) or from wasaATapN; (S;) he made mediation, or intercession, (Eamila AlwasaATapa,) between them. (K.) ― -b3- tws~T also signifies He took what was of a middle sort, between the good and the bad. (K.)

wasoT *
wasoT, with the s quiescent, is an adv. n.; [as such written wasoTa, meaning In the middle of: in the midst of; or among;] (S, M, IB, Mgh, K;) and it is for this reason that it has its middle letter quiescent, (S, IB,) like bayona (IB) with which it is syn.; (IB, Msb;) [for] it may be used in any case in which bayona may be substituted for it; (S, IAth, K;) and, like bayona, it does not denote a part of the thing denoted by the noun to which it is prefixed, wherein differing from wasaT↓. (S, IB, K.) You say, jalasotu wasoTa Alqawomi (S, IB, Msb) I sat [in the middle of, or in the midst of,] or among, the people, or company of men, (IB, Msb;) not being one of them. (IB.) And wasoTa raA^osihi duhonN [In the middle of his head is oil]; not meaning a component part of the head. (IB.) And it is said in a trad. AljaAlisu wasoTa AlHaloqapi maloEuwnN [The sitter in the midst of the ring is cursed]: for he must of necessity turn his back towards some of those who surround him, and so displease them; wherefore they curse him and revile him. (IAth.) ― -b2- It may not [properly] be used as a decl. n., (IB,) i. e. as an inchoative, (Mgh,) nor as an agent, nor as an objective complement; (IB, Mgh) &c.; thus, also, differing from wasaT↓; unless it have the adverbial particle [fiY] prefixed to it; in which case it has the sense of wasaT, and you say, jalasotu fiY wasoTi Alqawomi and fY wasoTi raA^osihi duhonN [like as you say jalasotu wasoTa Alqawomi and wasoTa raA^osihi duhnN, explained above]: and sometimes it is used as a subst., preserving the quiescence [and the adverbial form], like as bayona is used as a subst. though virtually an adv. n., in cases like that where it is said in the Kur, [vi. 94,] laqado taqaT~aEa bayonakumo [meaning maA bayonakumo, or, as explained in the Expos. of the Jel., waSolukumo bayonakumo]: (IB:) or wasoT is sometimes used for wasaT↓, improperly; (S;) or it may be so used; (Msb;) or it is so used by poetic license; (M;) or, as some say, each of them may take the place of the other; and this seems the most likely: (IAth:) or one says wasoT, with sukoon, only, of that whereof the component parts are separate, or distinct, (IAth, K *,) such as a number of men, and beasts of carriage, &c.; (IAth;) and wasaT↓, (IAth,) or both, (K,) of that whereof the component parts are united, (IAth, K *,) such as a house, and the head, (IAth,) or such as a ring: (K:) it is related, as on the authority of Th, that Al$~aYo'i wasaTu↓ and wsoTuhu [both meaning The middle, or midst, of the thing] are said when the thing is solid; but when its component parts are separate, or distinct, the word is wasoTN, with sukoon, exclusively. (M.)

wasaTN *
wasaTN [The middle, midst, or middle part, of a thing; i. e.,] properly, the part of which several lateral, or outer, portions are equal; as, for instance, the middle finger: but also meaning the part which is surrounded, or enclosed, on its several sides, although unequally: (Msb:) or the part that is between the two sides or extremities of a thing; (M, IB, Mgh, K;) [or the part, or point, that is between every two opposite extremities of a thing; and properly when equidistant;] as, for instance, the centre of a circle: (Mgh:) as also A^awosaTu↓, (M, K,) which is [likewise] a subst., like A^afokalN and A^azomalN [but imperfectly decl. because originally an epithet]: (M:) wasaTN has its middle letter with fet-h in order that it may agree in measure with its contr., which is TarafN; the like agreement being frequent: (IB:) and it is only used in cases in which bayona may not be substituted for it, herein [and in other respects, mentioned in the next preceding paragraph,] differing from wasoT: (S, IB, K:) [respecting the similar and dissimilar usages of wasaT and was~T, sufficient observations have been made in the next preceding paragraph, which see throughout, and more especially in its latter part:] the pl. of wasaTN is A^awosaATN; and that of its syn. A^awosaTu↓ is A^awaAsiTu; or this may be a pl. of waAsiTN↓, and originally wawaAsiTu. (M.) You say, jalasotu fiY wasaTi Ald~aAri [I sat in the middle, or middle part, of the house]; (S, Mgh, Msb;) because wasaT is a subst. (S.) And A_it~asaEa wasaTuhu [The middle, or middle part, thereof, became wide]. (Mgh, Msb.) And Darabotu wasaTa raA^osihi [I smote the middle, or middle part, of his head]. (Mgh, * Msb.) And kasarotu wasaTa Alr~umoHi [I broke the middle, or middle part, of the spear]. (IB.) And wasaTuhu xayorN mino Tarafihi [The middle, or middle part, thereof is better than the extremity]. (Mgh, Msb.) And xayaru AlA^umuwri A^awosaATuhaA The best of affairs, or actions, or cases, are such of them as are between two extremes. (M. [See R. Q. 1, in art. Hq.]) It is sometimes put in the accus. case as an adv. n.; as in the saying, jalasotu wasaTa Ald~aAri; but this is an instance of departure from the original usage; and [the meaning is jalasotu fiY wasaTi Ald~aAri signifying as explained above; so that] it is not here syn. with bayona, like as wasoTa is. (IB.) ― -b2- It is also used as an epithet: (IB, Mgh:) [as such signifying Middle; intermediate; midway, or equidistant, between the two extremities or extremes; in place, or position: but in this sense superseded in usage by A^awosaTu↓ and waAsiTN↓ and mutawas~iTN↓: and in time; but in this sense also superseded in usage by A^awosaTu↓:] middling; of middle sort, kind, or rate; (Msb;) as also A^awosaTu↓ (S, * M, Mgh, Msb, K) and mutawas~iTN↓ (M, Mgh, Msb) and wasuwTN↓ (M, TA) [and wasiyTN↓]; between good and bad; (Msb, TA;) as also A^awosaTu↓: (Msb:) conforming, or conformable, to the just mean; just; equitable: (Zj, S, K:) good; (Zj, M, Msb, K;) as also wasiyTN↓: (M:) most conforming, or conformable, to the just mean; most just; most equitable; applied to what is so of a thing; (S, M, K;) whatever it be; (S, K;) as also A^awosaTa↓: (M:) best; (Msb;) as also A^awosaTu↓: (S, * Msb, K *:) most generous: (M:) and when used as an epithet, it is applied alike to a masc., fem., sing., dual, and pl., subst.: (Mgh:) the fem. of A^awosaTu↓ is wusoTaY; (Mgh, Msb;) and the pl. masc. A^awaAsiTu; and pl. fem. wusaTN. (Msb.) Hence, (Msb,) AlA_iSobaEu AlwusoTaY↓ (S, Msb, K) The middle finger. (Msb.) And Alyawomu AlA^awosaTu↓ [The middle day]. (Msb.) And All~ayolapu AlwusoTaY↓ [The middle night. (Msb.) And AlEa$arapu AlA^awaAsiTu↓, meaning The [ten middle] days. (Msb.) And AlEa$oru AlwusaTu↓, meaning The [ten middle nights: not
AlEa$oru AlA^awosaTu↓; for this is a vulgar mistake, into which relaters of traditions have fallen; or it may be a mistake of transcription. (Msb.) And AlS~al`wpu AlwusoTaY↓, (M, Mgh, &c.,) mentioned in the Kur, [ii. 239,] (M, K,) meaning The middle prayer (Bd, TA) between the other prayers, (Bd,) or between the prayers of the night and the day; (TA;) or the most excellent of them in particular: (Bd:) i. e. the prayer of the afternoon; ('Alee Ibn-Abee-Tálib, I'Ab, and others, Mgh, Bd, K;) because the prophet said, on the day of the Ahzáb, “ they have diverted us from AlSlwp AlwsTY, the prayer of the afternoon: ” (Bd:) or the prayer of daybreak; (also said to be on the authority of 'Alee, Mgh, Bd, K;) because it is between the prayers of the night and the day; (Bd;) for the saying of the prophet mentioned above does not contravene this and other assertions, since what is meant in the trad. is not what is meant in the Kur: (K:) or, (M, K,) accord. to Abu-l-Hasan, (M,) the prayer of Friday; (M, K;) because it is the most excellent of the prayers; (M;) and he who says otherwise errs, unless he trace up the assertion to the prophet: (M, K:) these three opinions are of the strongest authority; (B;) and the first is that which commonly obtains: (Mgh:) or the prayer of noon; (Mgh, Bd, Msb, K;) because it is in the middle of the day: (Bd:) or the prayer of Friday on the day thereof; but on other days the prayer of noon: (K, and also said to be on the authority of 'Alec:) or the prayer of sunset: (Mgh, Bd, K:) or the prayer of nightfall: (Bd, K:) or [the night-prayer called] Alwitor: (K:) or the prayer of the breaking of the fast: (K:) or the prayer of sacrifices: (K:) or the prayer of the period called the DuHaY: (K:) or the prayer of the congregation: (K:) or the prayer of fear: (K:) or the prayers of nightfall and daybreak together: (K, and said to be on the authorities of 'Omar and 'Othmán:) or the prayers of daybreak and the afternoon together: (K:) or any of the five prayers; because before it are two prayers and after it are two prayers: (K:) or all the divinely-appointed prayers: (K:) or certain prayers not particularized: (K:) or prayer of middling length, between long and short. (K.) Hence also, $aYo'N wasaTN A middling thing; a thing of middle sort or kind; (Msb;) between good and bad; (S, Msb;) as also A^awosaTu↓: (Msb:) and in like manner it is applied to a male slave, and a female slave, (Msb,) and two male slaves, and two sheep or goats. (Mgh.) And maA tuToEimuwna mino A^awosaTi↓ A^aholiykumo, in the Kur, [v. 91,] Of the middle sort of that which ye give for food to your families, (Mgh, Msb,) between what is prodigal and what is niggardly. (Mgh.) And Aln~amaTu AlA^awosaTu↓ The middle class of men: occurring in a saying of 'Alee, cited in full in art. gT. (M.) And Eal~imoniY diynFA wasuwTA↓ Teach thou to me a religion of the middle sort: occurring in a saying of an Arab of the desert to El-Hasan, cited in full voce faraTa. (M, TA.) And jaEalonaAkumo A^am~apF wasaTFA, in the Kur, [ii. 137,] (S, Mgh, Msb,) [We have made you to be a nation] conforming, or conformable, to the just mean; just; equitable: (Zj, S, IB, Bd, K:) or good. (Zj, Bd, Msb, K.) And maroEFY wasaTN Choice pasturage. (M.) And rajulN wasaTN A good man; as also wasiyTN↓: (M:) or a man having good grounds of pretension to respect. (TA.) And fiY qawomihi fulaAnN wasiyTN↓, (S, K *,) or bayonahumo, (as in some copies of the K,) Such a one is the best of his people (A^awosaTuhumo↓) in race, and the highest of them in station. (S, K.) And Ald~aAri waAlHasabi fulaAnN wasiyTu↓ [Such a one is of good quality, or of the best quality, in respect of tribe, and of grounds of pretension to honour]. (Lth.) And huwa mino wasaTi qawomihi, and mn A^awosaTihimo↓, He is of the best of his people. (Msb.) And in like manner, huwa mino wasaTi Al$~aYo'i, and mn A^awosaTihi↓, It is of the best of the thing. (Msb.) And qaAla A^awosaTuhumo↓ in the Kur, lxviii. 28, The best of them said: (Jel:) or the most rightly directed, of them, to the truth: (Msb:) or it means A^awosaTuhumo↓ raA^oyFA [the most remote, of them, from either extreme, in judgment]; or sin~FA [in age]. (Bd.)

wasuwTN *
wasuwTN: see wasaTN, as an epithet, in two places.

wasiyTN *
wasiyTN: see wasaTN, as an epithet, in five places. ― -b2- A mediator, or an intercessor, for the purpose of accommodation, (O, K,) between people, (O,) or between two persons engaged in mutual altercation or litigation. (K.)

wasaATapN *
wasaATapN [originally an inf. n.: (see 1:) ― -b2- and hence, as a subst., Mediation, or intercession]. (S, K: see 5.) ― -b3- wasaATapu Ald~anaAniyri The best of deenárs. (TA.)

wasiyTapN *
[wasiyTapN A mean, or means: pl. wasaAy^iTu.]

waAsiTN *
waAsiTN: see wasaTN, as a subst., and also as an epithet. ― -b2- waAsiTu Alkuwri, (Lth, S, K,) or Alr~aHoli, (ISh, Az, M,) and waAsiTatuhu↓, (Lth, M, K,) and mawosiTatuhu↓, (Lh, M, [or perhaps muwsiTatuhu↓, corresponding to muw^oxiratuhu↓,]) The fore-part of the camel's saddle: (S, K:) accord. to Lth, (Az, TA,) the part, of the camel's saddle, which is between the taAdimap and the A=xirap; (Az, M, L;) but this is a mistake; (Az, L;) for the wAsT of the camel's saddle is one of the $aroxaAni, (ISh, Az, L,) which are its two extremities, [or upright pieces of wood,] like the qarabuwsuAni of the horse's saddle, (Az, L,) between which the rider sits; (ISh, Az, L;) it is the extremity which is next to the head of the camel; (Az, L;) the tall forepart next to the breast of the rider, (ISh, Az, L,) against which the breast of the rider sometimes strikes; (TA, in art. nHz;) the A=xirpa being the extremity which is next to the tail of the camel; (Az, L;) the hinder part of the saddle, which is its tall and broad piece of wood that is against (tuHaA*iY) the head of the rider: (ISh, Az, L:) the former of these is not called wAsT as being a middle part between the A=xrp and the qAdmp, as Lth says; nor has the camel's saddle any [part called] qAdmp. (Az, L.) ― -b3- AlwaAsiTu also signifies The piece of wood that is in the middle, between the two pieces called the EiDaAdataAni, in the yoke that is upon the neck of a bull which draws a cart or the like. (L in art. ED*.)

waAsiTapN *
waAsiTapN The jewel that is in the middle of a qilaAdap [or necklace], which is the best thereof; (S;) the large pearl (dur~ap) that is in the middle thereof, which is the most precious of the beads thereof. (L.) ― -b2- [In modern Arabic, A means of doing a thing. You say, biwaAsiTapi ka*aA By means of such a thing. ― -b3- Also, An intermediary, interposer, or agent between parties; a go-between.] ― -b4- See also waAsiTN. ― -b5- huwa fiY waAsiTapK mina AlEayo$i (assumed tropical:) He is in a good condition of life. (Er-Rághib, TA, in art. Hf.)

A^awosaTu *
A^awosaTu; fem. wusoTaY; pl. masc. A^awaAsiTu; pl. fem. wusaTN: see wasaTN, as a subst., in two places; and as an epithet, throughout.

muwsaTN *
muwsaTN What is in the middle of a bayot [i. e. house, or tent, &c.], particularly. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

mawosiTapN *
mawosiTapN, or muwsiTapN: see waAsiTN.

qatala fulaAnFA muwas~aTFA *
qatala fulaAnFA muwas~aTFA He slew such a one cut [in the middle, or midst,] in two halves. (TA.) [This mode of slaughter, termed tawosiyTN, was often practised under the rule of the Egyptian Sultáns; many instances thereof being mentioned by ElMakreezee and other historians. See De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., 2nd ed., vol. i. p. 468.]

mutawas~iTN *
mutawas~iTN: see wasaTN, as an epithet, in two places.

R. Q. 1
R. Q. 1: [wa$owa$a, inf. n. wa$owa$apN, He spoke in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, manner, with confusedness; accord. to an explanation, given by Khaleefeh, of the inf. n.; or the word of which he gave that explanation was wasowasapN, with s: (see wasowasa:) or he spoke confusedly, so as to be hardly intelligible: or he spoke in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, manner: (see wa$owa$apN below: and see R. Q. 2:) in the present day it signifies he whispered: and wa$owa$ahu, he whispered to him.] ＝ -A2- wa$owa$otuhu, [or rather, app., wa$owa$otuhu A_iy~aAhu,] I gave or handed, it to him in a small quantity. (K.)

R. Q. 2 tawa$owa$uwA *
R. Q. 2. tawa$owa$uwA They were in a state of commotion, and spoke together one to another, or some of them to others, in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, manner. (IDrd, K.)

wa$owa$N *
wa$owa$N: see wa$owaA$N.

wa$owa$apN *
wa$owa$apN Speech with confusedness, (S, K,) so as to be hardly intelligible: (TA:) or confused speech: or low, faint, gentle, or soft, speech: or such a word or saying. (TA.) See R. Q. 1. ＝ -A2- Lightness, activity, or agility. (K.)

wa$owa$iY~N *
wa$owa$iY~N: see wa$owaA$N.

wa$owaA$N *
wa$owaA$N Light, active, or agile; (Lth, S, K;) applied to a man; (S;) and to an ostrich; (AA, K;) and so wa$owaA$apN↓ applied to a she-camel; (K;) or this last, so applied, signifies quick, and light or active or agile; and so wa$owaA$N applied to a he-camel; and wa$owa$N↓ applied to a he-camel and to a man. (TA.) You say also, Al*~iraAEi rajulN wa$owa$iY~u↓, meaning, n$ana$iyy~uhu, (K,) i. e., A man slender in the [fore] arm, and light, or active, in work. (AO, TA.)

wa$obN *
wa$obN [app. meaning Fleshy] is from the expression tamorapN wa$obapN, (in one copy of the K, wa$obaA'u, TA,) A date having a thick liHaA=' [i. e. pulp, or flesh]. (K.) Of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

wi$obN *
wi$obN sing. of A^awo$aAbN, (K,) which is the same as A^awobaA$N (S, K) and A^a$owaAbN, (TA,) [but see this last word, in art. $wb,] and signifies, A medley, or mixed multitude; (K;) or sundry, or separate sorts of people; (S;) and young men of the baser sort. (TA.) A term of dispraise only. (Marg. note in a copy of the S.)

1 wa$ajati AlEuruwqu wAlA^agoSaAnu *
1. wa$ajati AlEuruwqu wAlA^agoSaAnu The roots and branches became entangled together. (S.) ― -b2- wa$aja, aor. ya$iju, inf. n. wa$ojN and wa$iyjN, It (anything) became entangled, intermixed, confused, or intricate. (TA.) ― -b3- wa$ajato fiY qalobihi A^umuwrN wahumuwmN (tropical:) Affairs, and griefs, or solicitudes, became perplexing in his heart. (TA.) ― -b4- qado wa$ajato bika qaraAbapu fulaAnK, aor. ta$iju, K,) (tropical:) The relationship of such a one to thee has become intricate; (S, K, TA;) like as the roots and branches of trees become intricate. (TA.)

2 wa$~j AlqaraAbapa *
2. wa$~j AlqaraAbapa, inf. n. tawo$iyjN, (tropical:) He (God) made the relationship intricate. (S, K.) ― -b2- w$~j All~`hu bayonahumo (tropical:) God joined and mixed them together. (TA.) ― -b3- w$~j He laced together a maHomil [or basket in which grapes are carried to the dryingplace] with a leather thong, or the like, (such as a $ariyT, TA,) lest anything should fall from it. (K.)

wa$iyjN *
wa$iyjN Trees of which spears are made: (S, K:) or canes growing obliquely, or, as in the M, in an intricate manner: or the hardest of canes: or, as a coll. gen. n., (tropical:) spears; n. un. with p: (TA:) [See also EijolapN:] or, originally, the roots of canes: and afterwards applied to signify spears, themselves; so called because of their intermingling when meeting together. (Ham, p. 165.) ― -b2- taTaAEanuwA biAlwa$iyji (tropical:) They thrust one another with the spears. (A.) ― -b3- A^afonati Als~anapu Alwa$iyja Drought destroyed the tangled trees, or their roots; no moisture remaining in the earth. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- wa$iyjN The roots of the sinews. (TA.) ― -b5- wa$iyjN (tropical:) Intricacy of relationship: (S, K:) pl. wa$aAy^iju. (TA.) Ex. bayonahumo wa$aAy^iju Aln~asabi There is an intricacy of relationship between them. (TA.)

wa$iyjapN *
wa$iyjapN The root (Eiroq) of a tree. (S, K.) ― -b2- See waA$ijapN. ― -b3- wa$iyjapN [An implement made of] fibres of the palm tree (lyf) twisted, and then tied (or, as in some lexicons, attached in the manner of a net, TA,) between two pieces of wood, (or a net between two pieces of wood, TA,) upon which reaped wheat &c. are carried. (S, K.)

waA$ijN *
waA$ijN Anything entangled, intermixed, confused, or intricate. (TA.)

waA$ijapN *
waA$ijapN (S, K) and wa$iyjapN↓ (TA) (tropical:) Intricate relationship; or intricate uterine relationship; (S, K;) and close. (TA.) Ex. bayonahumo waA$ijapu raHimK Between them is an intricate and close relationship. (TA.)

A^amorN muwa$~ajN *
A^amorN muwa$~ajN An intricate, or a confused, affair. (TA.)

2 w$~H AlmaroA^apa *
2. w$~H AlmaroA^apa, inf. n. tawo$iyjN, He put on the woman a wi$aAH, q. v. (S, K.) ― -b2- See 5. ― -b3- w$~Hhu wi$aAHFA (tropical:) He struck him a blow upon the place of the wi$aAH. (TA.)

5 tw$~Ht *
5. tw$~Ht, (S, K,) and At~$Ht↓, (K,) She (a woman) put on, or decked herself with, a wi$aAH q. v. (S, K.) ― -b2- t~w$H bivawobihi, (S, K, &c.,) and bihi At~$H↓, (Msb,) (tropical:) i. q. taqal~ada: (K:) but MF disapproves of this explanation: (TA:) or He put his garment under his right arm-pit, and threw it [meaning a portion of it] over his left shoulder, like as the muHorim does; (T, Msb;) like taA^ab~aTa and AiDoTabaEa: (T:) or he threw a portion of his garment over his left shoulder, and drew its extremity under his right arm, and tied the two extremities together in a knot upon his bosom. (M.) Also, He wrapped himself up in his garment. (L.) ― -b3- Alv~awoba w$~Hhu↓, as also A^a$~aHahu (tropical:) He put on him the garment in the manner described in the explanation of the phrase tw$~H bivawobihi. (M, L.) ― -b4- tw$~H bisayofihi (S, K, &c.) (tropical:) i. q. taqal~adahu: (K:) [or i. q.] tw$~H biHamaAy^ili sayofihi He put the suspensories of his sword over his left shoulder, leaving the right bare: (T:) and tw$~H binijaAdihi [signifies the same]. (A.) ― -b5- tw$H bilijaAmihi (L) (tropical:) He threw the bit and bridle of his horse upon his shoulder, and put his arm through it, so that it became like a wi$aAH. (Expos. of the Mo'allakát printed at Calcutta, p. 171.) [See the verse of Lebeed quoted below.] ― -b6- tw$~H A@moraA^apF (tropical:) Inivit feminam: (A, TA:) or he embraced a woman round the neck, and turned her over. (TA.)

8 A_iwota$aHa
8: see 5, in two places.

A_iA^u$aAHN *
A_iA^u$aAHN: see wi$aAHN.

wi$aAHN *
wi$aAHN and wu$aAHN, (S, K,) also written A_i$aAHN↓ and A^u$aAHN, and by poetic licence wi$oHan~N↓, (S.)
