An ornament worn by women, (L,) [consisting of] two series (kirosaAni) of pearls and jewels strung or put together in regular order, which two series are disposed, or placed, contrariwise, (yuxaAlafu bayonahumaA,) one of them being turned (maEoTuwf) over the other [so that they cross each other]: (L, K:) or a thing woven of leather, and adorned with jewels, like a qilaAdap, worn by a woman: (Msb:) or a wide [piece, or thing, of] leather, (K,) or a thing woven of leather, in a wide, or broad, form, (S,) and adorned with jewels, which a woman binds (ta$ud~uhu) between her shoulders and her flanks: (Lth, S, Mgh, K:) or a qilaAdap of the belly, which is sometimes long, so that the redundant portions of its two extremities are thrown over the shoulders: (Mgh:) or one of a pair of necklaces which a woman makes to hang down upon her sides; one upon her right side, and the other upon her left: (W. 144:) [hence it seems to be of different kinds; one kind consisting of two ornaments resembling necklaces, one of which rests upon the right shoulder and against the left flank, the other resting upon the left shoulder and against the right flank; another kind seems, from an expression in the A, “ a woman bearing a wi$aAH, and wi$aAHayoni, ” to be one such ornament; another, an ornament resembling a necklace, thrown over the head, so as to rest upon the shoulders, crossing in front, and passing round the loins, and is tied or crossed in front, and of which the redundant portions are thrown over the shoulders: see also ka$oHN:] pl. wu$uHN and A^awo$iHapN (S, K) and wa$aAy^iHu: (M, K:) the last thought by ISd to be formed as though from w$AHp. (L.) ― -b2- Lebeed says:
walaqado Hamayotu AlHaY~a taHomilu $ik~itiY
furuTN wi$aAHiY A_i*o gadawotu lijaAmuhaA
[And I have protected the tribe; a swift, outstripping, horse, whose bit and bridle were my wi$aAH when I went away, bearing my arms: see tw$~H bljAmh]: he relates his having gone forth as a scout for his people, mounted on his camel, with his horse by his side, and bearing its bit and bridle like a w$AH, so that he might bit the horse if he perceived the enemy. (L.) ― -b3- wi$aAHN (assumed tropical:) A bow: (L:) [so called because of the manner in which it is worn]. ― -b4- wi$aAHN (M) and wi$aAHapN↓ (M, K) (assumed tropical:) A sword: (M, K:) so called because of the manner in which it is worn: see 5. (M.) ― -b5- hiYa garovaY Alwi$aAHi, [and EaTo$aY Alwi$aAHi, or EaTi$apu Alwi$aAHi, and jaAy^iEapu Alw$AH,] (tropical:) She is slender in the belly and flanks. (K.) [See also art. grv.]

wi$aAHapN *
wi$aAHapN: see wi$aAHN.

wa$oH~A='u *
wa$oH~A='u A she-goat (S, K) that is black, (L,) with a white mark, or with two white marks, like a wi$aAH; expl. by muwa$~aHapN bibayaADK. (S, L, K.)

muwa$~aHN *
muwa$~aHN (tropical:) A garment, and a cock, having two marks like a wi$aAH. (L.) ― -b2- muwa$~aHapN (tropical:) A gazelle, and a sheep, and a bird, having two streaks, or strips, one on each side. (L.) [See SuloSulN.]

1 wa$ara *
1. wa$ara, (S, K,) inf. n. wa$orN, (TA,) He sawed a piece of wood with a miy$aAr; a dial. form of A^a$ar; (S, K;) i. q. na$ara. (K.) ― -b2- w$arato, aor. ta$iru, (Msb,) inf. n. wa$orN, (S, K,) She (a woman) sharpened (S, Msb, K) her teeth, (S, K,) or her canine teeth, (Msb.) and made them thin [and serrated], (S, Msb, K,) meaning their edges: (TA:) [as also A^a$arato.] See waA$irapN.

10 Astw$rt *
10. Astw$rt She (a woman) asked for her [teeth or] canine teeth to be sharpened and made thin [and serrated]. (Msb.)

wu$urN *
wu$urN a dial. form of A^u$urN [A serration and a sharpness of the extremities of the teeth]. (Sgh, K.)

waA$irapN *
waA$irapN A woman who sharpens and makes thin [and serrated] the [teeth, or] canine teeth. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., laEan All~`hu AlwaA$irapa waAlmuwta$irap [May God curse her who sharpens and makes thin and serrated the teeth, or the canine teeth, and her who orders one to do this, or who asks for it to be done]. (S, TA.) An old woman does this in order to make herself like the young. (TA.)

muw^a$~aru AlEaDudayoni *
muw^a$~aru AlEaDudayoni, applied to the beetle, [meaning, Having the fore-shanks formed thin, and serrated;] as also without '. (K.)

miy$aAr *
miy$aAr, without ', A saw; a dial. form of miy^o$aArN. (S, * K.)

muwta$irapN *
muwta$irapN A woman who orders one to sharpen teeth and to make them thin [and serrated]: (L:) or who asks for this to be done; as also musotawo$irapN↓: (K:) if with ', it is from A^a$orN, not wa$orN; and if without ', accord. to the regular way it should be mut~a$irapN. (K.)

musotawo$rapN *
musotawo$rapN: see muwta$irapN.

2 wS~St *
2. wS~St, (AZ, TA,) or waSowaSato↓, (M,) She (a girl, M,) put on, or wore, her niqaAb [a kind of fare-veil], (AZ, TA,) or her qinaAE [a kind of head-covering], (M,) in such a manner that nothing was seen but her eyes: (AZ, M, TA:) tawoSiySN and taroSiySN signify the same: (AZ, S, CK:) the former is of the dial. of Temeem: (AZ, TA:) or both the above verbs signify she (a woman) contracted her nqAb (K, TA) so that it shewed nothing but her eyes: (TA:) or wSwSt signifies she (a woman) put her nqAb near to her eyes. (Fr. TA.)

R. Q. 1 waSowaSato *
R. Q. 1. waSowaSato: see 2, throughout. ― -b2- waSowaSa He looked through a hole such as is termed waSowaSN. (K.) ― -b3- He (a whelp) opened his eyes. (K.) ＝ -A2- waSowaSa Eayonahu He (a man) contracted his eye in order to obtain a sure view. (IDrd, M.)

waSaAy^iSN *
waSaAy^iSN: see waSowaSN.

waSowaSN *
waSowaSN, (S,) or waSowaASN↓, (M,) or both, (K,) the latter on the authority of Lth, (TA,) A hole in a veil or the like, of the size of the eye, through which one looks. (S, M, K.) And waSaAwiSu, [the pl. of the former, or of either,] The narrow parts of the apertures for the eyes of a buroquE [a kind of woman's face-veil]; (M, TA;) as also waSaAy^iSu. (TA.)

waSowaASN *
waSowaASN: see waSowaSN. ― -b2- A small buroquE [a kind of face-veil]: (S, M:) pl waSaAwiSu (S,) signifying small baraAqiE worn by a girl. (K.) ― -b3- buroquEN waSowaASN A buroquE that is contracted [so as to show nothing but the eyes]. (M, TA.)

1 waSiy^a *
1. waSiy^a, as also Say^iy^a, (mentioned by Lb, TA,) It (a garment) was, or became, dirty. (K.)

1 waSaba *
1. waSaba, aor. yaSibu, inf. n. wuSuwbN; (S, K;) and AwSb↓; (K;) It continued; was constant; (S, K;) was fixed, settled, or firm. (K.) ― -b2- waSaba labanu Aln~aAqapi (assumed tropical:) The milk of the camel continued, or was constant. (A.) ― -b3- waSiba, aor. yawoSabu, inf. n. waSabN; (S, K, Msb;) and wS~b↓ and AwSb↓ and twS~b↓; (K;) He (a man, S,) was, or became, diseased, ill, or sick: (S, K:) or in pain: (Msb:) [or in violent pain: or in continual, or constant, pain: or emaciated in body by reason of fatigue or disease: or in a state of excessive fatigue: and, sometimes, he suffered fatigue, or weariness, and languor: see waSabN:] tawoSiyobN is also explained as signifying the being languid: (TA:) and twS~b↓, as signifying he felt, or experienced, pain in his body. (A.) ― -b4- waSaba Al$~aHomu (tropical:) The fat [in an animal] continued. (TA.) ― -b5- waSaba EalaY AlA^amori, (S, K,) aor. yaSibu, [inf. n. wuSuwbN;] and waSiba, aor. yaSibu; the latter aor. extr. [with respect to analogy]; (Kr;) like waviqa, aor. yaviqu, and wamiqa, aor. yamiqu, &c.; but not mentioned by the lexicographers with these verbs; (TA;) [and AwSb↓; see below;] and wASb↓; (TA;) i. q. waAZaba; He kept. attended, or applied himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to the thing; (S, K;) and managed it, or conducted it, well. (K.) ― -b6- waSaba fiY maAlihi, and EalaY mAlh; and wiSiba; aors. as above; He kept, attended, or applied himself, constantly to his property, [meaning his camels &c.,] and managed it well. (Kr.) ― -b7- Alqawomu EalaY Al$~aYo'i AwSb↓ The people kept, attended. or applied themselves, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to the thing. (S, K.)

2 wS~bhu *
2. wS~bhu He took care of him, tended him, or nursed him, in his sickness: like mr~Dh. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b2- See 1.

3 waAoSaba
3: see 1, and 4.

4 AwSbhu *
4. AwSbhu It (a disease) rendered him ill, or sick. (TA.) See waSabN. ― -b2- AwSbhu He (God) afflicted him with a disease, sickness, or malady. (S, K.) See waSabN. ― -b3- AwSb He (a man) had diseased children born to him. (K.) Accord. to IKtt, AwSb Alqawomu The people had their children wearied by disease. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AwSbti Aln~aAqapu Al$~aHoma (tropical:) The she-camel grew fat, (K,) and continued so: (TA:) [explained in the K by nabata $aHomuhaA, [which is probably a mistake for vabata; and if so, I prefer another reading of the phrase in the K, mentioned in the TA; namely, AwSb Aln~aAqapa Al$~aHomu; i. e., the she-camel was constantly fat]. ― -b2- AwSbt Aln~aAqapu, and wASbt↓, (assumed tropical:) The she-camel yielded milk continually, or constantly. (A.) ― -b3- See 1.

5 tawaS~aba
5: see 1, in two places.

waSobN *
waSobN The space between the third finger and the first finger; or, lit., what is between those two fingers. (K.)

waSabN *
waSabN A disease, sickness, or malady: (S, K:) or pain: (Msb:) or violent pain: or continual, or constant, pain: or continuance of pain: (TA:) or emaciation of the body by reason of
fatigue or disease: (IDrd:) or excessive fatigue: (Zj:) and, sometimes, fatigue, or weariness, and languor: (TA:) pl. A^awoSaAbN. (K.)

waSibN *
waSibN (S, K) and waASibN↓ (TA) Diseased; ill; sick: (S, K:) or in pain: (Msb:) [or in violent pain: or in continual, or constant pain: &c.: see waSabN]: pl. of the former waSaAbaY and waSaAbN. (K.)

waASibN *
waASibN: see waSibN. ― -b2- Ea*aAbN waASibN [Kur. xxxvii. 9,] A continual, perpetual, constant, or fixed, punishment. (Fr, TA.) ― -b3- lahu Ald~iynu waASibFA, [Kur, xvi. 54,] as Zj observes, is said to mean To Him shall be rendered obedience perpetually, or constantly: (Fr, S:) or it may mean To Him shall be rendered obedience, whether man be content with that which he is commanded to do, or not; or whether it be easy to him, or not: to Him shall be rendered obedience, even if it be attended by excessive fatigue. (TA.) ― -b4- mafaAzapN waASibapN A desert far-extending, [as though] without end; (S;) that extends so far as scarcely to have an end; (A;) very far-extending. (K.)

muwaSabN *
muwaSabN Afflicted by God with a disease, sickness, or malady. (S.)

naAqapN muwSibapN *
naAqapN muwSibapN, and muwaS~ibapN↓ [perhaps a mistake for muwaASibapN: see 4:] (assumed tropical:) A she-camel that yields milk continually, or constantly. (A.)

muwaS~abN *
muwaS~abN Having many pains [or diseases]. (S, K.)

muwaS~ibapN *
muwaS~ibapN: see naAqapN muwSibapN.

4 AwSd *
4. AwSd He closed, a door, or an entrance; syn. A^agolaqa; (S, M, A, L, K;) and A^aTobaqa: (Msb, K:) as also A=Sada. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- See 10. ― -b3- A^uwiSida It (a door, or entrance) became closed. (S.) ― -b4- AwSd He covered, or covered over, a cooking-pot. (M, A, L.) ― -b5- waqaEa Aljabalu EalaY baAbi Alkahofi faA^awoSadahu The mountain fell upon the entrance of the cavern, and stopped it up. (L, from a trad.) See also A^awoTada. ― -b6- AwSdwA Ealayohi (tropical:) They straitened him, and imposed on him a difficulty which he was unable to bear. (A.)

10 AstwSd *
10. AstwSd (S, A, L, K) and AwSd↓ (A, K) He made a fold, such as is called waSiydap, (S, L,) or waSiyd, (K,) or a HaZiyrap, for his sheep or goats, (A,) in a mountain. (S, L.)

wiSaAdN *
wiSaAdN (M, L,) as also A_iSaAdN, (L,) and waSiydN↓ [see the Kur, xviii. 17,] (K,) i. q. mTbq: (M, L, K.:) [in a copy of the M written maTobaqN: in the L, without any syll. signs: in the CK, muTobaq: and in my MS. copy of the K, muTobiq: see the remarks on these words in art. A^aSd:]) or wiSaAdN and A_iSaAdN are like TibaAqN. (O.)

waSiydN *
waSiydN A court, or an open or a wide space in front of a house or dwelling, or extending from its sides: (S, M, A, L, Msb, K:) as also A^aSiydN; q. v.: (L:) pl. wuSudN and waSaAy^idu. (TA.) ― -b2- A threshold (Msb, K) of a door or entrance. (Msb.) ― -b3- A door, or entrance. (A.) See wiSaAdN. ― -b4- It has the first of these meanings in the Kur, xviii. 17; (A, L, TA;) or the second: (TA:) or the third: (A, TA:) or it there means The cavern of the Asháb el-Kahf. (K *, TA.) ― -b5- Also, waSiydN, (K,) or waSiydapN↓, (S, A, L,) [as also A^aSiydapN,] A fold (HaZiyrap) for sheep or goats: (A:) or a house like a HZyrp, of stones, made in the mountains, for flocks or herds; (L, K;) i. e., for sheep or goats &c.: (TA:) an enclosure like a HZyrp, made for flocks or herds, excepting that it is of stones, and a HZyrp [is] of branches of trees: (S, L:) F, misunderstanding this explanation, has erroneously said in the K, that waSiydN also signifies a HZyrp of branches of trees: (TA:) pl. waSaAy^idu. (A.) ― -b6- [Snares, or traps, for catching beasts of prey: see raSaAy^idu in art. rSd.] ― -b7- waSiydN Herbage having the roots near together. (S, L, K.) ― -b8- waSiydN (tropical:) Strait; straitened; (K, TA;) as also Ealayohi muwSadN↓. (A, TA.)

waSiydapN *
waSiydapN: see waSiydN.

muwSadN *
muwSadN A door, or entrance, closed: (L:) or become closed. (S.) ― -b2- In the Kur, eiv. 8, [and xc. 20,] muwSadapN (as some read instead of muw^oSadapN, L) signifies Closed over. (S, L.) ― -b3- See waSiydN.

wiSorN *
wiSorN A covenant, compact, or contract: (S, K:) a dial. form of A_iSorN; like as they said A_irovN and wirovN, and A_isaAdapN and wisaAdapN. (S.) ― -b2- Also, (S, A, K,) and waSar~apN↓ (Lth, A, K) and waSiyrapN↓ (K) and A^awoSarN↓, (Lth, TS, L,) A written statement of a purchase or sale, transfer, bargain, or contract: (S, A, K, TA:) the first is from A_iSorN, and is generally used in this sense: pl. of the first, A^awoSaArN; and of the second, waSar~aAtN: Lth says, that the second is an arabicized word; and others say, that the first and second are Persian words, arabicized. (TA.) One says, A^aqoTaEahu AlA^aroDa wakataba lahu AlwiSora, and AlwaSar~apa↓, [He made him a grant of the land to be held in fee, and wrote for him the statement of the transfer.] (A.) And it is said in a trad., h`*aA A@$otaraY min~iY A^aroDFA waqabaDa min~iY wiSorahaA falaA huwa yarud~u EalaY~a AlwiSora walaA yuEoTiyniY Alv~amana [This man purchased of me some land (or daArFA a house, as in the TA) and received of me the written statement of its sale, but he will not restore to me the written statement of the sale, nor will he give me the price]. (S.)

waSar~apN *
waSar~apN: see wiSorN.

waSiyrapN *
waSiyrapN: see wiSorN.

A^awoSarN *
A^awoSarN: see wiSorN.

1 waDuw^a *
1. waDuw^a (S, K) aor. yawoDuw^u, inf. n. waDaA='apN; (TA;) and waDiy^a, aor. yawoDaA^u; (IO, &c.;) He was, or became, fair, beautiful, neat, or clean. (S, K.) ― -b2- fawaDaA^ahu waADaA^ahu↓, (S, K,) aor. of the latter yaDaA^u, (S,) dev. from rule, by which, as a verb of the class called AfEAl AlmgAlbp, it should be like yanoSuru, (TA,) He vied with him for the honour of surpassing in fairness, or comeliness, and prevailed over him therein. (S, K.)

2 wD~A^hu *
2. wD~A^hu [He made him, or assisted him, to perform the ablution termed wuDuwo'F, or waDuwo'. (M, TA.) [See an ex. voce qisoTN.]

3 waAoDaAa
3: see 1.

5 twD~A^ *
5. twD~A^, (S, K,) inf. n., [or rather quasi-inf. n., used for the regular inf. n. tawaD~uw^N,] wuDuwo'N, or waDuwo'N, or both, [see these two nouns below,] from waDaA='apN, (lit., He made himself fair, beautiful, neat, or clean: TA:) He performed ablution, liloS~alaApi for, or preparatory to, prayer. (S, K.) ― -b2- It sometimes signifies He washed some one or more of his members: he purified his hand, or hands, and mouth, by washing, from the foul smell of fat, or greasy, food: he washed his hand. ― -b3- Some say tawaD~ayotu [for tawaD~aA^otu]; but this should not be said: (S:) it is of weak authority, or is viciously so pronounced: (K:) it is said to be of the dial, of Hudheyl. (TA.) ― -b4- twD~A^, and twD~A^t, He (a youth), and she (a girl), arrived at the age of puberty. (K.)

A_iDaA'N *
A_iDaA'N: see waDiYo'N.

waDuwo'N *
waDuwo'N: see wuDuwo'N.

wuDuwo'N *
wuDuwo'N signifies The act of ablution, &c. (S, K) (see 5); and waDuwo'N↓, the water with which that act is performed, or the water that is prepared for that act, (S, K, TA,) and is said to be also an inf. n., [or rather a quasi-inf. n., signifying the act itself]: (S, K:) or they are syn. words of two different dialects, each sometimes used as an inf. n., signifying the act, (though inf. ns. of the measure faEuwlN deviate from constant rule, TA,) and each sometimes as signifying the water. (S, K, TA.) AA says, that waDuwo'N↓ signifies “ the water with which one performs the ablution above mentioned; ” and he knew not wuDuwo'N [though it occurs in many traditions]: and A 'Obeyd disallows waDuwo'N, and allows only waDuwo'N↓. (TA.)

waDiYo'N *
waDiYo'N, (S, K,) pl. A^awoDiyaA='u and wiDaA='N; (K;) and wuD~aA='N↓, [S, K; in the CK, erroneously, wuD~aA='K;]
pl. wuD~aAw^uwna and waDaADiy^u; (K;) and waADiy^N↓, (K,) which is used in the future sense, accord. to Lh, [like an act. part. n., though from a neut. verb,] as in the ex. [mentioned in the K] maAhw biwaADiy^K; waDiYo'N being used in the present sense; (TA;) Fair, beautiful, neat, or clean. (S, K.) ― -b2- In the following of En-Nábighah,
fahun~a A_iDaA='N SaAfiyaAtu AlgalaAy^ili
[And they are fair, beautiful, neat, or clean; unsullied as to their inner garments], A_iDaA='N↓ may be put for wiDaA='N. (TA.)

waDaA='ap *
waDaA='ap Fairness, beauty, neatness, or cleanness. (S, K.)

wuD~aA='N *
wuD~aA='N and waADiy^N: see waDy^'N.

A^awoDaA^u *
A^awoDaA^u Fairer, neater, or cleaner. (TA, from a trad.)

miyDaA^apN *
miyDaA^apN, and, sometimes, miyDaA='ap↓, A place in which, and from which, one performs the ablution termed wDw'; (K;) [as also mutuwaD~aA^N↓:] a miToharap (K: in the CK, maToharap), meaning that from which, or in which, one performs the said ablution: (TA:) [a tank for ablution, accord. to present usage].

myDaA='apN *
myDaA='apN: see what precedes.

mutawaD~aA^N *
mutawaD~aA^N: see miyDaA^apN. A privy; or place where one performs ablution. (K, TA, voce ma*ohab, &c.)

1 waDaHa *
1. waDaHa, aor. yaDiHu, inf. n. wuDuwHN (S, Msb, L, K) and DiHapN and DaHapN, (L, K,) the last with fet-hah because the guttural letter; (TA;) and At~DH↓, (S, Msb, K,) and AwDH↓, and twD~H↓; (L, K;) It (an affair, A^amorN, S, K, and a thing, $aYo'N, L,) appeared; became apparent, or plainly apparent, overt, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, plain, obvious, or evident; (S, L, K;) became clear, unobscured, exposed to view, displayed, laid open, disclosed, or uncovered. (Msb.) ― -b2- (tropical:) It (language) was perspicuous. (The Lexicons, passim.) ― -b3- maloku AlT~ar~iyqi twD~H↓ The middle of the road became plainly apparent, obvious, or conspicuous. (S.) ― -b4- mano A^ayona waDaHa Alr~aAkibu, as AZ says, or, as others say, mn Ayn AwDH↓, Whence did the rider make his appearance? (L.) Or waDaHa Alr~aAkibu signifies the rider came forth: (ISd:) and mn Ayn A^awoDaHta↓ whence hast thou come forth? (IAar, S,) and [in like manner one says] mn Ayn badaA waDaHuka. (S.) ＝ -A2- waDaHati AlA_ibilu biAll~abani (tropical:) i. q. A^alomaEat. (K.) ＝ -A3- waDiHa, aor.
waDaHa
, inf. n. waDaHN, [a verb of which the inf. n. is explained in the Msb by the word drn: if this be not a mistake of a copyist, it app. signifies He, or it, was dirty; or was dirtied, soiled, or besmeared].

2 waD~aHa
2: see 4.

4 AwDHhu *
4. AwDHhu, (S, Msb, K,) and AwDH Eanohu, (L,) inf. n. A_iyDaAHN: (TA,) and wD~Hhu↓, (K,) inf. tawoDiyHN; (TA;) He rendered it apparent or plainly apparent, overt, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, plain, obvious, or evident; (S, L, K;) rendered it clear, or unobscured; exposed it to view; displayed it; laid it open; disclosed or uncovered it. (Msb.) ― -b2- He rendered language perspicuous. (The lexicons, passim.) ― -b3- AwDHt Al$~aj~apu fiY Alr~aA^osi The wound upon the head laid bare the bone. (Msb,) [See muwDiHapN.] ― -b4- AwDH lahu AlA^amora, (S, K,) and AlkalaAma, (S,) He made the affair, (S, K,) and the language, (S,) plain, or clear, to him. (S, K.) ― -b5- See 1. ― -b6- AwDH qawomFA He saw a people. (L.) ― -b7- AwDH He (a man) had white children born to him: (S, L:) and in like manner one says [AwDHt] of a woman. (L.)

5 tawaD~aHa
5: See 1. ― -b2- twD~H [app., He (a sheep or goat) had a whiteness predominant over other colours, overspreading generally his whole body: or in his breast and back and face]. (L.)

8 A_iwotaDaHa
8: see 1.

10 AstwDH $ayoy^FA *
10. AstwDH $ayoy^FA He put his hand over his eyes (in the sun, L) to try if he could see a thing, (S, L, K,) guarding his eyes with his hand from the rays of the sun: as also Aisotakaf~ahu, and Aisota$orafahu. (L.) One says AisotawoDiHo Eanohu yaA fulaAnu [Try if thou canst see him, or it, by putting thy hand over thine eyes, O such a one]. (S.) ― -b2- AstwDH Als~abiyla He sought or endeavoured to see plainly or clearly the way: syn. AistabaAnahu (Beyd, vi. 55.) ― -b3- AstwDH Al$~amosa He blinked at the sun; syn. taHaAwaSa A_ilayohaA. (A.) ― -b4- AstwDHhu AlA^amora, (S, K,) and AlkalaAma, (S,) He asked him to make the affair, (S, K,) and the language, (S,) plain, or clear, to him. (S, K.) ― -b5- AstwDH Eani AlA^amori He inquired respecting the thing or affair; sought for information respecting it; inquired into it; investigated it. (L.)

waDaHN *
waDaHN Light, and whiteness, (S,) of anything: (TA:) the whiteness of daybreak, or dawn: and of the moon; (K;) and its light. (TA.) ― -b2- SuwmuwA mina AlwaDaHi A_ilaY AlwaDaHi Fast ye from new moon to new moon. (IAth, from a trad.) ― -b3- waDaHN (tropical:) Leprosy; syn. baraSN. (S, K.) It is sometimes used in this sense, metonymically. (S.) ― -b4- waDaHN A mark in a horse differing in colour from the generality of his coat. You say biAlfarasi waDaHN In the horse is such a mark. (S.) ― -b5- waDaHN A blaze, or white mark on a horse's forehead or face. (K.) ― -b6- What is termed taHojiylN in the legs of a horse. (L, K.) And also applied to other varieties of colour. (L.) ― -b7- frasN *uw A^awoDaAHK A horse having a blaze and what is termed tHjyl. (A.) ― -b8- waDaHN Whiteness of the hair, or hoariness; or white, or hoary, hair. (K.) ― -b9- (tropical:) Milk: (L, K:) thought by ISd to be so called because of its whiteness: or milk that has not been mixed with water: (L:) or that is just drawn. (TA, art. zhr.) Aboo-Dhueyb says,
Eaq~awoA bisahomK falamo ya$oEuro bihi A^aHadN
vum~a A@sotafaw^uwA waqaAluwAHab~a*aA AlwaDaHu
[They shot an arrow towards the sky, and no one knew of it: then they returned, and said, An excellent thing is milk]: meaning, we would rather have milk than the blood of him who has killed our companion: they preferred that camels should be given them in compensation. (L.) [See also 2, in art. EqY.] ― -b10- waDaHN A sound, whole or perfect, [silver coin, of the kind called] diroham. (S, K.) dirohamN waDaHN A clean, white dirhem: pl. A^awoDaAHN. (TA.) ― -b11- waDaHN The middle, or main part and middle, of a road; the part of a road along which one travels. (S, K.) ― -b12- waDaHN A woman's ornament (HaloYN) of silver: (A 'Obeyd, K:) or, of stones; (El-Meshárik;) i. e. of silverstones: (Towsheeh:) so called because of its whiteness: (TA:) pl. A^awoDaAHN: (K:) or A^awoDaAHN signifies a kind of woman's ornament (HaloYN) made of whole [silver coins such as are called] daraAhim: (S:) and (according to some, TA,) waDaHN signifies an anklet; syn. xaloxaAlN (K) ― -b13- waDaHN (K) or waDaHN AlT~ariyfapi, (L, but the latter word is there written; Tryqp,) Small portions, or parts, of herbage; (L, K;) what he has become white thereof: (AHn:) pl. A^awoDaAHN: (L:) or A^awoDaAHN mino kalaA_K signifies somewhat of herbage that has become white: (As:) Az says, I have mostly heard the term waDaHN, with respect to herbage, applied to the naSiY~ and Sil~iyaAn SayofiY~ which is not a year old and has not become black: and on another occasion he says, that it is the remains of the HaliY~ and Sil~iyaAn only. (L.) ― -b14- waDaHN Whiteness predominating over other colours in sheep or goats, overspreading generally the whole body: pl. A^awoDaAHN: (L:) or, in the breast and back and face: (T:) you say also lahu tawoDyHN↓. (L.) ― -b15- mino A^ayona badaA waDaHuka: see 1. ― -b16- waDaHu Alqadami Whiteness of the hollow of the sole of the foot. (L.)

waDaHapN *
waDaHapN A she-ass. (K.)

waDiyHapN *
waDiyHapN, Camels, or camels and sheep; syn. naEamN: pl. waDaAy^iHu. (L, K.)

waD~aAHN *
waD~aAHN: see waADiHN.

waADiHN *
waADiHN and waD~aAHN↓ [but the latter has an intensive signification] Apparent, or plainly apparent; overt; conspicuous; manifest; notorious; plain; obvious; or evident; (L, K;) clear, or unobscured; exposed to view; displayed; laid open; disclosed, or uncovered. (So accord. to the explanation of the verb in the Msb.) ― -b2- Perspicuous language. (The Lexicons passim.) ― -b3- Also the ↓latter, A man of white, or fair, and beautiful, complexion: (S, L, K:) of beautiful and smiling countenance. (L.) ― -b4- See mutawaD~iHN. ― -b5- Also the ↓latter, (tropical:) Leprous. Hence Jedheemeh El-Abrash was called AlwaD~aAHu. (S.) ― -b6- AlwaD~aAHu↓ The day. (L, K.) The night is called Ald~ahomaAnu. (L.) ― -b7- bikoru AlwaD~aAHi↓ The prayer of morning, or daybreak. The prayer of nightfall is called vinoYu dahomaAna. (L, K [but in the CK and a MS. copy of the K, for dahomaAna, we find duhomaAna].) ― -b8- EaZomu waD~aAHK↓, (L, K,) and EuZayomu waD~aAHK, (L,) A certain game (of the children of the Arabs of the desert, L,) in which children take a white bone and throw it in the darkness of night, and then disperse themselves in search of it: (L, K:) he who finds it wins. (L.) [See more in art. EZm.] ― -b9- huwa minoka A^adonaY waADiHapK↓ He is plainly apparent to thee, as though he had become white. (Th.) ― -b10- rajulN waADHu AlHasabi, and waD~aAHuhu↓, (tropical:) A man as though he were conspicuous, clean, or pure, and white, with respect to rank or quality, nobility, reputation, or the like. (L.) ― -b11- In like manner one says, lahu Aln~asabu AlwaD~aAHu↓ (tropical:) He is of conspicuous and pure race, or lineage. (TA.) ― -b12- waADiHN (assumed tropical:) An illustrious man. (EsSaadee.) ― -b13- [And so] min Aln~aAsi waA^awobaA$N A^awoDaAHN↓ [Illustrious people, and mixed people of the baser sort;] companies of people of various tribes. No sing. of AwDAH in this sense has been heard. (L.) ― -b14- AlwuD~axu [pl. of waADiHN] The stars called AlkawaAkibu Alxun~asu [namely, Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Venus, and Mercury,] when in conjunction with the bright stars of the Mansions of the Moon. (L.)

waADiHapN *
waADiHapN: see waADiHN. ― -b2- SiyaAmu AlA^awaADiHi, originally wawaADiH, (Hr, K,) pl. of waADiHapN, (TA,) or SiyaAmu AlA^awoDaAHi, (IAth,) The fasting during the days of the white nights: (K *, TA:) which was commanded by Mohammad: (K:) these are the 13th, 14th, and 15th, [of the lunar month]. (TA.) ― -b3- AlwaADiHapN The teeth that appear when one laughs: (S, K:) an epithet in which the quality of subst. predominates: pl. DawaAHiku. (TA.) ― -b4- See muwDiHap.

A^awoDAaHN *
A^awoDAaHN: see waDaHN and waADiHN.

tawoDiyHN *
tawoDiyHN inf. n. of 2, q.v. ― -b2- And see waDaHN at the end.

muwDiHapN *
muwDiHapN (S, K) and waADiHapN↓ (TA) A wound by which the head or face is broken, that shows the whiteness of the bone: (S, K, TA:) or, that removes the skin which is between the flesh and the bone: the only kind of $aj~ap for which retaliation is allowed: for [some] other kinds there are assigned mulets: and for this too is assigned a mulct, consisting of five camels: but a mwDHp may also be in other parts than the head or face; and respecting this, a judge must give his sentence: pl. mawAaDiHu. (TA.) [See $aj~apN.] ― -b2- mawaADiHu AlHaq~i i. q. mabaAyinuhu, q.v. (TA, in art. byn.) ― -b3- muwDiHapN A woman who brings forth white children. (O, in TA, art. byD.)

mutawaD~iHN *
mutawaD~iHN and waADiHN↓ A camel that is white, but not intensely so; (En-Nadr, L, K;) more white than such as is termed A^aEoyaS [app. a mistake for A^aEoyas] and A^aSohab: (En-Nadr, L:) also (the former accord. to the K, and the latter also accord. to the L) of such a colour in the A^aqoraAb [or flanks]. (L, K.) ― -b2- mutawa D~iHN One who is apparent, or plainly apparent. (K.) ― -b3- One who shows himself openly in the road, (S,) or who goes along the middle, or main part and middle of the road, (K,) and does not enter a woody place or the like where he would be concealed. (S, K.)

1 waDaxa Ald~alowa *
1. waDaxa Ald~alowa, and AwDxhA↓, He nearly half-filled the bucket, so that it resembled one half-full. (L, K.) [See also 4.]

3 wADxhu *
3. wADxhu, inf. n. muwaADaxapN (S, K) and wiDaAxN, (K,) He emulated, or imitated, him (that is his companion) in drawing water, doing as he did. (As, Ks, S, K.) This is the original signification: afterwards used with reference to any two persons emulating each other. (Ks, S.) [Hence,] ― -b2- (tropical:) He emulated him, or imitated him, in running; (L, K;) and exerted himself excessively, or exceeded the usual bounds or degree, therein: (L:) or [so in the L; in the K, and] went, journeyed, or marched, like him; or kept pace with him in going, journeying, or marching; (S, L, K;) not a vehement rate; (S, L;) as also wADxhu Als~ayora. (L.) Az says, that mwADxp, as used by the Arabs, signifies emulation, although not with unusual exertion, or an exceeding of the usual bounds or degree, in running. (L.) [See also 6.]

4 AwDx biAld~alowi *
4. AwDx biAld~alowi He drew water with the bucket and shook it about vehemently [app. so that it did not become, or remain full]: or he drew with it little water. (L.) [See also 1.] ― -b2- AwDx lahu He drew for him little, or a little, water. (S, L, K.) ― -b3- Also, AwDxt Albiy^oru The well contained little water; its water became little; (K;) water having been taken from it for irrigation. (TA.)

6 twADxA *
6. twADxA They (two men standing together over a well, L) emulated each other [in drawing water and] in watering, or irrigating. (L, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) They (two horses) emulated each other [in running]; (L:) and twADxt AlA_ibilu the camels emulated one another in going, journeying, or marching. (L, K *.) [See also 3.]

wuDuwxN *
wuDuwxN Water in a bucket resembling half [of the quantity that would fill it]: (S, L, K:) or what is less than the quantity that would fill it. (L.)

1 waDira *
1. waDira, (M, Msb, K,) said of a vessel, (TA,) and waDirato, said of a bowl, (qaSoEapN, S,) aor. yawoDaru (Msb) and tawoDaru, (S,) inf. n. waDarN, (S, Msb,) It was, or became, dirty, or filthy, (S, M, Msb, K,) with grease or gravy, or the dripping that exudes from flesh-meat, (S, M, K,) or otherwise, with what is termed waDarN. (M, K.)

2 wD~rhu *
2. wD~rhu [He made it (a vessel) dirty, or filthy, with waDar, i. e., grease, or the like]. ― -b2- kaAna naqiY~a AlEiroDi fawaD~arahu biAld~anaA='api [He was unsullied in honour, and he sullied it by baseness]. (A.)

waDarN *
waDarN Dirt, or filth: (S, Msb): and grease, gravy, or dripping that exudes from flesh-meat or from fat; (S:) or the dirt of grease or gravy, or of what exudes from flesh-meat, and of milk: (M, A, K:) and (so in the M; but in the K, or) the washings of a skin that is used for milk or for water, and of a bowl and the like: (M, K:) [see xaDoraA='u AlwaDari voce Eu$obN:] and remains of hinaA=' [or tar] (AO, S, K) &c.: (AO, S:) [and feculence of clarified butter, adhering to the interior of a skin: see EabakapN and EabaqapN:] and the soil, or stain, of saffron and the like; (K;) or of [the perfume called] xaluwq, or of [other] perfume having a colour: and a mark that remains from what is not perfume: (TA:) pl. A^awoDaAr. (K.) ― -b2- Also, The odour, (A,) or what a man smells of the odour, (AA, S, K,) of food in a corrupt state. (AA, S, A, K.) ― -b3- You say also of a man, fiY A^axolaAqihi waDarN (tropical:) In his dispositions is foulness. And huwa *uw A^awoDaArK (tropical:) He possesses foul qualities. (A.)

waDirN *
waDirN Dirty, or filthy, (M, A, Msb, K,) with grease, or gravy, or what exudes from flesh-meat,
or otherwise, with what is termed waDarN; (M, A, K;) applied to a vessel: (A:) fem. waDirapN (M, A, K) and waDoraY↓; (M, K;) both applied to a woman; (M;) and the former, to a hand. (A.) See sahikN. ― -b2- [Hence] AlwaDoraY (IAar, K) and AlwaDoraA='u↓ (A, Sgh, K) The anus; syn. AlA_isotu, (A, TA,) and Alfunoduwrapa, (K, TA, [in the CK, Alfinodiyrapu, which is a mistranscription,]) both of which signify the same. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] fulaAnN waDiru AlA^axolaAqi (tropical:) Such a one is foul in dispositions. (A.)

waDoraY *
waDoraY and waDoraA='u: see waDirN; the former in two places.

1 waT~N *
1. waT~N, [an inf. n., of which the verb is waT~a, aor., accord. to rule,
waTi3a
, but accord. to the TK,
waTu3a
,] The crying of the waTowaAT. (Sgh, K.) ― -b2- The creaking of the [kind of vehicle called] maHomil. (Sgh, K.)

R. Q. 1 waTowaTapN *
R. Q. 1. waTowaTapN, [inf. n. of waTowaTa,] The uttering speech, or words rapidly, or near together. (K.) [See waTowaATN.] ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The being weak. (K.)

R. Q. 2 tawaTowaTa *
R. Q. 2. tawaTowaTa He (a child) cried out. (Ibn 'Abbád, Sgh, K.)

wuTuTN *
wuTuTN: see the last sentence of the next paragraph.

waTowaATN *
waTowaATN The bat; syn. xuf~aA$N: (As, S, K:) or the large xuf~aA$: (Msb:) or the swallow; syn. xuT~aAfN; (S, Msb;) this is thought by A'Obeyd to be, more probably than the first, the correct meaning; (S;) or the last may be right, but the first is that which is commonly known: (IB:) or it has the first signification, and also signifies a species of the swallows (xaTaATiyf) of the mountains, (K, TA,) black and likened to a species of the xa$aA$iyf [or bats], because of its [frequent] receding and turning aside [in its flight]: (TA:) [Golius says, as on the authority of the K, “ pec. genus montanum et. vocale, quod ἄπουσ dicitur; i. e. the swift:] pl. waTaAwiyTu, (Msb,) or waTaAwiTu, (S,) or both, (Kr, K,) but the latter, which is irreg., only allowable in poetry, in cases of necessity. (Kr.) It is used in the first of these senses in the proverb, A^aboSaru fiY All~ayoli mina AlwaTowaATi [More clear-sighted in the night than the bat]. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- Clamorous; (Lh, K;) applied to a man: (Lh:) and one who utters his speech, or words, rapidly, or near together; (Lh, K;) as though his voice were the voice of bats: so they assert it to mean: (Lh:) fem. with p: (K:) and [in like manner] waTowaATiY~N↓ signifies loquacious; a great talker; a babbler. (K *, TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A man weak in intellect and judgment: (ISh:) or weak and cowardly; (A 'Obeyd, S K;) in the opinion of A'Obeyd, as being likened to the flying thing so called; (S;) as also waTowaATiY~N↓: (K:) and wuTuTN↓, (IAar, K,) of which waTowaATN is the sing., (TA,) men (IAar) weak in intellects and bodies. (IAar, K.)

waTowaATiY~N *
waTowaATiY~N: see waTowaATN, in two places.

1 waTiy^a *
1. waTiy^a, aor. yaTaA^u; (S, K;) the w, falls out from the aor. of this verb, and from that of wasiEa, because they are transitive; for other verbs of the class faEila, having the aor. of the measure yafoEalu, and the first radical letter infirm, are intransitive; and as these two differ from their class in being transitive, they are also made to differ in the aor.; (S;) or yaTaA^u was originally yaTiy^u, and therefore the w, falls out from it; (TA;) inf. n. waTo'N, (TA) [and Tiy^apN, q.v. infra]; and wT~A^↓, (K, but this has an intensive signification, MF;) and twT~A^↓ (S, K) He trod; trod upon; (birijolihi with his foot; S) trod under foot; trampled upon: (S, K, TA:) or waTiy^ahu signifies he pressed, or bore, upon him, or it, with his hand or his foot. (TA, in art. vTA^.) [See also waToA^apN.] ― -b2- Th, at the commencement of the 20th ch. of the Kur, is read by some Taho, and said to be for TaA^o, (the h being substituted for ',) and to signify Tread upon the ground with the soles of both thy fect; because Mohammad raised one of his feet in prayer. (TA.) ― -b3- humo yaTaw^uhumu AlT~ariyqu (tropical:) They (i. e. the sons of such a one) sojourn, or encamp, near the road, so that its passengers tread upon them [i. e., became their guests]: (Sb, K:) a tropical phrase, in which AlTryq is put for A^aholu AlT~ariyqi; this being done to give greater force to the phrase, as it is one expressive of praise; for the road is a thing that is constant; whereas its passengers are sometimes upon it, and sometimes absent. (L.) [It means They are a people who take up their abode near the road in order that many passengers may enjoy their hospitality.] ― -b4- [See also TariyqN.] ― -b5- Of the same kind is the phrase A^axa*onaA EalaY AlT~ariyqi AlwaATiy^i libaniY fulaAnK (tropical:) [We look to the road whose passengers tread on (i. e., make themselves the guests of,) the sons of such a one]. (IJ.) ― -b6- So too, mararonaA biqawomK mawoTuwy^iyna biAlT~ariyqi (tropical:) [We passed by a people trod on (i. e., resorted to for their hospitality,) by the passengers of the road]. (IJ.) ― -b7- Also, yaA Tariyqu TaA^o binaA baniY fulaAnK (tropical:) O road, bring us near to [or, lit., make us to tread on, i. e., make us the guests of,] the sons of such a one! (IJ.) ― -b8- waTiy^a, (S, K,) aor, as above, (S,) Inivit feminam. (S, K.) ― -b9- waTaA^a, inf. n. Tiy^apN, (assumed tropical:) He trod under foot, and despised. Ex. naEuw*u biAll~`hi mino Tiy^api Al*~aliyli We put our trust in God for protection from the vile person's treading us under foot, and despising us. (Lh.) ― -b10- waTaA^a and wT~A^↓ (in MF's copy of the K wATA^) He prepared, and made plain, smooth, or soft. (K.) ― -b11- waTayotu; for waTaA^otu, is disallowed. (TA.) ― -b12- waTuw^a, aor. yawoTuw^u, inf. n. wTA^, [so in the TA: probably a mistake for waTaA='apN: see Tiy^apN below:] He (a horse &c.) was, or became, easy to ride upon. (TA.) ― -b13- waTuw^a, aor. yawoTuw^u, inf. n. waTaA='apN (S, K) and wuTuwo'apN (TA) and TaA^apN (TA, as from the K) [and, app., Tiy^apN, q.v. infra], It (a place, S) was plain, level, smooth, soft, or easy to be travelled, or to walk, or ride or lie upon. (S, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- kunotu A^aTaA^u *ikorahu (assumed tropical:) I used to conceal the mention of him, or it. (TA, from a trad.)

2 waT~aAa
2: See 1, in two places. ― -b2- wT~A^, inf. n. tuwoTiy^apN, He made plain, level, smooth, soft, or easy to be, travelled, or to walk or ride or lie upon. (S, K.) He made a beast of carriage easy to ride upon; trained, or broke, it (M, voce raADa.) ― -b3- Also, (TA,) and twT~A^↓, (L,) He prepared (L, ubi supra, and TA,) a bed, or a chamber. (TA.) ― -b4- He arranged, or facilitated, an affair. (TA.) waT~ayotu [for waT~aA^otu] is disallowed. (S.) ― -b5- wT~A^ He (i. e. God) rendered a land plain, level, smooth, soft, or easy to walk or ride or lie upon. (TA.) ― -b6- Also, He (God,) rendered a land depressed. (K.) ＝ -A2- See 4.

3 waATaA^ahu EalaY A^amorK *
3. waATaA^ahu EalaY A^amorK, (AZ, S, K,) inf. n. muwaATaA^apN (S) and wiTaA='N; (TA;) and twATA^hu↓ and twT~A^hu↓; (K;) (tropical:) He agreed, or concurred, with him respecting a thing. (S, K.) The radical signification of wATA^ is said to be He trod in the footsteps of another: and the signification of agreement is therefore figurative. (MF.) ― -b2- fulaAnN yuwaATiy^u A@somuhu A@somiY (tropical:) [Such a one's name agrees, or is the same, with mine]. (S.) ― -b3- liyuwaATiy^uwA Eid~apa maA Har~ama All~`h (tropical:) [That they may agree in the number of (the mouths) which God hath made sacred: Kur, ix. 37]. (S.) ― -b4- A^a$ad~u wiTaA='N, as some read, [in the Kur, lxxiii. 6,] signifies (tropical:) More, or most, suitable; (S;) [i. e., prayer, and the recitation of the Kur-án]: but some read waToA^F, in the sense of qiyaAmFA: see naA$iy^apN. (S, L.) See 4.

4 AwTA^hu gayorahu *
4. AwTA^hu gayorahu He made another to tread, or trample, upon him. (TA.) ― -b2- AwTA^h farasahu He made his horse to tread, or trample, upon him. (K, TA.) ― -b3- AwTA^hu AlA^rDa He made him to tread upon the ground. (Msb.) ― -b4- A^awoTaw^uwhumo (assumed tropical:) They overcame them, or prevailed over them, in a
contention, or dispute. (TA.) ― -b5- In a trad. it is said, that the pastors of the camels, and the shepherds, boasted, one party over the other, and the former overcame the latter (AwTw^whm). (TA.) The verb is used in this sense because it originally signifies, with the annexed pronoun, they made (others) to tread, or trample, upon them: (K, TA:) for him with whom you wrestle or fight, and whom you throw down, you trample upon, and make to be trampled upon by others. (TA.) ― -b6- AwTA^hu AlEa$owapa, (K,) and Ea$owapF, (S, K,) He made him to pursue a course without being rightly directed. (K *, TA.) See art. E$w. ― -b7- AwTA^ fiY Al$~iEori, (S, K,) inf. n. A_iyT~A='N; (TA;) and AwTA^ Al$~iEora, and fiyhi wATA^↓, and wT~A^hu↓, and A^aT~aA^ahu, and A=TaA^ahu, (K,) in which last the w is changed into A; (TA;) He repeated a rhyme in a poem, (S, K,) using the same word in the same sense: (Akh, K:) when the word is the same, but the meaning different, the repetition is not called AyTA' [but jinaAsN taAm~N]. (TA.) This repetition (AyTA') is deemed by Arabs a fault: or it is only deemed a fault if it occur two, or three, or more, times. (TA.)

5 tawaT~aAa
5: See 1, 2, 3. ― -b2- tawaT~ayotu for tawaT~aA^otu is incorrect. (S.) ― -b3- twT~A^ He, or it, was, or became, prepared. (K.) [See also 8.]

6 tawaATaw^uwA *
6. tawaATaw^uwA (assumed tropical:) They agreed together. (S.) ― -b2- twATw^wA Ealayh (assumed tropical:) They agreed together, or concurred, respecting it. (TA.) [See 3.]

8 A_it~aTaA^a *
8. A_it~aTaA^a It was prepared, and became plain, smooth, or soft. (K.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- A_it~aTaA^a AlEi$aA='u (in a trad.) The evening became completely dark: [or the period of nightfall fully came:] also read A_iytaTaY, accord. to the dial. of the tribe of Keys, and explained as signifying the period of nightfall came. The latter verb also signifies “ concurrence, or concord, and agreement, with another. ” (TA.) ― -b3- A_iytaTaA^a Al$~ahoru [About half the month has elapsed]. This is said a day before the half, and a day after the half. (AZ.) ― -b4- A_it~aTaA^a, (as in the CK,) or A_iytaTaA^a, (as in a MS. copy of the K,) measure A_ifotaEala [in the TA written A_isotaTaA^a, which is doubtless a mistake,] It was right, and attained its full period; was perfect, or complete. (K.)

10 AstwTA^ *
10. AstwTA^ He found, or deemed, a thing plain, level, smooth, soft, or easy to walk or ride or lie upon. (K, TA.) ― -b2- He found, or deemed, the thing on which he rode smooth, soft, or easy to ride upon. (S.)

waTo'N *
waTo'N and waTaA='N↓ and miyTaA^N↓ (measure mifoEalN, as shown in the TA; but in the CK, myTaA='N;) Depressed land, or low ground, between eminences ni$aAz [in the CK na$Az] and A^a$oraAf [in the CK A_i$orAf]): (K:) n$Az, is pl. of na$azN, and A$rAf is pl. of $arafN; and both signify “ eminences. ” (TA.)

TaA^apN *
TaA^apN: see Tiy^apN.

Tiy^apN *
Tiy^apN and TaA^apN↓ (in both of which the final p is a substitute for the incipient w, S) and waTaA='apN↓ (S, K) and wuTuw'apN↓ (K) Plainness, levelness, smoothness, softness, or state of being easy to walk or ride or lie upon. (S, K, TA.)

waToA^apN *
waToA^apN [A tread, or a treading. ― -b2- And hence,] (tropical:) A pressure; oppression; affliction; violence: (S, K:) or a vehement assault, or punishment; syn. A^axo*apN $adiydapN: (K:) also, a hostile expedition or engagement; battle, fight, or slaughter. (TA.) ― -b3- All~`hum~a A@$odudo waToA^ataka EalaY muDara, in a trad., O God, make thy punishment of Mudar severe. (S, TA.) ― -b4- waTiy^anaA AlEaduw~u waToA^apF $adiydF (tropical:) [The enemy assaulted, or punished, us with a very vehement assault, or punishment]. (TA.) A=xiru waToA^apK waTiy^ahaA All~`hu biwaj~K, in a trad., (tropical:) The last assault, or conflict, which God caused to befall (the unbelievers was) in Wejj [a valley of Et-Táïf]. (TA.) ― -b5- waToA^apN and mawoTaA^N↓ (K) and mawoTiy^N↓ (S, K) A place on which the sole of the foot is placed; a footstep, or footprint. (S, K.)

waTaA='N *
waTaA='N: see wiTaA='N, and waTo'N.

wiTaA='N *
wiTaA='N (S, K) and waTaA='N↓, (K,) the former is the word commonly known and approved; the latter disapproved by many; (TA;) The contr. of giTaA='N (a covering); [what is placed, or spread, beneath one, to sit or lie upon]: (S, K:) pl. AwoTiy^apN. (TA, in art. xwr.)

waTiYo'N *
waTiYo'N Plain, level, smooth, soft, or easy to be travelled, or to walk or ride or lie upon. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- daAb~apN waTiYo'N (IAar) A beast easy to ride upon. (TA.) ― -b3- Eayo$N waTiYo'N [An easy life]. (TA.) ― -b4- waTiYo'u Alxuluqi Easy in nature, or dispositon. (TA.)

waTaA='apN *
waTaA='apN: see Tiy^apN.

wuTuwo'apN *
wuTuwo'apN: see Tiy^apN.

waTiyoy^apN *
waTiyoy^apN A certain kind of food, (S,) i. q. HayosapN: (IAar:) or dates of which the stones are taken out, and which are kneaded with milk: or what is called A^aqiT, with sugar: (K:) or a food of the Arabs, prepared with dates, which are put into a stone cooking-pot; then water is poured upon them, and clarified butter if there be any; (but no AqT is mixed up with them;) and then it is drunk, like Hysp: (T:) or it is like jayos; dates and AqT kneaded together with clarified butter: (ISh:) or a certain kind of food, also called waTiYo'N; a thin EaSiydap: when it is thickened, it is called nafiytap; when a little more thick, nafiyvap; when a little thicker, lafiytap; and when so thick that it may be chewed, ESydp. (El-Muffaddal.) ― -b2- Also, (as some say, TA,) A thing like [the kind of sack called] a giraArap: (S:) or a grArp containing dried meat (qadiyd) and kaEok (K) and other things: (TA:) ― -b3- A^axorijo A_ilayonaA valaAva A^ukalK mino wTyy^pK Take forth and give us three cakes of bread from a grArp. (S, TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- [See also waATiy^ap and muwaT~aA^N.]

waATiy^apN *
waATiy^apN Fallen dates. (K.) An act. part. n. in the sense of a pass.: (K:) [such dates being so called] because they are trodden under foot. (TA.) Or [it is changed] from waTaAyaA, pl. of waTiyoy^apN, [which is] from waTaA^a; [and such dates are] so called because their owner has despised them, or trampled upon them, (*ll~hA,) and spread them about, for those who may take them; wherefore they are not included in the conjectural estimate of the produce of the tree [made by the collector of the legal alms]. (TA.) ― -b2- waTaA^apN (K) [pl. of wATiy^N] and wATiy^apN (S, K) Travellers; wayfarers: (S, K:) so called from their treading the road. (S.)

laA yutawaD~aA^u mino mawoTaA_K *
laA yutawaD~aA^u mino mawoTaA_K One is not to perform wDw' (i. e., to repeat it,) on account of treading on filth in the road: but this does not mean that one is not to wash off the filth. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b2- See waToA^apN.

mawoTiy^N *
mawoTiy^N: see waToA^apN.

miyTaA^N *
miyTaA^N: see waTo'N.

A=vaArN mawoTuwo'apN *
A=vaArN mawoTuwo'apN (in a trad. respecting destiny) Tracks trodden [as it were] by past predestined events, good and evil. (TA, from a trad.)

muwaT~aA^u AlA^akonaAfi *
muwaT~aA^u AlA^akonaAfi, (K,) and AlAknAf waTiYo'u↓, (TA,) A man of easy nature, or disposition, generous, and very hospitable: or one in whose vicinity his companion is possessed of power, authority, or dignity; not harmed, nor inconveniently situated. (K.) ― -b2- All~`hum~a A@joEalohu muwaT~aA^a AlEaqibi (assumed tropical:) O God, make him to be (a Sultán, followed by many dependants, and) one whose heels shall be trod upon: (K *, TA:) an imprecation, occurring in a trad. respecting a man who had been secretly informed against to 'Omar, who said this with reference to the informer if a liar. (TA.)

waTobN *
waTobN A skin (siqaA'N) in which milk is put, (S, K,) specially used for that purpose: (S:) or a skin in which are put clarified butter and milk: (Mejma' el-Bihár, &c.:) it is made of the skin of an animal such as is termed ja*aEN, [meaning a goat in its second year,] or what is above that [in age]: (ISk, S, K:) the skin of a sucking kid, in which milk is put, is called $akowapN; and that
of one that is weaned, badorapN; and the like of a $kwp, in which clarified butter is put, Euk~apN; and the like of a bdrp, misoA^adN: (ISk, S:) see also badorapN: pl. of pauc. A^awoTubN, and of mult. wiTaAbN (S) and A^awoTaAbN, (dev. with respect to analogy, (TA,) [accord. to most grammarians; but not so accord. to Fr, because its first radical letter is w;] and pl. pl. (i. e. pl. of AwTb, TA,) A^awaATibu. (K.) ― -b2- waTobN (tropical:) A hard, rough, rude, or coarse, man: syn. rajulN jaAfK. (S, K.) ― -b3- waTobN (tropical:) A large breast: (K:) likened to the skin so called. (TA.) ― -b4- Safiratu wiTaAbuhu (tropical:) He died: or he was slain: (K:) the body's becoming empty of the soul is compared to the skin's becoming empty of the milk: or the meaning is his blood issued forth from his body: or, as some say, his skins became empty of their milk; a hostile attack having been made upon his camels, and no milch camel remaining in his possession. (TA.) [See similar sayings voce rfodN; and see Ham., p. 34.]

Tbp *
Tbp, without teshdeed, [but whether TabupN or Tibap is meant is not said,] A piece of skin, or hide: thought by ISd to be perhaps from AlwaTobu: but the word commonly known is Tb~p, with teshdeed, mentioned in art. Tb. (TA.)

waTobapN *
waTobapN, occurring in a trad., accord. to one relation, and explained by En-Nadr as signifying The kind of food called HayosN, made of dates and A^aqiT and clarified butter: but said to be erroneous: accord. to another relation, rTbp, which is erroneous: accord. to another, waTiyy^apN [q. v., app. the right reading]. (TA.) See HayosN.

waTobaA'u *
waTobaA'u (tropical:) A woman having large breasts: (S, K:) as though having a waTob; (S;) i. e., carrying a wTb of milk. (TA.)

1 waTava *
1. waTava, (aor. yaTivu, K,) inf. n. waTovu, He struck the ground vehemently with his foot: (S, K:) or he (a camel) struck vehemently with his foot: (TA:) a dial. form of waTasa, or viciously pronounced for the latter word: (S:) or the v of wTv is a substitute for the s of wTs; and the meaning is he broke: (Yaakoob:) or waTavahu, aor. yaTivuhu, inf. n. waTovN, signifies he trod, or trampled, upon it so that he broke it. (T.)

1 waTaHahu *
1. waTaHahu, aor. yaTiHu, (inf. n. TiHapN, TA,) He pushed him, or thrust him, with his hands, ungently, harshly, or violently. (K.)

6 twATH Alqawomu *
6. twATH Alqawomu The people did evil, or mischief, one to another, by turns: or fought together. (El-Umawee, S, K.) ― -b2- twATHt AlA_ibilu EalaY AlHawoDi, (TA,) or twATHt AlHawoDa, (K,) The camels crowded, or pressed together, to the tank or cistern. (K.)

waTaHN *
waTaHN [so in the S] and so written by Aboo-Sahl, but in the copies of the K waToHN, (TA,) Dung (Ear~ap) or mud that adheres to cloven hoofs, and to the claws, or talons of birds: (S, K:) n. un. with p. (TA.)

1 waTada *
1. waTada, aor. yaTidu. inf. n. waTodN (S, L, K) and TidapN; (L, K;) and wT~d↓, (K,) inf. n. tawoTiydN; (S, L;) He made a thing constant, firm, steady, steadfast, fast, or established. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- waTada, aor. yaTidu, inf. n. waTodN (S, L, K) and TidapN; (L, K;) and wT~d↓, (K,) inf. n. tawoTiydN; (S, L;) He, or it, pressed upon a thing heavily; syn. vaq~ala. (S, L, K.) ― -b3- waTadahu A_ilayohi He drew and pressed him to him; hugged him. (L, K *.) ― -b4- waTada, inf. n. waTodN, He pressed a thing to another thing, and made it fast. (AA, L.) ― -b5- waTadahu A_ilaY AlA^aroDi He pressed him to the ground [with his hand, or hands, or foot, or feet,] and kept him fixed upon it, preventing his moving: (IAth, L:) he trod upon him vehemently: (S, L:) occurring in a trad. (L.) ― -b6- waTada lahu manozilapF (tropical:) He prepared, or established, (mah~ada,) for him a station; (L, K;) as also wT~d↓. (TA.) ― -b7- waTada AlA^aroDa He closed up, (K,) and trod, (TA,) the ground, in order that it might become hard. (K, TA.) ― -b8- See 5. ― -b9- waTada He trod; trod upon; trod under foot; trampled upon; a dial. form of waTiy^a. (K.) ― -b10- waTadotu EalaY baAbi AlgaAri AlS~axora I piled up the rocks at the entrance of the cave so as to stop it up with them. (S, L.) See also 4.

2 waT~ada
2: see 1. ― -b2- wT~d A@ll~`hu lls~uloTaAni mulokahu, as also AT~dhu, (tropical:) God established, or confirmed, to the Sultán his dominion. (L.) ― -b3- waT~adahu He beat it with the implement called miyTadap. (A.)

entry.key: waqaEa Aljabalu EalaY baAbi Alkahofi faA^awoTadahu

superEntry.entry:
4 waqaEa Aljabalu EalaY baAbi Alkahofi faA^awoTadahu *
4. waqaEa Aljabalu EalaY baAbi Alkahofi faA^awoTadahu The mountain fell upon the entrance of the cavern, and stopped it up with its ruins. Occurring in a trad. IAth says, One should only say waTadahu; or perhaps wTdh is a dial. form. Another relation gives A^awoSadahu. (L.) See also 1.

5 twT~d *
5. twT~d, (S, L, K,) and At~Td↓; (L;) and waTada↓, (L, K,) inf. n. waTodN; (L;) It became constant, firm, steady, steadfast, fast, or established. (S, *, L, K.)

8 A_iwotaTada
8: see 5.

waTodapN *
waTodapN i. q. waToA^apN: so in the following words [of a trad.]; All~`hum~a A@$odudo waTodatako EalaYa muDara [O God, make thy punishment of Mudar severe!] (K *, TA.) [See also waToA^apN.]

waTiydN *
waTiydN and mawoTuwdN↓ Rendered constant, firm, steady, steadfast, fast, or established. (L, K.) See also waATidN. ― -b2- waTiydN and mawoTuwbN Pressed upon heavily; syn. muvaq~alN. (L, K.)

waTiydapN *
waTiydapN (assumed tropical:) An established station which a man holds. (Yaakoob, L.)

waTaAy^idu *
waTaAy^idu (tropical:) The foundations, or bases, or the columns, (qawaAEid,) of a building: (S, L, K:) the columns (A^asaATiyn) of a mosque. (A.) ― -b2- fulaAnN mino waTaAy^idi AlA_isolaAmi (tropical:) [Such a person is one of the columns of el-Islám.] (A.) ― -b3- waTaAy^idu (tropical:) The supports called A^avaAfiY~ of a cooking-pot: (A, K:) app. pl. of waTiydapN. (TA.)

waATidN *
waATidN Constant, firm, steady, steadfast, fast, settled, or established; as also, by transposition, TaAdK [q. v. in art. Tdw]. (S, L.) See also waTiydN, and mutawaATdN, and muwaT~adN.

mawoTuwdN *
mawoTuwdN: see waTiydN, and muwaT~adN.

miyTadapN *
miyTadapN A wooden implement with which the foundations of a building &c. are compressed, in order that they may become hard. (A, L, K.) ― -b2- A piece of wood with which a boring-instrument, or drill, is held: [i. e., a wooden socket which fits upon the top]. (S, L.)

Eiz~N muwaT~adN *
Eiz~N muwaT~adN, and mawoTuwdN↓, and waATidN↓, (tropical:) Established, or confirmed, might, or glory. (A.)

mutawaATidN *
mutawaATidN Continuous; or constant and uninterrupted; (K;) as also waATidN↓ and TaAdK. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Strong; vehement; hard. (K, TA.)

waTarN *
waTarN A want; an object of want or need: (Zj, S, A, Msb, K:) or one which one purposes to accomplish: (Lth:) or for which one is anxious, (A, K,) or desirous: (Msb:) pl. A^awoTaArN. (S, A, Msb, K.) It has no verb. (Kh, S, Msb.) You say, qaDayotu waTariY I accomplished, or obtained, my want, &c. (A, Msb, K.) And qaDayotu mino ka*aA waTariY I accomplished my want of such a thing [so as to have no further need of it: see Kur, xxxiii. 37, in two places]. (Lth.)

1 waZaba EalaY $aYo'K *
1. waZaba EalaY $aYo'K, (aor. yaZibu, K,) inf. n. wuZuwbN, (and waZobN, Msb,) He continued, to do a thing; persevered in it: (Lth, Lh, S, K:) or, (as also waZabahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, TA,) i. q. waAZaba↓, [which is the more common,] inf. n. muwaAZabahN, he kept, attended, or applied himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to a
thing; he was, or became, intent upon it; (AZ, Lh, S, K;) wAZb↓ is said to be sometimes trans. without a preposition, like laAzama; but Es-Saad denies this. (TA.) ― -b2- wuZibati Alr~awoDapu The meadow was incessantly pastured on, [so that it became destitute of herbage]. (TA.) See the pass. part. n. ― -b3- fulaAnN yuwZabu Ealayohi, and Ealayohi↓ yuwaAZabu↓, [Such a one is deprived of his property (his camels &c.) by successive misfortunes]. (TA, [but for ywZb is there written yZb.]) See the pass. part. n. ＝ -A2- waZaba, inf. n. waZobN, He trod; trod upon; trod under foot; trampled upon. (K, TA.)

3 waAoZaba
3: see 1. ― -b2- wAZbhu EalaY xidomapi fulaAn He incited him, or urged him, to keep to, or continue in, the service of such a one. (TA, from a trad.)

waZobapN *
waZobapN The vulva (HayaA', L, or jahaAz, K,) of a solid-hoofed animal. (L, K.)

waAZibN ElY ka*aA *
waAZibN ElY ka*aA, and muwaAZibN Ealayohi↓, Keeping, attending, or applying himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to such a thing; intent upon it. (Lh.)

miyZabN *
miyZabN i. q. ZurarN, (K,) which is a kind of stone. (TA.)

rajulN mawoZuwbN *
rajulN mawoZuwbN A man deprived of his property (mAl [app. meaning his camels &c.]) by successive misfortunes. (S, K.) ― -b2- A^aroDN mawoZuwbapN A land that has been pastured on by turns, so that there remains in it no herbage, or pasture. (S, K.) In like manner, rawoDapN mwZwbp: or a meadow that has been incessantly pastured on. And waAdK mwZwb A valley of which the herbage has been eaten by cattle &c., so that it has become barren, or bare. (TA.)

muwaAZibN *
muwaAZibN: see waAZbN.

1 waEabahu *
1. waEabahu, aor. yaEibu, (inf. n. waEobN, Msb;) and AwEbhu↓, (inf. n. A_iyEaAbN; Msb;) and AstwEbhu↓; (and twE~bhu↓; TA, voce taEaboEaba;) He took it altogether; took the whole of it. (K, Msb.) See 4.

4 A^awoEaba
4: see 1. ― -b2- AwEbhu (TA) and AstwEbhu↓ (S, TA) He extirpated it; eradicated it. (S, TA.) ― -b3- AwEb and AstwEb↓ He went to, or attained, the utmost limit in anything. (TA.) ― -b4- AwEb Alji*oEa (tropical:) He extirpated the trunk of a palmtree. (K.) But this is a mistake: the right reading is AwEb AljadoEa He made the mutilation (of a nose, ear, hand, or lip) to be radical, or total. (TA.) See muwEabN. ― -b5- AwEb A^anofahu He cut off the whole of his nose. (S, TA.) ― -b6- AwEbhu He cut off the whole of his tongue. (TA.) ― -b7- AsotaraTa mawozapF faA^awoEabahaA He swallowed a banana-fruit, and left nothing of it. (Lh.) ― -b8- AwEb Al$~aYo'a fiY Al$~aYo'i, (K,) and fiyhi waEabahu↓, (Az,) He put, inserted, or introduced, the whole of the thing into the [other] thing. (K, Az, Msb.) ― -b9- AwEb fiY maAlihi He lent, or paid in advance, of his property, syn. A^aslf: (IM:) or he was prodigal of his property; syn. A^asorafa: (IKtt:) or, as some say, he expended his property in every way. (TA.) ― -b10- AwEb Alqawomu (tropical:) The people collected themselves together; congregated: (S, TA:) they came all together. (TA.) ― -b11- AwEb He collected; gathered together; congregated. (K.) ― -b12- AwEb banuw fulaAnK jalaA'F falamo yaboqa bibaladihimo minohumo A^aHadN (tropical:) [The sons of such a one came all together, emigrating, so that there remained not in their country one of them]. (ISk, S.) ― -b13- AwEb banuw fulaAnK libaniY fulaAnK The sons of such a one collected together a company for the sons of such a one. (Lh.) ― -b14- AwEb Alqawomu (tropical:) The people went forth all together on a military expedition. (TA.) ― -b15- AwEbwA Alnafara They [collected together the men, and] went forth all together on a military expedition. (TA, from a trad.)

5 tawaE~aba
5: see 1.

10 A_isotawoEaba
10: see 1. ― -b2- AstwEb Al$~ayo'a (tropical:) It (a place, or a vessel,) was large enough to contain the thing; it held the thing, or received it into its capacity. (TA.) ― -b3- Aln~iEomapu AlwaAHidapu tasotawoEibu jamiyEa Eamali AlEabodi yawoma AlqiyaAmapi (tropical:) One favour [of God] will be equivalent to all the works of a man on the day of resurrection. A trad. (TA.) ― -b4- A$twEb [generally signifies He, or it, took, took in or comprised or comprehended or included, or took up or occupied, altogether, wholly, or universally; or took in the gross; engrossed: like Aisotagoraqa]. See 1: and 4, in two places. Ai*aA A@sotuwEiba jadoEuhu Ald~iyapu, said in a trad. respecting the nose, If the mutilation thereof be total, so that nothing be left of it, the [whole] price of blood [shall be paid]: (S:) or, accord. to another relation, A^uwEiba kul~uhu [If] the whole of it be cut off. (TA.)

waEobN *
waEobN A wide road. (K.) You say, TariyqN waEobN: and the pl. is wiEaAbN. (TA.) ― -b2- wiEaAbN Wide places in a land. (K.) Correctly, it is pl. of waEobN; but in the Moajam [el-Buldán] it is made a proper name of certain places. (TA.)

waEiybN *
waEiybN An ample house, or tent. (K.) An ample vessel, that takes in the whole of what is put into it. (TA.) ― -b2- jaA'a Alfarasu birakoDK waEiybK The horse came at his utmost rate. (S, K.) ― -b3- waEiybN Pudendum mulieris amplum. (TA.)

h`*aA A^awoEabu lika*aA *
h`*aA A^awoEabu lika*aA This is most proper, or fit, for the full giving, or receiving, or the like, of such a thing: syn. A^aHoraY liAsotiyfaAy^ihi. (K.) This is taken from the following words of a trad. ― -b2- nawomapN baEoda AljimaAEK A^awoEabu lilomaA'i A sleep after coitus is most proper for the complete evacuation of the semen remaining in the penis. (TA.)

jadoEN muwEabN *
jadoEN muwEabN, (also written muwEibN, TA,) A mutilation of the nose, ear, hand, or lip, by which it is extirpated. One says, in reviling, jadaEahu All~`h jadoEFA mwEbFA May God mutilate him by an utter mutilation of the nose, &c.! (S.)

jaAw^uwA muwEibiyna *
jaAw^uwA muwEibiyna (tropical:) They came having collected together all that they could: (S, K:) they came all together, not one of them remaining behind. (Msb.)

1 waEiva *
1. waEiva, aor.
waEava
, (inf. n. waEovN, TA,) and waEuva, aor.
waEuva
, (inf. n. wuEuwvapN and waEaAvapN, TA,) It (a road) was difficult to travel, (K,) and arduous to ascend. (TA.) ― -b2- waEiva, aor.
waEava
, inf. n. waEovN and waEavN; and waEuva, aor.
waEuva
, inf. n. wuEuwvapN; it (a road) was soft, and like what is termed waEovN. (ISd.) ― -b3- waEiva It (dust) was fine, and it (land) was soft, and loose, so that the feet of beasts of carriage sank in it. (TA.) ― -b4- waEivato yaduhu His hand broke. (K.)

2 wE~v *
2. wE~v, inf. n. tawoEiyvN, He withheld, or restrained, and turned, or diverted, [another from a thing]. (K.) wE~vhu Eano ka*aA He turned him, or diverted him, from such a thing; as also Ew~vhu. (Az.)

4 AwEv *
4. AwEv He came upon a tract such as is called waEovN: (S, K:) he came upon an even and soft tract: (A:) he walked along a tract such as is called waEovN. (Msb.) ― -b2- AwEv fiY maAlihi He was prodigal of his wealth, (ISk, S, K.) ＝ -A2- AwEv, inf. n. A_iyEaAvN, He confounded, or confused. (TA.)

waEovN *
waEovN A place that is even and soft, (S, K,) such as is termed dahosN, (K,) or kaviyru Ald~ahasi, (S,) in which the feet sink, (S, K,) and upon which it is troublesome to walk: (S:) or sand in which the feet of camels, &c., sink: (ISd:) and [in like manner] waEovaA'u↓ signifies that in which the hoofs of horses and the like, and the feet of camels, sink, consisting of fine sand, and what is termed dahaAs, of small pebbles: (Az, from Khálid Ibn-Kulthoom:) or waEovN signifies whatever is soft and even: (As:) or sand that is not much in quantity: or a soft place: pl. wuEovN and wuEuwvN: and [in like manner] naqFA muwaE~avN↓ an extended and gibbous tract of sand, which is soft, and in which the feet sink. (TA.) ― -b2- Also waEovN and waEivN↓ and muwaE~avN↓ A difficult road. (K.) ― -b3- huwa yamo$iY fiY AlwaEovi, and fiY AlwuEuwvi, He walks along a tract such as is called dahaAs, (and along tracts of that kind,) in which walking is laborious.
(TA.) ― -b4- waEovN (tropical:) A bone broken, (S, K,) and chipped, or notched. (S.) ― -b5- waEovN Leanness: (K:) soft leanness. (TA.) ― -b6- waEovN A corrupt and confused state of an affair: pl. wuEuwvN. (L.) ― -b7- waEovN (tropical:) Anything inconvenient, troublesome, difficult, or toilsome. (Msb.) ― -b8- A_imoraA^apN waEovapN A woman who is fat, (K,) or fleshy; (S;) as though the fingers would sink into her, by reason of her softness and fleshiness. (TA.) AmrAp waEovahu AlA^arodaAfi (tropical:) A woman having soft buttocks. (ISd.) Ru-beh says,
tumiyluhaA A^aEojaAzuhaA AlA^awaAEivu
[Her soft buttocks make her to bend]. Here AwAEv may be pl. of waEovN, contr. to analogy; or it may be pl. of A^awoEuvN, which may be pl. of waEovN. (ISd.) waEovaA'u↓ also signifies the same as waEovN. (ISd.) ― -b9- [For the prov.]
EalaY maA xuy~ilato waEovu AlqaSiymi
(TA,) [see 2, in art. xyl.]

waEivN *
waEivN: see waEovN.

wuEuwvN *
wuEuwvN Adversity; difficulty; distress; affliction; evil. (TA.) ― -b2- See waEovN.

waEovaA'u *
waEovaA'u (tropical:) Inconvenience, trouble, difficulty, or toil, (S, K,) of travel: (S:) or severity of trouble, difficulty, or toil, thereof. (A'Obeyd.) ― -b2- Also the like with respect to crimes, sins, or the like: you say, rakiba AlwaEovaA'a meaning (tropical:) He committed a crime, sin, fault, or act of disobedience. (A'Obeyd.) ― -b3- See waEovN.

muwoEuwvN *
muwoEuwvN A man deficient in rank or quality, nobility, or eminence, reputation or note or consideration, or what is termed Hasab. (S, K.)

muwaE~avN *
muwaE~avN: see waEovN.

1 waEada *
1. waEada, aor. yaEidu, inf. n. waEodN and EidapN, (S, L, Msb, K,) [in which the p is a substitute for the elided w,] or the latter is a quasi-inf. n., (L,) and mawoEidN and mawoEidapN, (L, Msb, K,) or the last is a quasi-inf. n., (L,) and mawoEuwdN and mawoEuwdapN, (L, K,) the last two being instances of inf. ns. of the measures mafoEuwlN and mafoEwulapN, (L,) He promised. (TA.) It is trans. immediately, and by means of the prep. b; (L, Msb, K;) but some say that the b is redundant in this case; and most of the lexicologists disallow it with this form of the verb, allowing it only with A^awoEada. (TA.) It is also used with reference to good and evil: (S, L, Msb, K:) you say waEadahu xayorFA [He promised him good]: and waEadahu $ar~FA (tropical:) [He threatened him with evil]: (Fr, Fs, S, L, Msb, K, &c.:) and, [accord. to some,] wEdh bixayorK, and bi$ar~. (IKoot, Msb.) When neither good nor evil is mentioned, if you mean the former, you say waEada [He promised good]: and if you mean the latter, A^awoEada↓, (Fr, T, S, L, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iyEaAdN, with which waEiydN is syn., (S, L, Msb, K,) being one irregular inf. n., [or quasiinf. n.,] (Msb,) [He threatened,] or threatened with, evil]; and A^awoEadahu↓ [He threatened him, menaced him, or threatened him with evil]; (Msb;) as also twE~dhu↓, (L, Msb,) inf. n. tawaE~udN; (S, L, K;) and At~Edhu↓. (L.) You also say xayorFA AwEd↓ [He promised good]; (IAar, T, ISd, Msb, K;) but this is extr.: (L:) and bi$ar~K AwEd↓ [He threatened, or threatened with, evil]: (S, L, Msb, K:) when b is introduced after this form of the verb, it relates only to evil: (Fs, Msb:) but you also say $ar~FA AwEdh↓. (Msb.) ― -b2- Failure of performance, with respect to a promise, the Arabs regard as a lie; but with regard to a threat, as generosity. A poet says,
waA_in~iY waA_ino A^awoEadotuhu A^awo waEadotuhu
lamuxolifu A_iyEaAdiY wamunojizu mawoEidiY
[And verily I, if I threaten him or promise him, fail to perform my threat, but fulfil my promise]. (Msb.) Nay, they do not apply the term xulofN to the failure of performing a threat. (TA.) ― -b3- yawomunaA yaEidu barodFA (tropical:) Our day promises cold. (L.) ― -b4- waEadati AlA^arD (tropical:) The land promised good produce. (A.) ― -b5- waAEadahu fawaEadahu: see 3.

3 wAEdhu *
3. wAEdhu, inf. n. muwaAEadapN, He promised him, the latter doing the same to him. (Aboo-Mo'ádh, L.) ― -b2- waAEadahu fawaEadahu He vied with him in promising, and surpassed him therein, by promising more. (L, K. *) ― -b3- waAEadhu Alwqota, and AlmawoDiEa, [He appointed with him the time, and the place]. (L, K.) A^awoEadaniY mawoEidFA is a vulgar mistake. (Aboo-Bekr, L.)

4 A^awoEada
4: see 1 throughout. ＝ -A2- AwEd, (A, L,) inf. n. A_iyEaAdN, (L,) in the sense of which waEiydN is also used [as a quasi-inf. n.], (S, A, L, K) (tropical:) He (a stallion-camel) brayed, (hadara, S, A, &c.) on his being about to attack and fight with other camels. (S, A, L.)

5 tawaE~ada
5: see 1.

6 twAEdwA *
6. twAEdwA and At~EdwA↓ signify the same, [They promised one another]: (K *, TA:) or the former relates to good, (S, Msb, K,) signifying they promised one another something good: (S, Msb,) and the latter, to evil, (S, L, K,) signifying they threatened one another: (L:) and this distinction is commonly admitted and observed. (TA.) ― -b2- tawAaEadonaA AlmawoDiEa, [and Alwaqota, We appointed mutually the place, and the time]. (Msb.)

8 At~Ed *
8. At~Ed, (A,) [aor. yat~aEidu,] inf. n. A_it~iEaAdN, (S, L, K,) He accepted a promise: (S, A, L, K:) originally A_iwotaEada; the w being changed into t and then incorporated [into the augmentative t]: some persons say A@y^otaEada, aor. yaA^otaEidu, (inf. n. A@y^otiEaAdN, TA) and pronounce the act. part. n. muw^otaEidN, with '; (S, L, K;) like as they say yaA^otasiru: (S, L:) but [if they do not change the w into t] they should say A_iytaEada, and yaAtaEidu, and muwtaEidN, without
waEuda
. (IB, L.) ― -b2- Also, He confided in the promise of another. (L.) ― -b3- See also 1: ― -b4- and 6.

waEodN *
waEodN and EidapN↓ (in which latter the p is a substitute for the [elided] w, S, L) and mawoEidN↓ and mawoEidapN↓ and mawoEuwdN↓ (A) and mawoEuwdapN↓: (L:) see 1: A promising; a promise; (A, L;) meaning, of something good: (S, L, &c.:) pl. of the first, wuEuwdN; (IJ, L;) or this has no pl.: (T, S, L, Msb:) and of the second, EidaAtN: (T, S, L, Msb:) (and of the ↓third, mawaAEidu:] and of mwEwd↓, mawaAEiydu. (L.) When Eidap is used as a prefixed n., [in a case of wasl,] the p is elided, (Fr, S, L,) and Y is substituted for it: (Fr, L:) a poet says,
waA^axolafuwka EidaY A@loA^amori A@l~a*iY waEaduwA
[And they have broken to thee the promise of the thing which they promised]. (Fr, S, L.) ― -b2- EaTiy~apN AlEidapu↓ [A promise is equivalent to a gift]: i. e., it is base to break it as it is to take back a gift. A proverb. (TA.) ― -b3- Alvry~aA waEadahu Eidapa↓ biAlqamari [He promised him as the moon promises the Pleiades]: for the moon and the Pleiades are in conjunction once in every month. Another proverb. (TA.) [Perhaps we may also read Eid~apa Alv~uzay~aA Alqamara: see mdaAd, in art. Ed.] ― -b4- A_ixolaAfu AlwaEodi mino A^axolaAqi Alwagodi [The breaking of a promise is one of the natural habits of the mean and base]. A saying of the Arabs. (MF.) ― -b5- waEodN also signifies The fulfilment of a promise. Ex. mataY h`*aA AlwaEodu, in the Kur, [x. 49, &c.] means, When shall be the fulfilment of this promise? (L.) ― -b6- Also, a thing promised. (TK, art. njz.)

EidapN *
EidapN: see waEodN, and 1.

EidiY~N *
EidiY~N Of, or relating or belonging to, a promise: rel. n. of EidapN, like ziniY~N of zinapN, formed without restoring the w like as it is restored in [the rel. n. of] $iyapN: [see art. $yw:] but Fr says EidawiY~N and zinawiY~N, like $iyawiY~N. (S, L.)

waEiydN *
waEiydN: see 1: A threatening; a threat: (S, L, K:) also written wiEiydN. (TA.) See also 4.

AlwaEiydiy~apu *
AlwaEiydiy~apu A certain sect of the xawaArij, who are extravagant in threatening; asserting that transgressors [who have been true believers] shall remain in hell for ever. (TA.)

waAEidN *
waAEidN (tropical:) A horse that promises run after run. (L, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A beast that promises to be productive of good, and fortunate. (L.) (tropical:) See an ex. in a verse cited voce maSodaq. ― -b3- (tropical:) A tree, or herbage, promising good produce. (A.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A cloud, which, as it were, promises rain. (L, K.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A day which promises heat; (L;) as also a year: (TA:) or of which the commencement promises heat; or cold. (S, L, K.) ― -b6- A^aroDN waAEidapN (tropical:) Land of which the herbage is hoped to prove good and productive, (As, S, A, L, K,) by reason of its first appearance. (As, L.)

mawoEidN *
mawoEidN signifies A covenant, or compact. So, accord. to Mujáhid, in ch. xx. vv. 89 and 90, of the Kur-án. (L.) ― -b2- mawoEidN and mawoEidapN: see 1, and waEodN. ― -b3- See also miyEaAdN.

miyEaAdN *
miyEaAdN (S, A, L, Msb, K) and mawoEidN↓ (S, A, L, Msb) A time, and a place, of promise: (S, A, L, Msb, K:) [and, of appointment; an appointed time, and place]. ― -b2- miyEaAdN A mutual promising, or promise. (S, K.)

mawoEuwdN *
mawoEuwdN and mawoEuwdapN: see 1, and waEodN ― -b2- Alyawomu AlmwEwd [The promised day; meaning] the day of resurrection. (TA.) ― -b3- maEohuwdN wama$ohuwdN wamawoEuwdN Past and present and future: the tenses of a verb. (Kh, in L, art. Ehd.) ― -b4- mawoEuwdN is one of the inf. ns. which have pls. governing as verbs; its pl. being mawaAEiydu. Ex. mawaAEiyda Euroqwb A^axaAhu biyavoriba [As 'Orkoob's promisings of his brother in Yethrib.] (IJ, ISd.) See EuroquwbN.

1 waEura *
1. waEura, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. yawoEuru; (TA;) and waEara, aor. yaEiru; (Msb, K;) and waEira, (Lh, A, K,) aor. yawoEaru (K, TA) and yaEiru; (Lh, TA;) inf. n. wuEuwrapN (S, Msb, K) and waEAarapN, (Msb, K,) of the first (Msb, TA) and second; (TA;) and waEorN, (Msb, K,) of the first (TA) and second; (Msb, TA;) and wuEuwrN, (K,) of the second only; (TA;) and waEarN, (K,) of the third: (TA:) It (a place, A, K, and a mountain, S, Msb,) was, or became, rugged; (A, K;) as also twE~r↓: (S, * A, K:) or difficult. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] twE~r↓ (tropical:) It (an affair), and he, (a man,) was, or became difficult, or hard. (K, * TA.) You say, saA^alonaA fulaAnFA HaAjapF fatawa E~ara EalayonaA (tropical:) We asked of such a one a thing wanted, and he was hard, or difficult, to us. (Sgh, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] waEura, inf. n. waEaArapN and wuEuwarpN, (tropical:) It (a thing) was, or became, little, or scanty. (K, TA.)

2 wE~rhu *
2. wE~rhu, inf. n. tawoEiyrN, He made it (a place, K, and a mountain, S,) rugged: (S, * K:) [or difficult.]

4 AwEr bihi AlT~riyqu *
4. AwEr bihi AlT~riyqu The road became rugged to him: or brought him to a rugged land. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- AwEr He came, or lighted, upon a rugged place. (A, K.) ― -b3- See also 10. ― -b4- (tropical:) His (a man's) property became little, or scanty. (K, * TA.) The man is thus likened to a rugged place without plants or herbage. (TA.) ― -b5- AwErhu (tropical:) He made it (a thing, A, K,) little, or scanty. (S, A, K.)

5 tawaE~ara
5: see 1, in two places.

10 AstwErhu *
10. AstwErhu He found it, (S, Msb,) or deemed it, (K,) namely a place, (Msb,) or a road, (A, K,) or a thing, (S, Sgh,) rugged, (S, * K,) or difficult; (Msb;) as also AwErhu↓. (Sgh, K.)

waEorN *
waEorN Rugged; contr. of saholN: (A, K:) or difficult: (Msb:) applied to a place, (TA,) and a road, (A,) and a mountain: (S, Msb:) as also waEirN↓, (A, K, or, accord. to As, this latter is not allowable, (S,) and F's assertion, that this which is said in the S is nothing, being a negation of a negation without evidence, is a thing unheard of, MF,) and waAEirN↓ and waEiyrN and A^awoEaru↓: (K:) and plain with ruggedness: and a mountain rugged, and difficult of ascent: and a place inspiring fear, and desolate: (TA:) pl. A^awoEurN, (K,) a pl. [of pauc.] of waEorN, (TA,) and wuEuwrN, (A, K,) a pl. of mult. [of the same], (TA,) and wuEuwrapN, (A,) [of the same,] and A^awoEaArN, (A, K,) a pl. [of pauc.] of waEirN and wiEiyrN. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a place where a thing is sought, (maTolabN, S, and Msb) (assumed tropical:) Difficult [of access]. (Msb.) ― -b3- Also, applied to a thing, (tropical:) Little, or scanty. (A, TA.) And you say, fulaAnN waEoru AlmaEoruwfi, meaning, (tropical:) Such a one has little goodness, beneficence, or kindness. (S, A, K.) ― -b4- It is also an imitative sequent to qaliylN; (S, K;) [but in this case it is only a corroborative;] and to watoHN: (S:) and so is waEirN↓ to maEirN, in the phrase $aEarN maEirN waEirN, (K,) meaning, (assumed tropical:) Little, scanty, hair. (TA.)

waEirN *
waEirN: see waEorN, in two places.

waEiyrN *
waEiyrN: see waEorN.

waAEirN *
waAEirN: see waEorN.

A^awoEaru *
A^awoEaru: see waEorN.

1 waEaza *
1. waEaza: see 4.

2 waE~aza
2: see 4.

4 AwEz A_ilayohi fiY ka*aA *
4. AwEz A_ilayohi fiY ka*aA, (S, K,) or bika*aA, (Mgh,) inf. n. A_iyEaAzN, (Mgh, TA,) He commanded, ordered, or enjoined, him, respecting such a thing, syn. tqd~m, (S, Mgh, K,) and A^amara, (Mgh, K,) A^ano yafoEala A^awo yatoruka that he should do [it] or not do [it]; (K;) as also Alyh wE~z↓, (S, K *) inf.n tawoEiyzN; (S;) and (sometimes S) Alyh waEaza↓, (S, K, *) inf. n. waEozN; (S;) which are also explained by qad~ama [signifying the same as taqad~ama and A^amara]: or the first and second are correct, accord. to ISk, but the last (waEaza) is not allowable, accord. to him, nor is it, as related by AHát, accord. to As. (TA.)

1 waEaZahu *
1. waEaZahu, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor. yaEiZu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. waEoZN and EiZapN, (S, Msb, K,) in which the p is a substitute for the elided w, (TA,) and EaZapN, (TA,) and mawoEiZapN, (K,) in which the p is not to denote the fem. gender, because this is not real, (TA,) or this last is a simple subst., (Msb,) He exhorted him, admonished him, or warned him; he put him in fear: (IF:) he exhorted him to obedience; commanded him to obey: (Msb:) he gave him good advice, or counsel; and reminded him of the results of affairs: (S:) he reminded him by informing him of that which should make the heart tender: (Kh:) he reminded him of that which should soften his heart, by the mention of reward and punishment. (K.) It is said in the Kur, [xxxiv. 45,] A_in~amaA A^aEiZkumo biwaAHidapK I only exhort you, or command you, to do one thing. (Msb.) And you say, wuEiZa bigayorihi [He was exhorted, admonished, or warned, by the example of another: see 8]. (S.) [And wEaZa, alone, He preached a sermon or sermons.]

8 A_it~aEaZa *
8. A_it~aEaZa [He became exhorted, admonished, warned, or put in fear:] he obeyed, or conformed to, [an exhortation to obedience, or] a command, and restrained himself: (Msb:) he accepted good advice, and the being reminded of the results of affairs: (S:) he became reminded of that which should soften his heart, by the mention of reward and punishment. (K.) It is said, Als~aEiydu mano wuEiZa yigayorihi waAl$~aqiY~u mano A@t~aEaZa bihi gayoruhu [The happy is he who is exhorted, or admonished, or warned, by the example of another, and the unhappy is he by the example of whom another becomes exhorted, or admonished, or warned]. (S, L.)

EiZapN *
EiZapN: see 1. ― -b2- [As a simple subst.,] it has for its pl. EiZaAtN: and is syn. with mawoEiZapN↓: (TA:) [the pl. of the latter is mawaAEiZu.] It is said in trad., laA^ajoEalan~aka EiZapF I will assuredly make thee a warning, or an example, to others. (TA.) And in the Kur, [ii. 276,] famano jaA='ahu mino rab~ihi mawoEiZapN↓ [But he to whom cometh an
exhortation, or an admonition, or warning, from his Lord]. (TA.) And AlqatoluwbiAlmawoEiZapi↓ [The slaying by way of warning], mentioned in a trad., is when the innocent is slain in order that he who gives reason for suspicion may become warned. (TA.)

waE~aAZN *
waE~aAZN: see waAEiZN.

waAEiZN *
waAEiZN [One who exhorts, admonishes, warns, or puts in fear:] one who exhorts to obedience; who commands to obey: (Msb:) one who gives good advice, or counsel; [who reminds of the results of affairs; &c.: and a preacher of a sermon or sermons: see 1:] and in like manner waE~aAZN↓ [one who exhorts, &c., much, or frequently]: (TA:) pl. of the former wuE~aAZN. (Msb, TA.)

mawoEiZapN *
mawoEiZapN: see 1: ― -b2- and EiZapN, in three places.

1 waguba *
1. waguba, aor. yawogubu, inf. n. wuguwbapN (and wagaAbapN, IM and others), He (a camel) was, or became, large, big, or bulky. (S, K.)

wagobN *
wagobN What is of a mean sort, of the utensils and furniture of a house, or tent: (S, K:) pl. A^awogaAbN and wigaAbN: (K:) the former, of pauc.; the latter, of mult. (TA.)
