The Awgb of a house, or tent, are the wooden bowl and the stone cooking-pot and the like: (S:) [as also A^awoqaAb]. ― -b2- A sack, such as is called giraArap: (K:) but this is included among the meaner sort of the utensils of a house, or tent; and is therefore not particularly mentioned by any of the lexicographers except T. (TA.) ― -b3- wagobN (As, S, K) and wagabapN (Th, K) Stupid: foolish; of little sense: (S, K:) i. q. lagobN, a weak, stupid, man: (TA, voce lgb:) pl. as above. (K, TA.) See also waqobN. ― -b4- wagobN Weak in body: (as also wagodN: TA:) pl. as above. (K.) ― -b5- Base; mean; vile.: (as also wagodN: TA:) pl. as above. (K.) ― -b6- wagobN A large, big, or bulky, camel: (S, K:) pl. as above: fem. with p. (K.)

1 waguda *
1. waguda, aor.
waguda
, (S, K, &c.,) inf. n. wugaAdapN, (L, Msb, K,) He was, or became, a low, or ignoble, mean, or sordid, and weak person, (S, Msb,) who served for the food of his belly: (S, L, Msb:) or light, (L,) stupid, and weak (L, K) in intellect, (L,) low, or ignoble, and mean, or sordid; (L, K;) or weak in body: (L, K:) or light in intellect: or weak as is a slave. (Msb.) ― -b2- wagada Alqawoma, aor. yagidu, (S, L,) inf. n. wagodN, (L,) He served the people; acted as a servant to them. (S, L.)

3 wAgdhu *
3. wAgdhu, (L,) inf. n. muwaAgadapN, (S, L, K,) He (a man) did like as he (another man) did: (L, K:) accord. to some, specially in pace, or in going, or marching; (L;) he went like him; or kept pace with him: (S *, L:) and he ran with him; or vied with him in running: (K:) you say waAgadati Aln~aAqapu AlA^uxoraY the she-camel went like, or kept pace with, the other: (L:) and sometimes the term muwaAgadapN is used in relation to a single she-camel, because one of her fore legs, and her hind legs, moves with (tuwaAgidu) the other. (As, S, L, K.)

wagodN *
wagodN A low, or ignoble, mean, or sordid, and weak person, (S, A, Msb:) who serves for the food of his belly: (S, A, L, Msb:) or light, (L,) stupid, weak (L, K) in intellect, (L,) low, or ignoble, and mean, or sordid: (L, K:) or weak in body: (L, K:) or light in intellect: (Msb:) or weak; as is a slave: (Umm-El-Heythem, Msb:) or who eats and carries away. (Expos. of the Lámeeyeh of Et-Tughráee.) ― -b2- A servant of a people. (L, K.) ― -b3- A slave. (L, K.) ― -b4- A boy. (L, K.) ― -b5- Pl. A^awogaAdN (A, L, Msb, K) and wugodaAnN and wagodaAnN. (L, K.) ― -b6- A certain arrow, (S, A, L, K,) of those used in the game called Almayosir, (S, L,) to which no portion, or share, pertains. (S, A, L, K.) Accord. to the A, this is the original signification. (TA.) ― -b7- The fruit of the baA*inojaAn. (L, K.) ― -b8- AlmuwaAgadapu A certain game (K) of the Arabs, in which one player does like as the other does. (TA.) ― -b9- See also 3.

1 wagaratohu Al$~amosu *
1. wagaratohu Al$~amosu The sun fell vehemently upon him. (A.) ― -b2- wagarati AlhaAjirapu, (K,) aor. tagiru, (K, * TA,) inf. n. wagorN, (TA,) The summer-midday was, or became, intensely, or vehemently, hot. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- [Hence, (see wagorN,)] wagira Sadoruhu, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yawogaru (S, Msb, * K, *) and yiyogaru, with kesr to the first letter, (Fr, K,) [an irreg. form,] like yiyjalu; (TA;) and wagara, aor yagiru; (K, TA;) but yawogaru is more common than yagiru; (Az, TA;) inf. n. wagarN, (S, Msb, K,) of the former, (S, Msb,) and wagorN, (K,) [of the latter,] or wagorN is a simple subst., and the inf. n. is wagarN; (S, * Msb, [but perhaps this is said because only the former of the two verbs is mentioned in the S and Msb];) His bosom was, or became, affected with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, and enmity; and burned with wrath, or rage; (S, A, Msb, K;) EalaY fulaAnK against such a one: (S, A: *) or became filled with wrath, or rage, (Msb, TA,) and rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite: (TA:) or burned by reason of intense, or violent, wrath, or rage: (TA:) and twg~r↓ he (a man, TA,) burned, and was, or became, hot, with wrath, or rage. (K, TA.) You say also, wagira EalaY~a fulaAnN, aor. yygaru, [see above, Such a one became affected with rancour, &c.; or burned with wrath, or rage; against me]. (Fr, TA.)

2 wag~ara
2: see 4, in two places.

4 AwgrwA *
4. AwgrwA They entered upon the summer-midday when the heat was intense, or vehement. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Awgr AlmaA='a He heated the water, (K, TA,) by putting into it heated stones: (TA:) or i. q. A^aHoraqahu: (TA:) ― -b2- He made the water to boil. (S, K.) Sometimes, a live pig has its hair scalded off in it, and is then slaughtered: (S, K:) or, accord. to some lexicons, is then roasted. (TA.) This is done by certain Christians. (S, K.) You say A^awogara Aln~aSaAraY Alxinoziyra The Christians boiled some water, and scalded off the hair of a live pig in it, and then slaughtered it. (A.) ― -b3- Awgr All~abana, He made the milk what is termed wagiyr and wagiyrap; as also, wg~rhu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. tawogiyrN. (S.) ＝ -A3- Awgrhu He made him to be affected with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, and enmity, and to burn with wrath; or rage: (K:) or he made him to be affected with wrath, or rage: (A:) [in like maner,] wg~rhu↓ Ealayohi, (TK,) inf. n. tawogiyrN, (K,) he incited him to rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against him. (K, * TK.) You say also, A^awogarotu Sadorahu EalaY fulaAnK I made his bosom hot with wrath, or rage, against such a one. (S.)

5 tawag~ara
5: see 1.

wagorN *
wagorN Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, and enmity; and a burning with wrath, or rage; (S, A, K;) as also wagarN↓; (A, K;) or the latter is an inf. n., (S, TA,) but the former is a simple subst.: (TA:) or the state of being filled with wrath, or rage: (Msb:) from wagorapN, explained below. (S.) You say, fiY Sadorihi EalaY~a wagorN In his bosom is rancour, &c., against me. (S,) And *ahaba wagoru Sadorihi The rancour, &c., of his bosom departed. And Alhadiy~apu tu*ohibu wagora AS~adori The gift dispelleth the rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, and the heat, of the bosom. (TA.)

wagarN *
wagarN: see wagorN.

wagorapN *
wagorapN, (S, K,) and wagorapu Har~K, (Msb,) Intenseness, or vehemence, of heat: (Msb, K:) or of the burning thereof, (S, TA,) when the sun is in the meridian. (TA.) You say, nazalonaA fiY wagorapi AlqayoTi EalaY maA='i ka*aA We alighted during the intense midday heat at such a water. (TA.)

wagiyrN *
wagiyrN Milk into which heated stones are thrown, and which is then drunk: (K:) or (so accord. to the TA; but in the K, and) milk boiled and cooked: (K:) or milk made hot with heated stones; as also wagiyrapN↓: (S:) or the latter, or pure milk alone, heated until it is thoroughly cooked; and sometimes clarified butter is put into
it. (ISd, TA.) ― -b2- Also, Flesh-meat roasted upon heated stones: (Lth, TA:) or upon stones heated by the sun. (L, K.)

wagiyrapN *
wagiyrapN: see wagiyrN.

huwa waAgiru AlS~adori *
huwa waAgiru AlS~adori He has the bosom [affected with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, and enmity, and] burning with wrath, or rage; EalaY~a against me: (TA:) or filled with wrath, or rage. (Msb.)

karihati AlxanaAziyru AlHamiyma Almuw gara *
karihati AlxanaAziyru AlHamiyma Almuw gara The pigs hated the boiled hot water. A proverb. (TA.) See 4.

1 wafada Ealayohi *
1. wafada Ealayohi, (S, M, A, K,) [in the Msb, wafida, but this appears to be a mistake,] and A_ilayohi, (M, K,) aor. yafidu, (M, K,) inf. n. wufuwdN (M, A, K) and wafodN (M, K) and wifaAdapN, (M, A, K,) or this last is a simple subst., (S,) and A_ifaAdapN, (M, K,) in which the w is changed into A_, (M,) He came to him, (S, M, A, K,) namely, to a king, (A,) or governor, (S, A,) or great man, ('Ináyeh,) as an ambassador, envoy, or messenger; (S, A;) or to convey gifts, and to ask aid, or assistance: ('Ináyeh:) or he went forth to him, namely, to a king, or governor. (As, L.)

2 waf~ada
2: see 4.

4 Awfdhu Ealayohi *
4. Awfdhu Ealayohi, (M, A, K,) and A_ilayohi, (S, M, K,) inf. n. A_iyfaAdN; (K;) and A_ilayohi wf~dhu↓, (L,) inf. n. tawofiydN; (K;) He sent him to him, (S, M, A, K,) namely, to a king, (A,) or governor, (S,) [or great man, as an ambassador, envoy, or messenger; or to convey gifts, and to ask aid, or assistance: see 1]. ― -b2- AlA^amiyru A_ilaY AlA^amiyri Al~a*iY wf~dhu↓ fawotahu [The governor, sent him as an envoy to the governor who was above him]. (L.) ― -b3- maA A^awofadaka EalayonaA (assumed tropical:) [What hath caused thee to come to us?]. (TA.) ― -b4- bayonamaA A^anaA fiYDiyqK A_i*o A^awofada A@ll~`hu EalaY~a birajulK faA^axorajaniY manohu (tropical:) While I was in difficulty, lo, God brought to me a man, and extricated me from it. (A.) ＝ -A2- Awfd EalaY Al$~aYo'i, inf. n. A_iyfaAdN, (tropical:) It rose up, or stood up, so as to be higher than the thing; overtopped it; overpeered it; overhung it; overlooked it. (S, L, K *.) A poet (Homeyd Ibn-Thór El-Hilálee, TA) says,
taraY AlEilaAfiY~a EalayohaA muwfidaA
kaA^an~a barojFA fawoqahaA mu$ay~adaA
[Thou seest the 'Iláfee saddle overtopping her, as though a high-raised tower were upon her.] (S, L.) And one says of a horse, maA A^aHosana maA A^awofada HaArkuhu How beautiful is the prominence of his withers! (S, L.) twf~d↓ is also syn. with Awfd in the above sense. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Awfd inf. n. A_iyfaAdN, (tropical:) It (a white antelope) raised its head and erected its ears. (L, K.) ― -b3- Awfd, inf. n. A_iyfaAdN, He hastened, or went, quickly: (S, L, K:) occurring in the poetry of Ibn-Ahmar. (S, L.) ― -b4- Awfd, inf. n. A_iyfaAdN, (tropical:) It rose, or became elevated. (A, L, K.) ― -b5- Awfd, (tropical:) He raised, or elevated, a thing. (L.)

5 twf~dt AlA_ibilu *
5. twf~dt AlA_ibilu, and AlT~ayoru, (assumed tropical:) The camels, and the birds, strove to outgo, or outstrip, one another. (L.) ― -b2- twf~dt AlA^awoEaAlu fawoqa Aljabali (tropical:) The mountain-goats ascended upon the mountain. (A.) ― -b3- See 4.

6 twAfdnA Ealayohi *
6. twAfdnA Ealayohi [We came together as ambassadors, or envoys, &c., to him: see 1]. (A.)

10 A_isotawofadaniY *
10. A_isotawofadaniY (assumed tropical:) [app. He asked, or desired, me to come]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Astwfd (tropical:) He elevated himself, and made himself erect, in his manner of sitting; (A;) a dial. form of Astwfz [q. v.] (S.)

wafodN *
wafodN: see waAfidN. ― -b2- AlHaAj~u wafodu A@ll~`hi (tropical:) [The pilgrims of Mekkeh are the ambassadors of God]. (A.) ― -b3- wafodu A@ll~`hi valaAavapN AlgaAziY waAHaAj~u waAlmuEotamiru (tropical:) [The ambassadors of God are three; the warrior, and the pilgrim of Mekkeh, and the performer of the ceremonies of the Eumorap]. A tradition. (L *, El-Jámi' es-Sagheer.) ＝ -A2- wafodN The upper part of an elevated long tract (Habol: in some copies of the K, jabal:) of sand. (S, L, K.)

wafaAdapN *
wafaAdapN, subst. from wafada Ealayohi, (S,) A coming to a king, (A,) or governor, (S, A,) [or the like,] as an ambassador, envoy, or messenger, [&c.: see 1]. (S, A.) ― -b2- lahu wifaAdapN [a phrase of frequent occurrence in notices of companions of Mohammad, meaning, He had the honour of coming as an envoy to the Prophet]. (TA, passim; and other works.)

waAfidN *
waAfidN A man coming to a king, (A,) or governor, (S, A,) [or great man,] as an ambassador, or envoy, or messenger; (S, A;) [or to convey gifts, and to ask aid, or assistance: See 1:] pl., (S, L,) or [rather] this first is a quasi-pl. n., (L,) wafodN↓ (S, A, L, K) and wuf~adN (K) and wuf~aAdN; (A, Msb;) and pl. of wafodN, A^awoqaAdN and wufuwdN: (S, L, Msb, K:) wafodN is also explained as signifying a party that assembles together and comes to a country or town: and a party that repairs to princes, or governors, to visit, and to ask aid, or assistance, or some benefit, &c.: (L:) and a party that comes to a king respecting an affair of conquest, or for congratulation, or the like: (Mgh:) and a company chosen to go forth for the purpose of having an interview with great men: (En-Nawawee:) and a company of riders: (Jel, xix. 88:) and a company riding and honoured: (Zj, in explanation of the same verse of the Kur-an:) but from the explanations in the K, and other lexicons, it seems to signify a party coming, whether walking or riding, chosen for the purpose of having an interview with great men, or not: the explanations of En-Nawawee and some others may be in accordance with general or conventional acceptations, and those of the rest may be proper, or literal. (TA.) ― -b2- waAfidN (tropical:) A camel, (S, A, K,) or bird, (A,) or bird of the kind called AlqaTaA, (K,) that precedes the others (S, A, K) in pace, and in coming to water. (A.) ― -b3- AlwaAfidaAni (in the poetry of ElAasha, S, L) (tropical:) The parts of the two cheeks which project when one chews, and which become depressed when one grows old. (S, A, L, K.) One says of a very old man, gaAba waAfidaAhu (tropical:) [The middles of his cheeks have become depressed]. (A.)

humo EalaY A^awofaAdK *
humo EalaY A^awofaAdK They are upon a journey: (L, K:) as also A^awofaAzK. (TA.)

muwfidN *
muwfidN (tropical:) Prominent, or elevated: (A, L:) applied to a camel's hump, (A,) and to the pubes. (L.)

musotawofidN *
musotawofidN (tropical:) Erecting himself, and not placing himself at his case, in his manner of sitting; (L;) i. q. musotawofizN. (L, K.)

2 waf~ara
2: see wafarahu, and what follows it in the same paragraph.

4 A^awofara
4: see wfarahu.

5 tawaf~ara
5: see wafara. ― -b2- twf~r Ealayohi (tropical:) He was regardful of those things pertaining to him (namely his companion, A) which one is under an obligation to respect or honour; (S, A, K;) and held loving communion, commerce, or intercourse, with him. (TA.) ― -b3- twf~r EalaY ka*aA (tropical:) He turned his purpose, or intention, or strong determination or resolution, (him~atahu,) toward such a thing. (A, Mgh, Msb.)

8 A_iwotafara
8: see wafara.

10 A_isotawofara
10: see wafara: ＝ -A2- and see wafarahu, in two places.

waforN *
waforN: see wufuwrN. ― -b2- Also, [an inf. n. used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predodominates] Much, or abundant, property, (Lth, T, S,) of which nothing is deficient: (Lth, T:) what is much, abundant, ample, or copious, of property, and of goods, or commodities, or household furniture and utensils; (M, A, K;) whereof nothing is deficient: (TA:) or what is generally, or universally, comprehensive, (EaAm~N,) of anything: (M, A, K:) pl. wufuwrN. (M, K.) See also waAfrN.

firapN *
firapN: see wufuwrN.

waforapN *
waforapN: see wufuwrN. ― -b2- Also, Hair collected together upon the head: or hair hanging down upon the ears: or hair extending beyond the lobe of the ear: (M, K:) or hair extending to the lobe of the ear: (S:) or hair (T, Mgh, Msb) such as is termed jum~ap, (T, A, Mgh,) extending to the ears: (T, A, Mgh, Msb:) it is said to be larger than what is termed jum~ap; but this is a mistake: (M:) the order is this: first, the waforap; then, the jum~ap; then, the lim~ap: (S, M, K:) the second of these three is what extends beyond the ears; (M;) and the third is what descends upon the shoulder-joints: (S, M:) pl. wifaArN. (M, K.)

wufuwrN *
wufuwrN and waforN↓ and waforapN↓ and firapN↓ [are inf. ns., (see 1,) used as simple substs.,] all signify the same: (S, TA:) Fulness, completeness, perfectness, wholeness, or entireness: (S:) or muchness, abundance, ampleness, or copiousness: (TA:) and the second also, richness; or competence. (A, K.) You say, h`*ihi A^aroDN fiY nabotihaA waforN, (S,) and waforapN↓, (S, A,) and firapN↓, (S, A, K,) i. e., wufuwrN, (S, A, TA,) This is land in the herbage of which is fulness, &c., (S,) or abundance; (TA;) the herbage of which has not been pastured upon. (S, A, TA.) And huwa fiY waforapK mina AlmaAl [He is in possession of abundance of property]. (A.)

waAfirN *
waAfirN and mawofuwrN↓ and muwaf~arN↓ and mutawaf~irN↓ [and A^awofaru↓ and waforN↓] all signify the same: [i. e., Full, without lack or defect, full-sized, complete, perfect, whole, or entire: or much, abundant, ample, or copious.] (A, TA.) You say, maAlN waAfirN and nabaAtN waAfirN, &c., [Full, or complete, &c., or] much, or abundant, property, and herbage, &c., (TA.) And $aYo'N mawofuwrN↓ A thing that is full, complete, &c. (S.) And jazaA='N muwaf~arN↓ A recompense of which nothing is deficient. (TA.) And Al$~aEari fulaAnN muwaf~aru↓ (tropical:) Such a one has his hair left to become abundant and long. (TA.) And siqaA='N A^awofaru↓, (T, S, A, K,) and waforN↓, (Sgh, K,) A skin for milk, or water, made of hide of which nothing is deficient. (T, S, A, K.) And in like manner, mazaAdapN waforaA='u A leather water-bag made of a complete skin; (S, M, A, K;) nothing thereof being deficient: (S, TA:) also signifying a leather water-bag filled (M, K, * TA) completely. (M, TA.) And A^aroDN waforaA='u↓ Land in the herbage of which is abundance: (M, K, * TA:) and land of which the herbage has not been diminished. (S, K.) And A^u*unN waforaA='u↓ An ear having a large lobe: (M:) or a large ear, (K, TA,) large in the lobe. (TA.) You say also, humo mutawaAfiruwna↓ They are numerous. (S, K.) ― -b2- AlwaAfiru The fourth metre (baHor) in prosody; (M, * K;) the measure of which consists of mufaAEalatuno six times [in its original state]: (Sgh, K:) or, [in practice,] mufaAEalatuno mufaAEalatuno faEuwluno, twice: or mufaAEalatuno mufaAEalatuno, twice: (M, L:) so called because its feet are made full like those of the kaAmil, except that there is [in practice] an elision in their letters, so that it is not complete. (M, L.)

A^awofaru *
A^awofaru, fem. waforaA='u, [pl. wuforN:] see faAfirN.

muwaf~arN *
muwaf~arN: see waAfirN, in three places. ― -b2- tarakotuhu EalaY A^aHosani muwaf~arK (tropical:) I left him in the best state, or condition. (TA.)

mawofuwrN *
mawofuwrN: see waAfirN.

mutawaf~rN *
mutawaf~rN: see waAfirN.

mutawAfirN *
mutawAfirN: see waAfirN.

3 wAfzhu *
3. wAfzhu He hastened with him; vied, or strove, with him in hastening; or made haste to be, or get, before him; syn. EaAjalahu. (A, TA.)

4 Awfzhu *
4. Awfzhu He hastened him. (K.)

5 twf~z *
5. twf~z He prepared himself (A, K) lika*aA for such a thing, (A,) or lil$~ar~i for evil, or mischief. (K.) ― -b2- Also, He turned over and over upon his bed. (A.) See also 10.

10 Astwfz fiY qiEodatihi *
10. Astwfz fiY qiEodatihi He put himself in an upright posture, not at his ease, in his manner of sitting; he sat erect, not at his ease: (S, Mgh, K:) or he put down his knees [upon the ground] and raised his buttocks: (Aboo-Mo'ádh, K:) or he raised himself upon his legs, or feet, without
having yet set himself firmly in a standing posture, but having prepared himself to leap, or spring, (Lth, K, TA,) or to go away: (Lth, TA:) or he sat in a posture as though he desired to rise and stand up; whether in the manner termed A_iqoEaA=' [i. e. sitting upon the ground with the shanks erect], or otherwise. (MF.)

wafozN *
wafozN and wafazN↓ Haste: pl. (of the latter, TA,) A^awofaAzN. (S, K.) You say, naHonu EalaY A^awofaAzK, (S, K,) and EalaY wafazK, (K,) We are in haste: (K:) or we are on a journey; [like Ealay A^awofaAdK;] the time of our journeying has come. (S, TA.) And laqiytuhu EalaY A^awofaAzK, and EalaY wafazK, I found him in a state of haste: (Az, TA:) or preparing [his apparatus for travel]. (M, TA.)

wafazN *
wafazN: see wafozN.

wafazapN *
wafazapN An upright posture in sitting, so that one is not at his ease. (Lth, TA.) See 10.

mutawaf~izN *
mutawaf~izN Turning over and over upon the bed, scarcely sleeping: (K, * TA:) mentioned by Z, and by Sgh in the O, on the authority of Ibn- 'Abbád. (TA.)

musotawofizN *
musotawofizN act. part. n. of 10, q. v. One says, A_iTomay^in~ faA_in~iY A^araAka musotawofizFA [Be thou at ease, for I see thee to be sitting in an upright and uneasy posture]. (TA.)

1 wafaDa *
1. wafaDa, (A, Mgh, K.) aor. yafiDu, (K,) inf. n. wafoDN (A, K) and wafaDN; (IDrd, K;) and AwfD↓, (S, Mgh, K,) and AstwfD↓; (S, K;) He ran: (A, Mgh, K:) he hastened, or went quickly. (S, A, Mgh, K.) Hence, in the Kur. [lxx. 43,] kaA^an~ahumo A_ilaY nuSubK yuwfiDuwna↓, or naSobK, As though they were hastening, or going quickly, to a thing set up for worship. (Fr, S, TA.) You say also wafaDati AlA_ibalu The camels hastened, or went quickly: (M:) or went the pace termed xabab. (Khaleefeh El-Hoseynee.) And The camels became dispersed: (AA:) and AstwfDt↓ they became dispersed (K, TA) in their pasturing. (TA.)

4 AwfD *
4. AwfD: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also, He made a she-camel to go the pace termed xabab; as also AwDf. (Khaleefeh El-Hoseynee.) And He dispersed camels. (The same, and K.) See also 10. ＝ -A3- AwfD lahu He spread for him a carpet, or the like, by which to preserve himself from the ground; (K, TA;) as also AwDm. (TA)

10 AstwfD *
10. AstwfD: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also, He required, or commanded, another to hasten, or be quick, or he hastened, hurried, or urged, him. (S, M, A, K, [but in the M; it seems to relate to camels, or an ostrich.]) ― -b2- He drove away (S, M, K) camels, or an ostrich; as also AwfD↓: (M:) he drove away, or expelled, another from his country: (M:) he banished him. (Mgh, K.)

wafoDN *
wafoDN (S, M, K,) and wafaDN↓ (M, K) Haste: (S, M, K:) [like wafozN and wafazN:] pl. A^awofaADN. (K.) You say, jaA='a EalaY wafoDK, and wafaDK↓, and A^awofaADK, He came in haste. (M.) And laqiytuhu EalaY A^awofaADK I found him in a state of haste: (S, K:) like A^awofaAzK. (S.)

wafaDN *
wafaDN: see wafoDN, in two places.

wafoDapN *
wafoDapN A pastor's [bag of the kind called] xariyTap, for his implements and provisions, (M, K,) which he carries therein. (M.) ― -b2- And hence, as being likened thereto, (M,) A [quiver of the kind called] jaEobap, (M, K,) or a thing like the jaEobap. (S,) for arrows, (M,) of skins, or hides, (S, M, K,) in which is no wood: (S, M:) or [a quiver] smaller than the jEbp, having its upper and lower parts of equal size: the jEbp is round and wide, and has a cover on the top, over its mouth: [see the latter word:] (ISh:) pl. wifaADN (S, M, A, K) and wafaDaAtN. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Also, A thing like a quiver (kinaAnap), (Fr, M,) of small size, (Fr,) in which a man of the class called A^awofaAD puts his food. (Fr, M.) ― -b4- Also, The small depression between the two mustaches, beneath the nose, (K, TA,) of a man. (TA.)

A^awofaADN *
A^awofaADN Parties of men: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) a mixed multitude: (A'Obeyd, M, K:) from wafaDati AlA_ibalu meaning “ the camels became dispersed: ” (AA:) or poor, weak, defenceless people: (L:) or an assemblage, (K,) or a mixed multitude or collection, (S,) from various tribes, such as the A^aSoHaAbu AlS~uf~api: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) or a company of whom every one has a wafoDap for his food, (Fr, M, K,) i. e. a thing resembling a kinaAnap, (Fr, M,) of small size, (Fr,) in which he puts his food; (Fr, M;) but this explanation is disapproved by A'Obeyd (TA) [and by ISd]: or AlA^awofaADu applies to the persons called A^aholu AlS~uf~api, (M,) who were a mixed multitude (A'Obeyd, M) from various tribes, (A'Obeyd,) consisting of ninety-three men. (TA.) [See Suf~apN.]

miyfaADN *
miyfaADN Going quickly, or swiftly; applied to a she-camel, (S, M, K,) and to an ostrich. (S, M.)

musotawufiDN *
musotawufiDN Going quickly, or hastening, by reason of fright; (As;) or running away by reason of fright; as though desiring his wafoD, or running: (Sgh:) or frightened. (TA.)

1 waqaba AlZ~alaAmu *
1. waqaba AlZ~alaAmu The darkness came in upon the people. (S, K *.) ― -b2- So in the verse of the Kur. [cxiii. 3,] wamino $ar~i gaAsiqK A_i*aA waqaba And from the mischief of night when it cometh in upon men; (S;) [for other explanations see gaAsiqN in art. gsq.] ― -b3- waqabati Al$~amosu, (inf. n. waqobN and wuquwbN, K,) (tropical:) The sun set: (S, K:) entered its place [of setting.] (S.) ― -b4- waqaba Alqamaru, (inf. n. wuquwbN, TA,) The moon entered upon a state of eclipse; (K;) entered into the cone-shaped shade of the earth. (TA.) ― -b5- waqabato EayonaAhu (and simply waqaba, TA,) His eyes became sunk, or depressed, in his head. (S.) ― -b6- waqaba, aor. yaqibu, inf. n. waqobN and waqiybN, He (a horse) made a sound with his prepuce: [in the S and K, the verb is not mentioned, but only the latter of the two inf. ns., which is explained as signifying “ the sounding of a horse's prepuce: ”] or made a sound by the motion of his penis in its prepuce. (TA.) ― -b7- waqaba, aor. yaqibu, inf. n. waqobN It (a thing) entered: (S:) but it is said in a marginal note in a copy of the S, that the inf. n. is correctly wuquwbN, because the verb is intrans.: accord. to some, it signifies he, or it, entered into a waqobN, q. v.; and in the K, waqobN is given as the inf. n. of the verb in this sense. (TA.) [In the CK, waqot is put by mistake for waqob.] ― -b8- waqaba, [aor. yuqibu,] inf. n. waqobN and wuquwbN, He, or it, became absent, hidden, or concealed. (K.) ― -b9- waqaba [aor. yaqibu,] inf. n. waqobN, He, or it, came; approached; advanced. (K.)

4 Awqb Aln~axolu *
4. Awqb Aln~axolu The palm-tree became rotten in the fruit-bearing stalks of its racemes. (TA.) ― -b2- Awqb He (K), or it, (a people, S,) hungered; suffered hunger. (S, K.) ― -b3- Awqb $ayoy^FA, (inf. n. A_iyqaAbN, TA,) He put a thing into a waqobap, q. v.: (Fr, S, K:) or, as in some Lexicons, into a waqob. (TA.)

waqobN *
waqobN A small hollow, or cavity, (nuqorapN,) in which water collects, in a mountain: (S:) or in a rock: as also waqobapN↓: (K:) or, accord. to some, wqb is a coll. gen. n., of which wqbp is the n. un.: (MF:) pl. A^awoqaAbN: (TA:) or waqobN, accord. to the K, (but accord. to the TA waqobapN↓,) signifies what is like a well, in a tract of hard and large stones that produce no plants, a fathom, or two fathoms, in depth, (K,) in which the rain-water stagnates. (TA.) ― -b2- The cavity, or socket, of the eye: (S:) any cavity, or socket, in the body; as that of the eye, and that of the shoulder-blade: (K:) pl. wuquwbN and wiqaAbN. (TA.) ― -b3- The pit, or cavity, above the eye of a horse: (K:) pl. wuquwbN and wiqaAbN. (TA.) ― -b4- The hole into which enters the axle of a pulley. (K.) ― -b5- See also waqobapN. ＝ -A2- Stupid; foolish; of little sense: (S, K:) like wagobN: (S:) an epithet of a man: pl. A^awoqaAbN: (K, TA:) fem. with p. (TA.) ― -b2- So in the following trad. of El-Ahnaf: A_iy~aAkumo waHamiy~apa AlA^awoqaAbi [Beware of the care with which stupid people defend their rights: a proverb]. (TA.) For AlAwqAb, another relation substitutes AlA^awgoAb, meaning the same, or weak persons. (TA,
art. wgb, on the authority of AA.) ― -b3- See A^awoqaAbN ― -b4- A despised, or contemptible, low, base, or ignoble, man. (Th, K.)

qibapN *
qibapN The thing that is in the belly, resembling the faHiv: (TA:) the A_inofaH~ap [a name given to the stomach of a sucking kid, &c.] when it has grown large, of a $Ap, [i. e., a sheep or goat or the like]: (K:) not in any animals but those termed $A': (IAar:) mentioned before, in art. qb, [q. v., where it is also written qib~apN]. (TA.)

waqobapN *
waqobapN A large aperture, or hole, in a wall, in which is shade: (K:) pl. A^awoqaAbN. ― -b2- See waqobN. ― -b3- waqobapu Alv~ariydi, (S, K,) and Ald~uhoni, (K,) but the latter is a mistake, and the correct word is Almudohuni, [a vase for ointment], (TA,) i. q. A^anoquwEatuhu, [i. e., its cavity or hollow]. (S, K.) Lth says, that waqobN↓ signifies any cavity, hollow, or pit; as that in a [stone of the kind called] fihorN, and in a mudohun, or mudohunap, q. v. (TA.)

wuqobiY~N *
wuqobiY~N Fond of, or given to, the company of A^awoqAb, i. e., stupid, or foolish, persons. (K.)

A^awoqaAbN *
A^awoqaAbN [pl. of waqobN?] The utensils and furniture, of the meaner sort, of a house, or tent: (K, TA:) as also A^awogaAbN. (TA.)

*akarN A^awoqabu *
*akarN A^awoqabu Multum penetrans in vulvam penis. (K.) ― -b2- rakiy~apN waqobaA'u, A well of which the water sinks into the earth. (TA.)

miyqabN *
miyqabN i. q. wadaEapN [The shell called cowry]. (K.)

miyqaAbN *
miyqaAbN A man who drinks much of water: (K:) or of the beverage called nabiy*. (L.) ― -b2- miyqaAbN A stupid, or foolish, woman: or one who gives birth to stupid, or foolish, children; syn. muHomiqapN. (K: [so in the CK: in a MS. copy, muHam~aqapN, one to whom stupidity, or folly, is imputed: but the former is evidently the right reading; myqAb being an epithet similar to mi*okaArN and miy^onaAvN &c.]) ― -b3- Also Latam vulvam habens mulier. (K.) ― -b4- banuw AlmiyqaAbi a reproachful appellation, (K,) referring to the mother of the persons to whom it is applied. (TA.) ― -b5- sayoru AlmiyqaAbi A journeying continued during a day and a night together. (K.)

1 waqata *
1. waqata, aor. yaqitu, inf. n. waqtN; and wq~t↓, inf. n. tawoqiytN; He determined, defined, or limited, a thing as to time; (IAth, L, Msb;) and otherwise: (L, Msb:) he determined, or defined, times. (S, K.) waqatahu He declared [or appointed] a time in which it should be done. (S.) waqata All~`hu AlSlaApa, aor. yaqitu; and waq~atahaA↓, God hath determined, or defined, a time for prayer. (Msb.) wq~t↓, as also A^aq~ata, He assigned, or appointed, for a thing, a particular time; he assigned, or appointed, a particular time for doing a thing. (IAth, L.) liyawomi waq~at~uhu↓ ka*aA [I appointed him, or it, for such a day]; like A^aj~alotuhu. (S.) ― -b2- In the following words of the Kur. [lxxvii. 11,] waA_i*aA Alr~usulu A^uq~itato, Aqtt↓ is a dial. form of wuq~itato, like as A^ujuwhN is of wujuwhN; (S;) and the meaning is And when the Apostles shall have one [particular] time assigned to them to decide between the people [to whom they have been sent to preach]: (Zj:) or, shall be collected at their appointed time, on the day of resurrection. (Fr.) This is the general reading: but there are other reading; namely, wuq~itato, and wuqitato, (S, TA,) and wuwqitato, which last is of the measure fuwEilato, from AlmuwaAqatapu. (K.) ― -b3- lamo yaqito fY Alxamori Had~FA He (Mohammad) did not determine, or define, for [drinking wine,] a castigation consisting of a certain number [of blows, or stripes]. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- waqata sometimes signifies He [i. e. God] made the entering upon the state of A_iHoraAm in pilgrimage, and prayer at the commencement of its appointed time, obligatory, or incumbent, upon men. (TA.) ― -b5- liA^aholi Almadiynapi *aA AlHulayofapi waq~ata↓ He appointed, for the people of El-Medeeneh, Dhu-l-Huleyfeh as the place where they should enter upon the state of A_iHoraAm. (TA, from a trad.)

2 waq~ata
2: see 1 throughout.

3 wAqthu *
3. wAqthu, inf. n. muwaAqatahN, [He made an appointment with him for a particular time]. (K.)

waqotN *
waqotN (S, K) A time; or space, or measure, of time, (M, L, K, Msb,) appointed for any affair; a season: (Msb:) mostly used with respect to what is past: (M, K:) sometimes with respect to the future: (TA:) as also miyqaAtN↓, (K, Msb:) or, accord. to some, there is a difference between these two words; the former having an absolute signification, and the latter signifying a time appointed for the performance of some action: [as in the S:] (TA:) pl. of the former A^awoqaAtN, and of the latter mawaAqiytu. (Msb.) [Hence, waqotay^i*K Then; at that time.] ― -b2- waqotN (tropical:) A space, or measure, of local extension; as a mile, &c. (Sb.)

mawoqitN *
mawoqitN, [of the measure] mafoEilN from Alwaqotu: (S, K:) [it may therefore be an inf. n., or a noun of place, or a noun of time]. El-'Ajjáj says,
waAljaAmiEu Aln~aAsa liyawomi Almawoqiti
[And He who congregateth mankind for the day of the appointment of a particular time, or, of the place of a certain event, or, of the time of a certain event; i. e., for the day of resurrection]. (S.)

miyqaAtN *
miyqaAtN: see waqotN. ― -b2- Also, A place in which a certain action is appointed to be performed. (S.) Ex. miyqaAtu AlHaj~i The place where the pilgrims enter upon the state of A_iHoraAm: (S, K:) you say, h`*aA myqAtu A^aholi Al$~aA^omi This is the place where the people of Syria enter upon the state of AHrAm. (S.) ― -b3- [Also, A place in which a meeting is appointed to take place at a particular time. Ex.] AlA=xirapu miyqaAtu Alxaloqi [The world to come is the place in which mankind are appointed to meet after the resurrection]. (L.) ― -b4- [Also, That which determines the commencement, or the like, of a period &c. Ex.] AlhilaAlu myqAtu Al$~ahori [The crescent is that which determines the commencement of the month]. (L.) ― -b5- See also mawoqitN.

mawoquwtN *
mawoquwtN and muwaq~atN↓ Determined, defined, definite, or limited, as to time. (L.) ― -b2- waqotN mawoquwtN, and muwaq~atN↓, A determined, defined, definite, or limited, time. (K.) ― -b3- A_in~a AlS~alaApa kaAnato EalaY Almuw^ominiyna kitaAbFA mawoquwtFA [Kur. iv. 104,] For prayer is to the believers a prescript, or an appointment, or ordinance, ordained [to be performed] in the times [thereof]. (S, K, &c.) ― -b4- Also [mawoquwvN (see 1) and] muwaq~atN↓ Determined, defined, or definite, as to its extreme limit, extent, or amount: (L:) both signify anything defined, definite, or limited. (Msb.)

muwaq~atN *
muwaq~atN: see mawoquwtN.

1 waquHa *
1. waquHa, (S, K,) aor. yawoquHu; (S;) and waqiHa, (K,) aor. yawoqaHu; (TA;) and waqaHa, (K,) aor. yaqiHu; (TA;) inf. n. waqaAHapN and wuquwHapN, (S, K,) inf. ns. of the first, (TA,) and wuqoHN and wuquHN, (S,) [also of the first,] and waqaHN, so in [most of] the copies of the K, [but in the CK wuqoHN.] inf. n. of the second, (TA,) and qiHapN and qaHapN, (S, K,) in both of which the p is a substitute for the [elided] w, (S,) and in the latter of which the fet-hah is put in the place of kesreh because of the guttural letter, both inf. ns. of the second and third; (TA;) and AwqH↓, and AstwqH↓; (S, K;) It (a solid hoot, S, K, and a camel's foot, and the back, TA) was, or became, hard. (S, K.) ― -b2- waquHa,(S, K,) and waqiHa, and waqaHa, (K,) inf. n. waqaAHapN and qiHapN and qaHapN (S) and wuqoHN and wuquwHN; (Lh;) and twq~H↓; (A;) He (a man) had little shame: (S, K:) he was hard-faced, having little shame: he was bold to do bad, foul, or abominable, things, and cared not for them, accord. to Bd and Z. (TA.)

2 wq~H *
2. wq~H, inf. n. tawoqiyHN, He repaired a tank, or cistern, with pieces of dry clay, or tough clay in which was no sand, and (or, as is sometimes done, TA) with broad and thin stones. (K.) ― -b2- wq~H, inf. n. tawoqiyHN, He rendered a solid hoof
hard by means of melted fat, (S, K,) burning with the melted fat the places where the hoof was worn by treading, and the hairs next to the hoof. (TA.)

4 A^awoqaHa
4: see 1.

5 tawaq~aHa
5: see 1.

10 A_isotawoqaHa
10: see 1.

waqiHN *
waqiHN and waqaAHN↓ (tropical:) A man having little shame. (S, A.) ― -b2- waqaAHu Alwajohi, an epithet applied to a woman, (S,) without p, as well as to a man, and Alwajohi waqiyHu↓, applied to a man, (tropical:) Hard-faced, having little shame; (TA;) as also waqoHaY↓ applied to woman. (Msb.)

waqaAHu Al*~anabi *
waqaAHu Al*~anabi (assumed tropical:) A man patient in riding. (IAar, K.) [See *anabN.] ― -b2- waqaAHN (S, K) and waAqiHN↓ (K,) A hard solid hoof, (S, K,) and camel's foot, and the back; the former an epithet both masc. and fem.: (TA:) pl. of the former wuquHN, (S, K,) and wuq~aHN. (TA.) farasN waqaAHN (assumed tropical:) A hard and strong horse. (Msb.) ― -b3- See waqiHN.

waqiyHN *
waqiyHN and waqoHaY: see waqiHN.

waAqiHN *
waAqiHN: see waqaAHN.

rajulN muwaq~aHN *
rajulN muwaq~aHN (tropical:) A man who has been tried or proved, or rendered experienced or expert (Lh. S, K) by trials which have befallen him; as also muwaq~aE. (Lh, S.) ― -b2- baEiyrN muwaq~aHN (tropical:) A camel jaded by work. (TA.)

1 waqadati Aln~aAru *
1. waqadati Aln~aAru, aor. taqidu, inf. n. wuquwdN (S, A, L, Msb, K) and waquwdN, (Sb, Zj, L, K,) but this is a deviation [as to form] from the constant course of speech, and most hold that the former is an inf. n. and the latter a subst. signifying “ fire-wood ” [or “ fuel ”], though there are some instances of inf. ns. of the measure faEuwlN, whereof qabuwlN is one, (El-Basáïr, TA,) and waqodN (S, A, L, Msb, K) and waqadN and qidapN and waqadaAnN (S, L, K) and waqiydN; (S, L;) and twq~dt↓, and At~qdt↓, (S, L, Msb, K,) and Astwqdt↓; (L, Msb, K;) The fire burned; burned up; burned brightly or fiercely; blazed; or flamed; syn. Ai$otaEalat; (Msb, art. $El;) and haAjat; (L;) and saTaEato waA@rotafaEa lahabuhaA. (Bd, ii. 16.) ― -b2- waqadato bika zinaAdiY (assumed tropical:) [May my znd emit fire by thy means!] a prayer, like wariyato bk znAdY: (L:) [meaning, do thou aid, or help, me]. ― -b3- waqada and twq~d↓ It (anything) shone, or glistened. (L.) ― -b4- qalobuhu twq~d↓ (tropical:) His heart became excited with ardour, or eagerness. (L.) ― -b5- [And twq~d↓ (tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, clever, ingenious, acute, sharp, or penetrating. (See waq~aAdN.)]

2 waq~ada
2: see 4.

4 A^awoqada
4: Awqd Aln~aAra, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iyqaAdN; (L, Msb;) and wq~dhA↓, (L,) and twq~dhA↓, (K,) and AstwqdhA↓; (S, L, Msb, K;) He lighted, or kindled, the fire; made it to burn, to burn up, to burn brightly or fiercely, to blaze, or to flame; syn. A^aDoramahaA; (K, art. Drm;) and A^a$oEalahaA; (TK;) he raised the fire, or made it to burn up, with fire-wood, or fuel: (A:) or the ↓last signifies he desired, or endeavoured, to kindle the fire. and to make it burn up, or burn brightly or fiercely, and blaze, or flame. (Bd, ii. 16.) ― -b2- kul~amaA A^awoqaduwA naArFA liloHarobi A^aTofaA^ahaA A@ll~`hu (tropical:) [Whenever they kindle a fire for war, God extinguisheth it; Kur. v. 69,] meaning, whenever they contrive a mischievous and deceitful plot, God annulleth it. (Msb.) ― -b3- A^awoqadotu lilS~ibaA naArFA [in some copies of the K, lilS~abiY~i,] (assumed tropical:) I relinquished silly and youthful conduct. (L, K.) A poet says,
SaHawotu waA^awoqadotu lil~ahowi naAraA
warad~a EalaY~a A@lS~ibaA maA A@sotaEaAraA
(assumed tropical:) [I recovered from intoxication, and relinquished vain and frivolous diversion; and youthfulness restored to me what it had borrowed]. (L.) ― -b4- A^aboEada A@ll~`hu daArahu waA^awoqada naAraA A^avarahu (tropical:) [May God remove his dwelling far away, and] may He not bring him back, or restore him! (L, K.) It was a custom of Arabs, when a man whose evil or mischief they feared removed from them, to light a fire behind him, that his evil or mischief might go with him. (L.)

5 tawaq~ada
5: See 1 and 4. ― -b2- twq~d is also said of the odour of perfume, (S, A, K, in art. whj,) meaning (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, hot [or strong]. (TK.)

8 A_iwotaqada
8: see 1. ― -b2- At~qdt Al$~amosu [The sun was, or became, burning, or fiercely burning]. (M, K, in art. Sqr, conj. 4, &c.)

10 A_isotawoqada
10: see 1 and 4.

waqadN *
waqadN Fire itself. (A, L, K.) Ex. maA A^aEoZama h`*aA Alwaqada How great is this fire! (A.) ― -b2- See also 1.

Alwaqodapu *
Alwaqodapu, (S, K,) or waqodapu AlHar~i, (L,) (tropical:) The greatest heat; (S, L, K;) which is a period of ten days, or of half a month. (S, L.) ― -b2- Tabaxatohumo waqodapu AlS~ayofi (tropical:) [The greatest heat of the summer affected them with a hot, or burning, fever]. (A.) ― -b3- waqadaAtu suhayolK: see the last paragraph of art. Edl.

waqadaY *
waqadaY, fem. Shining, or glistening. (L.) ― -b2- See also miyqaAdN.

waquwdN *
waquwdN Fire-wood; (S, L, Msb, K;) but it is only so called when kindled; (El-Hareeree, in De Sacy's Anthol. Gramm. Ar., p. 31 of the Arabic text;) as also wiqaAdN and waqiydN: (K:) or any fuel; anything with which fire is kindled, or made to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame: (L:) or the blaze, or flame, of fire, which one sees. (Lth, L.) ― -b2- waquwduhaA Aln~aAsu waA@loHijaArapu [Kur. ii. 22; and lxvi. 6; The fuel whereof shall be men and stones]. (L.) ― -b3- See also 1. In the Kur. lxxxv. 5, it is most properly rendered as an inf. n.; (Az, L;) and some in this case read Alwuquwd. (Yaakoob, S, L.)

waq~aAdN *
waq~aAdN Shining, or shining brightly; (L, K;) applied to a star. (L.) ― -b2- waq~aAdN (L, K) and mutawaq~idN↓ (L) (tropical:) A heart, or mind. quickly excited with ardour, or eagerness, in liveliness and acuteness or penetration. (L, K.) ― -b3- Also, both words, (tropical:) A man (L) clever, ingenious, acute, sharp, or penetrating. (L, K.)

gaAy^iru AlwaAqidayoni *
gaAy^iru AlwaAqidayoni (tropical:) Blind: (A:) by AlwAqdyn are meant the two eyes: El-Aashà says, accord. to one reading,
raA^ato rajulFA gaAy^ira AlwaAqidayoni
but the reading commonly known is AlwaAfidayoni. (JK.)

mawoqidN *
mawoqidN (S, A, L, Msb) and musotawoqadN↓ (A, L) and muwqadN↓ (JK) A fire-place; a place in which fire is lighted. (S, A, * L, Msb.) See an ex. voce HasaAsN.]

muwqadN *
muwqadN: see muwoqidN.

zanodN miyqaAdN *
zanodN miyqaAdN A znd that quickly produces fire. (A, L, K.) You also say znd waqadaY, i. e., mutawaq~idapN. (JK.)

mutawaq~idN *
mutawaq~idN: see waq~aAdN.

musotawoqidN *
musotawoqidN: see mawoqidN.

1 waqa*ahu *
1. waqa*ahu, aor. yaqi*u, (S, L, &c.,) inf. n. waqo*N, (S, L, K, &c.,) He beat him, or struck him, violently: (L, K:) he beat him until he became relaxed, or languid, and at the point of death: (S, L, Msb:) or he beat him so that he became at the point of death: (A:) he broke his skull, wounding the brain: (L:) he beat or struck, him upon the small protuberance above the back of the neck, so that the sound of the blow or blows reached the brain, and deprived him of reason: (Aboo-Sa'eed, L:) he beat him (a man) until he died. (L.) ― -b2- waqa*ahu biAlD~arobi [He killed him with beating]. (ISk, L.) ― -b3- waqa*a Al$~aApa He beat the ewe, or she-goat, to death with pieces of wood [&c.: see waqiy*N]. (L.) ― -b4- waqa*ahu He prostrated him. (K.) ― -b5- Darabotu AlHay~apa Hat~aY waqa*otuhaA I beat the serpent until I killed it. (A.) ― -b6- waqa*ahu (assumed tropical:) It (clemency, forbearance, or gravity,) rendered him still, quiet, or tranquil: (L, K:) it (the fear of God) rendered him still, quiet, or tranquil, and had such an effect upon him as to prevent his
committing an unlawful action. (L.) ― -b7- waqa*ahu (tropical:) It (drowsiness, S, L, Msb) overcame him: (S, L, K:) or made him to fall down. (Msb.) ― -b8- waqa*ahu (assumed tropical:) He, or it, left him ill, or sick; as also A^awoqa*ahu↓. (K.) ― -b9- waqa*ahu AlmaraDu, and Algam~u, (assumed tropical:) [Disease, and grief, overcame him, or rendered him infirm, or caused him to be at the point of death]. (L.) ― -b10- waqa*atohu AlEibaAdapu (tropical:) [Religious service rendered him infirm, or caused him to be at the point of death]. (A) ― -b11- waqa*atoniY kalimapN samiEotuhaA (tropical:) [A word, or sentence, that I heard, distressed me.] (A.) ― -b12- wuqi*ato (tropical:) She (a camel) was milked against her wish, so that her milk became little. (A.) ― -b13- fiY qialobiY waqo*ahN mino *`lika (tropical:) In my heart is some distress remaining in consequence of that. (A.)

4 A^awoqa*a
4: see 1.

waqiy*N *
waqiy*N Beaten [violently: or] until he has become relaxed, or languid, and at the point of death: [&c.: see 1:] as also mawoquw*N↓. (Msb.) ― -b2- waqiy*N (ISk, L, K) and mawoquw*apN↓ (Fr, ISk, S, L, Msb, K) A ewe, or she-goat, beaten to death; (Fr, ISk, L;) after which it is eaten: (ISk, L:) killed with pieces of wood (S, L, Msb, K) &c.; (Msb;) not legally slaughtered: (Fr, L, Msb:) beaten to death with a staff, or stick; (A, El-Basáïr;) or with blunt stones: (El-Basáïr:) the Arabs in the time of paganism killed beasts thus. (A.) ― -b3- waqiy*N Prostrated. (K.) [In the TA, AlsryE is erroneously put for AlS~ariyEu.] ― -b4- waqiy*N (assumed tropical:) A man in whom is no fat or strength; maA bihi TiroqN. (S, L.) ― -b5- waqiy*N (assumed tropical:) A slow, heavy man: (L, K *:) as though his heaviness and weakness overcame him, or prostrated him, waqa*ahu. (L.) ― -b6- waqiy*N (tropical:) Violently sick, and at the point of death; as also mawoquw*N↓: (L, K:) heavy, (Lth, L,) suffering from sickness that cleaves fast to him, and at the point of death: (Lth, A, L;) suffering from a swoon, and in such a state that it is not known whether he be dead or not. (ISh, L.) ― -b7- waqiy*N (tropical:) Ill, sick; as also muwqa*↓. (TA.) ― -b8- waqaAy^i*F Stones spread about: (L, K:) sing. waqiy*apN. (L.) ― -b9- waqiy*u AljawAaniHi (assumed tropical:) Grieved in the heart; as though it were broken and weakened by grief. The jwAnH [are the ribs that] enclose the heart. (L.)

muwqa*N *
muwqa*N: see waqiy*N.

mawqi*N *
mawqi*N An extremity of the person, (K,) or place upon which a blow is severe, (A,) as, (K,) or namely, (A,) the elbow, (A, L, K,) and shoulder-joint, (K,) or extremity of the shoulderjoint, (A, L,) and knee, and ankle-bone: pl. mawaAqi*u. (A, L, K.)

mawoquw*N *
mawoquw*N and mawoqaw*apN: see waqiy*N.

muwaq~a*apN *
muwaq~a*apN A she-camel suffering in her dugs from the effect of the rag with which they have been bound to prevent their being sucked, (S, L, K,) by reason of its tightness: (L:) or that has been sucked by her young one without its drawing her milk otherwise than scantily, by reason of the largeness of her udder, in consequence of which she suffers disease, (S, L, K,) and has a tumour (S, L) in her udder. (L.)

1 waqara *
1. waqara as syn. with A^awoqara: and wuqirati Aln~axolapu as syn. with A^awoqarat: see 4. ＝ -A2- [Hence,] waqara A@ll~`hu A^u*unahu, aor. yaqiruhaA, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. waqorN, (S, Msb,) (tropical:) God made his ear heavy, or dull of hearing: (Msb, K: *) or deaf. (S, K.) You say, A^all~`hum~a qiro A^a*uhahu (tropical:) O God, make his ear heavy, or dull of hearing: (A:) or deaf. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] waqirato A^u*unuhu, (ISk, S, TA,) aor. tuwqaru, inf. n. waqorN; (ISk, TA;) and waqirato, aor. tawoqaru; (S, Msb, TA;) and waqarato, aor. taqiru; (Msb, TA;) inf. n. waqorN, (S, Msb, TA,) which by rule should be waqarN, as inf. n. of waqirato, (S, TA,) but which is regular as inf. n. of waqarato; (TA;) (tropical:) His ear was, or became, heavy, or dull of hearing: (Msb, TA: *) or deaf: (S, TA:) but in the K we find, less properly, waqara and waqira, [as though signifying he (a man) was, or became, dull of hearing: or deaf:] inf. n. waqorN, which by rule should be waqarN; and wuqira, like EuniYa. (TA.) You say also, waqarato A^u*uniY Eanohu (tropical:) [My ear was dull of hearing, or deaf, to (lit. from) him]: (A:) and wuqirato Eani A@sotimaAEi kalaAmihi (tropical:) [it was dull of hearing, or deaf, to (lit. from) the hearing of, or listening to, his speech]. (A, TA: but in the latter, waqirato.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] waqara, aor. yaqiru, inf. n. waqArN, (assumed tropical:) He, or it, was, or became, still, or motionless; rested; syn. sakana. (TA.) So in the phrase waqara fiY Alqalobi (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) rested in the heart, or mind: and waqarafiY Sadorihi (assumed tropical:) it (a secret) rested in his bosom: occurring in a trad., accord. to different relations. (TA.) You say also, kal~amotuhu kalimapF waqarato fiY A^u*unihi (tropical:) I spoke to him a speech which rested (vabatato) in his ear. (As, A.) And waqara fiY Als~amoEi wawaEaAhu Alqalobu (tropical:) [It rested in the ear; and the heart, or mind, kept it in memory]. (A.) And waqara fiY qalobihi ka*aA (tropical:) Such a thing came into his mind and left its impression remaining. (A.) ― -b4- [And hence,] waqara, aor. yaqiru; (Msb, K, TA;) and waqira, aor. yawoqaru; (TA;) inf. n. waqorN, (K, TA,) of the former, (TA,) and wuquwrapN, (K, TA,) of the latter; (TA;) (tropical:) He (a man, TA) sat: (K, TA:) or he sat with waqaAr [i. e. gravity, &c.]. (Msb.) ― -b5- [Hence also,] waqara, aor. yaqiru; (S, K;) and waqura, aor. yawaquru; (Msb, K;) inf. n. waqaArN, (S, Msb, K,) of the former, (S,) or of the latter, (Msb, K,) and qirapN, of the former, (S, K,) and waqaArapN, of the latter; (K;) He was, or became, grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm; (S, Msb, K;) [see waqaArN, below;] as also A_it~aqara↓ and tawaq~ara↓: (K:) or this last, signifies he showed, exhibited, or manifested, gravity, staidness, steadiness, sedateness, or calmness: (KL:) [and also, agreeably with analogy, he endeavoured, or he constrained himself, to be grave, &c.] It is said in the Kur. [xxxiii. 33,] waqirona fiY buyuwtikun~a [meaning, accord. to some, And be ye grave, &c., in your houses, or chambers]: (S, A:) or the meaning is, and sit ye, &c.: (TA:) and so another reading, waqazona: (TA:) or this latter, (S,) or each of these two readings, (TA,) is from AlqaraAru, (S,) [i. e.,] from qar~a, aor. yaqar~u and yaqir~u; (TA;) and is a contraction of A_iqorarona [or A_iqorirona]. (S.)

2 wq~rhu *
2. wq~rhu, inf. n. tawoqiyrN, (assumed tropical:) He made him (a beast of carriage) to be still, or quiet. (K, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He pronounced him, or held, or reckoned him, to be grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm; syn. of the inf. n. taroziynN. (S.) ― -b3- (tropical:) He treated him, with honour, reverence, veneration, or respect; (S, A, K, TA;) did not hold him in light estimation. (A, TA.)

4 Awqrhu *
4. Awqrhu (inf. n. A_iyqaArN and qirapN, K, which latter is anomalous, TA,) He loaded him: (S, A, Msb, K:) or loaded him heavily: (A, K:) namely a camel, (S, Msb,) or a beast (K) or a mule, and an ass: (A:) [see wiqorN, below: and waqarahu↓, aor. yaqiruhu, signifies the same; and its inf. n. seems to be waqoraY, q. v., as also, probably, waqorN: waqara, aor. yaqiru, is explained by Golius, as on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof, as signifying “ gravavit, aggravavit. ”] You say, A^awoqara Ald~aAb~apaqirapF $adiydapF [He loaded the beast of carriage severely]. (TA.) And A^awoqara raAHilatahu *ahabFA He loaded his riding-camel with a load, or heavy load, of gold. (TA.) ― -b2- Awqrhu Ald~ayonu (tropical:) Debt burdened him, or burdened him heavily. (S, A. *) ― -b3- A^awoqarati Aln~axolapu, (S, A, Msb,) and wuqirato↓, (A,) The palm-tree became laden, or heavily laden, with fruit; (A;) became abundant in fruit. (S, Msb.) ― -b4- And A^awoqara, or A^uwqira, (accord. to different copies of the S, in art. dm,) [or Awqr $aHomFA or biAl$~aHomi,] said of a camel &c., i. q. dum~a biAl$~aHomi [He was, or became, loaded, or overspread, with fat: see dum~a]. (S, in that art.)

5 tawaq~ara
5: see 1, last signification.

8 A_iwotaqara
8: see 1, last signification.

10 Astwqr wiqorahu TaEaAmFA *
10. Astwqr wiqorahu TaEaAmFA He took, or received, his load, or heavy load, of wheat or other food. (K.) ― -b2- Astwqrt AlA_ibilu, (K, TA,) or Astwqrt AlA_ibilu $aHomFA (A,) The camels became fat; (K;) [lit.] carried fat: (TA:) or became heavy with fatness. (A.)

waqorN *
waqorN A heaviness in the ear; (S, A, K;) a
heaviness, or dulness, of hearing: (Msb, TA:) or deafness; entire loss of hearing. (K, TA.) See 1.

wiqorN *
wiqorN A load, (S, A, Msb, K,) in a general sense, (A, K, TA,) whether heavy or light or moderate, (TA,) of a mule and of an ass and of a camel; (Msb;) or mostly of a mule and of an ass; that of a camel being mostly termed wasoqN: (S, TA:) or a heavy load: (A, K:) or a weight that is carried upon the back or head: (TA:) pl. A^awoqaArN. (A, K.) You say, jaA='a yaHomilu wiqorahu He came carrying his load [&c.]. (S.)

waqarN *
waqarN, or waqurN: see waquwrN.

A^u*unN waqirapN *
A^u*unN waqirapN: see mawoquwrN.

waqoraY *
waqoraY: see muwqarN.

waqaArN *
waqaArN Gravity, staidness, steadiness, calmness; syn. razaAnapN, (S, Msb, K,) and HilomN, (S, Msb,) and sakiynapN, and wadaAEapN; (L, TA;) and tayoquwrN↓ is syn. with waqaArN [in this sense], (S, K,) of the measure fayoEuwlN, (K,) originally wayoquwrN, (S,) the w being changed into t: (S, K:) [see 1:] or, accord. to some, it is syn. with tawoqiyrN. (TA.) El-'Ajjáj says,
faA_ino yakuno A^amosaY AlbilaY tayoquwriY
i. e. AmsY waqaAriY. [And if wear, or waste, hath become the cause of my gravity, &c.: or, if it be syn. with tawoqiyriY, the cause of making me still, or quiet]. (S, TA.) Some make it to be of the measure tafoEuwlN, like ta*onowbN, &c. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, The greatness, or majesty, of God: as in the Kur. lxxi. 12. (S. [See 1, in art. rjw.]) ― -b3- See also waquwrN.

waquwrN *
waquwrN (S, A, K) and waqaArN↓, and waqurN↓, (K,) or waqarN↓, (L,) and mutawaq~irN↓, (TA,) Grave; staid; sedate; calm: applied to a man: (S, A, K, TA:) and the first applied also to a woman: (K:) pl. of the first, wuqurN, (A, TA,) applied to men, (A,) and to women. (TA.)

waqiyrN *
waqiyrN (tropical:) Heavily burdened with debt. (TA.) ― -b2- A^u*unN waqiyrapN: see mawoquwrN.

janaAnN waAqirN *
janaAnN waAqirN (tropical:) A heart which fright does not make to flutter. (A.)

tayoquwrN *
tayoquwrN: see waqaArN.

muwqarN *
muwqarN [Laden;] having a load: or [heavily laden;] having a heavy load: [as also mawoquwrN↓:] applied to a man: (K:) and also [the former] applied to a woman, in the same sense: (TA:) or you apply to a woman the epithet muwqarapN, meaning, bearing a heavy burden. (Fr, S, TA.) You say also daAb~apN waqoraY↓, meaning mawoquwrapN↓ [A beast of carriage laden: or heavily laden]: (K:) but ISd holds that waqoraY↓ is used elliptically, for *aAtu waqoraY, and is an inf. n., of the measure faEolaY, like HaloqaY and EaqoraY. (TA.) [mawoquwrN↓, in the same sense, is also applied to a ship; as in the Expos. of the Jel, ii. 159.] ― -b2- naxolapN muwqarapN, (S, A, K,) and muwqirapN↓, (S, K,) and muwqirN↓, (S, A, K,) like as one says, A_imoraA^apN HaAmilN, (S,) and muwqarN, which is anomalous, (S, K,) and miyqaArN↓, (K,) and mawoquwrapN↓, (A,) and muwaq~arapN↓, (K,) A palm-tree laden, or heavily laden, with fruit; (A, K;) abounding in fruit: (S:) pl. [of the first, second, third, and fourth,] mawaAqiru, (S, K,) and [of myqAr and mwqwrp,] mawaAqiyru. (A.) ― -b3- See also waqiyrN.

muwqirN *
muwqirN, and with p: see muwqarN.

muwaq~arN *
muwaq~arN pass. part. n. of 2, q. v. ― -b2- naxolapN muwaq~arapN: see muwoqarN.

mawoquwrN *
mawoquwrN, and with p: see muwqarN. ＝ -A2- (tropical:) A man [dull of hearing: or deaf. (S.) And A^u*unN mawoquwarpN (tropical:) An ear dull of hearing: or deaf: (ISk, A, TA:) as also waqirapN↓, (A,) or waqiyrapN↓. (TA.)

miyqaArN *
miyqaArN: see muwqarN.

mutawaq~irN *
mutawaq~irN: see waquwrN.

1 waqaSa Eunuqaha *
1. waqaSa Eunuqaha, (Ks, S, K,) and Al$~aYo'a, (A'Obeyd, TA,) aor. yaqiSu, (Ks, S, K,) inf. n. waqoSN, (Ks, S, Mgh,) He broke his neck, (Ks, S, Mgh, K,) and the thing. (A'Obeyd, TA.) You say also, waqaSato bihi raAHilatuhu [His riding-camel, or she-camel, broke its neck]: (S, K:) like as you say, xu*i AlxiTaAma and xu*o biAlxiTaAm: (S:) and waqaSati Aln~aAqapu biraAkibihaA The she-camel threw her rider and broke his neck. (Msb.) And wuqiSa He had his neck broken; (S, K;) said of a man; (S:) [and also] said of a camel, signifying, he became diseased in his back, and without motion: and in like manner said of the neck, and of the back. (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh.) And waqaSotu raA^osahu I pressed, or squeezed, his head; sometimes meaning, so as to break the neck. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] waqaSa Ald~ayonu Eunuqahu (tropical:) Debt [oppressed him as though it] broke his neck. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] Alfarasu yaqiSu AlA_ikaAma (tropical:) The horse bruises the hills, or rising grounds: (S, K:) or breaks the summits thereof: (A:) and in like manner one says of a she-camel. (TA.) ― -b4- You say also, Ald~aAb~apu ta*ub~u bi*anabihaA fataqiSu EanohaA Al*~ubaAba (tropical:) The beast of carriage beats off from her with her tail, and kills, the flies. (TA.) ＝ -A2- waqaSati AlEunuqu The neck broke: thus the verb is intrans. as well as trans.: (K:) or, accord. to Ks, one does not say this: (S:) i. e., one only says of the neck wuqiSat, using the pass. form. (TA.) ＝ -A3- waqiSa, (S, K,) aor. yawoqaSu, (S,) inf. n. waqaSN, (S, A, Mgh, K,) He (a man, S) was short in the neck. (S, A, Mgh, K.)

2 wq~S EalaY naArihi *
2. wq~S EalaY naArihi, (S, A,) inf. n. tawoqiySN, (TA,) He threw fragments, or broken pieces, of sticks upon his fire: (S, * A:) or he broke in pieces sticks upon his fire. (TA.)

4 AwqShu *
4. AwqShu He (God) made him to be short in the neck. (S, K.)

5 twq~S *
5. twq~S (tropical:) He went a pace between that called AlEanaq and that called Alxabab; (K;) falling short of the latter, but exceeding the former, and removing his legs as in the pace called Alxbb, excepting that they were nearer to the ground, and throwing himself [forward]: (AO:) or he trod vehemently in going, (K, TA,) with short steps, (TA,) as though breaking what was beneath him: (K, TA:) or he (a horse) bounded (As, S, A) in his running, (As,) making short steps, (As, S, A,) as though breaking his steps. (A.) You say, mar~a fulaAnN yatawaq~aSu bihi farasuhu Such a one passed along, his horse bounding, and making short steps, with him. (S.)

6 twAqS *
6. twAqS He made himself like, or imitated, him who is short in the neck: (K:) said of a man. (TA.) Hence, tawaAqaSa EalaY burodatihi kaYo laA tasoqT He bent and shortened himself to hold on his burodap with his neck, that it might not fall. (TA, from a trad.)

waqoSN *
waqoSN: see what next follows.

waqaSN *
waqaSN (tropical:) Fragments, or broken pieces, of sticks, which are thrown upon, (S,) or into, (K,) a fire: (S, K:) or small pieces of fire-wood with which a fire is made to burn more vehemently; (A, TA;) as also waqa$N: so, says Aboo-Turáb, I heard Mubtekir say. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, sing. of A^awoqaASN, as used in relation to the [tax called Sadaqap; signifying (tropical:) What is between one firiyDap and the next fariyDap: (S, K:) as, for instance, when camels amount in number to five, one sheep or goat is to be given for them; and nothing is to be given for such as exceed that number until they amount to ten: thus, what is between the five and the ten is termed waqaSN: (S:) sometimes pronounced waqoSN↓: (Msb:) and in like manner, $anaqN: (S:) or (accord. to some of the learned, S) wqS relates to bulls and cows particularly, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or to these and to sheep and goats, (Msb,) and $nq [q. v.] to camels: (S, Mgh, Msb:) both signifying what is between one fryDp and the next: (S, Mgh, Msb: *) or, accord. to Aboo-'Amr, (Mgh, L,) i. e. Esh-Sheybánee, (L,) waqaSN signifies camels for which it is incumbent to give sheep or goats in payment of the Sadaqap, (Mgh, L,) when the camels are between five and twenty in number; (L;) but some disapprove of this: (Mgh, L:) accord. to
IB, it signifies sheep or goats taken in payment of the Sadaqap for camels. (L.) ＝ -A3- You also say, SaAruwA A^awoqaASFA (assumed tropical:) They became scattered, or dispersed: and A^ataAnaA A^awoqaASN mino baniY fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) There came to us separate portions of the tribe of the sons of such a one: (Ibn-'Abbád, K: *) AwqAS in these cases being a pl., [namely of waqaSN,] like A^asobaAbN, pl. of sababN. (TA.)

waqiySapN *
waqiySapN: see mawoquwSN.

waAqiSapN *
waAqiSapN: see mawoquwSN.

A^awoqaSu *
A^awoqaSu A man (S, Mgh) short in the neck; (S, A, Mgh, K;) naturally so: (TA:) or having the neck inclining and short: (A'Obeyd, TA:) fem. waqoSaA='u. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- xudo A^awoqaSa AlT~ariyqayoni (tropical:) Take thou the nearer of the two ways: (Ibn- 'Abbád, K: *) or shorter thereof. (A, TA.)

mawoquwSN *
mawoquwSN A man (S) having his neck broken: (S, K:) and so mawoquwSu AlEunuqi: (A:) the fem. is with p: and waAqiSapN↓ occurs in the sense of mawoquwSapN in a trad. of 'Alee, in which he is said to have given judgment in the case of the qaAriSap and the qaAmiSap and the waAqiSap↓, that the price of blood, or fine for homicide, should be paid in thirds; these being three girls, who were playing together, and mounted, one upon another; and the lowest pinched the middle one, who thereupon leaped off, so that the uppermost fell, and her neck broke; wherefore he imposed a third of the fine for the killing of the uppermost upon the lowest, and the like upon the middle one, annulling the third of the uppermost because she aided against herself: (Mgh, TA, in art. qrS, and Msb,) here, [accord. to those who hold that waqaSa is trans. only,] wAqSp↓ is like raADiyapN, in the phrase Eiy$apN raADiyapN; (TA, in art. qrS and in the present art.;) and is used in the place of mwqwSp for the sake of agreement in form with the two other epithets: (Mgh, in art. qrS, and Msb:) waqiySapN↓, also, signifies having her neck broken; and its pl. is waqaAy^iSu. (Meyd, as in Freytag's Lex., excepting that the pl. is there written waqaAyiSu.) You say also EunuqN mawoquwSapN A broken neck. (Msb.) And mawoquwSN is also applied to a camel, signifying, Become diseased in his back, and without motion. (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh.)

1 wakVAa
1: see 8.

3 wAkA^ EalaY yadayohi *
3. wAkA^ EalaY yadayohi He leaned upon his hands, or arms. Mohammad was seen to do so when he raised and extended his hands in supplication to God. (IAth.)

4 A^awokaA^ahu *
4. A^awokaA^ahu, (S, K,) inf. n. A_iykaA'N, (S,) He set up for him a thing upon which to recline (mut~akaA^N.) (S, K.) ― -b2- A^atokaA^ahu, (in which t is substituted for w,) inf. n. A_itokaAhu, He propped him up by a cushion or other thing whereon to recline; made him recline upon a cushion &c. (AZ, TA.) ― -b3- Darabahu faA^atokaA^ahu, (A,) or TaEanahu Hat~aY A^atokaA^ahu, originally A^awokaA^ahu, (S,) (tropical:) He smote him, (A,) or pierced him, (S,) so that he made him fall in a reclining posture: (S, A, K: *) or, so that he threw him down upon his left side. (K.) ― -b4- See 3.

5 tawak~aAa
5: see 8.

8 Ait~akaA^a *
8. Ait~akaA^a He sat in a firm, or settled, manner: and he sat leaning upon one of his sides: (Msb, in art. tkA^:) the vulgar know it only in the latter sense: but it signifies he leaned, rested, or stayed, his back, or his side, against, or upon, a thing: and he leaned, rested, or stayed, himself in any manner, upon a thing. (IAth, in Msb, art. wkA^.) ― -b2- Ait~akaA^a EalaY $aYo'K, (S,) and twk~A^↓, (S, K,) and AwkA^↓; (K;) and takiy^a↓, [in which t is substituted for w,] aor. yatokaA^u, inf. n. tako'N; (Lth;) and wakaA^a↓; (CK;) He leaned, or reclined, upon a thing; supported, propped, or stayed, himself upon it. (K.) ― -b3- Ait~akaA^a He reclined upon a cushion, &c. (TA.) ― -b4- Ait~akaA^a He made for him [i. e., app., for himself,] a thing upon which to lean, or recline: (CK, and a MS. copy of the K:) or he made him to be a thing upon which to lean, or recline. (TA.) [The latter seems to be wrong, unless the verb be read A^atokaA^a.] ― -b5- Ait~akaA^onaA Einoda fulaAnK (tropical:) We ate a repast with, or at the abode of, such a one. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Ait~akaA^ato (MF) and tawak~aA^ato↓ (K) She (a camel) was taken with the pains of labour, and cried out. (K.) Accord. to Lth, tawak~uw^u Aln~aAqapi signifies tSl~fhA End mxADhA: (TA:) [but it is evident that the right reading is tSl~qhA; and the sense agreeable with the above explanation].

tukaA^apN *
tukaA^apN (in which t is substituted for w, TA) A staff, or stick, (K,) upon which one leans in walking; a walking-stick: (TA:) that upon which one leans or reclines. (S, K.) ― -b2- One who reclines much. (S, K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A heavy person [app., in disposition]. (TA.)

mut~akiy^N *
mut~akiy^N act. part. n. of 8. ― -b2- laA A=kulu mut~akiy^FA I (said Mohammad) eat not sitting in a firm, or settled, posture, cross-legged, or in such other similar manner as is adapted for much eating: for he used to eat sitting upon his hams, with his shanks erect, so as to be ready to rise. The meaning is not [only] “ inclining on one side, ” as the vulgar among students imagine. (K.)

mut~akaA^ *
mut~akaA^ A place in which one reclines: (S:) a chamber, or sitting-room. (Akh, S.) ― -b2- That upon which one leans, or reclines, in eating, drinking, or talking. (Zj.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Food, or a repast: so called because people used to recline when they sat to eat: but the Muslims are forbidden to do so. [See mut~akiy^N.] It is said to have this last meaning in the Kur. xii. 31. (TA.)

1 wakaba *
1. wakaba, aor. yakibu, inf. n. wukuwbN (K) and wakabaAnN (S) and wakobN (CK), He walked, went, or marched along, in a leisurely manner, (S, K,) or, as in some copies of the S, in a grave and leisurely manner. (TA.) See mawokibN. ＝ -A2- wakiba He (an antelope) proceeded at a quick pace, (IKtt,) [and with long steps: see wakuwbN]. [Thus the verb bears two contr. significations.] Hence the word mawokibN↓ (IKtt) [as meaning “ a certain mode, or manner, of walking, &c. ”]. ＝ -A3- wakaba, inf. n. wakobN, He, or it, stood erect; became erected, set up, raised, or reared: (S, K:) he stood. (K.) ― -b2- wakaba EalaY AlA^amori, and waAkaba↓, (in a copy of the S, wAkb, which is also mentioned in the sense here following by IKtt and IM, as stated in the TA,) He kept, attended, or applied himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to the thing, or affair. (S, K.) ＝ -A4- wakiba; and wk~b↓ inf. n. tawokiybN; It (a date) became black when ripe: (K:) or wakiba signifies, as below, “ it (the skin, or a garment,) was dirty, or filthy; ” and wk~b↓, it (a grape) became black: (TA: where it is said that this distinction [excepting that the second verb relates to the grape rather than the date] is meant in the K; the passage presenting what is termed laf~N wana$orN murat~abN:) or the latter verb signifies it (a grape or a date) showed some degree of blackness. (Az.) See muwak~ibN. ― -b2- wakiba, aor. yawokabu, inf. n. wakabN, It (the skin, or a garment,) was dirty, or filthy. (TA.) See wakabN.

2 wak~b *
2. wak~b, inf. n. tawokiybN, [app., He pursued a middle or just, way with respect to the SiraAr; which is a cord, or a piece of rag, that is bound over a she-camel's udder, or teats, to prevent her young one from sucking her]. (K: the inf. n. is explained by the words AlmuqaArabapu fiY AlS~iraAri: written in the TA AlSrA^r; to which is there added, with kesr.) ― -b2- See 1.

3 waAkbhumo *
3. waAkbhumo (inf. n. muwaAkabapN, TA,) He marched, or journeyed, or kept pace, with them; syn. saAyarahumo: or he hastened with them, and strove to be before them; syn. baAdarahumo: (K:) or he rode with them (S, K) in their mawokib [or procession]: (TA:) and also, he contended with them in a race or the like. (S.) ― -b2- See 1.

4 Awkb *
4. Awkb He (a camel) kept to the mode of walking, &c.,] or kept with [the kind of procession, called] a mawokib. (ISk, S, K: [but accord. to the K, the latter is the meaning intended; or, as said in the TA, he kept with the procession of riders or camels; for which,
however, SM knows no authority.) ＝ -A2- Awkb He (a bird) rose to fly; ex., Awkb vum~a TaAra. he rose to fly, and then flew: (Er-Riyáshee:) or prepared to fly; (S, K:) or flapped his wings while falling. (K.) ＝ -A3- Awkbh He made him angry. (K.)

wakabN *
wakabN The blackness of dates; (K;) or of grapes, &c., (T,) when they become ripe. (K, T.) Generally used with reference to grapes. (TA.) ― -b2- Dirt, or filth, (K,) upon the skin or upon a garment. (TA.)

ZayobahN wakuwbN *
ZayobahN wakuwbN also An antelope that keeps to its herd. (TA.) ― -b2- ZayobahN wakuwbN An antelope proceeding at a quick pace, with long steps; syn. Alt~Y tuEoniqu fY sayorihaA: (S:) and in like manner naAqapN muwaAkibahN↓ a she-camel that proceeds in that manner: (S, K:) see wakaba: or the latter signifies a she-camel that journeys, or marches, or keeps pace, with the mawokib: (K:) that does not lag behind the [company of] riders. (A.)

wak~aAbN *
wak~aAbN A man (TA) grieving, or mourning, much; very sorrowful, sad, or unhappy. (K.)

waAkibapN *
waAkibapN i. q. qaAy^imapN [app. signifying The leg of a quadruped]: (S, K:) from wakaba “ he stood. ” (TA.)

mawokibN *
mawokibN A certain mode, or manner, of walking, marching, proceding, or journeying. (S.) See 1. ― -b2- A company [or procession] of men, riding or walking [or marching by slow degrees, or gradually; or in a grave manner, and by slow degrees, or gradually]: (K:) or a party of people riding upon camels, for the sake of pomp, or parade, (S, K,) or to go forth to the gardens or the like for amusement: (TA:) and in like manner, a company of horsemen, or a cavalcade: (S:) pl. mawaAkibu. (TA.) ― -b3- saAra sayora Almawokibi He walked, marched, or journeyed [in the manner, or at the rate, of a ceremonious procession, or by slow degrees, or] without hastening. (TA, from a trad.)

muwak~ibN *
muwak~ibN A date (or grape, TA,) becoming black, when ripe: (K:) or a grape or date in which the least blackness appears. (Az.) ― -b2- Also An unripe date that is pricked with a thorn in order that it may ripen. (AHn.)

muwaAkibapN *
muwaAkibapN: see wakuwbN.

mawokuwbN *
mawokuwbN: see 1.

1 wakata *
1. wakata, aor. yakitu, (inf. n. wakatN, He, or it, made a mark, or impression, or left a mark. (K.) You say wakata $ayoy^FA He, or it, made a mark, or impression, or left a mark, upon a thing. (TK.) ＝ -A2- wakata aor. yakitu, inf. n. wakotN; and wik~t↓, inf. n. tawokiytN; He filled (K.) a qirobap, (Lh,) or a cup, or the like, as also zkt. (Fr.) ＝ -A3- wakata, aor. yakitu, inf. n. wakotN, He walked, or went, with short steps. (Sh, K.) ― -b2- He (a beast of carriage) raised and put down his feet quickly. (L.) ― -b3- wakata Alma$oYa, inf. n. wakotN and wakataAnN, He went, or walked, with short steps, but in a heavy and ugly manner. (L.) ― -b4- fiY sayorihi wak~t↓ He went with a particular kind of pace. (L, from Kr.) ＝ -A4- wakata AlkitaAba, inf. n. wakotN, He pointed, or dotted, the book, writing, or letter. (L.)

2 wak~avati Albusorapu *
2. wak~avati Albusorapu inf. n. tawokiytN, The date became speckled, by reason of its ripening. (S, M, K.) ＝ -A2- See 1.

wakotN *
wakotN, (Nh, &c.,) or wakotahN, (L,) A mark, (L,) or a small mark, (Nh,) in a thing, resembling a speck (nqTp), of a different colour from the thing itself: (Nh, L:) pl. of the latter [or rather coll. gen. n., of which the latter is the n. un.] wakotN. (L.) ― -b2- wakotN A little; not much, a little thing. (Sh, K.) ― -b3- wakotN and wakotapN A speck that appears in a date by reason of its ripening. (TA.) ― -b4- wakotapN A speck (nuqoTap) in a thing: (K:) or what resembles a nuqoTap in a thing: (S:) a red speck, or spot, in the white of the eye, which, if neglected, becomes a wadoqap: (ISd:) or a white speck, or spot, in the black of the eye: (TA:) you say, fiY Eyonihi wktpN [In his eye is a speck, &c.]. (S.) ― -b5- fiY qalobiY wakotapN mim~aA qulota (tropical:) On my heart is a slight impression made by what thou saidst. (A.)

wukotapN *
wukotapN i. q. furoDapu zanodK (K: in the CK, faroDp) [app., The notch in a wooden instrument for striking fire; as understood by Golius: but accord. to the TA, the notch, or the like, in the joint called znd of a camel].

wakiytN *
wakiytN The act of calumniating, or slandering, syn. siEaAyapN and wi$aAyapN, (K,) to one possessed of command, or power. (TA.)

rajalN wak~aAtN *
rajalN wak~aAtN, mentioned by Kr; thought by ISd to be from wakata Alma$oYa; [and therefore to signify A man who walks, or goes, with short steps, but in a heavy and ugly manner]; because were it by the phrase mentioned by Kr [i. e. wak~t fY syrh] it would be muwak~itN. (TA.)

waAkitN *
waAkitN, in a camel, i. q. naAkitN. (K.)

mawokuwtN *
mawokuwtN (tropical:) Changed in colour (kamidN) by reason of anxiety, or grief: (K:) or changed in colour (kamidN), and full of malevolence, and of anxiety, or grief. (TA.) ― -b2- EayonN mawoquwtpN An eye in which is a wakotap. (A, &c.)

busorapN muwak~itapN *
busorapN muwak~itapN, and muwak~itN, (the latter on the authority of Seer, TA) A date speckled, or becoming speckled, by reason of its ripening. (T, M, K.) When it is speckled in the part next the stalk, it is called mu*an~ibapN (TA.) See busorN.

10 Astwkv *
10. Astwkv He ate of what is called wkAv: (K:) he hastened, and ate somewhat of that which is called wkAv, thereby to attain the period of the morning-meal called AlgadaA='. (L.)

wikaAvN *
wikaAvN and wukaAvN Food, aliment, or nutriment, (gi*aA='N: so in some copies of the K, and in the TA: in the CK, gadaA='N, or a morning meal:) that is prepared, or taken, in haste, (yusotaEojalu bihi,) [before the morning-meal called gadaA=': see 10]. (K.)

10 AstwkHt AlfiraAxu *
10. AstwkHt AlfiraAxu The young birds became big, bulky, or coarse. (S, K.)

wukuHN *
wukuHN Big, bulky, or coarse, young birds: (K:) after the manner of a rel. n., as though pl. of waAkiHN, or wakuwHN, since it cannot be pl. of musotawokiHN. (TA.)

1 wakada *
1. wakada, aor. yakidu, inf. n. wukuwdN, He remained, continued, stayed, abode, or dwelt, (L, K,) bimakaAnK in a place. (L.) ＝ -A2- See 2. ＝ -A3- wakada A^amorFA, (L, K, *) aor. yakidu, inf. n. wakodN, (L,) He aimed at a thing; sought, endeavoured after, or pursued, it; desired it; intended it, or purposed it; syn. qaSada (L, K) and Talaba. (L.) See also below. ― -b2- wakada wakodahu He directed his course to, or towards, him, or it; or he pursued his (another's) course; syn. qaSada qaSodahu; (S, L, K;) doing as he did. (L.) ― -b3- wakada A^amorFA, aor. and inf. n. as above, also signifies He laboured at, and endeavoured after, a thing. (L.) ― -b4- wakada, (L, K,) aor. yakidu, inf. n. wakodN, (L,) i. q. A^aSaAba He, or it, did, or went, right; attained an object; hit, struck, smote, affected, hurt, befell; &c.]. (L, K.)

2 wk~d *
2. wk~d, (S, L,) inf. n. tawokiydN; (S, K;) [and wakada↓ as is implied in the K, but app. by the unintentional omission of the word wak~ada;] and Awkd↓, inf. n. A_iykaAdN; (S, L;) He made a horse's saddle, (S, L,) and a camel's, (L, K,) firm, fast, or strong; or bound or tied it firmly, fastly, or strongly; (S, L, K;) as also A^ak~ada and A=kada: but more chaste with w. (S, L, K. *) ― -b2- Also, He confirmed, ratified, or corroborated, a compact, a contract, a covenant, or an engagement; as also Ak~d (S, L, K) and A=kd: but, in this sense also, more chaste with w; (S, L;) or in this sense more approved with
A^: (L:) and in like manner wk~d he confirmed an oath: you say, A_i*aA Eaqadota faA^ak~ido wA_i*aA Halafota fawak~ido When thou makest a contract, ratify; and when thou swearest, confirm.

4 A^awokada
4: see 2. ― -b2- A^awokadataAhu yadaAhu His arms, or hands, exercised him with work. From a trad., relating to a seeker of knowledge. (L.)

5 twk~d AlA^amoru * and tA^k~d
5. twk~d AlA^amoru tA^k~d signify the same, [The thing, or affair, became confirmed, ratified, or corroborated]. (S, L, K. *)

wakodN *
wakodN Desire; purpose; intention; aim; endeavour. (L, K.) See also 1.

wukodN *
wukodN Work; labour; exertion; endeavour. (L, K.) Ex. maA zaAla *`lika wukodiY That ceased not to be my work, (L, K,) and endeavour. (L.)

wikaAdN *
wikaAdN A rope with which cows are tied on the occasion of milking. (S, L.) ― -b2- Also wikaAdN and A_ikaAdN sings. of wakaAy^idu [and A^akaAy^idu], (IDrd, L, K,) [pls. deviating from the constant course of speech in relation to the sings.; see art. A^kd;] signifying, (i. e. the pls.,) Thongs, or straps, with which one binds (L, K) a camel's, or horse's saddle: (L:) or the thongs, or straps, by which the qarabuws is bound to the two side-boards of a horse's saddle; (IDrd, L;) as also mayaAkiydu↓ and taA=kiydu and tawakiydu↓; (K;) or these are called myAkyd, but not twAkyd: (L:) and it [myAkyd] is a pl. that has no [proper] sing. (TA.)

muwaAkidapN *
muwaAkidapN A she-camel that strives, or exerts herself, in her progress, course, or pace. (K.)

mayaAkiydu *
mayaAkiydu and tawakiydu: see wikaAdN.

mutawak~idN biA^amorK *
mutawak~idN biA^amorK, (L,) or liA^amorK, (K,) Standing ready, or prepared, for a thing, or an affair (L, K.)

1 wakara *
1. wakara, aor. yakiru, inf. n. wakorN (S, K) and wukuwrN, (K,) He (a bird) came to the wakor [or nest]: (K:) or entered his wakor. (S.) ― -b2- wakara, (Mgh, Msb,) aor. yakiru, (Msb,) He (a bird) took for himself, or made, or prepared, (A_it~ax*,) a wakor; (Mgh, Msb;) as also wk~r↓, (A, Mgh, Msb, TA,) inf. n. tawokiyrN; (TA;) but the latter has an intensive signification; (Msb;) and A_it~akara↓. (K.) A^awokara in this sense is a mistake. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- wakara, aor. yakiru; (K;) or wk~r↓, (A, L, Msb,) inf. n. tawokiyrN; (Fr, S, L;) He made, or prepared, the food called wakiyrap; (Fr, S, A, L, Msb;) lahumo for them. (L, K.)

2 wak~ara
2: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- See also wakiyrapN, in two places.

8 A_iwotakara
8: see 1.

wakorN *
wakorN The nest (Eu$~) of a bird; (AA, S, A, Msb, K;) wherever it is; in a mountain or a tree; (AA, S, Msb;) and so if the bird is not in it; (M, A, K;) as also wakorapN↓: (K:) the place in which a bird lays its eggs, and has, or hatches, its young; being a hole in a wall, or in a tree: (T, TA:) the place into which the bird enters; as also wakonN: (As, TA:) [see also Eu$~N; and sarabN:] pl. (of pauc., TA:) A^awokurN (K) and A^awokaArN, (S, A, Msb, K,) and (of mult., TA) wukuwrN (S, K) and wikaArN (Msb) and wukarN. (K.) You say, buyuwtN kaA^awokAri AlT~ayori [Houses like the nests of birds]. (A.) ― -b2- (tropical:) [A house: as in the following saying,] maA daAra fiY fikoriYnuzuwluka fiY wakoriY (tropical:) Thine alighting at my house was not revolved in my mind]. (A.) See also wakiyrapN. ― -b3- The faroD [q. v.] of a zanodap. (A, in art. frD.)

naAqapN wakaraY *
naAqapN wakaraY: see jam~aAzN.

wakorapN *
wakorapN: see wakorN. ＝ -A2- See also wakiyrapN.

wakarapN *
wakarapN: see wakiyrapN.

wakiyrN *
wakiyrN: see wakiyrapN.

wakiyrapN *
wakiyrapN Food that is prepared on account of the completion of a building; (S, * Msb, * K;) as also wakiyrN↓ and wakorapN↓ and wakarapN↓: (K:) food which a man prepares on the occasion of building his wakor [or house], or buying it, (A, TA,) and to which he invites [others]: (TA:) accord. to Fr, [food] prepared by a woman among the requisites for a bride or a traveller (fiY AljahaAzi); sometimes, he says, called tawokiyrN: which latter word also signifies the act of feeding [with the food called wikiyrap]. (TA.)

1 wakazahu *
1. wakazahu, (S, Msb,) aor. yakizuhu, (Msb,) inf. n. wakozN, (Msb, K,) He struck, or beat him, (S, Msb,) [with anything,] as, for ex., with a staff, or stick: (TA:) or it signifies, (Msb,) or signifies also (S) he struck, or beat, him with his fist upon his chin: (S, Msb:) or, accord. to Ks, i. q. lakamahu; (Msb;) [i. e.] he struck, or beat, him with his fist. (A, K.) ― -b2- He pushed, or impelled, or repelled, him. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b3- He pierced him (Ks, K, * TK) with a spear. (TK.) ― -b4- He goaded him. (TA.) ― -b5- He broke his nose. (T, TA.)

wakozapN *
wakozapN A blow with the fist. (A.)

wak~aAzN *
wak~aAzN One who strikes, or beats, much with his fist. (A.)

mutawak~izN bA^amorK *
mutawak~izN bA^amorK Standing ready, or prepared, for a thing, or an affair. (L, art. wkd.)

1 wakasa *
1. wakasa, aor. yakisu, inf. n. wakosN, It (a thing, S, Msb) was, or became, defective, or deficient; it fell short; it diminished, or decreased. (S, A, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad., (S, Msb,) of Ibn-Mes'ood, (TA,) lahaA mahoru mivolihaA laA wakos walaA $aTaTa She shall have the dowry of her like: there shall be no falling short nor exceeding: (S, A, * Msb, * TA:) or there shall be no diminishing nor exceeding of the limit. (Mgh.) [For] wakasahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies He rendered it defective, or deficient; diminished it, or decreased it; (A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also wk~shu↓, (TK,) inf. n. tawokiysN. (K, TK.) ― -b2- He made him (a man) to suffer loss; syn. naqaSahu; (S, TA; as also wk~shu↓ inf. n. tawokiysN: (K, * TA:) or he cheated, or defrauded him. (IKtt, TA.) You say, wukisa fiY tijaAratihi, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. wakosN, (TA,) He suffered loss, (S, A, Msb, TA,) or diminution of the price, (TA,) [in his traffic, or merchandise; as also A^uwkisa↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iykaAsN; (TA;) and so wakasa, aor. (K) and inf. n. (TA) as above. (K, TA.)

2 wk~shu *
2. wk~shu, inf. n. tawokiysN: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Also, He reproved, or blamed, him, or did so severely; or with the utmost severity; or he reproached, or upbraided him. (AA, K.)

4 A^awokasa *
