4. A^awokasa, (A,) or A^awokasa maAluhu, (Ibn-'Abbád, A, K,) His property went away. (Ibn-'Abbád, A, K.) ― -b2- A^uwkisa fiY tijaAratihi: see 1.

A^awokasu *
A^awokasu [More, and most, defective, or deficient: less, and least, in value]. The saying respecting the division of a building, yanoZaru A_ilaY SaAHibi AlA^awokasi means, One shall look to see which is he whose place is of the less, or least, value. (Mgh.) ― -b2- A man having a small portion, or little good fortune: (A:) or a low, an ignoble, or a mean, or sordid, man. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

1 walaba *
1. walaba, aor. yalibu, inf. n. wuluwbN, He entered (K) into a house or tent, or into a tract, or quarter, or the like. (TA.) ― -b2- walaba He hastened (K) in entering. (TA.) ― -b3- walaba A_ilayoka Al$~aYo'u, aor. yalibu, inf. n. wuluwbN, The thing, of whatever kind it was, came to thee, or reached thee. (A'Obeyd, S.) In the copies of the K, walaba Al$~aYo'a wA_ilayoka; accord. to which, the verb, in the sense of waSala, there assigned to it, is trans. both immediately and by means of A_ilaY: but the correct reading is wlb AlykAl$Y', as above. In an old, and generally correct, copy of the Tahdheeb el-Af'ál of IKtt, it is said that wlb Alyk Al$~ar~u signifies The evil reached thee:
syn. tawaS~ala. (TA.) ― -b4- walaba, inf. n. wuluwbN and walobN, It (corn or the like) germinated in offsets around the older plants. (IKtt.) ― -b5- walaba bnw fulaAnK The sons of such a one multiplied, or increased. (IKtt.)

waAlibN *
waAlibN, Going into a thing; entering into it. (Esh-Sheybánee, S.)

waAlibapN *
waAlibapN The offsets of the corn and the like: (K:) so called because they enter into the roots of the parent-plants: (TA:) or corn or the like growing from the roots of that which has preceded it: (S:) pl. A^awaAlibu. (TA.) ― -b2- waAlibapN The offspring of camels, (IAar, S,) and of sheep or goats, (IAar, K,) and of cows, (K,) and of a people. (IAar.)

tawolabu *
tawolabu: see art. tlb. Accord. to Suh, the t is substituted for w, and the word is derived from wAlyp, the “ offsets of corn and the like: ” and Ibn-'Osfoor and IKtt assert the same. (TA.)

1 walatahu Haqahu *
1. walatahu Haqahu, aor. yalitu, inf. n. walotN; and Awlthu↓; He diminished unto him his due, or right; [or defrauded him of part thereof]: (K:) as also laAtahu, and A^alatahu, or A^alitahu. (TA.)

4 A^awolata
4: see 1.

1 walavatonaA Als~amaA'u *
1. walavatonaA Als~amaA'u, [aor. talivu,] inf. n. walovN, The sky wetted us with a little rain. (TA.) ― -b2- walavahu, aor. yalivu, (S,) inf. n. walovN, (S, K,) He beat, struck, or smote, him, (AA, S, K,) with a staff, or stick, (AA, S,) a little: (As:) or he beat him, or struck him, without wounding him. (Aboo-Murrah El-Kusheyree.) ― -b3- walava lahu EaqodFA He made with him a covenant, compact, or contract, that was unintentional, or not firmly concluded, or settled. (S.) walava lahumo, [aor. yalivu,] inf. n. walovN, He gave them, or granted them, somewhat of a covenant, compact, or contract. (TA.) ― -b4- walava, [aor. yalivu?] inf. n. walovN, He concluded a covenant, compact, or contract. (TA.) ― -b5- walava lahu, aor. yalivu, inf. n. walovN, He made to him a weak promise. (TA.) ― -b6- walava fulaAnN lanaA mino A^amorinaA, inf. n. walovN, Such a one appointed the manner of somewhat of our affair for us; syn. waj~aha. (TA.) ― -b7- walava limamoluwkihi EitoqFA, [aor. yalivu, inf. n. walovN,] He promised his slave manumission after his death, saying, Thou art free after my death. (ISh.)

walovN *
walovN A little of rain: (S, K:) ex. A^aSaAbanaA walovN mino maTarK A little rain fell upon us. (S.) ― -b2- walovu Als~aHaAbi A little rain. (TA.) ― -b3- walovN A covenant, compact, or contract, between a people, that happens unintentionally, mino gayori qaSodK: (S:) or, not firmly concluded, or settled: (S, K:) or somewhat, or a little, of a covenant, compact, or contract: ex., in a trad., lawo laA walovN laka mina AlEahodi laDarabotu Eunuqaka Were it not for somewhat, or a little, of a covenant granted to thee, I had beheaded thee: (TA:) or the remainder [or what remains unfulfilled] of a covenant &c.: (T:) or a covenant &c. firmly concluded, or settled. (TA.) ― -b4- walovN A little of anything that is much in quantity. (IAar.) ― -b5- walovN What remains, of dough, in a platter. (K.) ― -b6- What remains, of water, in a mu$aq~ar. (K.) ― -b7- What remains, of the beverage called nabiy*, in the vessel. (K.) ― -b8- walovN A weak promise. (K [See 1. In the CK, and in a MS. copy of the K, for AlwaEodu is put Alwagodu.]) ― -b9- You also say lahumo walovN DaEiyfN, and walovN muHokamN, [A weak promise has been made to them, and a firm promise]. (TA.) ― -b10- walovN A vestige, or trace, of ophthalmia. (K.) ― -b11- lamo A^ara manohu A_il~aA walovapF↓ I saw not, of him, or it, aught save a small vestige, or trace. (A.) ― -b12- walovN i. q. tawojiyhN; i. e., The saying to a slave (mamoluwk), Thou art free after my death. (K.)

walovapN *
walovapN: see walovN. ― -b2- EinodiY walovapN mino xabarK I have a little news. (TA.)

$ar~N waAlivN *
$ar~N waAlivN A lasting, or constant, evil. (K.) ― -b2- dayonN waAlivN, an expression used by Ru-beh, (TA,) A burdensome debt: (K:) or a lasting, or constant, debt: (IAar:) or, as some say, a debt by which one constantly binds himself (yatafal~aduhu), as he does by a contract. (L.) As disapproves of the expression. (TA.)

1 walaja *
1. walaja, aor. yaliju, inf. n. wuluwjN and lijapN; and A_it~alaja↓; (S, K;) and twl~j↓; (L;) He, or it, entered. (S, K.) You say walaja Albayota, and At~ljh↓, and twl~jhu↓, He entered the house. (L.) And walaja Al$~aYo'u fiY gayrihi The thing entered into another thing. (Msb.) As is said in the S and L, Sb says that walaja has for its inf. n. wuluwjN, which is of one of the measures of the inf. ns. of intrans. verbs, because the meaning [of walajotu Albayota] is walajotu fiyhi: and it is said in the M, that Sb holds the intermediate particle to be dropped: but Mohammad Ibn-Yezeed holds the verb to be trans. without an intermediate particle. MF observes, that Sb's words appear to make wlj a trans. verb, which no one asserts it to be: that if he mean that it has as its complement a noun in the acc. case as an adverbial noun of place, it is like daxalotu and other intrans. verbs: but if he mean that it governs a simple objective complement, like Darabotu zayodFA, his opinion is not correct. (TA.)

4 Awlj *
4. Awlj, (S, K,) inf. n. A_iylaAjN; (Msb;) and A_it~alaja↓, as in the CK and in several MS. copies of the K) or A^atolaja, (as in the L, and all the copies of the K consulted by SM, in this art., and in art. tlj,) in which t is substituted for w, and this is the correct reading; (TA;) He, or it, caused to enter; introduced; inserted. (S, K.) ― -b2- The expression in the Kur. [xxii. 60; and other chapters,] yuwliju A@ll~ayla fiY Aln~ahaAri wayuwliju Aln~ahaAra fiY A@ll~ayoli signifies He maketh the night, by increasing it, to enter into, [or encroach upon,] the day, and maketh the day, in like manner, to enter into, [or encroach upon,] the night: (Jel:) or He increaseth the night with a part of the day, by taking from the latter and adding to the former, and in like manner increaseth the day with a part of the night. (S.) ― -b3- [Awlj is often used for Awlj *krh; and hence as meaning Inivit.]

5 tawal~aja
5: see 1.

8 A_iwotalaja
8: see 1 and 4.

rajulN xurajapN wulajahN *
rajulN xurajapN wulajahN, (S,) and xar~aAjN wal~aAjN↓, and xaruwjN waluwjN↓, (TA,) A man frequently going, or coming, out and in. (S, TA.) [This is the primary meaning: for others see art. xrj.]

walajapN *
walajapN A place, (S,) or a cavern, in which passengers shelter themselves from rain &c.: pl. A^awolaAjN and walajN, (S, K,) [or rather the latter, which is omitted in the CK, is a coll. gen. n., of which wljp is the n. un.] or wulujN. (L.) ― -b2- Also, A bend, or place of bending, of a valley: (IAar:) pl. as above. (K.)

waluwjN *
waluwjN and wal~aAjN: see wulojapN.

waliyjapN *
waliyjapN Anything that is introduced, or inserted, into a thing, and that does not belong to it: any such thing is termed a wlyjp of a thing. (A'Obeyd.) ― -b2- huwa waliyjatuhumo He is an adherent to them; (K;) one who has entered, or become introduced, or included, among them,] and not belonging to them. (TA.) Pl. walaAy^iju. (TA.) ― -b3- waliyjapN (assumed tropical:) A particular, or special, intimate, friend, or associate, of a man; syn. xaAS~apN (S, K) and biTaAnapN (S) and daxiylapN: (K:) by these syns. A'Obeyd explains it in the Kur. ix. 16: and it is applied to one and to more than one: (TA:) or one whom a person takes to rely upon, or to place confidence in, not being of his family: (K:) and so some explain the word in the verse above referred to: (TA:) or it there signifies an intimate friend who is one of the polytheists. (Fr.)

A^awolaju *
A^awolaju [More, or most, penetrating]: applied to language or discourse. [TA, in art. jmE: see an ex. voce mujomaEN.]

tawolajN *
tawolajN The hiding place of a wild beast, (or antelope, TA,) among trees, (S, K,) into which he enters (Al~a*iY yalij fiyhi); like dawolajN: the t, says Sb, is substituted for w, and the word is of the measure fawoEalN; for tafoEalN is scarcely found in Arabic as the measure of a subst., whereas fawoEalN is frequent. (S.)

mawolijN *
mawolijN A place of entrance; a place into which one enters: (TA:) pl. mawaAliju. (S.) [See its contr. maxorajN.]

mawoluwjN *
mawoluwjN A man attacked by the disease called waAlijap, or dubayolap. (K, TA.)

waliyHapN *
waliyHapN A [sack of the kind called] giraArap: (S, L, K:) or such as is called a juwaAliq: or a large and wide jwAlq: (L:) and a date-basket of palm-leaves; syn. jul~apN: (S, L, K:) and a sack or the like forming one half of a beast's load, in which are carried perfumes and clothes (baz~) and the like: (L:) n. un. of waliyjN, pl. walaAy^iHu. (S, L, K.)

1 waladato *
1. waladato, (S, K, &c.,) aor. talidu, (L, K, &c.,) inf. n. wilaAdahN and walaAdN (S, A, L, Msb, K) and walaAdahN and walaAdN, but each is more common with kesr, (Msb,) and A_ilaAdahN and mawolidN (L, K) and lidapN, (K,) [and app. miylaAdN, like miqodaArN, (see an ex. voce tilaAdN, in art. tld,)] She (a woman, S, L, or mother, L, or any animal having an ear, as distinguished from one having merely an car-hole, (Msb,) brought forth a child, or young one; or children, young, or offspring. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also, wlada, (aor. as above, Msb,) He begot a child, or young one; &c. (Th, L, Msb, K.) ― -b3- A^aroDu AlbaloqaA='i talidu Alz~aEofaraAna (tropical:) [The land of El-Balkà produces saffron]. (A.) ― -b4- All~ayaAliY HabaAlaY layosa yudoraYmaA yalidona (tropical:) [The nights are pregnant: it is not known what they will bring forth]. (A.) ― -b5- [lamo yalodihi occurs in a verse cited voce rub~a, for lamo yalidohu; like lm A^ajodi for lamo A^ajido.]

2 wl~dhA *
2. wl~dhA, inf. n. tawoliydN, He assisted her [namely a woman, A, L, Msb, and a ewe or she-goat, S, A, L, Msb, or other animal, Msb) in bringing forth; delivered her of her child or young one: (S, L, Msb, K *:) he acted as a midwife to her. (L.) ― -b2- wldhA A^awolaAdFA He made her to be the mother of children. (MA.) See 4. ― -b3- wl~dhu, (inf. n. tawoliydN, K,) He reared him; educated him; brought him up. The Christians (as Th says, T, L) have corrupted, in the Gospel, God's saying to Jesus, on whom be peace! A^anota nabiy~aY waA^anaA wal~adotuka [in the CK, erroneously, wladotk,] Thou art my prophet, and I reared thee: altering it thus, Ant bunay~aY wAnA waladotuka [Thou art my little son, and I begot thee]; attributing to Him a son. (T, * L, K. *) ― -b4- wl~d (tropical:) He innovated, or originated, language, and a story or the like. (A.) (assumed tropical:) [It (a thing) generated, engendered, produced, or originated, another thing.]

4 Awldt *
4. Awldt, (inf. n. A_iylaAdN, Msb,) She (a woman, S, L, Msb, and a ewe or goat, L) attained to the time of bringing forth; was about to bring forth. (S, L, Msb, K. *) ― -b2- Awld Alqawomu The people attained to the time of [their having] children. (IKtt.) ― -b3- Awld AljaAriyapa He made the girl to be the mother of a child. (MA.) See 2.

5 twl~d Al$~aYo'u mina Al$~aYo'i *
5. twl~d Al$~aYo'u mina Al$~aYo'i, (S,) or Eano gayorihi, (Msb,) (assumed tropical:) The thing became generated, or engendered, or produced; it originated; from the other thing. (Msb.) ― -b2- twl~dt AlEaSabiy~apu bayonahumo (tropical:) [Party-spirit originated, or became engendered, among them]. (A.)

6 twAldwA *
6. twAldwA They multiplied, or became numerous, [by propagation,] and begot one another; (S, L;) as also At~ldwA↓. (TA.)

8 A_iwotalada
8: see 6.

10 AstwldhA *
10. AstwldhA He rendered her pregnant; got her with child. AwldhA in this sense is not of established authority; and some expressly disallow it. (Msb.)

walodN *
walodN: see waladN.

wulodu rajulK *
wulodu rajulK, and wiloduhu↓, A man's people, tribe, or family. So, accord. to some, in the Kur. lxxi. 20. (T.) ― -b2- See waladN.

wilodN *
wilodN: see wulod, and waladN.

waladN *
waladN (of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, Msb) and wulodN↓ (S, A, L, Msb, K) and wilodN↓ (S, L, K) and walodN↓, (K,) each used alike as sing. and pl., (S, M, A, L, K,) and masc. and fem., (M, L, Msb,) A child, son, daughter, youngling, or young one; and children, sons, daughters, offspring, young, or younglings; of any kind: [often applied to an unborn child, &c.; a fœtus:] (M, L, Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] of waladN, (M, L, Msb, TA,) and of wulodN, (M, L,) A^awolaAdN; (M, L, Msb, K;) and [pl. of pauc. of waladN,] wilodapN and A_ilodapN: (M, L, K:) and pl. of waladN, wulodN, (S, M, L, Msb, K, *) like as A^usodN is pl. of A^asadN, (S, L, Msb,) in the dial. of the tribe of Keys, (T, Msb,) who make waladN singular. (T.) ― -b2- mano dam~aY Eaqibayoki wuloduki↓, a proverb, (T, S, L; but in the S, Eaqibayoka;) of the Benoo-Asad, (S, L,) Thy son is he who made thy two heels to be smeared with blood; (TA;) i. e., whom thou thyself broughtest forth; (K, TA;) he is thy son really; not he whom thou hast taken from another, and adopted. (TA.) ― -b3- maA A^adoriY A^aY~u waladi Alr~ajul huwa I know not what man he is. (S, K.)

lidapN *
lidapN, in which the p is a substitute for the w that is elided from the beginning, for it is from AlwilaAdapu, (S, L,) or, accord. to some, it is from ladY, q. v., (TA,) applied to a male and to a female, (TA, voce tirobN,) i. q. tirobN; (S, L, K;) meaning One born at the same time with another; coëtanean, or a contemporary in birth (TA) of a man: (S, L:) dual lidaAni; (S, L;) [but lidapN occurs in a dual sense in the Jm and O and K, voce SawogN, q. v.;] pl. lidaAtN and liduwna: (S, L, K:) AHei and other expositors of the Tesheel say, that words like ldp have the latter form of pl. when they become proper names. (TA.) The dim. [of the pl.] is wulayodaAtN and wulayoduwna, (K,) because the formation of a dim. restores a word to its original form; (TA;) not luday~aAtN and luday~uwna, as some of the Arabs erroneously make it: (K:) but this which F pronounces an error is accordant to the authority of the leading writers on inflexion, who say that by regarding the original form, and restoring it thereto, the word is made to depart from the meaning intended by it; for if its dim. were made wulayodN, there would be no difference between it and the dim. of waladN. (TA.) See also art. ldY. ― -b2- See miylaAdN.

wilaAdN *
wilaAdN and walaAdN: see 1. ― -b2- Pregnancy: (A, L, in which the former only is mentioned, and Msb:) the former is the more common. (Msb.)

waluwdN *
waluwdN [Prolific; that breeds, or brings forth, plentifully.] (S, K, art. A^bd.) ― -b2- See waAlidN.

waliydN *
waliydN (of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, TA,) and mawoluwdN↓ signify the same, (T, L, K,) i. e., A new-born child: (M, L:) a young infant: (the former in the L, and the latter in the Msb:) the former, as well as the latter, masc.: (M, L:) or, accord. to some, the former is applied also to a female: as also waliydapN↓ and mawoluwdapN↓: pl. of wlyd, wilodaAnN; and of wlydp. (L.) ― -b2- Alwlaiydu fiY Aljan~api The child that dies in early infancy, or that is prematurely born, is in paradise. (L, from a trad.) ― -b3- Also waliydN, walaAy^idu. A boy: (S, A, L, K:) a youth: (AHeyth, L:) (tropical:) a boy who has arrived at the age when he is fit for service, before he attains to puberty: (A, L:) a youthful servant; one is so called from the time of his birth until
he attains to manhood: the servant of a man in paradise is a wlyd always, never changing in age: (L:) a slave; (S, L, K;) or, as some say, one born in servitude: (TA:) fem. in these senses, with p: (S, A, L, K:) a female slave is called wlydp even if aged: (L:) pl. (of the masc., S, L) wilodaAnN (S, L, K) and wilodahN; (L;) and (of the fem.,: S, L) walaAy^idu. (S, L, K.) ― -b4- See also muwal~adN. ― -b5- A^um~u Alwaliydi The domestic hen. (K.) ― -b6- humo fiY A^amori laA yunaAdaY waliyduhu (S, L, K *) [They are in a case, or an affair, wherein (lit. whereof) the boy, or servant-boy, or slave, will not be called out to]: a proverb, (L,) originally meaning, they are in a case of difficulty or distress, such that the mother forgets her child, and does not call out to him: and afterwards applied to any case of difficulty or distress: (M, L:) or they are in a formidable case, in which children are not called out to, but those advanced in age: (AO, or As, M, L:) and sometimes it means, they are in such a state of abundance and affluence that if a wlyd put forth his hand to take a thing he is not chidden away from it: (M, L:) or it is applied to a case of good and to one of evil, and means, they are so occupied with their case or affair that if a wlyd put forth his hand to the most valuable of things he is not called out to for the purpose of chiding him: (K:) some say, that its original reference is to the running of horses; because a fleet and excellent horse goes without being called out to; and that it is secondarily applied to any case of great moment, and to any case of abundance. (S, L.) ― -b7- One also says, fiY AlA^aroDi Eu$obN laA yunaAdaY waliyduhu [In the land is fresh herbage respecting which the servant-boy, or slave, will not be called out to]; because it matters not in what part of such land the beasts are; the whole abounding with herbage: and jaAw^uwA biTaEaAmK laA yunaAdaY waliyduhu [They brought food respecting which the servant-boy, or slave, would not be called out to]; meaning, that one would not care what injury he might do to it, nor when he ate of it. (ISk, L.) ― -b8- Muzarrid Eth-Thaalebee says,
tabar~aA^otu mano $atomi Alr~ijaAli bitawobapK
A_ilaY A@ll~`hi min~iY laA yunaAdaY waliyduhaA
[I have become clear of the vice of reviling men, by my turning unto God with repentance respecting which the servant (myself) will not be called out to]; meaning, respecting which I shall not be questioned. (ISk, L)

waliydapN *
waliydapN: see waliydN.

wuluwdiy~apN *
wuluwdiy~apN, (IAar, L, K,) an inf. n. which has no verb, (Th, L,) and waluwdiy~apN (K) and waliydiy~apN, which, accord. to Th, is the original form, and walaAdapN↓, (L,) Infancy: (IAar, L, K:) boyhood; girlhood: the state of a waliyd or waliydap. (L.) Ex. faEala *`lika fiY wuluwdiy~atihi, and waluwdiy~atihi, He did that in his infancy: (El-Basáïr:) and fiY waliydiy~atihi when he was a waliyd. (L.) ― -b2- wuluwdiy~apN (L, K) and waluwdiy~apN (L) Rudeness; coarseness; hardness; churlishness; deficiency in gentleness, (L, K,) and in knowledge of affairs: (L:) illiterateness. (L.)

SuHobapu fulaAnK wal~aAdapN liloxoyri *
SuHobapu fulaAnK wal~aAdapN liloxoyri (tropical:) [The society of such a one is very productive of good.] (A.)

waAlidN *
waAlidN and waAlidapN, (M, L, K) the former as a possessive epithet, and the latter as an act. part. n. (M, L.) A woman, and any pregnant animal, having a child or young one, or children or young; and bringing forth. (Th, M, L.) ― -b2- Also waAlidN A father: (S, L, Msb:) and a mother; (L;) as also waAlidapN; (S, L, Msb;) [which latter is the more common in this sense:] pl. of the former, waAliduwna; and of the latter, waAlidaAtN: (Msb:) the dual waAlidaAni signifies the two parents; the father and mother. (S, L, Msb.) ― -b3- $aApN waAlidN A pregnant ewe or goat; (ISk, S, A, L, Msb, K; *) as also waAlidapN and waluwdN↓: (L, K:) pl. wulodN, (as in the L, and most other lexicons, accord. to the TA, and in some copies of the K,) or wul~adN, (as in the A, and in other copies of the K,) each of which is correct. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, A prolific ewe or goat; that breeds, or brings forth, plentifully; (Nh, L;) [as also waluwdN↓: see S, K, art. A^bd: see also an ex. of waluwdN, applied to a woman, voce A^asowaA^u.] ― -b5- mino $ar~i waAlidK wamaA walada, occurring in a trad. respecting prayer for God's protection, [lit., From the evil of a parent and what he hath begotten,] is said to mean Iblees and the devils: (L:) or Adam and the true friends and the prophets and the martyrs and the believers whom he hath begotten. (El-Basáïr.)

mawolidN *
mawolidN The place of birth (T, S, M, A, Msb) of a man. (S, L, &c.) ― -b2- See also miylaAdN.

muwlidN *
muwlidN [A woman, and] a ewe or she-goat, (L,) about to bring forth: (L, K: *) pl. mawaAlidu and mawaAliydu. (L, K.)

miylaAdN *
miylaAdN The time of birth (T, S, M, A, L, Msb, K) of a man; (S, L, &c.;) as also mawolidN↓, (T, M, A, L, Msb, K,) and lidapN↓: (K:) but this last is mentioned only in the K, and requires proof. (TA.) ― -b2- [See also 1, of which it is app. an inf. n.]

mawoluwdN *
mawoluwdN: see waliydN.

rajulN muwal~adN *
rajulN muwal~adN, (S, L, Msb,) and Earabiy~apN muwal~adapN, (S, L,) A man, and an Arab female, not of mere Arabian extraction: (S, L, Msb:) or muwal~adN (L) and its fem. muwal~adahN (M, L, K) signify a boy, or slave-boy, (L,) and a girl, or slave-girl, (M, L,) born among the Arabs; (M, L, K;) as also waliydN↓ (M, L) and waliydapN: (M, L, K:) or a boy, or slave-boy, and a girl, or slave-girl, who has been born among the Arabs, and has grown up with their children, and been educated, disciplined, or bred, in their manner: (A, L:) or the latter, mwl~dp, signifies one born in a country in [and of] which is only her father or her mother: (ISh, L:) or one born at thine own abode, or home; (ISh, T, S, in art. tld;) like tilaAdN: (S, art. tld:) or born in the territory of the Muslims. (Mgh, art. tld.) ― -b2- $aAEir muwal~adN (tropical:) [A post-classical poet;] a poet of the last of the four classes; of the class next after the A_isolaAmiy~uwn; also called muHodavN: (Mz, 49th nwE:) called by the former appellation [as well as the latter] because of his recent age. (L, K.) [It is difficult to mark the exact line of distinction between the Islámees and the Muwelleds, so as always to be certain to which of these two classes a poet belongs. The latter are those born, not merely since the first corruption of the Arabic language, which happened in, or before, the age of Mohammad, (see Mz, 44th nwE,) but since the extensive corruption which happened after the Arabs had spread themselves, by their conquests, among foreigners, in consequence of which their language became simplified. This change took place in the latter half of the first century of the Flight. Hence the poetry of the Muwelleds in not cited as authoritative in lexicology or grammar, or as to the metres of verse, or rhymes. (See $aAhidN.)] Ibn-Rasheek mentions, as the most famous of the Muwelleds, El-Hasan (surnamed Aboo-Nuwás) Habeeb, ElBohturee, Ibn-Er-Roomee, Ibn-El-Moatezz, and El-Mutanebbee: [the first of whom died in the year of the Flight 195, or -6, or -8]. Aboo- 'Amr Ibn-El- 'Alà [who died in the year of the Flight 154, or -9,] termed El-Farezdak and Jereer Muwelleds, in comparison with the Pagan poets and the Mukhadrams, though others call them Islámees. (Mz, 49th nwE.) ― -b3- kalaAmN muwal~adN (tropical:) [Postclassical,] or innovated, or modern, or modernized, language; (L;) language which is not of the original dialect of the Arabs; (A;) language which is not genuine Arabic. (Msb.) And simply muwal~adN (tropical:) [A post-classical phrase or word;] a modernism; an innovated, or a modern, or modernized, phrase or word; a phrase or word innovated by any of the Muwelleds, whose phrases or words are not cited as authoritative [in lexicology, or grammar, or as to the metres of verse, or rhymes: see above]: the difference between it and the maSonuwE is, that the latter is given by its author as chaste (fSyH) Arabic; whereas this is the contrary [i. e., confessedly innovated]. (Mz, 21st nwE.) It is opposed to
lugapN. The lexicons passim.) ― -b4- Also muwal~adN, (L,) and its fem. with p, (K,) (tropical:) Anything innovated. (L, K.) ― -b5- kitaAbN muwal~adN (tropical:) A forged writing. (L, K.) ― -b6- bay~inahN muwal~adapN (tropical:) Evidence not verified. (L, K.)

muwal~idapN *
muwal~idapN A midwife. (A, L, K.)

1 wamaA^a A_ilayohi *
1. wamaA^a A_ilayohi, (S, K,) aor. yamaA^u, inf. n. wamo'N; (S;) and AwmA^↓, (S, K, which is the chaste word, MF,) inf. n. A_iymaA='N; (TA;) and wm~A^↓; (K;) He made a sign to him. (K.) A^awomayotu [for A^awomaA^otu] is disallowed: (S:) [but see what follows in this paragraph]. Lth says, that AlAymA' is the making a sign with the head or the hand, as a sick man does with his head for the inclination and prostration in prayer: (TA:) and AwmA^ biraA^osihi sometimes signifies He [made a sign with his head as though he] said “ No: ” Akh cites this verse:
A_i*aA qal~a maAlu Almaro'i qal~a Sadiyquhu
waA^awomato A_ilayohi biAlEuyuwni AlA^aSaAbiEu
[When the man's wealth becomes little, his friends become few; and the fingers, together with the eyes, make signs to him]; in which Awmt is for AwmA^t. (TA.) ― -b2- [For a further explanation of AwmA^, and the manner in which it is said to differ from AwbA^, see art. wbA^.]

2 wam~aA^a *
2. wam~aA^a: see 1. ― -b2- wm~Y biAl$~aYo'i [for wm~A^: as there is no such root as wmY:] He took away the thing. (TA.)

3 fulaAnN yuwaAmiy^u fulaAnFA *
3. fulaAnN yuwaAmiy^u fulaAnFA, and yuwaAy^imu, [Such a one agrees, or vies, with such a one]. These two verbs are of two different dialects, or the former is formed by transposition from the latter. (K, TA.) ― -b2- ISh quotes,
faA^anaA Alg*aApa muwaAmiy^uho
meaning, accord. to Abu-l-Khattáb, “ And I, in the morning, shall see him, or it: ” syn. muEaAyinuhu. (TA.)

4 A^awomaAa
4: see 1.

10 AstwmY EalaY AlA^amori *
10. AstwmY EalaY AlA^amori [for AstwmA^: as there is no such root as wmY:] He made himself master of the thing: like AstwlY. (Fr.)

waAmiy^apN *
waAmiy^apN A misfortune; calamity: (S, K:) thought by ISd to be a subst. [not an act. part. n.] because no verb from which it could be derived is known. (TA.) ― -b2- waqaEa fiY waAmiy^apK He fell into a misfortune or calamity. (S.) ― -b3- *ahaba vawobiY famaA A^adoriYmaA kaAnato waAmiy^atuhu My garment is lost, and I know not what misfortune has taken it away: (M, K:) or, who has taken it. (Yaakoob, S.) The phrase without negation is also used. (L.) [See a similar phrase in art. lmA^.]

$aYo'N mawomuwtN *
$aYo'N mawomuwtN A thing that is known, and decided, or determined; syn. maEoruwfN muqad~arN. (K.)

1 wamidati All~ayolapu *
1. wamidati All~ayolapu, (S, L, K.) aor. tawomadu, inf. n. wamadN, (L,) The night was, or became, one of wamad, i. e., intense heat, &c., as explained below. (S, L, K. *) One also says wamida Alyawomu: but the former is more common. (M, L.) ― -b2- wamida Ealayohi, (S, * M, A, L, K *,) aor. yawomadu, (K,) inf. n. wamadN, (M, L, K;) (tropical:) He was angry with him; (S, M, A, L, K;) was incensed against him; i. q. wabida, (S, L,) of which it is a dial. form. (S.)

wamadN *
wamadN Intenseness of the heat of night; as also wamadapN↓: (S, L, K:) or intense heat: (CK:) or sultriness; i. e., intense heat with stillness of the wind: (Ks, T, L, K:) or heat of whatever kind with stillness of the wind: (M, L:) or dew, or moisture, that comes during the greatest heat, (M, A, L, K,) from the direction of the sea, (M, L, K,) with stillness of the wind: (M, L:) or a dew, or moisture, that comes from the direction of the sea, when its vapour rises and is blown by the east wind, so that it falls upon the bordering regions like the dew of heaven, very noxious to men by reason of its offensive smell: (T, L:) and wamadapN a dew, or moisture, from the sea, falling upon men in the intenseness of heat, when the wind is still: (L:) it comes during the greatest heat, from the direction of the sea, and falls upon men in the night; (Lth, T, L;) and sometimes in the days of autumn also. (T, L.)

layolapN wamidN *
layolapN wamidN: (L, K:) and wamidapN↓, (T, M, A, L, K,) which latter is the more common, (TA,) A night of wamad, i. e., intense heat, &c., as explained above. (T, M, A, L, K.) One also says yawomN wamidN: but not so commonly. (M, L.) ― -b2- huwa Ealayohi wamidN (tropical:) He is angry with him. (A.)

wamadapN *
wamadapN: see wamadN.

wamidapN *
wamidapN: see wamidN.

1 wamVDa
1: see 4.

4 AwmD *
4. AwmD It (lightning) flashed, gleamed, or shone, slightly, (S, A, Msb, K,) not extending sideways in the adjacent tracts of cloud; (S, K;) for when it does thus, it is termed xafowN; and when it extends high in the sky, without extending sideways to the right and left, it is termed EaqiyqapN: (S:) it is also said of other things, beside lightning: (M:) and wamaDa↓, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor. yamiDu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. wamiyDN and wamoDN (S, M, A, K) and wamaDaAnN (S, A, K) and tawomaADN, (M,) signifies the same; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) or it (lightning) flashed faintly or weakly, and then disappeared, and then flashed again; (IAar;) and is also, sometimes, said of fire, (M, TA,) and of anything of a clear [or bright] colour: (El-' Eyn:) or both verbs signify it (lightning) gleamed, or shone. (Ham, p. 785.) ― -b2- Hence, A^awomaDati AlmaroA^apu (tropical:) The woman smiled, so as to display her teeth: the glistening of her front teeth being likened to the flashing of lightning. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The woman stole a glance, or glances; (S, M, K;) as also AwmDt biEayonihaA: (A:) or this last,(assumed tropical:) the woman looked, or gazed with widely opened eyes. (L.) ― -b4- And AwmD lahu biEayonihi (assumed tropical:) He made a sign to him with his eye: (M:) or AwmD fulaAnN (tropical:) such a one made a private, or secret, sign, (K, TA,) A_ilay~a to me. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, He saw the slight flashing, or gleaming, or shining, of lightning, or of fire. (M, TA.)

wamoDapN *
wamoDapN [A slight flash of lightning, &c.] You say, $imotu wamoDapa baroqK kanaboDapi EiroqK [I looked at a slight flash of lightning, like a single pulsation of an artery, to see whither it tended, and where it might rain]. (A, TA.)

baroqN wamiyDN *
baroqN wamiyDN i. q. waAmiDN↓ [Lightning flashing, gleaming, or shining, slightly; &c.: wmyD in this case being app. an inf. n. used as an epithet.] (TA.)

waAmiDN *
waAmiDN: see what next precedes.

2 wn~bh *
2. wn~bh, inf. n. tawoniybN, He reprehended, reproved, blamed, chid, or reproached, him severely; &c.: (K:) a dial. form of A^an~abahu. (TA.)

1 wahaba lahu $ayoy^FA *
1. wahaba lahu $ayoy^FA, (aor. yahabu, K; said to be originally yawohibu; which is changed into yahibu because of the kesr; and then, into yahabu because of the medial guttural letter; Msb, voce wasiEa;) inf. n. wahobN and wahabN and hibapN (S, K) and mawohibN and mawohibapN, (Msb,) or the last two are substs., (S, K, &c.) He gave him a thing; properly, as a free gift, disinterestedly, and not for any compensation. (Msb, TA.) You should not say wahabakahu [he gave it to thee], (K, &c.,) making
the verb doubly trans.: (TA:) or [this is allowable, as it is said that] AA has related this on the authority of an Arab of the desert: so in the K: but in the L, it is said that Seer has related this, from 'Amr, (meaning Sb,) from an Arab of the desert. (TA.) En-Nawawee allows the expression wahabutu ka*aA minohu, meaning, I gave such a thing to him, &c.; (mn being redundant, as in biEotu ka*aA minohu “ I sold such a thing to him; ”) as occurring in several trads. (MF.) ― -b2- See 3. ― -b3- wahabaniYA@ll~`hu fidaAka May God make me [or give me as] thy ransom! (IAar, K.) wuhibotu fidaAka May I be made [or given as] thy ransom! Ibn-Umm-Kásim says, that whb is one of the verbs which signify He caused to be, or to become: and he cites the above phrase from IAar; and adds, that the verb is only used in the pret. tense. Others assert it to be rare. (TA.) ― -b4- haboniY faEalotu *`lika Suppose me; syn. Zun~aniY; (AHei, cited by Fei;) or count me, or reckon me; syn. A^uHosuboniY waA@EodudoniY; (M, K;) [or grant me;] to have done that. (M, K. *) habo zayodFA manoTaliqFA Suppose Zeyd to be going away, or gone away; syn. A_iHosabo. (So in two copies of the S: in another, A^uHosubo.) Thus this verb is doubly trans.: (S:) but it is not used in this sense in the pret., nor in the aor.: (S, K:) you do not say wahabotuka faEalota *`lika [I supposed thee to have done that]: nor (as some assert, Msb,) do you say habo A^an~iY faEalotu, (TA,) as say the vulgar, though what the grammarians say, respecting the class of verbs to which Zananotu belongs, that A^an~a and A_in~a [with what follows them] may supply the place of the two objective complements, [as when you say Zananotu A^an~a zayodFA qaAy^imN, and Znnt A_in~a zayodFA laqaAy^imN, “ I thought Zeyd to be standing, ”] affords matter for controverting this. (Msb.)

3 waAohaba
3: waAhabahu fawahabahu↓, aor. of the latter verb yahabu and yahibu, He strove to surpass him in giving, freely, or disinterestedly, and he surpassed him therein. (K.) [The former of the above aors., accord. to general opinion, is irregular; and the latter, regular; because the first radical letter is w; as in the case of waAEadahu fawaEadahu, aor. yaEidu: or, accord. to the rule laid down by Ks, the reverse is perhaps the case, because the medial radical letter is a guttural. See Lumsden's Ar. Gram., p. 171.]

4 Awhb lahu Al$~aYo'a *
4. Awhb lahu Al$~aYo'a He prepared, or made ready, the thing for him. (K.) ― -b2- A^awohabotuka AlT~aEaAma waAl$~araAba I prepared, or made ready, for thee the food and beverage, and abundance of them. (Tahdheeb el-Af'ál.) But see this verb in an intrans. sense. ― -b3- A^awohaba AlT~aEaAmu (tropical:) The food, or corn, or the like, became abundant and ample, so that some of it was given away. (A.) ＝ -A2- A^awohabotu liA^amori ka*aA (tropical:) I became capable of such a thing and able to do it. (A.) ― -b2- A^awohaba laka Al$~aYo'u The thing was, or became, within thy power, or reach, so that thou mightest take it. (K. *) Related on the authority of IAar alone, who says, They did not say A^awohabotuhu laka. (TA.) ― -b3- A^awohaba lahu Al$~aYo'u The thing was lasting to him. (A'Obeyd, AZ, S, K.) J cites the following verse:
EaZiymu AlqafaA rixowu AlxawaASiri A^awohabato
lahu EajowapN masomuwnapN waxamiyru
[Large in the back of the neck, soft (or loose or flabby) in the flanks: dates of the best that ElMedeeneh produces, prepared with clarified butter, and leaven, are lasting (provisions) to him]. But 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh says, that this is a mistake, and that the right reading is A^urohinato, meaning “ are prepared, and continued. ” So in a marginal note in a copy of the S. (TA.) [So too in the margin of one of my MS. copies of the S.]

6 twAhbwA *
6. twAhbwA They gave gifts, one to another. (S, K.) ― -b2- fiyhimi Alt~awaAhubu [They have a habit of mutually giving gifts]. (TA.) ― -b3- tawaAhabahu Aln~aAsu bayonahumo [The people gave it; one to another]. (TA.) ― -b4- walaA Alt~awaAhubu fiymaA bayonahumo SEpN [Nor is their mutual giving of what is (possessed) among them (from fear of) humiliation]: i. e., they do not give by constraint. (TA, from a trad.)

8 A_ithaba *
8. A_ithaba (originally A_iwotahaba, TA,) He accepted a hibap, or gift. (S, Msb.) At~hbh He accepted it [as a gift]. (K.) A_it~ahabotu minoka dirohamFA [I accepted from thee a dirhem, as a gift]. (L.)

10 Astwhb *
10. Astwhb, (S,) or Astwhb hibpa, (Msb,) He asked for a hbp, or gift. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- Astwhbhu xaAdimFA [He asked him to give him a servant.] (K, art. xdm.)

hiabpN *
hiabpN and mawohabapN↓ A gift (or thing bestowed); properly, one that is freely and disinterestedly given, not for any compensation; a free, or disinterested, gift. (L.) [In the K, the latter is explained as signifying simply a gift.] Pl. of the former hibaApN; and of the latter, mawaAhibu. (A, &c.) ― -b2- [A hibaApN is of two kinds: mawaAhibu A free gift, for no requital, or compensation: and hibapu vawaAbK A gift for a requital, or compensation. This distinction is made in law, &c.]

hubapN *
hubapN i. q. A^uhobapN q. v. (K, in art. Ahb.)

wahuwbN *
wahuwbN: see waAhibN.

wah~aAbN *
wah~aAbN and wah~aAbapN: see waAhibN.

waAhibN *
waAhibN and wahuwbN↓ (K) and wah~aAbN↓ and wah~aAbapN↓ (S, K) epithets from wahaba, [“ he gave, &c. ”: the first signifies Giving; properly, as a free gift, disinterestedly; and not for any compensation: or one who gives; &c.:] the others are intensive epithets, [as is said in the S of the third and fourth,] signifying one who gives liberally, or bountifully; &c.: and in this sense Alwah~aAbu↓ is used as an epithet of God; or, accord. to the Nh, it signifies He who dispenses his bounties universally and perpetually, freely, or without constraint, and disinterestedly, for no compensation. The p in wh~Abp↓ is added to give more force to the intensiveness; as in Eal~aAmapN. (TA.)

mawohib *
mawohib and mawohibapN↓ substs. of wahaba [“ he gave, &c.; ” signifying A gift (or act of giving); properly, that is free and disinterested, not for any compensation; a free, or disinterested, donation]. (S, K, &c.) See 1.

muwhabN *
muwhabN A thing, such as food, prepared, ready, at one's hand. (S.)

waAdK muwhibu AlHaTabi *
waAdK muwhibu AlHaTabi (tropical:) A valley abounding with fire-wood. (A.) ＝ -A2- A^aSobaHa fulaAnN muwhibFA Such a one became prepared, or ready, (muEad~FA; so in an excellent copy of the S: in another copy, muEid~FA:) and able. (S.)

mawohabapN *
mawohabapN: see hibapN. ― -b2- (tropical:) A cloud falling [in rain] in any place: (K:) pl. mawaAhibu: you say kavurati AlmwAhibu fiY AlA^aroDi The rains became abundant in the land. (TA.) ― -b3- mawohabapN and mawohibapN↓ (tropical:) A small pool of water left by a torrent: or the former only is the correct word, and the meaning of which, as explained in the S, is a small hollow, or cavity, in a mountain, in which water stagnates: pl. mawaAhibu: and in the T it is said that a small cavity, or hollow, in a rock, is called mawohabapN, with fet-h, being extr. [with respect to rule]. (TA.)

mawohibapN *
mawohibapN: see mawohibN and mawohabapN.

mawohuwb *
mawohuwb A thing given; properly, as a free gift, &c.: see the verb. (Msb.) ― -b2- mawohuwbN lahu Having a thing given to him; properly, as a free gift, &c. (Msb.) ― -b3- mawohuwbN A son; a child; offspring: and whatever is given to one by the Liberal, or Bountiful, Giver, i. e., by God. An epithet in which the character of a subst. is predominant. (TA.)

1 wahatahu *
1. wahatahu, aor. yahitu, inf. n. wahotN, He trod, or stamped upon it vehemently. (L.) ― -b2- He pressed, compressed, or pressed against, him; or it; syn. DagaTahu. (L, K.)

4 Awht *
4. Awht It (flesh-meat) became stinking: (S, K:) dial. form of Ayht. (TA.)

wahotapN *
wahotapN A depressed, or low, piece of ground: (K:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n. of which it is the n. un.] wahotN. (TA.)

1 wahava fiY $aYo'K *
1. wahava fiY $aYo'K, aor. yahivu, inf. n. wahovN, He was persevering, or assiduous, in the thing. (K.) ― -b2- wahava $ayoy^FA, aor. yahivu, inf. n. wahovN, He trod, or trampled, vehemently upon a thing. (K.)

5 twh~v fiY AlA^amori *
5. twh~v fiY AlA^amori He went, or penetrated, far into the affair. (M, K.)

waAhivN *
waAhivN One throwing himself into destruction. (TA.)

1 wahajati Aln~aAru *
1. wahajati Aln~aAru, aor. tahiju, inf. n. wahojN and wahajaAnN; (S, L, K;) and wahajata, [app. a mistake for wahijat,] aor. tawohaju, [inf. n. wahajN;] (L;) The fire burned; syn. Ait~aqadat; (S, K, &c.;) and so tawh~jt↓; (L;) syn. twq~dt; (S, L, K;) [or this last has an intensive sense, and signifies, as does the first accord. to the A, it burned fiercely; glowed]. ― -b2- Also, all these verbs, with the same inf. ns., It (the sun) burned, or was hot: and it (a fire) burned from a distance. (L.) ― -b3- Also, all the above verbs, with the same inf. ns., (tropical:) It (a day, and a night,) was violently hot. (L.)

2 wah~aja
2: see 4.

4 Awhj *
4. Awhj He kindled a fire; made it to burn; syn. A^awoqada: (S, K;) [or made it to burn fiercely, or to glow:] in the M, wh~j↓. (L.)

5 twh~j *
5. twh~j: see 1. ― -b2- (tropical:) It (the odour of perfume) was hot, or strong; syn. twq~d. (S, K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) It (a jewel) shone; glistened; glowed. (S, K.) ― -b4- (tropical:) It (a day) was violently hot. (A.) ― -b5- (tropical:) It (heat) was violent. (A.)

yawomN wahijN *
yawomN wahijN, and wahajaAnN↓, and layolapN wahijapN, and wahajaAnapN↓, (tropical:) A violently hot day, and night. (L.)

wahajN *
wahajN and wahiyjN↓ The burning, or heat, of fire. (S, K.) [See 1.] ― -b2- Also, The diffusion (in a neut. sense) of the odour of perfume; and the hot, or strong, odour, thereof. (L.) ― -b3- Also, the latter, The shining, glistening, or glowing, of a jewel. (L.)

wahajaAnN *
wahajaAnN and wamajaAnapN: see wahijN.

wahiyjN *
wahiyjN: see wahajN.

najomN wah~aAjN *
najomN wah~aAjN [A fiercely burning, or glowing, star]. (TA.) siraAjN wah~aAjN [A fiercely burning, or glowing, lamp: Kur. lxxviii. 13:] i. e., the sun. (TA.)

mutawah~ijapN *
mutawah~ijapN, as an epithet applied to a woman, Hot in the pudendum; expl. by HaAr~apu AlmataAE. (L.)

wahodN *
wahodN (L) and wahodapN (As, S, A, L) A low, or depressed, place; (As, S, A L;) as though it were a hollow, or cavity, dug, or excavated, for which the latter is also a name: (L:) and both words, low, or depressed, ground: (L, K:) pl. A^awohudN, (L, K,) a pl. [of pauc.] of the former, (TA,) and wihaAdN (S, A, L, K) and wuhodaAnN, or wihodaAnN, (as in different copies of the K, the former being the reading in the TA,) and wahodN of wahodapN: (S, L:) [or rather this last is a coll. gen. n., of which wahodapN is the n. un.:] also wahodapN a hollow, or cavity, or deep hollow or cavity, (huw~apN,) in the ground; (L, K;) and so makaAnN wahodN, and A^aroDN wahodapN: (L:) and a round hollow excavated in the ground, deeper than what is called gaAy^iTN, not having abrupt sides, in width two and three spear's lengths, and not producing any herbage. (L.) ― -b2- Also wahodapN The hollow, in the ground, in which the weaver puts his legs, or feet. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also, i. q. xunoEubapN, (IAar, L,) which latter, says Lth, signifies The part where the mustaches divide.

wayobN *
wayobN a word like wayolN (S, K) and wayoHN and wayosN: these four words agree in form and meaning, and have no fifth; although some of the lexicologists differ, in holding that some of them relate to what is good, and others to the falling into destruction. Accord. to what is said by Z, in the Fáïk, wyb and wyH and wys denote compassion: but wyl is used in reviling, and imprecating destruction. (MF.) IKtt says, in the Tahdheeb el-Af'ál, that the invariable verbs are nine in number: niEoma and biy^osu and layosa and EasaY and the verb of wonder and wayoHa zayodK and wayobahu and wayolahu and wayosahu; but that El-Mázinee asserts the last four to be inf. ns. (TA.) You say wayobaka, (S, K,) and wayobN laka, and wayobN lizayodK, and wayobFA lahu, and wayobK lahu, (K,) with the three different vowel-terminations, both in addressing a person and in speaking of one who is absent, (TA,) and wayobihi, and wayobi gayorihi, (K,) [and wayoba gayorika, (see below,)] and wayoba zayodK, (S, K,) and wayobi zayodK, (TA,) [and wayobu zayodK, (see below,)] and wayobi fulaAnN on the authority of IAar, (K,) who adds, except the bnw Asd, who, it appears, from his saying this, give fet-h to the b: (TA:) the meaning of all which is, May God make woe (wyl) to cleave to thee! [and ― -b2- to Zeyd! &c.: or Woe to thee! &c.: but see what is said above.] (S, K.) Dhu-l-Khirak Et-Tuhawee uses wyb in the sense of wyl, addressing to a wolf the ejaculation wayoba gayorika, [which is therefore the same in meaning as wayobaka]: (TA:) but accord. to what is said by Z, in the Fáïk, wayobaka and wayobN laka &c. signify Mercy on thee! or the like. (MF.) When wyb is put in the acc. case, it is so put as an inf. n. (S.) This is the opinion generally obtaining: the opinion that wayoba is a verb is extraordinary. (TA.) When you use the prep. l, you [generally say] wayobN lizayodK (or wayobFA lizayodK, L): when you use l, it is more elegant to put wyb in the nom. case, as an inchoative, than in the acc. case: but when you use wyb as a prefixed noun, with its complement, the acc. is more elegant than the nom. case: [i. e., it is more elegant to say wayoba zayodK than wayobu zayodK]. (S, L.) Ks says, Some of the Arabs say wayobaka and wayoba gayorika; and some of them say wayobFA lizayodK, like wayolFA lizayodK. (TA.) ― -b3- wayobFA liha*aA AlA^amori (K, * TA) i. q. EajabFA lahu, [I] wonder at, or with respect to, this thing! (K,) and so wayobahu. (TA.)

wayobapN *
wayobapN A measure consisting of twenty-two, or twenty-four, A^amodaAd (pl. of mud~N), which see in art. mk. (K.) Not mentioned by J nor by IF; and IDrd doubted respecting it. In truth it is a post-classical word, used by the people of Syria and Egypt and Africa Proper. (TA.) [At present, the wybp in Cairo is the sixth part of an A_irodab~, which latter is equivalent, very nearly, to five English bushels.]

wayoHN *
wayoHN a word denoting compassion, or pity: (AZ, As, S, K:) wayolN denotes [an imprecation of] punishment; (S;) or [of] removal from good, or from prosperity: (AZ, As:) or [of] destruction: (AZ:) and wayosN denotes the same as wyH; (AZ;) or less than wyH: (As:) or wyH and wys denote compassion, or pity, and admiration of one's beauty; as when you say of a child, wayoHahu maA A^amolaHahu, and wayosahu mA AmlHh, [Mercy on him! or the like: how beautiful is he!] (Kh) or, accord. to most of the lexicologists, wyl is a word said to, or of, any one who falls into destruction or trial, or misfortune, and on whom one does not wish God's mercy: and wyH is said to, or of, any one who falls into trial or misfortune, and for whom one wishes God's mercy, and his escape therefrom: the former word being so used in the Kur-án, and the latter by the Prophet: (T:) or wyl is said to, or of, him who falls into destruction: and wyH is a word by which one chides him who is at the point of falling into destruction: (Sb:) or wyH and wyl are syn., (Yz, En-Nadr, S, Ibn-Et-Faraj,) and wys signifies the same: (Ibn-El-Faraj:) or wyH is a little softer, or more gentle, than wyl: (En-Nadr:) [if so, wayoHahu signifies woe to him: in the same, or in a milder, manner than wayolahu:] or the original of
wyH is wayo; sometimes H being added to this latter word, and sometimes l and sometimes b, and sometimes s; (K;) so that it becomes wyH and wyl and wyb and wys. (TA.) [See wyl and wyb and wys and wy.] You say wayoHN lizayodK [Mercy on Zeyd! or woe to Zeyd!]; putting wyH in the nom. case as an inchoative; (S, K;) and in like manner, wayolN lizayodK: (S:) and also wayoHFA lizayodK; putting wyH in the acc. case because of a verb understood; (S, K;) as though you said A^alozamahu A@ll~`hu wayoHFA [May God make mercy, or woe, to attend him constantly!]; and in like manner, wayolFA lizayodK: (S:) or [it is put in the acc. case as an absolute complement of a verb understood, i. e., as an inf. n., and] the meaning is A^ataraH~amuhu taraH~umFA. [I say, May God have mercy on him! emphatically]: (Z, in the Fáïk:) you also say wayoHaka, and wayoHa zayodK; (S, K;) making wyH a prefixed n.; (S;) and putting it in the acc. case again because of a verb understood; (S, K;) and in like manner, wayolaka, and wayola zayodK: (S:) and also wayoHamaA zayodK in the same sense. (K.)

wayosN *
wayosN a word used to. denote compassion, or pity, and admiration of one's beauty; (M, K;) the object being a child; (K;) as when one says of a child, wayosahu maA A^amolaHahu [Merry on him! or the like: how beautiful is he!]: (TA:) or wayosN and wayoHN are used in the place of wayolN; (TA;) and wayosN lahu signifies wayolN lahu [Woe to him!]: (M, TA:) or, as some say, wayosN is a word denoting contempt; and has no verb; analogy forbidding that it should have one: (IJ, M:) Aboo-Turáb says, I heard Abu-sSemeyda' say, wayosN and wayoHN and wayolN have one meaning: (TA:) or wayosaka is not said except to children; and wayolaka is an expression in which is roughness and reproach; and wyH is a gentle and good expression. (AHát, TA.) See wyoHN and wayolN and wayobN. ― -b2- It also signifies Poverty. (ISk, M.) And one may say, if it be right to say so to one, wayosN lahu as meaning Poverty be to him. (ISk.) ― -b3- Also, What a man desires. (M, K.) So in the phrase laqiYa wayosFA He found, or met with, or experienced, what he desired; (M, K;) accord. to an explanation given by IAar; so that it means much: but in one place he says that this phrase signifies he found, &c., what he did not desire. (M.)
